Description: FUNDS WILL SUPPORT THE RECIPIENT OF TROUT UNLIMITED S TROUT IN THE CLASSROOM (TIC) PROGRAM. TIC IS AN ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PROGRAM IN WHICH STUDENTS IN GRADES 4 THROUGH 12 RAISE RAINBOW TROUT FROM EGGS TO FRY, MONITOR TANK WATER QUALITY, ENGAGE IN STREAM HABITAT STUDY, LEARN TO APPRECIATE WATER RESOURCES, BEGIN TO FOSTER A CONSERVATION ETHIC, AND GROW TO UNDERSTAND ECOSYSTEMS. STUDENTS OF ALL AGES HAVE A CHANCE TO RAISE TROUT IN THE CLASSROOM SETTING. DURING THE EIGHT MONTHS THAT CLASSES SPEND RAISING TROUT, THEY CLOSELY MONITOR WATER TEMPERATURE, WATER CLARITY, DISSOLVED OXYGEN, AMMONIA LEVELS, AND PH. BECAUSE TROUT ARE EXTREMELY SENSITIVE TO CHANGES IN THEIR ENVIRONMENT, STUDENTS LEARN THE IMPORTANCE OF CLEAN WATER AND ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION. TIC BRINGS NATURE INTO THE CLASSROOM AND ALLOWS STUDENTS TO DEVELOP A PERSONAL INTEREST AND A SENSE OF THE CONVERSATION ETHICS THAT ARE AT THE CORE OF TROUT UNLIMITED S MISSION.THE RECIPIENT WILL CONTINUE TO USE THE PROCESSES IN PLACE TO CHOOSE SCHOOLS TO PARTICIPATE IN THE PROGRAM. FUNDS FROM THIS GRANT WILL HELP THE RECIPIENT TO PURCHASE SUPPLIES NEEDED TO RAISE TROUT AT A SCHOOL LOCATION. SUPPLIES NEEDED INCLUDE AN AQUARIUM, FILTER, CHILLER, PUMP, AIR STONE, EGG BASKET, THERMOMETER, AQUARIUM HOOD, AQUARIUM STAND AND OTHER MISCELLANEOUS ACCESSORIES AND SUPPLIES. LOCAL TROUT UNLIMITED VOLUNTEERS SECURE EGGS FROM THE ARIZONA GAME AND FISH DEPARTMENT, FOOD FOR THE FISH, HELP SET UP AND MAINTAIN EQUIPMENT, PROVIDE GUEST SPEAKERS IN THE CLASSES ABOUT ALL SORTS OF TOPICS, AND HELP ORGANIZE OUTDOOR FISHING OPPORTUNITIES (IF POSSIBLE). IT IS ANTICIPATED FUNDS WILL HELP BRING TIC TO THREE ADDITIONAL CLASSROOMS IN ARIZONA IN THE UPCOMING SCHOOL YEAR.

ON MAY 25, 2023, TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT AND ITS PARTNERS WILL CELEBRATE THE 27TH ANNUAL LONE STAR LAND STEWARD AWARDS AT THE HYATT REGENCY IN AUSTIN. THE LONE STAR LAND STEWARD AWARDS RECOGNIZE PRIVATE LANDOWNERS IN TEXAS FOR THEIR CONTRIBUTIONS TO LAND, WATER, AND WILDLIFE STEWARDSHIP.

THE MINNESOTA SHARP-TAILED GROUSE SOCIETY, INC. IS REQUESTING FUNDING FROM THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM (PFW) TO DELIVER COST-SHARE FUNDING TO PRIVATE LANDOWNERS IN MINNESOTA. THE FUNDING WILL BE USED TO RESTORE AND ENHANCE HABITAT ON PRIVATE LANDS FOR WATER QUALITY PURPOSES (BOTH WETLAND AND UPLAND HABITAT IMPROVEMENTS) WHICH PROVIDES MUTUAL BENEFIT TO MIGRATORY BIRDS, POLLINATORS, AND LISTED, AT-RISK, AND OTHER ENDEMIC SPECIES OF THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER WATERSHED. THOSE SPECIES INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO MALLARD, BLUE-WINGED TEAL, SHARP-TAILED GROUSE, WOOD DUCK, BLACK-CROWED NIGHT HERON, AMERICAN BITTERN, BLANDINGS TURTLE AND MONARCH BUTTERFLY. THE FUNDING TO SUPPORT THIS WORK IS REQUESTED AT  157,500. WITH THIS FUNDING, IT IS REASONABLE TO EXPECT 15-20 PRIVATE LANDOWNER PROJECTS AND RESTORATION OF 150 ACRES (20 WETLAND ACRES PER YEAR AND 30 ACRES OF UPLAND PER YEAR FOR THREE YEARS).
ISLAND MARBLE BUTTERFLY PARTNERS IN CONSERVATION  HABITAT ESTABLISHMENT, MAINTENANCE, MONITORING AND OUTREACH IN SAN JUAN COUNTY.

THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL FUND HAZARDOUS FUELS REDUCTION ON PRIVATE LANDS SURROUNDING THE OKEFENOKEE SWAMP IN GEORGIA AND FLORIDA VIA ACTIVE FOREST MANAGEMENT. WILDFIRE IS A KEY THREAT TO PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LAND IN AND AROUND THE OKEFENOKEE, BUT PRIVATE LANDOWNERS CAN HELP TO MITIGATE THE RISK ON THEIR LAND AND TO SURROUNDING COMMUNITIES BY REDUCING FUEL LOADS IN THEIR FORESTS. HAZARDOUS FUEL REDUCTION IN OVERGROWN FORESTS CAN ALSO RESULT IN MANY CO-BENEFITS SUCH AS SOIL REJUVENATION, INVASIVE SPECIES CONTROL, INSECT AND DISEASE CONTROL, AND IMPROVED HABITAT FOR WILDLIFE. ACTIVE FOREST MANAGEMENT TO REDUCE FUEL LOADS IS VITAL TO MAINTAIN HEALTHY FOREST ECOSYSTEMS, BUT THERE IS OFTEN A LACK OF RESOURCES FOR LANDOWNERS TO CONDUCT THIS WORK ON A LARGER SCALE.ACTIVITIES PERFORMED THROUGH THIS AGREEMENT MAY INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO, PRESCRIBED BURNING, MECHANICAL THINNING, FIRELINE ESTABLISHMENT AND MAINTENANCE, AND HERBICIDE APPLICATION TO REDUCE FUEL LOADS AND IMPROVE FOREST STANDS.THE FOREST LANDOWNERS ASSOCIATION (FLA) WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR DISTRIBUTING FUNDS ALLOCATED THROUGH THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT FOR HAZARDOUS FUELS REDUCTION WORK ON IDENTIFIED PRIVATE LANDS. THE AGREEMENT WILL ALSO INCLUDE FUNDING FOR EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES SUCH AS  LEARN AND BURNS  OR OTHER EVENTS THAT DEMONSTRATE THE BENEFITS OF PRESCRIBED BURNING, FORESTRY BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES, AND OTHER FORMS OF ACTIVE FOREST MANAGEMENT IN THE SOUTHEAST. FLA WILL HOLD SUB AGREEMENTS WITH PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AND MANAGERS IN AREAS SURROUNDING THE OKEFENOKEE SWAMP IN GEORGIA AND FLORIDA THAT ARE IDENTIFIED FOR HAZARDOUS FUELS REDUCTION WORK OVER THE COURSE OF THIS GRANT. FLA AND THE SERVICE WILL CONDUCT INITIAL SITE VISITS AS WELL AS FOLLOW-UP MONITORING TO ENSURE PROJECT SUCCESS.THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES AND DELIVERABLES FOR THIS PROJECT ARE HEALTHIER AND MORE FIRE-RESILIENT PRIVATE FORESTLANDS THAT CAN MITIGATE THE SPREAD OF POTENTIAL WILDFIRES IN AND AROUND THE OKEFENOKEE WHILE SIMULTANEOUSLY PROVIDING THE CO-BENEFITS MENTIONED ABOVE. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO RESULT IN COMMUNICATION, TRUST AND RELATIONSHIPS FORGED BETWEEN LANDOWNERS AND THE SERVICE. LASTLY, THE EDUCATIONAL COMPONENT OF THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN BETTER UNDERSTANDING AMONG LANDOWNERS AND OTHER FOREST STAKEHOLDERS ABOUT THE IMPORTANCE OF FUELS MANAGEMENT ON PRIVATE LANDS TO BENEFIT FOREST HEALTH AND RESILIENCY AS WELL AS NATIVE WILDLIFE AND PLANT SPECIES.

THROUGH THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT, THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND SOUTHEAST ALASKA WATERSHED COALITION WILL WORK TO RESTORE AND STEWARD IMPORTANT FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT ON NON-FEDERAL LAND IN SOUTHEAST ALASKA. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO BUILD THE CAPACITY OF THE SOUTHEAST ALASKA WATERSHED COALITION (SAWC) AND ITS MEMBER GROUPS TO CARRY OUT INFORMED WATERSHED MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION, INCLUDING PROJECTS THAT ASSESS AND PRIORITIZE IMPORTANT PACIFIC SALMON HABITAT AND IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE MOST ECOLOGICALLY SIGNIFICANT HABITAT. THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT INCLUDES 12 PROJECTS RELATED TO WATERSHED STEWARDSHIP, RESTORATION, AND SCIENCE. THESE PROJECTS ARE OUTLINED FURTHER IN THE UPLOADED DOCUMENTS AND SCOPE OF WORK:PROJECT 1: REGIONAL WATERSHED OUTREACH AND SUPPORT SERVICESPROJECT 2: BOULDER CREEKS CHINOOK SPAWNING ENHANCEMENT (TWC)PROJECT 3: HENDRICKSON CREEK PRIVATE DRIVEWAY IMPLEMENTATION PROJECT 4:  SAWMILL CREEK MAINSTEM RESTORATIONPROJECT 5:  RESTORING SALMON WATERSHEDS ON TRIBAL HOMELANDSPROJECT 6: FISH CREEK ESTUARYPROJECT 7:LAKE CREEK RESTORATION PROJECT 8: 39-MILE CREEK CULVERT REPLACEMENTPROJECT 9: ENGAGING TRIBAL PARTNERS IN SALMON RESTORATION IN THE MARGARET CREEK AND WARD CREEK WATERSHEDS.  PROJECT 10: TWC ECOSYSTEM-BASED CONSERVATION PLAN FOR THE GREATER CHILKAT WATERSHED.  PROJECT 11: METLAKATLA INDIAN COMMUNITY FISH PASSAGE IMPROVEMENTSPROJECT 12:  FISH HABITAT RESTORATION ASSESSMENTS

THE FUNDS REQUESTED FOR THIS PROJECT WILL BE USED FOR A LANDOWNER AGREEMENT. NO COOPERATORS WILL BEINVOLVED, AND NO INDIRECT RATE CHARGED. THE PROJECT AREA IS DIRECTLY ADJACENT TO THE WOOD RIVERAPPROXIMATELY A MILE SOUTH OF THE TOWN OF FORT KLAMATH. WE HAVE ALREADY FUNDED RIPARIAN FENCING ANDINSTREAM STRUCTURE ON THIS PROPERTY THAT WILL BE COMPLETED SPRING AND SUMMER 2023 USING A COOPERATIVEAGREEMENT WITH TROUT UNLIMITED. THIS PROJECT IS AN EXTENSION OF THAT PROJECT AND ADDS TO CONSERVATIONVALUE IN THIS REGION OF THE WOOD RIVER. WE AIM TO INCREASE WETLAND SIZE FROM 1.5 TO 4 ACRES AND IMPROVEMANAGEMENT CAPABILITY TO BENEFIT WATERBIRDS AND OREGON SPOTTED FROG. CURRENTLY, THERE IS AN ARTESIANWELL THAT FILLS AN EXISTING WETLAND AREA AND FOLLOWS A DITCH DIRECTLY INTO THE WOOD RIVER. THE CURRENTFLOW PATH IS ERODING THE WOOD RIVER STREAM BANK. WE WILL PLUG THE DITCH CURRENTLY DRAINING THE WETLANDAND PIPE THE WATER THROUGH A WATER CONTROL STRUCTURE TO A DRAINED WETLAND APPROXIMATELY 100 YARDS TO THESOUTH (SEE FIGURES). WE WILL INSTALL A DITCH PLUG IN THE WETLAND TO THE SOUTH AND ROUT THE WATER THROUGH AWATER CONTROL STRUCTURE AND PIPE TO A RIPARIAN WET MEADOW AREA TO THE WEST (SEE FIGURES). THIS WETLANDSYSTEM WILL COMPLIMENT ANOTHER WETLAND SYSTEM ON THE NEIGHBORS PROPERTY TO THE SOUTH (WHOM WE ARECURRENTLY WORKING WITH) AND CONTRIBUTE TO A LARGER COMPLEX OF WETLANDS WITHIN THE WOOD RIVER VALLEY.SPECIES EXPECTED TO BENEFIT FROM THIS ARE NATIVE WATERBIRDS AND THREATENED OREGON SPOTTED FROG.MONITORING FOR OREGON SPOTTED FROM WAS INITIATED IN SPRING 2023 AND WILL CONTINUE THROUGH THE PROJECTPERIOD. MONITORING FOR WATER BIRDS, SPECIFICALLY YELLOW RAIL WILL BEGIN SPRING SUMMER 2024.

HURON PINES IS REQUESTING ADDITIONAL PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM FUNDS TO BOTH CONTINUE RESTORATION OF THE MAIN GLADE COMPLEX AND EXPAND RESTORATION EFFORTS TO TWO OTHER SMALLER GLADE COMMUNITIES WITHIN EMILY MIN HUNT PRESERVE.HURON PINES IS REQUESTING ADDITIONAL PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM FUNDS TO BOTH CONTINUERESTORATION OF THE MAIN GLADE COMPLEX AND EXPAND RESTORATION EFFORTS TO TWO OTHER SMALLER GLADECOMMUNITIES WITHIN EMILY MIN HUNT PRESERVE. THE PROPOSED WORK WITHIN THE MAIN COMPLEX WOULDCONSIST OF CONTINUED RETREATMENT OF SPOTTED KNAPWEED, ESPECIALLY THE COMPLETING OF THE INITIALTREATMENT ON THE REMAINING 2 ACRES. TREATMENT WILL TAKE PLACE ACROSS THE FULL COMPLEX (21.5 ACRES)AND COULD EXPAND TO LOWER PRIORITY INVASIVE SPECIES (QUEEN ANNES LACE, LEAFY SPURGE, AND ST.JOHNS-WORT) DEPENDING UPON INVASIVE SPECIES DENSITY IN AREAS TREATED IN 2022.   RE-TREATMENT OFWOODY INVASIVE SHRUBS IN AREAS WITHIN THE COMPLEX AND SURROUNDING FOREST. TREATMENT OF RESPROUTSRESULTING FROM THE WOODY ENCROACHMENT TREATMENT. THE LARGEST ECOLOGICAL IMPACT ON NATIVE SPECIESDISTRIBUTION WITHIN THE MAIN COMPLEX IS COOL SEASON GRASSES, IN PREPARATION FOR A PRESCRIBED FIRE TOREDUCE DENSITY AND REMOVE THE RESULTING THICK THATCH LAYER, HURON PINES WILL CREATE A BURN-BREAKAROUND THE MAIN COMPLEX. WITHIN ONE OF THE MOST INTACT SECTIONS, WE ARE PLANNING TO SUPPLEMENTTHE EXISTING VEGETATION COMMUNITY WITH ADDITIONAL LOCAL GENOTYPE SEED FROM PARTNER LANDS ANDFROM HIGHER DENSITY AREAS WITHIN THE COMPLEX. SPECIES TO BE DISPERSED WOULD INCLUDE SANDCOREOPSIS, YARROW, COMMON MILKWEED, HAREBELL AND WOOD LILY. THIS INPUT WILL PROMOTE ADDITIONALBENEFIT TO IMPERILED POLLINATOR SPECIES WHICH ARE KNOWN TO UTILIZE THE GLADE.

THE TIMBISHA SHOSHONE TRIBE IN DEATH VALLEY, CALIFORNIA, IS CONCERNED ABOUT THE HEALTH OF THE TREES IN A LARGE HONEY MESQUITE (PROSOPIS GLANDULOSA) BOSQUE LOCATED ON THE EDGE OF THE DEATH VALLEY PLAYA.  THESE TREES ARE IN A TRIBAL MESQUITE USE AREA, LOCATED ON LAND MANAGED BY THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE IN DEATH VALLEY NATIONAL PARK.  THE TRIBE HAS TRADITIONALLY HARVESTED THE MESQUITE PODS AS A MAJOR FOOD SOURCE.  THESE MESQUITE PODS ARE KNOWN TO BE THE SWEETEST TASTING SEED PODS IN THE AREA.  THE MESQUITE BOSQUE ALSO PROVIDES IMPORTANT HABITAT FOR MANY MIGRATORY BIRDS INCLUDING LUCYS WARBLER (OREOTHLYPIS LUCIAE), COSTAS HUMMINGBIRD (CALYPTE COSTAE) AND VERDIN (AEGITHALUS FLAVICEPS).THE TRIBE WOULD LIKE TO REMOVE INVASIVE PLANTS ON THEIR RESERVATION TO INCREASE THE AMOUNT OF WATER REACHING THE MESQUITE BOSQUE AND TO REDUCE THE RISK OF FIRE TO HISTORIC STRUCTURES.  THE FOLLOWING INVASIVE PLANTS HAS BEEN MAPPED ON THE RESERVATION:  89 ATHEL TAMARISK TREES (TAMARIX APHYLLA), 1 DATE PALM TREE (PHEONIX DACTYLIFERA), 3 FAN PALM TREES (WASHINGTONIA FILIFERA), 1 GIANT REED (ARUNDO DONAX), AND 6 OLEANDERS (NERIUM OLEANDER).   GIANT REED IS LISTED AS A STATE OF CALIFORNIA NOXIOUS WEED. THE ATHEL TAMARISK TREES ARE LOCATED CLOSE TO EIGHT HISTORIC HOMES, POSING A HUGE FIRE RISK TO THESE STRUCTURES.  THE TRIBE WILL HIRE A CONTRACTOR TO REMOVE ATHEL TAMARISK TREES WITH AN EXCAVATOR AND OR HIRE A HAND CREW TO DO CHAINSAW HAND WORK.  ONCE REMOVED, TREES WILL BE MOVED TO A BURN PILE, CUT-UP BY CHAIN SAW FOR USE AS FIREWOOD, AND OR CHIPPED USING A CHIPPER OWNED BY THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE.  PERMISSION WILL NEED TO BE OBTAINED FROM EACH HOMEOWNER PRIOR TO REMOVING THE TARGET WEEDS AROUND THEIR HOUSES.  EACH HOMEOWNER WILL SIGN A LANDOWNER AGREEMENT WITH THE SERVICE AND TIMBISHA SHOSHONE TRIBE BEFORE WORK CAN OCCUR.

AN AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE POINT BLUE AND PARTNERS PROGRAM WILL FOCUS ON PLANTING RIPARIAN, POLLINATOR, AND UPLANDPLANTS, AND PROTECTING NATIVE PLANTS IN NEVADA COUNTY, CA. IT WILL AID IN HABITAT RESTORATION AT MULTIPLE SITESAND FOCUS ON DARLEAN DOMINGUEZS PROPERTY. ACTIONS WILL HELP ACCOMPLISH THE CONSERVATION PLAN FOR THE PROPERTYWHICH INCLUDES  2.7 ACRES OF TREE AND SHRUB ESTABLISHMENT ALONG RIPARIAN AREAS AND A  71 FT HEDGE ROW. ACTIONSMAY INCLUDE PLANT PURCHASE, PLANTING, SITE PREPARATION, AND PROTECTION. DARLEAN HAS VOLUNTARILY ASSISTED WITHPOLLINATOR AND WILDLIFE RESTORATION ON HER PROPERTY INCLUDING COLLECTION OF MILKWEED SEEDS, AND COORDINATIONWITH FISH AND WILDLIFE TO SHARE POLLINATOR PLANT AND MONARCH INFORMATION.TASKS IDENTIFIED TO MEET PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE: 1) PLANNING AND PERMITTING COMPLIANCE WORK,2)SITE PREPARATION PRIOR TO PLANTING 3)PLANTS WILL BE PLANTED ALONG RIPARIAN AREAS, INCLUDING LITTLE WOLF CREEK( 0.2 MILES), A TRIBUTARY TO IT LITTLE WOLF CREEK, AT THE HEDGE ROWS SITE AND AT UPLAND LOCATIONS. RIPARIANFENCE AND GRAZING PRACTICES WILL AID MANAGEMENT AT THIS SITE. TASK 4) PROJECT MONITORING AND REPORTS.ANNUAL REPORTS WILL BE DUE DECEMBER EACH YEAR), TREATMENT AND RESTORATION INSPECTIONS SITE VISITS WILL BECOMPLETED BY 2028, AND A FINAL PROJECT REPORT WILL BE PROVIDED BY 2028. THE TIMELINE FOR EACH OF THESE TASKS ISINCLUDED IN A WORK PLAN THAT HAS BEEN AGREED TO BY THE POINT BLUE AND THE PARTNERS PROGRAM WHO WILL WORKTOGETHER TO ACCOMPLISH THIS SCOPE OF WORK.

THIS PROJECT WILL MAINTAIN AND IMPROVE THE LONG-TERM HEALTH OF THE CHENA RIVER AND OTHER INTERIOR WATERWAYS THAT SUPPORT THE SALMON POPULATION. THE CHENA RIVER AND ITS ASSOCIATED BODIES OF WATER ARE THE SECOND LARGEST PRODUCER OF CHINOOK OR KING SALMON TO THE YUKON RIVER ON THE AMERICAN SIDE. CHINOOK SALMON ARE CONSIDERED A TRUST RESOURCE OF THE USFWS. SALMON ARE CRITICALLY IMPORTANT TO PEOPLE AND ECOSYSTEMS IN ALASKA, SUPPORTING COMMERCIAL AND SUBSISTENCE FISHERIES AND TRANSPORTING NUTRIENTS FROM THE OCEAN TO INLAND AREAS, FERTILIZING THE ECOSYSTEMS IN AND AROUND THE RIVERS WHERE THEY SPAWN. THE CHENA WATERSHED IS CONSIDERED VITAL HABITAT FOR NOT ONLY CHINOOK SALMON, BUT OTHER SALMONIDS AS WELL. THIS PROJECT WILL ENHANCE ONGOING EFFORTS THAT BENEFIT THE INTERIOR WATERWAYS AND EDUCATE LOCAL LANDOWNERS ABOUT THE IMPORTANCE OF THESE WATERWAYS TO CHINOOK SALMON. THIS PROJECT WILL ASSIST PROPERTY OWNERS EXPERIENCING MINOR STREAMBANK EROSION AND CONTINUE THE FREE LAWN SOIL TESTING AND OUTREACH FROM PAST YEARS. FSWCD WILL HOST A WORKSHOP INTRODUCING THE IDEA OF A LANDOWNER-FSWCD-USFWS COST SHARE FOR STREAM BANK REVEGETATION AND WILDLIFE HABITAT ENHANCEMENT. LANDOWNERS WILL BE ENCOURAGED TO APPLY FOR THIS COST SHARE AND, IF ACCEPTED, WILL BE REQUIRED TO CONTRIBUTE THEIR FUNDS, MATERIALS, TOOLS, AND OR LABOR TO IMPLEMENT THE PROJECT. FSWCD WILL COORDINATE PROJECTS, OBTAIN VEGETATIVE MATERIALS (SUCH AS WILLOWS), SCREEN THE APPLICATIONS, MONITOR PROJECT PROGRESS, AND ASSIST WITH IMPLEMENTATION. IT IS IN THE BEST INTEREST OF FSWCD TO WORK WITH THE SERVICE PARTNERS TO DEVELOP WAYS TO ADDRESS THE CUMULATIVE IMPACTS OF A GROWING NUMBER OF HUMAN ACTIVITIES ON ANADROMOUS STREAMS THROUGHOUT THE INTERIOR.  BOTH ARE INTERESTED IN WORKING TOGETHER TO ACCOMPLISH RESTORATION PROJECTS, FOLLOWED BY ADEQUATE MONITORING AND EVALUATION OF THESE EFFORTS.  HEALTHY RIPARIAN AREAS WITH DIVERSE HABITATS ARE GOOD FOR ANADROMOUS FISH AND ENSURE HIGH WATER QUALITY FOR THE COMMUNITIES THE FSWCD SERVES. II. PROJECT GOALS AND OBJECTIVES THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO ESTABLISH A PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE SERVICE AND FSWCD TO CONSERVE, ENHANCE, AND PROTECT SALMONID HABITAT ALONG ANADROMOUS WATER BODIES IN THE INTERIOR AND FOR BOTH AGENCIES TO WORK IN COOPERATION WITH THE LANDOWNERS TO PROVIDE PROJECTS AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE.  THIS AGREEMENT WILL SUPPORT THE CONTINUATION AND ADVANCEMENT OF EFFECTIVE BIOLOGICAL PLANNING, CONSERVATION DESIGN, PROJECT DELIVERY, AND MONITORING ASPECTS OF EACH PROJECT.   UP TO 5 NEW PRIVATE LANDOWNER AGREEMENTS (PLA) WILL BE ADMINISTERED UNDER THIS PROJECT USING THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM FY 2023 MONIES THAT ARE BEING OBLIGATED AT THIS TIME.  CONSERVE AND SUSTAIN UP TO 150 FEET OF HEALTHY NEARSHORE FISH HABITAT AND RIPARIAN VEGETATION.           IMPROVE RIPARIAN ZONE HEALTH THROUGH A COST-SHARE PROGRAM OF UP TO 200 FEET FOR THE REVEGETATION AND STABILIZATION OF STREAMBANKS UNDERGOING MINOR EROSION AND EXHIBITING A LACK OF NATURAL VEGETATION ADJACENT TO THE RIVER.  ORGANIZE 1 RIPARIAN RESTORATION WORKSHOP BY MARCH 2024 TO EDUCATE LANDOWNERS AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS ABOUT TECHNIQUES FOR STREAM BUFFER ZONE ENHANCEMENTS AND INVASIVE SPECIES CONTROL AND MONITORING. THE WORKSHOP WILL INCLUDE A HANDS-ON DEMONSTRATION OF RESTORATION METHODS AND SHOWCASE A COMPLETED PROJECT BY A LOCAL LANDOWNER.  INVITE WATERFRONT LANDOWNERS FROM PREVIOUS SOIL AND SALMON PROJECTS TO PARTICIPATE. PROVIDE OUTREACH AND EDUCATION ABOUT THE IMPORTANCE OF HEALTHY STREAMBANK ECOSYSTEMS AND THE THREAT OF INVASIVE SPECIES ON OR NEAR CHENA WATERSHED STREAMBANKS. UP TO 5 WATERFRONT LANDOWNERS ALONG THE CHENA RIVER AND ITS SLOUGHS AND TRIBUTARIES WILL BE VISITED, HAVE THEIR SOIL TESTED, AND BE EDUCATED ABOUT SUSTAINABLE LAWN CARE, IDENTIFY INVASIVE SPECIES AND RIPARIAN ZONE AND OR STREAMBANK IMPROVEMENTS.  INTERIOR WATERSHED SALMONID HABITAT LANDOWNER OUTREACH TO PROVIDE INFORMATION ABOUT ONGOING RESTORATION AND INVASIVE SPECIES ERADICA

THE RESTORATION STRATEGY IS INSTREAM HABITAT RESTORATION BY ENHANCEMENT OF INSTREAM HABITAT AND FLOODPLAIN RECONNECTION. THE MIDDLE CREEK COHO HABITAT ENHANCEMENT PROJECT WILL ENHANCE CHANNEL FORM AND FUNCTION BY ADDING LARGE WOODY DEBRIS TO THE ACTIVE STREAM CHANNEL, PROVIDING 2,500 SQUARE FEET OF OFF-CHANNEL REARING HABITAT FOR JUVENILE COHO SALMON, INSTALLING CATTLE EXCLUSION FENCING AROUND ALL SENSITIVE AREAS, AND RESTORING DIVERSE NATIVE FLOODPLAIN PLANT COMMUNITIES TO APPROXIMATELY 1,640 LINEAR FEET OF MIDDLE CREEK FLOODPLAIN.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO INSTALL TWO SOLAR OFFSTREAM WATERING FACILITIES ON THE SYCAN RIVER NEAR TEDDY POWERS MEADOW. CURRENTLY, THE LANDOWNER USES THE RIVER TO WATER CATTLE VIA A WATER GAP INSTALLED BY THE NRCS SEVERAL YEARS AGO. BY INSTALLING SOLAR POWERED OFFSTREAM WATERING SITES, CATTLE WILL BE REMOVED FROM THE RIVER ELIMINATING BANK AND BED DISTURBANCE, SEDIMENTATION AND INCREASED LOCAL TURBIDITY AND POLLUTION IN THE RIVER.THIS PROJECT IS UPSTREAM OF LRS CRITICAL HABITAT AND DOWNSTREAM OF BULL TROUT CRITICAL HABITAT. BY INSTALLING THESE FACILITIES MORE WATER WILL BE LEFT INSTREAM FOR DOWNSTREAM USES (LRS) AND WILL ALSO IMPROVE DOWNSTREAM WATER QUALITY BY REMOVING CATTLE FROM THE RIVER.THIS LANDOWNER IS ALSO CURIOUS AND OPEN TO THE POTENTIAL OF LOW TECH RESTORATION ON HIS PROPERTY. WE ARE CURRENTLY STILL IN CONVERSATION AND MORE SITE VISITS ARE NEEDED.

THIS PROJECT WILL ASSIST THE PROPERTY OWNERS IN THE ENHANCEMENT AND MANAGEMENT OF THEIR PROPERTY. THE OBJECTIVE IS TO REMOVE SALT CEDAR (TAMARISK) AND REHABILITATE THE UPLAND AND WETLAND AREAS THAT WERE OCCUPIED BY THIS NON-NATIVE INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES. THE REMOVAL OF SALT CEDAR WILL HELP THE PROPERTY OWNERS CREATE MORE WILDLIFE HABITAT FOR NATIVE SPECIES AND IT WILL ALLOW THEM TO RESTORE UPLAND HABITAT AREAS ON THE PROPERTY. THIS 240-ACRE PROPERTY SUPPORTS A MIX OF UPLAND AND WETLAND HABITAT. THE UPLAND AREA PROVIDES HABITAT FOR QUAIL, COACH WHIP SNAKES, AND BURROWING OWLS. THE WETLAND HABITATS SUPPORT WATERFOWL AND SHOREBIRDS.

THE OVERALL GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO MOVE THIS NEWLY PURCHASED RANCH FROM ITS CURRENT CONDITION TO AROTATING, REGENERATIVE, AND EFFICIENT RANCH WHERE CATTLE IMPACTS TO RESOURCES (WETLANDS, UPLANDS,RIVERINE) ARE MITIGATED TO THE FULLEST EXTENT POSSIBLE.THIS PROPERTY HOLDS TWO SEMI-PERENNIAL CREEKS, BADGER AND PARADISE CREEKS. THESE CREEKS ARE SPRING FEDIMMEDIATELY UPSTREAM ON FOREST SERVICE PROPERTY AND FLOW DOWNSTREAM INTO BROWSEY ACRES BEFOREHEADING SUBSURFACE AND EMERGING TOWARDS THE NORTH END OF THE PROPERTY. WHEN WATER CONDITIONS ARESUCH THAT THE LANDOWNERS CAN IRRIGATE, THE MAJORITY OF IRRIGATION WATER ORIGINATES FROM BOTH PARADISE ANDBADGER CREEKS. THE LANDOWNERS HAVE AGREED TO CEASE SURFACE WATER IRRIGATING IF WE INSTALL TWOSTRATEGICALLY PLACED WELLS ON THE PROPERTY FOR OFF-STREAM WATERING. ONCE WATER IS CONTINUOUSLY FLOWINGTHROUGH THE PROPERTY, WE WILL MOVE THE CREEK FROM THE HILLSIDE BACK INTO ITS ORIGINAL ROUTE THROUGH THEPROPERTY CREATING A NATURAL FLOW REGIME, WETLAND OPPORTUNITY, AND INCREASED WATER TABLE HEIGHT LEADINGTO A HEALTHIER RIPARIAN AREA.THE SECONDARY GOAL TO THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE UPLAND CONDITIONS BY THINNING ENCROACHING JUNIPER TREESON THE PROPERTY. THINNING JUNIPER AROUND THE DRAINAGE AREA OF THE PROPERTY SHOULD INCREASE THE HEIGHT OFTHE WATER TABLE LEAVING MORE WATER FLOWING INTO WETLANDS AND RIPARIAN AREAS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS TO ESTABLISH A WORKING PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE SERVICE AND THE RECIPIENT WHILE PROMOTING CONSERVATION ON PRIVATE LANDS THROUGHOUT EASTERN COLORADO.  THE RECIPIENT WILL FACILITATE THE DEVELOPMENT OF CONSERVATION PROJECTS LANDS AND WORK COOPERATIVELY WITH THE SERVICE TO IDENTIFY, DEVELOP, ESTABLISH, AND COMPLETE MUTUALLY BENEFICIAL CONSERVATION PROJECTS.  ALL PROJECTS WILL BE FACILITATED BY SITE-SPECIFIC PRIVATE LANDOWNER AGREEMENTS (PLAS) AS APPROVED AND ADMINISTERED BY THE SERVICE.  THIS AGREEMENT WILL RESTORE AND ENHANCE 400 ACRES OF SHORTGRASS PRAIRIE HABITAT FOR THE BENEFIT OF (1) FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES  (2) GRASSLAND NESTING MIGRATORY BIRDS  (3) POLLINATORS  (4) OTHER WILDLIFE  AND (5) WORKING LANDS.  RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED BY SEEDING NATIVE GRASSES AND FORBS IN AREAS WITH LIMITED DIVERSITY, RETIRED AGRICULTURAL FIELDS, AND OR OTHER AREAS.  RESTORATION WILL OCCUR WITHIN HIGH PRIORITY CONSERVATION FOCUS AREAS THAT WILL CONTRIBUTE TOWARDS MEETING POPULATION AND HABITAT OBJECTIVES IDENTIFIED IN THE SERVICES FY 20222026 MOUNTAIN-PRAIRIE REGION STRATEGIC PLAN FOR THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM.

THIS IS A PLANNING AND ENGINEERING DESIGN PROJECT FOR THE SPRAGUE RIVER ON THE JERRY PARRISH PROPERTY NEAR THE TOWN OF SPRAGUE RIVER. PROJECT ELEMENTS LIKELY TO INCLUDE INSTREAM STRUCTURES TO ADD COMPLEXITY TO THE RIVER CHANNEL, AGGRADE THE RIVER, AND PROVIDE REARING HABITAT FOR FISH.

THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR PARTICIPANTS IN POINT BLUES STUDENTS AND TEACHERS RESTORING A WATERSHED (STRAW) APPRENTICE PROGRAM, MANY OF WHICH ALSO PARTICIPATE IN STRAWS COMMUNITY COLLEGE CONSERVATION INTERNSHIP (CCCI), TO DIRECTLY PARTICIPATE IN RIPARIAN HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS ON PRIVATE WORKING LANDS AT MULTIPLE SITES THROUGHOUT THE PARTNERS PROGRAM COASTAL CALIFORNIA FOCUS AREA, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE FEDERATED INDIANS OF GRATON RANCHERIA AND THE MARIN RESOURCE CONSERVATION DISTRICT (MRCD). THE SITES INCLUDE TRUE GRASS, STRAUS HOME, AND SOMAR FARMS.

THE UPPER BLACK RIVER RESTORATION COUNCIL (UBRC) WILL RESTORE 2 MILES OF RIVER HABITAT BY STRATEGICALLY PLACING AND SECURING LARGE LOGS WITHIN THE RIVER TO IMPROVE BROOK TROUT HABITAT BY PROVIDING SHELTER, A FOOD SOURCE, AND BY NARROWING AND DEEPENING THE RIVER. A LARGE EROSION SITE WILL BE REPAIRED WITH THE USE OF TOE-WOOD, FIELDSTONE AND SLOPING BACK AND STABILIZING THE BANK WITH NATIVE VEGETATION.  THIS WORK HAS BEEN PROVEN WITHIN THIS WATERSHED TO INCREASE SIZE OF FISH, NUMBER OF FISH AND INCREASED HEALTH OF FISH WITHIN RESTORED SECTIONS OF THE WATERSHED.  SIMILAR WORK HAS BEEN ONGOING IN THE WATERSHED SINCE 2001.

WESTERN FOOTHILLS LAND TRUST (WFLT) WILL WORK WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM TO RESTORE POLLINATOR HABITAT AND REMOVE INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES ON WFLTS SHEPARDS FARM PRESERVE. MONARCHS AND NATIVE BEES HAVE BEEN OBSERVED IN THE COUNTY OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT AREA. HOWEVER, THE PROPOSED PROJECT AREA CURRENT HAS LOW PLANT DIVERSITY, INCLUDING LOW FORB DIVERSITY. IN ADDITION, INVASIVE SPECIES SUCH AS AUTUMN OLIVE (ELAEAGNUS UMBELLATA) AND BLACK SWALLOW-WORT (CYNANCHUM LOUISEAE) ARE PRESENT IN MODERATE TO SEVERE LEVELS IN THE PROJECT AREA. BLACK SWALLOWWORT IS OF PARTICULAR CONCERN AS IS SIMILAR TO MONARCHS LARVAL HOST PLANT, BUT POISONOUS TO MONARCH CATERPILLARS. IN ORDER TO SUPPORT GREATER NUMBERS OF MONARCHS AND NATIVE POLLINATORS, RESTORATION OF THE NATIVE PLAN COMMUNITY MUST BE COMPLETED, AND INVASIVE SPECIES MUST BE SUPPRESSED. POLLINATOR HABITAT WILL BE ESTABLISHED AND RESTORED BY NON-CHEMICAL METHODS AND USING NATIVE PLANT SPECIES. INVASIVE SPECIES WILL BE TREATED BY NON-CHEMICAL METHODS. POLLINATOR HABITAT WILL BE RESTORED OVER 3 YEARS, APPROXIMATELY 0.25 AC EACH YEAR.

THE PROPOSED WORK AREA FOR THIS PROJECT ENCOMPASSES BUCK CREEK IN PULASKI COUNTY AND ROUNDSTONE CREEK IN ROCKCASTLE CREEK IN ROCKCASTLE COUNTY OF KENTUCKY. THE FUNDING PROVIDED THROUGH THIS PROJECT WILL FURTHER EXISTING EFFORTS TO WORK WITH PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AND CONSERVATION PARTNERS IN KENTUCKY THAT ARE INTERESTED IN IMPLEMENTING PROJECTS THAT WOULD RESTORE AND CONSERVE STREAMS, WETLANDS AND OTHER HABITATS THAT BENEFIT FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES. THESE EFFORTS WILL BE SPECIFICALLY DIRECTED TO PROJECTS ON PRIVATE LANDS AND WITH CONSERVATION PARTNERS THAT WOULD PROVIDE CONSERVATION BENEFITS FOR A WIDE VARIETY OF FISH AND WILDLIFE SPECIES INCLUDING MIGRATORY BIRDS, FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES AND OTHER AT-RISK SPECIES, AS WELL AS, GAME AND NON-GAME FISH AND WILDLIFE.

WHITE OAK CREEK RESTORATIONTHE WHITE OAK CREEK RESTORATION PROJECT FOLLOWS UP ON SEVERAL RECENTLY COMPLETED RESTORATION PROJECTS IN THE CANE CREEK WATERSHED. THE SITE IS JUST UPSTREAM OF THE RECENTLY COMPLETED BAKERSVILLE CREEKWALK RESTORATION PROJECT AND RESIDES AT THE OPPOSITE END OF THE CREEKWALK. THIS RESTORATION PROJECT PROPOSED TO RESTORE AND IMPROVE 500  OF WHITE OAK CREEK BEFORE IT S CONFLUENCE WITH CANE CREEK. RESTORATION TECHNIQUES WILL INCORPORATE NATURAL CHANNEL DESIGN METHODS SUCH AS ROOT WADS AND CROSS VANES. NATIVE RIPARIAN VEGETATION WILL BE PLACED ALONG THE BANKS AND FENCING WILL BE INSTALLED TO PROTECT THE STREAM BUFFER.MOUNTAIN BOGS RESTORATION PROJECTTHE MOUNTAIN BOGS RESTORATION PROJECT IS LOCATED WITHIN THREE MOUNTAIN BOGS NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE CONSERVATION EASEMENT HEAD BY PRIVATE LANDOWNERS WITHIN ASHE, HENDERSON, AND MCDOWELL COUNTIES, IN WESTERN NC. OWNERS: NATURE CONSERVANCY, CONSERVING CAROLINA, AND 130 OF CHATHAM, LLC. RESTORATION GOALS ARE TO RESTORE SOUTHERN APPALACHIAN BOG HABITAT BY ERADICATING NON-NATIVE INVASIVE SPECIES, RESTORING THE GROUND WATER HYDROLOGY, AND THE REMOVAL OF OVERGROWN VEGETATION TO A MEADOW BOG TO PROVIDE HABITAT FOR THE AT-RISK T (S A) SOUTHERN BOG TURTLE.

THE PROJECT WILL ENHANCE APPROXIMATELY 13 ACRES OF MATURE FLOODPLAIN FOREST ALONG THE WHITE RIVER IN MADISON COUNTY THROUGH INVASIVE SPECIES CONTROL ON PERMANENTLY PROTECTED LAND OWNED BY RED-TAIL LAND CONSERVANCY AS PART OF THE HIDDEN CANAL PRESERVE.  THE PROPERTY BORDERS THE WHITE RIVER NEAR THE CITY OF ANDERSON, INDIANA AND IS DIRECTLY ACROSS THE RIVER FROM MOUNDS STATE PARK, A 290-ACRE PROPERTY OWNED BY THE INDIANA DNR, WHICH FEATURES UNIQUE NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES, INCLUDING FEN HABITATS AND PRE-HISTORIC MOUND STRUCTURES.  THE 51-ACRE HIDDEN CANAL PRESERVE PROPERTY ALSO FEATURES A FORMER CANAL STRUCTURE USED FOR HYDROELECTRIC GENERATION PURPOSES, AND INCLUDES BOTH MATURE AND REGENERATING FLOODPLAIN FOREST, STEEP WOODED SLOPES, AND OLD AGRICULTURAL FIELDS REVERTING TO WOODY VEGETATION.TOGETHER WITH MOUNDS STATE PARK AND THE NEARBY RANGELINE NATURE PRESERVE, THESE PROPERTIES FROM AN IMPORTANT FORESTED CORRIDOR ALONG THE WHITE RIVER IN A MOSTLY AGRICULTURAL AND URBAN SUBURBAN LANDSCAPE, AND THUS PROVIDE AN IMPORTANT HABITAT CORRIDOR FOR MIGRATORY BIRDS AND OTHER WILDLIFE.  THE WHITE RIVER IN THIS REACH ALSO HAS A HIGHLY PRODUCTIVE AQUATIC COMMUNITY, AS EVIDENCED BY AN INDEX OF BIOTIC INTEGRITY (IBI) SCORE OF 56 AT THE LOCATION OF MOUNDS STATE PARK.  IN ADDITION, THE PARK BOASTS THE HIGHEST FLORISTIC QUALITY INDEX (FQI) OF ANY PROTECTED PROPERTY IN THE EAST-CENTRAL INDIANA AREA, WITH AN FQI OF 96.2 AND 478 NATIVE PLANT SPECIES.     A KEY GOAL OF MANAGING THE HIDDEN CANAL PRESERVE SITE IS TO REDUCE THE IMPACT OF NON-NATIVE, INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES AT THAT SITE, THE MOST DAMAGING OF WHICH ECOLOGICALLY INCLUDE AMUR HONEYSUCKLE, AUTUMN OLIVE AND CALLERY PEAR.  IMPROVING THE STRUCTURE AND COMPOSITION OF THE FLOODPLAIN FOREST BY REDUCING WOODY INVASIVE DOMINANCE IN THE UNDERSTORY WILL BENEFIT A VARIETY OF MIGRATORY BIRD SPECIES, INCLUDING WOOD THRUSH, ACADIAN FLYCATCHER, KENTUCKY WARBLER, INDIGO BUNTING, BLACK-BILLED CUCKOO AND WILD TURKEY. THE AMUR HONEYSUCKLE HAS BECOME THICK ENOUGH TO BLOCK SUNLIGHT FROM REACHING THE FOREST FLOOR AND INHIBITING THE NATIVE HERBACEOUS PLANT COMMUNITY. BENEFITS TO THESE BIRD SPECIES INCLUDE ENHANCED NESTING AND FORAGING HABITAT THROUGH IMPROVED HERBACEOUS AND SHRUB SAPLING DIVERSITY.  THIS RESTORATION PROJECT WILL HELP DEPLETE THE INVASIVE SPECIES SEED SOURCE AND CURB THE SPREAD OF INVASIVE SPECIES TO THE ADJACENT PERMANENTLY PROTECTED LANDS, INCLUDING MOUNDS STATE PARK.  THE WHITE RIVER CORRIDOR ALSO PROVIDES IMPORTANT HABITAT TO MULTIPLE THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES. MAINTAINING A HEALTHY FOREST ECOSYSTEM WOULD BENEFIT THE NORTHERN LONG-EARED BAT AND INDIANA BAT, WHICH UTILIZE FORESTED FLOODPLAIN CORRIDORS FOR MIGRATION AS WELL AS ROOSTING AND FORAGING HABITAT.  THE SERVICE WILL COORDINATE WITH THE LANDOWNER, PROJECT PARTNERS AND THE CONTRACTOR, AND WILL PROVIDE COST-SHARE FUNDING TO RED-TAIL LAND CONSERVANCY IN SUPPORT OF THE RESTORATION WORK. THE PFW COST SHARE WILL BE UTILIZED BY RTC TOWARD HIRING AN ECOLOGICAL RESTORATION CONTRACTOR FOR FECON AND HAND CUTTING WORK DURING THE LATE FALL WINTER AND FOLLOW-UP HERBICIDE APPLICATION TO CONTROL THE NON-NATIVE INVASIVE SPECIES. CUT-STUMP HERBICIDE TREATMENT WILL TAKE PLACE DURING THE WINTER MONTHS AND THE FOLIAR HERBICIDE APPLICATION WILL BE COMPLETED DURING THE GROWING SEASON.  RED-TAIL LAND CONSERVANCY WILL ALSO PROVIDE FUNDING TO THE CONTRACTOR FOR THE INVASIVE SPECIES CONTROL ACTIVITIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS TO ESTABLISH A WORKING PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE SERVICE AND THE COLORADO WILDLIFE HERITAGE FOUNDATION FOR THE PURPOSE OF SUPPORTING CONSERVATION EFFORTS ON PRIVATE, TRIBAL, COUNTY, LOCAL GOVERNMENT, AND OR NONPROFIT-OWNED LANDS THROUGHOUT COLORADO.  THE RECIPIENT WILL FACILITATE THE DEVELOPMENT OF CONSERVATION PROJECTS LANDS AND WORK COOPERATIVELY WITH THE SERVICE TO IDENTIFY, DEVELOP, AND ESTABLISH MUTUALLY BENEFICIAL CONSERVATION PROJECTS.  CONSERVATION PROJECTS TO BE JOINTLY IMPLEMENTED BY THE SERVICE AND THE COLORADO WILDLIFE HERITAGE FOUNDATION INCLUDE THE RESTORATION, ENHANCEMENT, AND ESTABLISHMENT OF PRIORITY WETLAND, UPLAND, STREAM, AND RIPARIAN HABITATS FOR THE BENEFIT OF FEDERAL TRUST AND PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE FOCAL SPECIES.  ALL PROJECTS WILL BE FACILITATED BY SITE-SPECIFIC PRIVATE LANDOWNER AGREEMENTS AS APPROVED AND ADMINISTERED BY THE SERVICE.  AGREEMENTS WILL IDENTIFY CONSERVATION PRACTICES SUCH AS SEEDING NATIVE GRASSES AND FORBS, TREATING INVASIVE PLANTS, INSTALLING IRRIGATION INFRASTRUCTURE, STREAM BANK STABILIZATION, IMPROVING LIVESTOCK MANAGEMENT, INSTALLING LOW TECH RESTORATION STRUCTURES, AND OR OTHER PRACTICES.  RESTORATION OF HABITATS WITHIN HIGH PRIORITY CONSERVATION FOCUS AREAS WILL CONTRIBUTE TOWARDS MEETING POPULATION AND HABITAT OBJECTIVES IDENTIFIED IN THE SERVICES FISCAL YEAR 20222026 MOUNTAIN-PRAIRIE REGION PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM STRATEGIC PLAN.

THE GOALS OF THE GOLD CREEK RESTORATION PROJECT ARE TO RESTORE NATURAL FLOW AND IMPROVE INSTREAM HABITAT COMPLEXITY FOR BULL TROUT. SPECIFICALLY, THE OBJECTIVES ARE: (1) FILL TWO GRAVEL PITS, GOLD AND HELIS POND, TO ELIMINATE THE SIPHON EFFECT THAT PULLS WATER AWAY FROM GOLD CREEK, AND (2) RESTORE THE GEOMORPHOLOGY OF LOWER GOLD CREEK (RIVER MILES 1-3) BY INSTALLING OVER 1,000 LOGS AND WOOD STRUCTURES TO IMPROVE BULL TROUT HOLDING, SPAWNING, AND REARING HABITAT. THIS FUNDING OPPORTUNITY WILL PARTIALLY FUND THE PERMITTING AND DESIGNS FOR THE GOLD CREEK RESTORATION PROJECT.

THESE PROJECTS WILL RESTORE AND OR ENHANCE APPROXIMATELY:  287 ACRES OF FLOODED AGRICULTURAL LAND  AND  4 RIVER MILES OF RIPARIAN OF RIPARIAN HABITAT ALONG THE LOST RIVER. THIS PROJECT ALSO INCLUDES DEVELOPMENT OF ENGINEERING SPECIFICATIONS FOR THE KLAMATH WING WATCHER WETLAND. THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT NUMEROUS SPECIES OF WILDLIFE INCLUDING DEER, ELK, TROUT, WATERFOWL, AND OTHER FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES.

THE LONGLEAF ALLIANCE, INC (TLA) IS REQUESTING FUNDING FROM THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM (PFW) TO DELIVER COST-SHARE TO PRIVATE LANDOWNERS IN NORTH CAROLINA, SOUTH CAROLINA, GEORGIA, FLORIDA, ALABAMA, MISSISSIPPI, AND LOUISIANA. THE FUNDING WILL BE USED TO RESTORE AND ENHANCE LONGLEAF PINE HABITAT ON PRIVATE LANDS FOR THE BENEFIT OF MIGRATORY BIRDS, POLLINATORS, AND LISTED, AT-RISK, AND OTHER ENDEMIC SPECIES OF THE LONGLEAF PINE ECOSYSTEM.  THOSE SPECIES INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO RED-COCKADED WOODPECKER, EASTERN INDIGO SNAKE, SOUTHERN HOGNOSE SNAKE, EASTERN DIAMONDBACK RATTLESNAKE, GOPHER TORTOISE, GOPHER FROG, FROSTED FLATWOOD SALAMANDER, POND BERRY, AMERICAN CHAFF SEED, AND VENUS FLYTRAP. THE LONGLEAF ALLIANCE REQUESTS  166,000. WITH THIS FUNDING, IT IS REASONABLE TO EXPECT 10 PRIVATE LANDOWNER PROJECTS TO RESTORE APPROXIMATELY 1,100 ACRES.

AN AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE MARIPOSA RESOURCES CONSERVATION DISTRICT AND PARTNERS PROGRAM WILL FUND PROJECTS TO RESTORE HABITAT FOR WILDLIFE IN MARIPOSA COUNTY, CA. OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT ARE TO ENHANCE WATER RETENTION, RESTORE A SECTION OF STREAM, AID IN MANAGEMENT OF THE AREA FOR MONARCH BUTTERFLIES AND OTHER POLLINATORS, AND TO PROVIDE WILDLIFE WATER. THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH THE PLACEMENT OF INSTREAM STRUCTURES, PLANTING, FENCING, AND THE BUILDING OF A WILDLIFE GUZZLER.RESTORATION ACTIVITIES WILL POSITIVELY IMPACT MONARCH BUTTERFLY WHICH HAVE BEEN OBSERVED AS CATERPILLARS AND ADULTS ON THE PROPERTY, AS WELL AS WILDLIFE. INCREASING WATER RETENTION IN THE STREAM CAN HELP PROVIDE MUDDY SOIL FOR BUTTERFLIES TO PUDDLE IN WHICH THEY DO TO OBTAIN MINERALS. IT ALSO AIDS IN REVEGETATION WHICH COULD PROVIDE NECTAR PLANTS IN THE FUTURE. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL BE DUE DECEMBER EACH YEAR, TREATMENT AND RESTORATION INSPECTIONS SITE VISITS WILL BE COMPLETED BY 2028, AND A FINAL PROJECT REPORT WILL BE PROVIDED BY 2028.

CRANE CREEK IS SPRING FED AND FLOWS THROUGH THE WEST SIDE OF THE WOOD RIVER VALLEY. IT IS A TRIBUTARY TO FOURMILE CREEK, AND IN THE PAST WAS LEVEED AND STRAIGHTENED FOR IRRIGATION USE. THE UPSTREAM HALF OF CRANE CREEK ON PRIVATE PROPERTY (SEVENMILE RANCH LLC) WAS RE-ROUTED FROM THE STRAIGHTENED REACH AND RESTORED IN 2008, AND THE DOWNSTREAM HALF ON PRIVATE PROPERTY (WAMPLER RANCHES LLC) WAS RE-ROUTED AND RESTORED IN 2021. BOTH OF THESE PROJECTS WERE FUNDED LARGELY BY US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE IN PARTNERSHIP WITH TROUT UNLIMITED AND OTHER COLLABORATORS. THERE IS A SMALL SECTION BETWEEN THE TWO RESTORATION PROJECTS WHERE A TOTAL FISH PASSAGE BARRIER EXISTS AND THE CHANNEL IS STILL LEVEED AND STRAIGHTENED. THE BARRIER, A DROP CULVERT THAT USED TO PROVIDE WATER CONTROL FOR IRRIGATION, PROHIBITS PASSAGE YEAR-ROUND FOR NATIVE REDBAND TROUT. WITH THE DOWNSTREAM RESTORATION COMPLETE, THERE IS ALSO THE POSSIBILITY FOR ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT LISTED THREATENED BULL TROUT OR FUTURE ANADROMOUS SALMONIDS TO ACCESS CRANE CREEK, AND THESE POPULATIONS WILL ALSO HAVE UPSTREAM PASSAGE BLOCKED IF THE FISH BARRIER IS NOT REMEDIED.FY 2022 FUNDS WERE GRANTED FOR AN ENGINEER TO DESIGN THE REMOVAL AND REPLACEMENT OF A CULVERT THAT IS A COMPLETE BARRIER TO FISH PASSAGE (SEE TENTATIVE DESIGN PLAN IMAGE BELOW, FIGURE 1). THE DESIGN DEVELOPED WILL BE SUFFICIENT FOR APPROVAL BY NATURAL RESOURCES CONSERVATION SERVICE, AS NATURAL RESOURCES CONSERVATION SERVICE HOLDS A WETLAND RESERVE EASEMENT ON THE PROPERTY AND MUST APPROVE ALL ACTIONS. THE NEXT PHASE IS IMPLEMENTATION OF THE DESIGN PLAN. FOR THIS PROJECT WE WILL REMOVE THE DROP CULVERT (WHICH IS IMPASSIBLE TO FISH) AND INSTALL A ROUGHENED CHANNEL TO MAINTAIN UPSTREAM WATER SURFACE ELEVATIONS. A NEW ACCESS ROAD CROSSING APPROXIMATELY 350 FT DOWNSTREAM OF THE EXISTING CULVERT WILL BE BUILT. A SECTION OF THE CRANE CREEK CANAL MAY BE DECOMMISSIONED BETWEEN THE EXISTING CULVERT AND WAMPLER RANCH, AND A NEW CHANNEL WILL BE BUILT TO THE EAST THAT UTILIZES EXISTING HISTORIC CHANNEL SCARS AND RECONNECTING PART OF THE WETLAND FLOODPLAIN. IF POSSIBLE, WE WANT TO REBUILD A PART OF THE OLD CRANE CREEK CANAL SO THAT IS LOOKS MORE LIKE A NATURAL STREAM WITH HABITAT SWALES. THIS WILL ADD HABITAT FOR BOTH FISH AND OREGON SPOTTED FROG.

THE NORTHERN GREAT PLAINS (NGP) ARE ONE OF ONLY FOUR REMAINING LARGELY INTACT TEMPERATE GRASSLANDS IN THE WORLD. THE NGP HAS CHANGED DRAMATICALLY WITH THE CONVERSION OF 44 MILLION ACRES TO LARGELY PERMANENT AND SEMI-PERMANENT CROPLAND AGRICULTURE. THE CONVERSION OCCURRED AT AN AVERAGE RATE OF 500,000 ACRES OF GRASS PER YEAR, 2015 TO 2020 (USDA, NASS, WWF PLOWPRINT 2022 REPORT). WITHIN THE ECOREGION, CONVERSION CONTINUES TO OCCUR DUE TO HIGH CROP PRICES, GOVERNMENT INCENTIVES AND A GROWING GLOBAL HUMAN POPULATION. THIS LEADS TO LOSS OF HABITAT AND THREATENS THE ABILITY OF THE LAND TO PROVIDE ECOSYSTEM SERVICES, SUCH AS CARBON SEQUESTRATION AND STORAGE, BIODIVERSITY, WATER FILTRATION AND REDUCED EROSION. GRASS-BASED ECONOMIES ARE A CRITICAL COMPONENT OF COMBATING GRASSLANDS CONVERSION BY MAINTAINING INTACT GRASSLANDS AND THE ECOSYSTEM SERVICES THEY PROVIDE. MUCH OF THE INTACT GRASSLANDS IN THE NGP, AND THE ASSOCIATED LIVELIHOODS OF ITS OWNERS AND OPERATORS, ARE SUPPORTED THROUGH RANCHING. SUSTAINABLE GRAZING MANAGEMENT FACILITATES THE COEXISTENCE OF LIVESTOCK WITH NATIVE WILDLIFE, PROMOTES VEGETATION PRODUCTIVITY, ENSURES HEALTHY ROOT AND MICROBIAL SYSTEMS, AND PROTECTS SOIL FROM EROSION. RANCHERS USE GRAZING MANAGEMENT PLANS TO MANAGE GRASSLANDS WHILE ALSO MANAGING EMISSIONS, PROMOTING CARBON SEQUESTRATION, AND IMPROVING SOIL HEALTH AND WATER INFILTRATION. TO FURTHER PROMOTE SUSTAINABLE RANCHING IN THE NGP, WWFS SUSTAINABLE RANCHING INITIATIVE (SRI) LAUNCHED THE RANCH SYSTEMS AND VIABILITY PLANNING (RSVP) NETWORK IN 2021. BY ENROLLING THEIR RANCH INTO RSVP AND AGREEING TO NON-CONVERSION, RANCHERS GAIN ACCESS TO FINANCIAL AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO SUPPORT GRAZING PLANNING, RANCH INFRASTRUCTURE DEVELOPMENT, ECOLOGICAL MONITORING, AND CONTINUING EDUCATION. THROUGH RSVP, WWF IS ESTABLISHING A COMPREHENSIVE SUPPORT SYSTEM FOR RANCHERS TO DEVELOP SUSTAINABLE GRAZING MANAGEMENT PLANS WITH ASSISTANCE FROM ON-THE-GROUND TECHNICAL SPECIALISTS AND TO ACCESS CONTINUING EDUCATION TO IMPROVE ECOLOGICAL OUTCOMES AT SCALE IN THE NGP.THIS PROJECT WILL JOIN WWF AND USFWS IN THEIR SHARED GOAL OF SUPPORTING THE INTEGRITY OF WORKING LANDS ACROSS THE SAGEBRUSH HABITATS OF THE NGP IN MONTANA. THIS WILL INCLUDE WORK ACROSS PRIORITY GRASSLAND AND SAGEBRUSH HABITAT CORES, WORKING DIRECTLY WITH RANCHES ENROLLED IN RSVP TO CONTRIBUTE TOWARDS POPULATION AND HABITAT OBJECTIVES FOR FEDERAL TRUST RESOURCES FOUND IN THE AREA. WE WILL DELIVER GRASSLAND RESTORATION (RESEEDING) TO AT LEAST 2,000 ACRES OF MARGINAL CROPLAND ADJACENT TO INTACT GRASSLAND CORES. WE WILL ALSO IMPROVE RANCH INFRASTRUCTURE, IMPROVE DROUGHT RESILIENCE OF OPERATIONS, AND PROMOTE MANAGED GRAZING SYSTEMS ON APPROXIMATELY 100,000 ACRES OF PRIVATE LAND IN SAGEBRUSH CORES TO PROVIDE FINANCIAL AND ECOLOGICAL BENEFITS. THIS PROJECT WILL DIRECTLY ADDRESS THE THREAT OF LAND CONVERSION BY MAINTAINING RESTORED AREAS AND INTACT RANCHES IN GRASSLAND SAGEBRUSH COVER FOR A MINIMUM OF 10 YEARS. ADDITIONALLY, WWF AND USFWS WILL COLLECT BIRD OCCUPANCY, SOIL CARBON, AND VEGETATION DIVERSITY DATA ON PARTICIPATING RANCHES TO ASSIST PARTNERS IN BOTH INDIVIDUAL AND COLLECTIVE UNDERSTANDING OF THE IMPACTS OF GRAZING MANAGEMENT ON A VARIETY OF ECOLOGICAL INDICATORS.

FIVEMILE CREEK IS A CLEARWATER TRIBUTARY TO THE NORTH FORK SPRAGUE RIVER WHICH CURRENTLY HAS AT-RISK WATER QUALITY. THE PROJECTS SITES ENCOMPASS ESSENTIALLY THE HEADWATERS OF FIVEMILE CREEK WHERE THE FLOW BECOMES PERENNIAL DUE TO SPRING INPUTS. HISTORICALLY, THIS AREA WAS DESCRIBED AS PONDEROSA PINE AND MIXED CONIFER FOREST. ALONG THE CREEK (PARTICULARLY WITHIN THE UPSTREAM SITES) ARE SPRINGS WHICH CREATE MARSHY WETLAND HABITAT. THE ENTIRE AREA IS NOW BURNED AND DEVOID OF GROUND VEGETATION, DECIMATING THE PREVIOUSLY HEALTHY AND INTACT ECOSYSTEM. BECAUSE THIS CREEK FLOWS INTO THE NORTH FORK SPRAGUE, IT IS A PRIORITY TO REDUCE POTENTIAL NUTRIENT LOADING BY CAPTURING OR PREVENTING SEDIMENT RUNOFF FROM THE FIRE. THE PROPOSED PROJECTS ARE A CONTINUATION OF RESTORATION WORK STARTED IN 2022, WHICH INCLUDED HAZARD TREE REMOVAL, REMOVAL OF BURNED FENCING, AND INSTALLATION OF NEW PERIMETER FENCE TO KEEP CATTLE OFF THE NORTHERN SITE AND PROTECT THE SENSITIVE RIPARIAN SPRING HABITATS. CURRENTLY THERE IS LIMITED INSTREAM COMPLEXITY COVERAGE, AND THE STREAM HAS FAIRLY UNIFORM DEPTH AND FLOW, WHICH LIMITS THE CAPACITY FOR FISH ABUNDANCE. INSTREAM STRUCTURES WILL PROVIDE FISH HABITAT COVER AND REDUCE WATER TEMPERATURES. RIPARIAN AND UPLAND PLANTINGS WILL STABILIZE THE SOILS TO CAPTURE OR PREVENT FURTHER EROSION, AND PROVIDE OVERBANK COVER (SHADE). THE PROPOSED INSTREAM STRUCTURES WOULD SUPPORT REARING, RESTING, AND FEEDING (ESSENTIALLY ALL LIVE STAGES OF REDBAND TROUT). ADDING WOODY STRUCTURES WITHIN THE STREAM WILL ALSO DECREASE THE VOLUME OF DISCHARGE NEEDED TO FORCE OVERBANK FLOW, WHICH WILL THEREFORE INCREASE THE FREQUENCY THAT HIGH-FLOW CHANNELS WILL BE CONNECTED AND SEASONAL WETLANDS WILL BE INUNDATED. BEAVER ACTIVITY POST-FIRE IS ALREADY PRESENT WITHIN THE SITES AND PROPOSED RIPARIAN PLANTINGS WOULD ENCOURAGE AND SUPPORT BEAVER ESTABLISHMENT. A LOW-TECH PROCESS BASED RESTORATION DESIGN MODEL WAS COMPLETED BY ANABRANCH SOLUTIONS AND WILL BE USED AS A GUIDE FOR OBJECTIVES OF INSTREAM HABITAT WORK. THE PLAN IS A PHASED APPROACH WITH MONITORING AND ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT OF STRUCTURES OVER A 5-YEAR PERIOD. MID AND LOWER REACHES OF FIVEMILE CREEK OUTSIDE THE BURNED AREA (ON FOREST SERVICE LAND NEAR FOSTER FIELD) WILL BE ALSO USED AS A REFERENCE SITE TO DRIVE RESTORATION GOALS. HAZARD TREES NEAR THE STREAM WILL BE FELLED BEFORE LOW-TECH RESTORATION BEGINS. SITE SELECTION, DESIGN, AND ALL OTHER ASPECTS OF INSTALLATION OR AUGMENTATION OF BEAVER DAM ANALOGS AND POST-ASSISTED LOG STRUCTURES WILL BE DEVELOPED USING THE BEAVER RESTORATION GUIDEBOOK 2.01 (POLLOCK ET AL. 2018) AND LOW-TECH PROCESS-BASED RESTORATION OF RIVERSCAPES  DESIGN MANUAL VERSION 1.0 (WHEATON ET AL. 2019). TO JUMPSTART REGROWTH IN THE RIPARIAN WETLAND AREAS WE WILL BE PLANTING NATIVE TREES AND SHRUBS SUCH AS WILLOW, ALDER, COTTONWOOD, SNOWBERRY, CURRANT, DOGWOOD, ETC. THE GRASSES, SAGES, AND RUSHES APPEAR TO BE REESTABLISHING. A PORTION OF THE PLANTS WILL BE PROTECTED WITH CAGES TO DETER BEAVER UNTIL THERE IS ENOUGH REGROWTH. ALL PLANTINGS (INCLUDING FUTURE UPLAND FOREST) WILL BE PHASED OVER A 5-YEAR PERIOD. IN SUMMARY, THE FISCAL YEAR 2023 FUNDING WILL BE USED FOR THE REMOVAL UTILIZATION OF BURNED TREES WITHIN THE RIPARIAN, PHASED LOW-TECH PROCESS-BASED RESTORATION INSTREAM HABITAT WORK, AND RIPARIAN PLANTINGS. A SEPARATE GRANT WAS OBTAINED TO FINISH CATTLE EXCLUSION FENCING AT SITES 2 AND 3 TO COMPLEMENT OVERALL RESTORATION GOALS.

THIS PROJECT IS A COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE S, PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE, INDIAN NATIONS CONSERVATION ALLIANCE, AND IS ENTERED INTO PURSUANT TO AUTHORITY CONTAINED IN THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE ACT OF 1956 (P.L. 109-294), THE FISH AND WILDLIFE COORDINATION ACT (16 U.S.C. 661 ET SEQ.) AND THE FISH AND WILDLIFE ACT OF 1956 (16 U.S.C. 7421-J), AS AMENDED. THE SCOPE OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS TO ENHANCE HABITAT FOR FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES BY PROVIDING FUNDING TO INDIAN NATIONS CONSERVATION ALLIANCE T WORK WITH PRIVATE LANDOWNERS, PROJECTS WILL IMPLEMENT BEST GRAZING AND RANGE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES TO ADDRESS RESOURCE CONCERNS, INCLUDING UPLAND AND RIPARIAN RESOURCES. THIS AGREEMENT AIMS TO RESTORE, ENHANCE, AND OR ESTABLISH TERRESTRIAL AND AQUATIC HABITATS THAT BENEFIT FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES, SPECIES OF SPECIAL CONCERN, AND OTHER WILDLIFE IN ARIZONA. IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT AT LEAST 1 SUBRECIPIENT AGREEMENT WILL BE COMPLETED UNDER THIS AGREEMENT. PROJECT(S) WILL OCCUR ON TRIBAL LANDS IN ARIZONA AND WILL BE COMPLETED WITHIN FIVE YEARS. ALL ENVIRONMENTAL COMPLIANCE DOCUMENTS WILL BE COMPLETED BEFORE ON-THE GROUND WORK IS TO BE BEGIN.

PIMA COUNTY S AWARD-WINNING SONORAN DESERT CONSERVATION PLAN (SDCP) GUIDES REGIONAL EFFORTS TO CONSERVE ECOLOGICALLY VALUABLE LANDS AND THE MOST PRECIOUS RESOURCES FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS OF PIMA COUNTY RESIDENTS TO ENJOY. THE SDCP GIVES HIGH PRIORITY TO PRESERVING AND PROTECTING IMPORTANT NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES. CONCURRENTLY, PIMA COUNTY HAS ACQUIRED OWNERSHIP AND OR MANAGEMENT OF NEARLY 250,000 ACRES OF LAND, NOW MANAGED BY PIMA COUNTY NATURAL RESOURCES, PARKS AND RECREATION, TO PROTECT AND CONSERVE THESE VALUABLE RESOURCES. THESE ECOSYSTEMS IN SOUTHERN ARIZONA FACE SIGNIFICANT THREATS DUE TO CLIMATE CHANGE, DECREASED BIODIVERSITY, DEGRADED BIOLOGICAL CONDITIONS, AND HABITAT FRAGMENTATION. THE SCOPE OF THIS LANDOWNER AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE S PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM AND PIMA COUNTY NATURAL RESOURCES, PARKS AND RECREATION DEPARTMENT IS TO ENHANCE HABITAT FOR FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES AT THE  GOFF POND  WHICH IS LOCATED ON THE ORACLE RIDGE PROPERTY. PIMA COUNTY NRPR WILL INSTALL FENCING AROUND THE POND TO REDUCE THE IMPACT OF TRESPASS CATTLE, IMPROVE WATER QUALITY, AND ENHANCE IT FOR WILDLIFE BENEFIT.

BRUSH MANAGEMENT ON 88 ACRES OF UPLAND HABITAT TO THIN ASHE JUNIPER AND OTHER WOODY PLANTS INVADING GRASSLAND AND WOODLAND HABITATS AT UNDESIRABLE DENSITIES. BRUSH MANAGEMENT WILL INVOLVE CUTTING TREES WITH A SKID-STEER LOADED EQUIPPED WITH A HYDRAULIC SHEARING DEVICE, BY MULCHING WITH A FORESTRY MULCHER, OR BY HAND WITH POWER SAWS, BUT NOT BY PUSHING WITH A BULLDOZER. ASHE JUNIPER (CEDAR) CAN SIMPLY BE CUT AND ALLOWED TO LAY IN PLACE. MESQUITE AND RED-BERRY JUNIPER AND OTHER BRUSH (SPROUTING SPECIES) WILL NEED TO BE CUT AND IMMEDIATELY TREATED WITH AN APPROPRIATE HERBICIDE (BASAL-BARK CUT-STUMP TREATMENT IS RECOMMENDED).

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO ASSIST THE WYOMING WEED AND PEST COUNCIL (WWPC) IN CONTROLLING INVASIVE ANNUAL GRASS IN SAGEBRUSH LANDSCAPES. THE WWPC WILL PROVIDE THE MECHANISM FOR TREATING INVASIVE ANNUAL GRASSES ON PRIVATE LANDS TO ENHANCE NATIVE PLANT COMMUNITIES, WHICH IN TURN WILL IMPROVE SAGE STEPPE GRASSLAND HABITAT FOR A VARIETY OF GAME AND NON-GAME SPECIES. PROJECTS DEVELOPED UNDER THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT ARE LOCATED WITHIN IDENTIFIED FOCAL AREAS FOR HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION UNDER THE PARTNERS FOR FISH   WILDLIFE PROGRAM 2022-2027 STRATEGIC PLAN. A LONG-TERM GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO FOSTER A SPIRIT OF COOPERATIVE CONSERVATION, WHEREBY AGRICULTURAL LANDS AND THOSE FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES THAT RELY ON THESE RURAL LANDS ARE PROMOTED HAND-IN-HAND. THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVE TO BE ACCOMPLISHED UNDER THIS PROJECT WILL BE ON-THE-GROUND HABITAT PROJECTS OR TREATMENTS. THE OUTCOMES WILL BE IMPROVED HABITAT FOR FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES, STATE FISH AND WILDLIFE SPECIES OF CONCERN, AND OTHER CONSERVATION PRIORITY SPECIES OF OUR PARTNERS, AS WELL AS IMPROVING THE LOCAL HUMAN ENVIRONMENT THOUGH ECONOMIC BENEFITS TO AREA COMMUNITIES. WE ANTICIPATE APPROXIMATELY TEN TO FIFTEEN SITESPECIFIC PRIVATE LANDOWNER AGREEMENTS WILL BE ADMINISTERED UNDER THIS PROJECT USING SAGE BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW (BIL) FUNDING. SPECIFIC INVASIVE ANNUAL GRASS TREATMENT AREAS WILL LIKELY INCLUDE APPROXIMATELY 4,000 ACRES, BENEFITTING APPROXIMATELY 100,000 ACRES OF THE SURROUNDING SAGE-STEPPE LANDSCAPE.

THE COCOPAH TRIBE AIMS TO RESTORE AND PROTECT THE WILDLIFE AND HABITAT OF THE LOWER COLORADO RIVER LIMITROPHE ON THE COCOPAH RESERVATION.  THE 23-MILE COLORADO RIVER RIPARIAN CORRIDOR BETWEEN THE UNITED STATES AND MEXICO, COMMONLY KNOWN AS THE LIMITROPHE, INCLUDES 12 RIVER MILES WITHIN THE COCOPAH RESERVATION AND 11 MILES UNDER FEDERAL MANAGEMENT.  THE LIMITROPHE IS A COMPLEX RIPARIAN ECOSYSTEM THAT CONTAINS THE BEST REMAINING NATIVE HABITAT ON THE RIVER TO SUPPORT A WIDE VARIETY OF BIRDS AND OTHER WILDLIFE.  IT IS ECOLOGICALLY VITAL AND CONTRIBUTES SIGNIFICANTLY TO THE SAFE PASSAGE OF MIGRATORY NEOTROPICAL SONGBIRDS, WATERFOWL, AND OTHER WETLAND BIRDS TRAVERSING THE DRY DESERT PORTION OF THE PACIFIC FLYWAY. THE LIMITROPHE IS TREMENDOUSLY IMPORTANT TO THE COCOPAH AS IT SUSTAINS SUBSISTENCE, CULTURAL, ECONOMIC, AND RECREATIONAL ACTIVITIES. A PRIMARY GOAL OF IMPLEMENTING THIS PLAN IS TO RESTORE NATIVE HABITAT FOR BOTH RESIDENT AND MIGRATORY WILDLIFE SPECIES ALONG THE LOWER COLORADO RIVER.  ANOTHER GOAL OF THIS RESTORATION PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE AN OPPORTUNITY TO PROMOTE THE VISION OF THE COCOPAH TRIBE, WHICH IS TO INCREMENTALLY RESTORE RIPARIAN AND WETLAND AREAS ALONG THE LOWER COLORADO RIVER ON TRIBAL LANDS AND EVENTUALLY CREATE TRADITIONAL NATIVE PLANT GARDENS, NATURE PARKS, AND INTERPRETIVE TRAILS. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL INCLUDE ASSESSING THE SITE FOR ECOLOGICAL CONDITIONS, CLEARING THE SITE OF NON-NATIVE VEGETATION AND REVEGETATING THE SITE WITH NATIVE VEGETATION APPROPRIATE FOR THE AREA.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS TO ESTABLISH A WORKING PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE SERVICE AND THE RECIPIENT FOR THE PURPOSE OF PROMOTING CONSERVATION ON PRIVATE LANDS THROUGH A VARIETY OF EFFORTS.  THE RECIPIENT WILL FACILITATE THE DEVELOPMENT OF CONSERVATION PROJECTS LANDS AND WORK COOPERATIVELY WITH THE SERVICE TO IDENTIFY, DEVELOP, ESTABLISH, AND COMPLETE MUTUALLY BENEFICIAL CONSERVATION PROJECTS.  ALL PROJECTS WILL BE FACILITATED BY SITE-SPECIFIC PRIVATE LANDOWNER AGREEMENTS (PLAS) AS APPROVED AND ADMINISTERED BY THE SERVICE.  THIS AGREEMENT WILL RESTORE, ENHANCE, AND ESTABLISH HABITATS FOR THE BENEFIT OF (1) FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES  (2) SAGEBRUSH OBLIGATE BIRDS  (3) GRASSLAND NESTING MIGRATORY BIRDS  (4) OTHER MIGRATORY BIRDS (E.G., WATERFOWL, WADING BIRDS, ETC.)  (5) NATIVE TROUT  (6) BIG GAME  AND (7) WORKING LANDS.  RESTORATION OF HABITATS WITHIN HIGH PRIORITY CONSERVATION FOCUS AREAS WILL CONTRIBUTE TOWARDS MEETING POPULATION AND HABITAT OBJECTIVES IDENTIFIED IN THE SERVICES FY 20222026 MOUNTAIN-PRAIRIE REGION STRATEGIC PLAN FOR THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM.

PHEASANTS FOREVER, INC., WILL WORK COOPERATIVELY WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE IN THE PROJECT AREA TO ASSIST IN ADMINISTERING THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM FOR THE BENEFIT OF FEDERAL TRUST RESOURCES ON PRIVATE LAND OWNED OR UNDER EASEMENT BY PHEASANTS FOREVER, INC. OR THE SERVICE.  OUR GOALS AND OBJECTIVES ARE TO RESTORE AND ENHANCE GRASSLAND AND WETLAND RESOURCES IN HIGH PRIORITY AREAS AS IDENTIFIED IN THE PRAIRIE POTHOLE JOINT VENTURE, THE MINNESOTA PRAIRIE CONSERVATION PLAN AND THE MINNESOTA PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM STRATEGIC PLAN. FUNDS WILL BE OBLIGATED AND SPENT ON CAPACITY SUPPORT (PERSONNEL) AND HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS ON PRIVATE LANDS THAT MEET FWS 640.1 PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM POLICIES. GOALS ARE TO RESTORE APPROXIMATELY 500 ACRES OF WETLAND AND UPLANDS IN HIGH PRIORITY FOCUS AREAS THROUGHOUT MINNESOTA.

UNDERSTORY THINNING: 40 ACRES. TO THIN EASTERN RED CEDAR, YAUPON, AND OTHER WOODY PLANTS INVADING GRASSLAND AND WOODLAND HABITATS AT UNDESIRABLE DENSITIES. BRUSH MANAGEMENT WILL INVOLVE CUTTING TREES WITH A SKID-STEER LOADED EQUIPPED WITH A HYDRAULIC SHEARING DEVICE, BY MULCHING WITH A FORESTRY MULCHER, BY USE OF AN EXCAVATOR AND INDIVIDUAL PLANT TREATMENT, OR BY HAND WITH POWER SAWS, BUT NOT BY PUSHING WITH A BULLDOZER. EASTERN RED CEDAR CAN SIMPLY BE CUT AND ALLOWED TO LAY IN PLACE, MULCHED ON SITE OR REMOVED, OR REMOVED COMPLETELY. YAUPON AND OTHER BRUSH (SPROUTING SPECIES) WILL NEED TO BE CUT AND IMMEDIATELY TREATED WITH AN APPROPRIATE HERBICIDE (BASAL-BARK CUT STUMP TREATMENT IS RECOMMENDED).

ARIZONA IS KNOWN FOR ITS UNIQUE AND DIVERSE ECOSYSTEMS, INCLUDING DESERTS, FORESTS, GRASSLANDS, AND RIPARIAN AREAS. HOWEVER, THESE ECOSYSTEMS FACE SIGNIFICANT THREATS DUE TO CLIMATE CHANGE, LAND USE CHANGES, AND INVASIVE SPECIES. THE SCOPE OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICES PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM AND PHEASANTS FOREVER QUAIL FOREVER IS TO ENHANCE HABITAT FOR FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES BY WORKING WITH PRIVATE LANDOWNERS. IN ADDITION, THIS AGREEMENT AIMS TO RESTORE AND IMPROVE THE BIODIVERSITY OF ARIZONAS ECOSYSTEMS THROUGH LANDOWNER AGREEMENTS. THE PROJECTS WILL FOCUS ON RESTORING DEGRADED HABITATS, CONSERVING THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES, AND CONTROLLING INVASIVE SPECIES ON PRIVATE LANDS IN ARIZONA. WE ANTICIPATE TWO OR MORE LANDOWNER AGREEMENTS WITH PRIVATE LANDOWNERS, TRIBES, CITIES, OR COUNTIES TO BE IMPLEMENTED UNDER THE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT TO ENHANCE WETLANDS, UPLANDS, AND RIPARIAN AREAS THROUGH VARIOUS TECHNIQUES. THE PRACTICES INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO REMOVING NATIVE AND NON-NATIVE TREES, INSTALLING EROSION CONTROL STRUCTURES, LIVESTOCK MANAGEMENT, INVASIVE SPECIES CONTROL, NATIVE VEGETATION PLANTING, WATER ACCESS AND MANAGEMENT STRUCTURES, AND OTHER PRACTICES.

1) BRUSH MANAGEMENT ON 44 ACRES OF UPLAND HABITAT TO THIN ASHE JUNIPER AND OTHER WOODY PLANTS INVADING GRASSLAND AND WOODLAND HABITATS AT UNDESIRABLE DENSITIES. BRUSH MANAGEMENT WILL INVOLVE CUTTING TREES WITH A SKID-STEER LOADED EQUIPPED WITH A HYDRAULIC SHEARING DEVICE, BY MULCHING WITH A FORESTRY MULCHER, BY USE OF AN EXCAVATOR AND INDIVIDUAL PLANT TREATMENT, OR BY HAND WITH POWER SAWS, BUT NOT BY PUSHING WITH A BULLDOZER. ASHE JUNIPER (CEDAR) CAN SIMPLY BE CUT AND ALLOWED TO LAY IN PLACE.2). NATIVE GRASSLAND RESTORATION ON 24 ACRES. THIS PROPOSED HABITAT ENHANCEMENT WOULD INCLUDE HIGH DENSITY, LOCALIZED PLANTINGS OF NATIVE GRASSES AND FLOWERING PLANTS (FORBS) TO BENEFIT NATIVE AND MIGRATORY POLLINATORS SUCH HUMMINGBIRDS AND THE MONARCH BUTTERFLY. THE COOPERATOR WILL WORK DIRECTLY WITH THE SERVICE PROJECT OFFICER TO DETERMINE SUITABLE NATIVE PLANT SEED MIXES FOR REPLANTING. ONLY NATIVE SPECIES ARE ACCEPTABLE. EXAMPLES INCLUDE LITTLE BLUESTEM, SIDEOATS GRAMA, HAIRY GRAMA, TEXAS GRAMA, AND DROPSEED. IN ADDITION, NATIVE MILKWEED (COLLECTED OR PURCHASED) AND NATIVE NECTAR PLANTS (9-SPECIES) SUCH AS ASTERS, PRAIRIE CLOVERS, AND BLACK-EYED SUSAN WILL BE ADDED TO THE SEED MIX TO SUPPORT THE MONARCH BUTTERFLY AND OTHER POLLINATOR SPECIES.

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PROVIDE TRUST RESOURCE PUBLIC BENEFITS THROUGH RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT OF 789 TOTAL ACRES OF HABITAT ASSOCIATED WITH THE EDWARDS PLATEAU, CHIHUAHUAN DESER, AND SOUTH TEXAS PLAINS TAMULIPAN THORNSCRUB ECOREGIONS. THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT LOCAL AND MIGRATORY WILDLIFE INCLUDING SONGBIRDS, SMALL MAMMALS, REPTILES, AND INSECTS INCLUDING MONARCH BUTTERFLY AND OTHER POLLINATOR SPECIES.IN THE NORTHERN CHIHUAHUAN DESERT, A SIGNIFICANT PORTION OR THE HISTORIC DESERT GRASSLANDS HAVE SHIFTED TO DESERT SCRUBLAND DUE TO DROUGHT, OVERGRAZING BY LIVESTOCK AND DECREASES IN FIRE OVER THE LAND 70-250 YEARS. THE DESERT GRASSLAND COMMUNITY HISTORICALLY WAS DOMINATED BY GRAMA GRASSES WITH LIMITED SHRUB COVER. MANY OF THE EXISTING DESERT SCBRUBLAND COMMUNITIES ARE NOW DOMINATED BY INVASIVE WOODY SPECIES SUCH AS CREOSOTE BUSH, CENIZO AND OTHER WOODY SPECIES. UNDOUBTEDLY, THIS SHIFT IN PLANT COMPOSITION HAS ADVERSELY IMPACTED MIGRATORY BIRDS THAT UTILIZE GRASSLAND COMMUNITIES IN THE CHIHUAHUAN DESERT.THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO RESTORE AND ENHANCE SOME OF THE HISTORIC ARID GRASSLAND COMMUNITIES THAT CURRENTLY EXIST AS ARID SCRUBLAND VIA SHRUB REDUCTION OF CENIZO, CREOSOTE AND OTHER SPECIES WHILE STIMULATING HERBACEOUS GRASSES AND FORBS SUCH AND GRAMA AND BOUTELOUA. PAST PROJECTS IN THE AREA HAVE SHOWN GREAT SUCCESS IN ALLOWING HERBACEOUS COVER TO INCREASE WHILE SHRUB WOODY COVER HAS DECREASED.ALTHOUGH NO INDIVIDUALS ARE KNOWN TO OCCUR THE PROJECT CAN ALSO BENEFIT TEXAS SNOWBELLS AND TOBUSCH FISHHOOK CACTUS. IN ADDITION, IMPROVED GRASSLAND HEALTH COULD ULTIMATELY BENEFIT WATER QUALITY AND QUANTITY FOR THE BENEFITS OF NUMEROUS FRESH WATER SPECIES FOUND IN THE RIO GRANDE RIVER BASIN.

THE LOWER YAKIMA RIVER RIPARIAN REFORESTATION PROJECT WILL PROTECT OFF-CHANNEL REFUGE HABITAT IN A GROUNDWATER-FED TRIBUTARY CHANNEL AND INCREASE SHADE AND FILTRATION BY REMOVING LIVESTOCK ACCESS FROM THE SHORELINE AND PLANTING THE LEFT BANK OF THE YAKIMA RIVER AT RIVER MILE 80. THE PROJECT WILL REPLANT 10.8 ACRES OF GRAZED LAND ALONG 3,250 STREAM FT OF THE MAINSTEM YAKIMA RIVER. IT WILL PLANT 1,440 NATIVE TREES AND SHRUBS AND INSTALL 2,135 FEET OF LIVESTOCK EXCLUSION FENCING TO PROTECT BOTH BANKS OF THE 1800-FT SPRING CHANNEL. THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT ALL YAKIMA SALMON RUNS, INCLUDING SPRING, SUMMER AND FALL CHINOOK, COHO, AND SOCKEYE. IT WILL ALSO BENEFIT FEDERALLY THREATENED STEELHEAD.

TROUT UNLIMITED (TU) PROPOSES TO WORK WITH LOCAL PARTNERS TO IMPROVE INSTREAM COMPLEXITY IN LITTLE CREEK (UPPER YAKIMA RIVER TRIBUTARY) FOR JUVENILE REARING AND ADULT SPAWNING OF STEELHEAD, COHO AND CHINOOK SALMON, AND RESIDENT BULL TROUT. TU WILL DESIGN AND IMPLEMENT ABOUT 10, COST-EFFECTIVE POST-ASSISTED (OR SIMILAR) IN-CHANNEL BANK-ANCHORED HABITAT FEATURES TO IMPROVE STREAM PROCESSES FOR FISH BENEFITS THROUGH A  500-1000 LINEAR FEET REACH. THE HABITAT FEATURES WILL RESTORE CHANNEL PROCESSES TO MIMIC NATURAL ELEMENTS THAT ARE PRESENTLY ABSENT IN THE TARGET REACH BUT PRESENT IN AN UPSTREAM REFERENCE REACH.TU IS FOCUSING ON LITTLE CREEK BECAUSE FLOW RESTORATION, JUVENILE FISH USE, AND REDD SURVEYS INDICATE LITTLE CREEK IS QUICKLY RECOVERING FROM YEARS OF DEGRADATION AND IS HABITAT FOR STEELHEAD AND SALMON. WITH STREAMFLOW RESTORED, TU IS ADDRESSING A PRIMARY LIMITING FACTOR THAT IS CHANNEL AND SUBSTRATE CONDITION (LIMITING FACTORS 2001). LITTLE CREEK S HABITAT IS IN EFFECTIVELY IN TWO CONDITIONS: (1) HIGH QUALITY HABITAT IN THE HEADWATERS AND (2) DEGRADED HABITAT DOWNSTREAM OF THE KITTITAS RECLAMATION DISTRICT CANAL (LOWER REACHES). THIS PROJECT WILL IMPROVE PROVIDE A PROVING GROUND FOR LOW-TECH RESTORATION TECHNIQUES TO DEMONSTRATE THEIR SUCCESS TO AREA LANDOWNERS AND HELP RECRUIT ADDITIONAL LANDOWNERS THAT MAY BE ADDED TO THE GRANT AS RESOURCES ALLOW.

THE MALPAI BORDERLANDS WORKING AREA IS WIDELY RECOGNIZED FOR ITS BIOLOGICAL DIVERSITY, UNFRAGMENTED LANDSCAPES, AND WORKING RANCHES IN SOUTHWESTERN NEW MEXICO AND SOUTHEASTERN ARIZONA. HOWEVER, THESE ECOSYSTEMS FACE SIGNIFICANT THREATS DUE TO CLIMATE CHANGE, LAND USE CHANGES, AND INVASIVE SPECIES. THE SCOPE OF THE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE S PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM AND MALPAI BORDERLANDS GROUP IS TO ENHANCE HABITAT FOR FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES BY WORKING WITH PRIVATE LANDOWNERS IN SOUTHEAST ARIZONA. IN ADDITION, THIS AGREEMENT AIMS TO RESTORE AND IMPROVE THE BIODIVERSITY OF SOUTHEASTERN ARIZONA S ECOSYSTEMS THROUGH LANDOWNER AGREEMENTS. THE PROJECTS WILL FOCUS ON RESTORING DEGRADED HABITATS, CONSERVING THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES, AND CONTROLLING INVASIVE SPECIES ON PRIVATE LANDS IN ARIZONA. WE ANTICIPATE AT LEAST ONE LANDOWNER AGREEMENT WITH A PRIVATE LANDOWNER, TRIBE, CITY, OR COUNTY TO BE IMPLEMENTED UNDER THE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT TO ENHANCE WETLANDS, UPLANDS, AND RIPARIAN AREAS THROUGH VARIOUS TECHNIQUES. THE PRACTICES INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO REMOVING NATIVE AND NON-NATIVE TREES, INSTALLING EROSION CONTROL STRUCTURES, LIVESTOCK MANAGEMENT, INVASIVE SPECIES CONTROL, PRESCRIBED FIRE, WATER ACCESS AND MANAGEMENT STRUCTURES, AND OTHER PRACTICES.

ARIZONA LAND AND WATER TRUST (RECIPIENT) SEEKS  25,000 FROM THE PFW TO WORK WITH A PRIVATE LANDOWNER AND OR NON-PROFIT IN SOUTHERN ARIZONA (LANDOWNERS AND SUB-RECIPIENTS) TO ENHANCE HABITAT FOR FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES. THE ANTICIPATED PROJECT WILL BE THE ENHANCEMENT OF UPLAND AND PASTURELAND VIA FENCING AND GRAZING MANAGEMENT. THE LANDOWNERS, RECIPIENT, AND USFWS WILL SIGN A SUB-RECIPIENT LANDOWNER AGREEMENT TO IDENTIFY WORK TO IMPROVE HABITAT AND BENEFIT FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES. THE SUB-RECIPIENT LANDOWNER AGREEMENTS WILL INCLUDE PROJECT NARRATIVES AND BUDGETS. ARIZONA LAND AND WATER TRUST WILL OVERSEE THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE LANDOWNER AGREEMENT. THIS PROJECT WILL ENHANCE WETLANDS, UPLANDS, OR RIPARIAN AREAS THROUGH VARIOUS TECHNIQUES ON PRIVATE LAND. THE PRACTICES INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO FENCING, INSTALLING EROSION CONTROL STRUCTURES, REDUCING SHRUB DENSITIES, ESTABLISHING NATIVE VEGETATION, AND OTHER PRACTICES AS APPROPRIATE.

THE ICE AGE TRAIL ALLIANCE (IATA) AND THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM (PFW) SEE A GROWING DEMAND FOR PLANTING NATIVE PLANTS ON PRIVATE AND PUBLICLANDS. LAND STEWARDSHIP CONTINUES TO GROW IN WISCONSIN AS MORE AND MORE LANDOWNERS, NONGOVERNMENTAL CONSERVATION GROUPS AND LAND TRUSTS ARE INTERESTED TO IMPROVE THE QUALITY OF HABITAT FOR WILDLIFE ON THEIR LANDS. GIVEN THE DEMAND FOR THIS WORK, LIMITED SEED AVAILABILITY, AND HIGH COST FOR PURCHASING SEED, THE IATA AND PFW ARE INTERESTED IN COLLABORATING WITH THE PLANT CONSERVATION ALLIANCE (PCA) TO PROMOTE THE NATIONAL SEED STRATEGY FOR REHABILITATION AND RESTORATION BY DEVELOPING A NATIVE SEED NURSERY, CONTRIBUTING TOWARDS HEALTHY PLANT COMMUNITIES AND SUSTAINABLE ECOSYSTEMS. THIS PARTNERSHIP EFFORT IS IN LOCK STEP WITH EXECUTIVE ORDER 14008, THE COMMITMENT TO CONSERVE 30  OF AMERICAS LANDS AND WATERS BY 2030, THE 2021 U.S. DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR (DOI) INVASIVE SPECIES STRATEGIC PLAN (2021) AND ADDRESSES NATIONAL PRIORITIES SUCH AS CLIMATE CHANGE.IN WISCONSIN, THE PFW IN PARTNERSHIP WITH IATA ARE COLLABORATING TO INCREASE THE AVAILABILITY OF PRAIRIE AND OAK SAVANNA PLANT SPECIES FOR HABITAT RESTORATION EFFORTS IN SOUTHERN AND SOUTHCENTRAL WISCONSIN. OVER THE LAST FIVE YEARS, IATA AND PFW HAVE COMPLETED OVER (50) HABITATRESTORATION PROJECTS TO RESTORE, ENHANCE AND PROTECT PRAIRIE AND OAK SAVANNA HABITATS IN SOUTHERN AND SOUTHCENTRAL WISCONSIN, TWO OF THE MOST IMPERILED ECOSYSTEMS IN THE STATE. COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS HAVE LEVERAGED OVER ( 850,000) OF FEDERAL AND PRIVATE FUNDING TO RESTORE AND ENHANCE (500) ACRES OF PRAIRIE AND OAK SAVANNA HABITAT. THIS EFFORT HAS LED TO COLONIZATION OF NEW SITES FOR THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED KARNER BLUE BUTTERFLY AND RUSTY PATCHED BUBBLE BEE  INCREASED NECTAR SOURCES FOR MONARCHS AND OTHER POLLINATORS, IMPROVED GRASSLAND HABITAT FOR NUMEROUS IMPERILED GRASSLAND BIRDS TO INCLUDE HENSLOWS, VESPER AND GRASSHOPPER SPARROWS, BOBOLINKS AND MEADOWLARKS AND WORKING IN RURAL LANDSCAPES, STIMULATED RURAL ECONOMIES USING LOCAL VENDORS AND CONTRACTORS DO TO MOST OF THE RESTORATION WORK. CURRENTLY, BOTH ORGANIZATIONS COLLECT LOCAL ECOTYPE SEED FROM REMNANT PRAIRIES OR RESTORATION PROJECTS WHERE THE SEED ORIGIN IS KNOWN. FOR EXAMPLE, IN 2022, PFW AND VOLUNTEERS COLLECTED 52LBS OF LUPINE, HOST PLANT FOR THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED KARNER BLUE BUTTERFLY, AT A VALUE OF  45,000. COLLECTION WAS FROM ENDEMIC NATIVE ECOTYPE SEED AND IS USED TO SEED FUTURE KBB SITES. IN ADDITION, OTHER NECTAR FORBS WERE COLLECTED AS WELL. THESE EFFORTS COULD BE ACCELERATED WITH APPROPRIATE FUNDING AND INFRASTRUCTURE CAPABILITIES. IATA IS DEDICATED TO CONSERVING, CREATING MAINTAINING AND PROMOTING THE ICE AGE NATIONAL SCENIC TRAIL IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE. THE IATA OWNS AND MANAGES MANY PROPERTIES ALONG ITS CONNECTED THOUSAND MILES OF TRAIL. RECENTLY, THE IATA PURCHASED A PROPERTY FOR EXPANSION OF THE ICE AGE TRAIL WHICH HOSTS APPROXIMATELY 20 ACRES OF AGRICULTURAL LANDS THAT WILL BE CONVERTED TO PRAIRIE BEDS FOR SEED COLLECTING. IN ADDITION, THE PROPERTY HAS A 50 X110-FOOT POLE BARN, IDEAL FOR SETTING UP A SEED CLEANING FACILITY. THIS EFFORT FITS INTO THE OBJECTIVES OF THE NATIONAL SEED STRATEGY, SUCCESS IS BEING ACHIEVED THROUGH THE ESTABLISHMENT OF NATIONWIDE NETWORKS OF BOTANISTS, SEED COLLECTORS, RESEARCHERS TO DEVELOP SEED  FARMERS TO GROW NATIVE SEED  NURSERIES AND SEED STORAGE FACILITIES TO SUPPLY ADEQUATE QUANTITIES OF APPROPRIATE SEED  AND RESTORATION ECOLOGISTS TO STUDY AND IMPLEMENT RESTORATION TECHNIQUES, NATIONAL SEED STRATEGY PROGRESS REPORT, 2015-2020.

THE HIGHLAND DITCH IRRIGATION AND FISH PROTECTION PROJECT IS ADDRESSING THE PROTECTION OF FEDERALLY PROTECTED OREGON COASTAL COHO SALMON.  THE SOUTH UMPQUA RURAL COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIP (501(C)3) IS PARTNERING WITH 11 STAKEHOLDER WATER USERS OF THE HIGHLAND DITCH TO IMPROVE IRRIGATION EFFICIENCY, WATER QUALITY, AND FISH PASSAGE SAFETY ON THE MAIN STEM OF CLEAR CREEK BELOW GALESVILLE RESERVOIR NEAR AZALEA IN DOUGLAS COUNTY. AS A RESULT OF AN OWEB OUTREACH GRANT STAKEHOLDERS HAVE FORMED THE HIGHLAND DITCH IRRIGATION DISTRICT. THE STAKEHOLDERS HAVE RESOLVED TO CORRECT AN EGREGIOUS AND CHRONIC CONDITION OF WATER MISMANAGEMENT , THREATS TO ESA LISTED OREGON COASTAL COHO SALMON AND OTHER SPECIES OF CONCERN LOCATED IN THE SOUTH UMPQUA BASIN. THE SENIOR 1911 WATER RIGHT IS DISTRIBUTED VIA A 3.2 MILE OPEN DITCH THAT IS SUBJECT TO EVAPORATION, TRANSPIRATION, INEFFICIENT WATER DISTRIBUTION, POLLUTION FROM LIVESTOCK AND FREQUENT DITCH CONTAINMENT FAILURES. THE CLEAR CREEK STREAM REACHES ON EACH SIDE OF THE DITCH S DIVERSION DAM ARE PRIME SPAWNING HABITAT FOR COHO, STEELHEAD, AND OTHER SPECIES OF CONCERN. THE GALESVILLE RESERVOIR IS A CRITICAL SOURCE OF UMPQUA BASIN WATER URBAN AND AGRICULTURAL WATER SUPPLIES. THE HIGHLAND DITCH IRRIGATION AND FISH PROTECTION PROJECT HAS SECURED PROFESSIONAL ENGINEERING SERVICES TO DEVELOP AN INNOVATIVE ALTERNATIVES AND PRELIMINARY DESIGN OPTION INTENDED TO ELIMINATE ADVERSE IMPACTS ON WATER QUANTITY, QUALITY AND THREATS TO OREGON COASTAL COHO (ESA LISTED SPECIES), STEELHEAD, PACIFIC LAMPREY, THE UMPQUA CHUB ETC.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO BUILD A FUNDING PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN DU AND THE SERVICE TO FACILITATE COOPERATION ON VARIOUS MUTUALLY ACCEPTABLE CONSERVATION EFFORTS ON PRIVATE LANDS THROUGHOUT IMPORTANT PFW CONSERVATION FOCUS AREA LOCATED IN NEBRASKA. THESE COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS WILL BENEFIT NUMEROUS FEDERAL TRUST FISH AND WILDLIFE SPECIES. THE OVERALL GOAL IS TO: (A) RESTORE, ENHANCE, MANAGE, MONITOR, AND EVALUATE HABITAT AND (B) CONTRIBUTE TOWARDS POPULATION AND HABITAT OBJECTIVES FOR FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES AND OTHER FEDERAL TRUST RESOURCES. THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO WORK COOPERATIVELY WITH THE SERVICE AND OTHER PARTNERS TO PROVIDE FINANCIAL SUPPORT FOR MIGRATORY BIRD HABITAT CONSERVATION INCLUDING: A) PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE IN PLANNING, DESIGNING, AND IMPLEMENTING RIVERINE, WETLAND AND UPLAND HABITAT PROJECTS  B) PROVIDING DIRTWORK FUNDS FOR MUTUALLY AGREED UPON PROJECTS  AND C) PROVIDING FINANCIAL SUPPORT FOR BIOLOGICAL PLANNING, CENSUSING, AND MONITORING ACTIVITIES TO ASSIST IN THE EVALUATION OF THE EFFECTIVENESS OF RESTORATION AND MANAGEMENT PRACTICES EMPLOYED TO IMPROVE FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES HABITAT. THIS PROJECT WILL RESTORE AND ENHANCE NATIVE RIVERINE, WETLAND AND GRASSLAND HABITATS FOR THE BENEFIT OF: (A) FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES (I.E., WHOOPING CRANES, LEAST TERNS, PIPING PLOVERS, AND WESTERN PRAIRIE FRINGED ORCHIDS)  (B) GRASSLAND NESTING BIRDS  (C) POLLINATOR AND OTHER INSECTS (E.G., MONARCH AND REGAL FRITILLARY BUTTERFLIES AND NATIVE BEES)  (D) MIGRATORY WATERBIRDS (E.G., SHOREBIRDS, WATERFOWL, WADING BIRDS, ETC.)  AND (E) NUMEROUS OTHER FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES. RESTORATION OF HABITATS THROUGHOUT HIGH PRIORITY CONSERVATION FOCUS AREAS WILL CONTRIBUTE TOWARDS MEETING POPULATION AND HABITAT OBJECTIVES IDENTIFIED IN THE SERVICE S 2022-2027 MOUNTAIN-PRAIRIE STRATEGIC PLAN FOR THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM, RWBJV IMPLEMENTATION PLAN, NEBRASKA NATURAL LEGACY PLAN (NEBRASKA S STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN), AND IS CONSISTENT WITH AND WILL CONTRIBUTE TOWARD THE MISSION OF DU.

PROJECT OBJECTIVE: TO REMOVE TAKELMA DAM, AND CONSTRUCT A NEW FISH-FRIENDLY WATER DIVERSION AT THE SAME SITE INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO REFURBISHMENT OF THE LEAKY AND INEFFICIENT WATER DELIVERY PIPE ON PRIVATE PROPERTY LEADING AWAY FROM THE DAM SITE AS WELL AS THE REMOVAL OF A COUNTY ROAD CULVERT ON TAKELMA CREEK AND REPLACEMENT WITH A FISH-FRIENDLY ALTERNATIVE, REMOVAL OF AN UPSTREAM LOGGING ROAD CULVERT ON A TAKELMA CREEK TRIBUTARY, AND STREAM RESTORATION WITHIN THE PROJECT FOOTPRINT.THE PROJECT LOCATION IS DUE WEST OF SELMA IN JOSEPHINE COUNTY ON TAKELMA CREEK ON BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT LAND, AND COUNTY RIGHT OF WAY. TAKELMA DAM IS AN APPROXIMATELY 10 FOOT TALL SINGLE STREAM-SPANNING CONCRETE STRUCTURE ON BLM LAND WITHOUT ANY FISH PASSAGE, THAT BLOCKS ACCESS TO 3.5 MILES OF UPSTREAM HABITAT.

THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS TO FORM A FIVE-YEAR PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) AND PHEASANTS FOREVER TO FACILITATE VOLUNTARY HABITAT CONSERVATION WORK ON PRIVATE AND TRIBAL LAND THAT IS MUTUALLY BENEFICIAL TO THE USFWS AND PHEASANTS FOREVER. THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM WILL BE THE USFWS LEAD FOR DELIVERING ALL FACETS OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT. AN EMPHASIS WILL BE PLACED ON RESTORING, CREATING AND ENHANCING WETLAND, GRASSLAND AND RIPARIAN HABITATS THAT ARE VITAL TO A WIDE VARIETY OF BIRD POPULATIONS. SPECIFIC CONSERVATION PRACTICES TO BE JOINTLY IMPLEMENTED BY THE USFWS AND PHEASANTS FOREVER INCLUDE WETLAND CREATIONS, WETLAND ENHANCEMENTS, WETLAND RESTORATIONS, NATIVE GRASS SEEDINGS, MANAGED GRAZING SYSTEMS, ALTERNATIVE WATERING SYSTEMS FOR LIVESTOCK GRAZING PLANS, AND RIPARIAN ENHANCEMENTS. THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE IS TO IMPLEMENT PROJECTS IN THE PRAIRIE POTHOLE REGION (PPR) PORTION OF SOUTH DAKOTA, HOWEVER FUNDS CAN ALSO BE USED TO COMPLETE ELIGIBLE HABITAT CONSERVATION PROJECTS IN THE PPR PORTIONS OF NORTH DAKOTA AND MONTANA AS NEEDED TO MEET PPR-WIDE CONSERVATION OBJECTIVES. BIRD SPECIES TO BE BEFITTED VIA THESE CONSERVATION ACTIONS INCLUDE MALLARDS, NORTHERN PINTAILS, RING-NECKED PHEASANTS, GREATER PRAIRIE CHICKEN, SHARP-TAILED GROUSE, GRASSHOPPERS SPARROWS, WESTERN MEADOWLARKS, AND UPLAND SANDPIPERS. ADDITIONAL NATURAL RESOURCE BENEFITS WILL BE PROVIDED IN THE FORM OF IMPROVED GRASSLAND CONDITION AND ENHANCED WATER QUALITY. DURING THE FULL PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IT IS PROJECTED THAT 30 INDIVIDUAL HABITAT PROJECTS WILL BE COMPLETED.

THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM WILL BE THE USFWS LEAD FOR DELIVERING ALL FACETS OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT. AN EMPHASIS WILL BE PLACED ON RESTORING, CREATING AND ENHANCING WETLAND, GRASSLAND AND RIPARIAN HABITATS THAT ARE VITAL TO A WIDE VARIETY OF BIRD POPULATIONS. SPECIFIC CONSERVATION PRACTICES TO BE JOINTLY IMPLEMENTED BY THE USFWS AND PHEASANTS FOREVER INCLUDE WETLAND CREATIONS, WETLAND ENHANCEMENTS, WETLAND RESTORATIONS, NATIVE GRASS SEEDINGS, MANAGED GRAZING SYSTEMS, ALTERNATIVE WATERING SYSTEMS FOR LIVESTOCK GRAZING PLANS, AND RIPARIAN ENHANCEMENTS. BIRD SPECIES TO BE BEFITTED VIA THESE CONSERVATION ACTIONS INCLUDE MALLARDS, NORTHERN PINTAILS, RING-NECKED PHEASANTS, GREATER PRAIRIE CHICKEN, SHARP-TAILED GROUSE, GRASSHOPPERS SPARROWS, WESTERN MEADOWLARKS, AND UPLAND SANDPIPERS. ADDITIONAL NATURAL RESOURCE BENEFITS WILL BE PROVIDED IN THE FORM OF IMPROVED GRASSLAND CONDITION AND ENHANCED WATER QUALITY.
