PHEASANTS FOREVER, (HEREINAFTER REFERRED TO AS THE RECIPIENT) AND THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (HEREINAFTER REFERRED TO AS THE SERVICE) ARE INTERESTED IN MANAGEMENT AND RESTORATION PRACTICES THAT PROTECT, RESTORE, AND ENHANCE NATIVE GRASSLAND HABITAT THROUGHOUT THE STATE OF KANSAS FOR FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES (I.E., GRASSLAND NESTING BIRDS, MIGRATORY BIRDS, AND FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES).  THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO BUILD A FUNDING PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE SERVICE AND THE RECIPIENT.  THIS PARTNERSHIP WILL FACILITATE COOPERATION BETWEEN THE SERVICE AND THE RECIPIENT ON VARIOUS HABITAT RESTORATION AND MANAGEMENT PROJECTS THROUGHOUT THE STATE OF KANSAS.  THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO WORK COOPERATIVELY WITH PRIVATE LANDOWNERS TO RESTORE, ENHANCE, ESTABLISH, AND MANAGE NATIVE HABITAT TO BENEFIT WILDLIFE SPECIES INCLUDING, GRASSLAND NESTING BIRDS (E.G., UPLAND SANDPIPER, LESSER PRAIRIE CHICKEN, GREATER PRAIRIE CHICKEN, HENSLOWS SPARROW, DICKCISSELS, AND BOBOLINKS), REPTILES (E.G.,TEXAS HORNED LIZARD), INSECTS (E.G., AMERICAN BURYING BEETLES, REGAL FRITILLARY BUTTERFLIES), PLANTS (E.G.,WESTERN PRAIRIE FRINGED ORCHIDS), AND OTHER NATIVE SPECIES FOUND THROUGHOUT THE STATE.  THE PROJECT INVOLVES RESTORING NATIVE PLANT COMMUNITIES AND ENHANCING THE ECOLOGICAL FUNCTIONS AND VALUES OF WILDLIFE HABITAT BY: (A) REMOVING INVASIVE WOODY SPECIES  (B) FACILITATING LANDSCAPE SCALE INCREASES IN HETEROGENEITY BY IMPLEMENTING PRESCRIBED MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES  (C) IMPROVING HABITAT CONDITIONS ON LARGE TRACTS OF INTACT GRASSLAND BY REDUCING FRAGMENTATION  (D) CONDUCTING FACILITATING OUTREACH AND EDUCATION CONCERNING HABITAT RESTORATION, AND (E) DEMONSTRATING SUSTAINABLE MANAGEMENT OF UPLANDS, WETLANDS, RIPARIAN AREAS AND STREAMS THROUGHOUT THE STATE OF KANSAS.

THE GRASSLAND LANDSCAPE OF MONTANA S  HI LINE  IS AMONG THE MOST INTACT IN THE UNITED STATES AND IS IDENTIFIED AS A PRIORITY AREA FOR CONSERVATION ACROSS MULTIPLE AGENCY AND CONSERVATION PARTNERS. THE REGION IS IMPORTANT FOR MANY SPECIES INCLUDING MIGRATORY WATERFOWL AND PRIORITY GRASSLAND SONGBIRDS, THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE HOLDS THOUSANDS OF ACRES IN PERPETUAL WETLAND-GRASSLAND EASEMENTS IN THIS REGION, WITHIN THE NORTHERN GREAT PLAINS REFUGE COMPLEX. MANY OF THESE EASEMENT PROPERTIES HAVE ADDITIONAL, UNMET HABITAT RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT NEEDS. THIS FUNDING WILL ADDRESS A PORTION OF THOSE NEEDS BY DELIVERING RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT ACTIVITIES ON USFWS WETLAND-GRASSLAND EASEMENT PROPERTIES.THIS RESTORATION WORK WILL TAKE PLACE ON EASEMENTPROPERTIES IN PRIVATE OWNERSHIP

THE WATTS TOPPIN FISH PASSAGE PROJECT ADDRESSES THE NEED FOR FISH PASSAGE IMPROVEMENT AT THE WATTS TOPPIN IRRIGATION DAM LOCATED AT RM 2.1 ON WILLIAMS CREEK - A LARGE TRIBUTARY TO THE APPLEGATE RIVER NEAR PROVOLT, OREGON. WILLIAMS CREEK AND TRIBUTARIES ARE AMONG THE MOST IMPORTANT PRODUCERS OF SALMON AND STEELHEAD IN THE APPLEGATE WATERSHED. WATTS TOPPIN DAM IS LISTED ON THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (ODFW) STATEWIDE FISH PASSAGE PRIORITY LIST AS THE 4TH HIGHEST PRIORITY IN THE APPLEGATE WATERSHED. THE 3 HIGHER PRIORITIES ARE CURRENTLY IN VARYING STAGES OF PLANNING AND OR DESIGN FOR REMOVAL OR RETROFIT BY APWC AND OR OTHER ENTITIES. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL IMPROVE FISH PASSAGE CONDITIONS AT WATTS TOPPIN DAM THROUGH CONSTRUCTION OF A ROUGHENED CHANNEL. THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT ESA-LISTED COHO SALMON, CHINOOK SALMON, STEELHEAD TROUT (SUMMER AND WINTER RUNS), COASTAL CUTTHROAT TROUT, AND PACIFIC LAMPREY. THE PROPOSED PROJECT SEEKS TO BUILD UPON THE RECENTLY COMPLETED LOWER BRIDGEPOINT FISH PASSAGE PROJECT, LOCATED ON BLM LAND APPROXIMATELY 1 MILE DOWNSTREAM OF WATTS TOPPIN DAM. THE SUCCESSFULLY COMPLETED PROJECT AT LOWER BRIDGEPOINT DIVERSION WAS SIMILAR IN SCALE AND DESIGN TO THE PROPOSED PROJECT AT WATTS TOPPIN. TOGETHER, THESE PROJECTS WILL SUBSTANTIALLY IMPROVE ACCESS TO VALUABLE UPSTREAM SPAWNING AND REARING HABITATS. THE PREFERRED ALTERNATIVE, A ROUGHENED CHANNEL, HAS BEEN VETTED AND DESIGNS COMPLETED BY THE CONSULTING ENGINEERING FIRM. CONSTRUCTION IS SET TO BEGIN IN SUMMER 2023. PROJECT PARTNERS INCLUDE WATER USERS, ROGUE BASIN PARTNERSHIP, BLM, PAUL ALLEN FAMILY FOUNDATION THROUGH AMERICAN RIVERS, OWRD, WILLIAMS CR WC, TROUT UNLIMITED, AND MIDDLE ROGUE STEELHEADERS.

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO CONSTRUCT A SERIES OF FOUR BEAVER DAM ANALOGS (BDA) ALONG A 450 FOOT REACH OF COTTONWOOD CREEK THAT LACKS IN-STREAM STRUCTURAL COMPLEXITY AND IS MODERATELY INCISED. THE BDAS WILL IMPROVE SALMONID HABITAT BY CREATING SLOW WATER REARING HABITAT AND ESTABLISHING A MORE OPTIMAL POOL-RIFFLE SEQUENCE.  BY SLOWING FLOWS AND DETAINING WATER, THE BDAS WILL ALSO IMPROVE FLOODPLAIN CONNECTIVITY AND RECHARGE GROUNDWATER, WHICH IN TURN RESTORES THE HEALTH AND VIGOR OF RIPARIAN VEGETATION. THE PROJECT IS ALSO INTENDED TO PROVIDE A FOUNDATION FOR BEAVERS TO BUILD OR MAINTAIN DAMS THAT LAST LONG ENOUGH TO ESTABLISH STABLE COLONIES.  THE BDAS WILL BE CONSTRUCTED BY DRIVING TEN FOOT LONG AND SIX TO SEVEN INCH DIAMETER DOUGLAS FIR POSTS FOUR TO SIX FEET INTO THE CREEK BED AND BANK. THE BDAS WILL BE APPROXIMATELY 20 FEET IN LENGTH WITH EACH BDA CONTAINING BETWEEN 14 AND 15 POSTS.  AFTER THE POSTS HAVE BEEN INSTALLED, WILLOW CUTTINGS WILL BE WOVEN BETWEEN THE VERTICAL POSTS.  WEED FREE STRAW WILL THEN BE STUFFED INTO THE WEAVE TO REDUCE POROSITY IN THE BDAS.  LASTLY, COBBLE AND CLAY WILL BE PLACED AT THE BASE OF THE BDAS FOR SCOUR PROTECTION.

THE YUROK TRIBAL FISHERIES DEPARTMENT  LOWER KLAMATH PROGRAM WILL COLLABORATE WITH FIORI GEOSCIENCES AND THE ARCATA PARTNERS FOR FISH   WILDLIFE PROGRAM TO ENHANCE STREAM AND FLOODPLAIN HABITATS IN MCGARVEY CREEK BY 1) INSTALLING CONSTRUCTED WOOD JAMS AND OTHER WOOD-BASED STRUCTURES  2) RECONFIGURING HABITATS TO REDUCE ROAD RELATED IMPACTS AND INCREASE FLOODPLAIN CONNECTIVITY AND ECOLOGICAL FUNCTION  3) ENHANCE AND CONNECT EXISTING OFF-CHANNEL WETLANDS  AND 4) PLANTING NATIVE VEGETATION. THIS PROJECT IS PART OF A COMPREHENSIVE EFFORT TO RESTORE HABITATS WITHIN THIS LOW GRADIENT COASTAL STREAM IN SUPPORT OF NATIVE FISH RECOVERY.PROJECT GOALS INCLUDE INCREASING FLOODPLAIN CONNECTIVITY, HABITAT COMPLEXITY, AND CLIMATE RESILIENCY TO PROVIDE IMMEDIATE AND SELF-MAINTAINING BENEFITS FOR COHO SALMON, CHINOOK, STEELHEAD, COASTAL CUTTHROAT TROUT, AND OTHER NATIVE FISH AND WILDLIFE. ADDITIONALLY, THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE THE OPPORTUNITY TO GAIN AND SHARE VITAL INFORMATION REGARDING THE EFFECTIVENESS OF FLOODPLAIN ENHANCEMENT EFFORTS AND APPLY LESSONS LEARNED TO FUTURE RESTORATION EFFORTS TO HELP ENSURE THAT BEST AVAILABLE SCIENCE IS GUIDING WATERSHED RECOVERY.PROJECT OBJECTIVES INCLUDE ENHANCING 0.8 MILES AND 0.3 ACRES OF STREAM AND FLOODPLAIN HABITAT IN MCGARVEY CREEK TO: 1) RECONFIGURE IMPAIRED HABITATS TO INCREASE FLOODPLAIN CONNECTIVITY AND CHANNEL DIVERSITY COMPLEXITY, 2) ADD THE NECESSARY STRUCTURAL ELEMENTS (E.G. WOOD ACCUMULATIONS, BEAVER DAM ANALOGUES) TO PROMOTE BENEFICIAL SELF-MAINTAINING PHYSICAL AND ECOLOGICAL PROCESSES, 3) IMPROVE REARING CONDITIONS IN MCGARVEY CREEK BY INCREASING THE AMOUNT OF SLOW VELOCITY REFUGE AREAS, AND 4) INCREASE REARING HABITAT RESILIENCY TO ENVIRONMENTAL PERTURBATIONS SUCH AS SEASONAL AND OR  PRO-LONGED DROUGHT AND POTENTIAL FUTURE CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACTS. PERFORMANCE ASSESSMENTS AND OUTREACH CONDUCTED AS PART OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE ESSENTIAL CONTRIBUTIONS TO ONGOING COHO ECOLOGY STUDIES AND SPECIES RECOVERY ACTIONS CONDUCTED THROUGHOUT THE KLAMATH BASIN.

THESE EFFORTS WILL ENHANCE AND RESTORE AN INITIAL 4 ACRES OF ROCKLAND HAMMOCK THAT WAS RECENTLY IDENTIFIED AS HOLDING THE SECOND LARGEST FLORIDA BRISTLE FERN POPULATION IN MIAMI-DADE COUNTY. IN PARTNERSHIP WITH FAIRCHILD TROPICAL BOTANIC GARDEN, ADDITIONAL LANDS AND PRIVATE LANDOWNERS HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED FOR RESTORATION EFFORTS. RESTORATION EFFORTS WILL INCLUDE THE REMOVAL OF INVASIVE SPECIES (I.E., SYNGONIUM PODOPHYLLUM, SCHEFFLERA ACTINOPHYLLA, ALSTONIA MACROPHYLLA) THROUGH HAND REMOVAL, MECHANICAL AND HERBICIDE TREATMENTS.

THIS PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM (PEW) PROJECT FOCUS ON THE IMPLEMENTATION OF AQUATIC HABITAT RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT ON WORKING LANDS IN TENNESSEE. THE GOAL OF THIS MULTI-YEAR PROJECT IS TO COMPLETE HABITAT RESTORATION ENHANCEMENT PROJECTS WITHIN THE CUMBERLAND PLATEAU FOCAL AREA OF THE PFW PROGRAM, AS DEPICTED IN THE 2022-2026 TN PFW STRATEGIC PLAN. THE PROJECTS WILL TARGET ONE OR MORE OF THE FOLLOWING SPECIES: LAUREL DACE, FLUTED KIDNEYSHELL, CUMBERLAND MOCCASINSHELL, SLABSIDE PEARLYMUSSEL, BLUEMASK DARTER, SPOTFIN CHUB, PURPLE BEAN, ANTHONY S RIVERSNAIL, AND OR SICKLE DARTER.THIS AWARD WILL ALLOW THE PFW PROGRAM TO RESTORE AND ENHANCE AQUATIC HABITAT CONDITIONS FORFOCAL SPECIES ON WORKING LANDS BY REDUCING NUTRIENT AND SEDIMENT INPUT, STABILIZING SUBSTRATES, AND CONNECTINGISOLATED HABITATS. PFW STAFF WILL WORK WITH NRCS, SOIL CONSERVATION DISTRICT, AND TENNESSEE DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE STAFF TO SELECT, DESIGN, AND DELIVER MULTIPLE PROJECTS THAT MEET THE NEEDS OF LANDOWNERS, REDUCE NON-POINT SOURCE POLLUTION, AND RESTORE FLUVIAL GEOMORPHIC FUNCTIONS THAT CREATE AND SUSTAIN IN-STREAM AND RIPARIAN HABITAT FEATURES, INCORPORATING THE FOLLOWING PRACTICES: INSTALLING LIVESTOCK EXCLUSION FENCING ALONG STREAMS AND RIPARIAN HABITATS, PROVIDING ALTERNATIVE WATER SOURCES, PLANTING RIPARIAN FOREST BUFFERS AND ENHANCING EXISTING BUFFERS, RESTORING STREAMBANKS AND INSTREAM HABITAT, AND REFORESTING ERODIBLE UPLAND HABITATS OR INSTALLING SOIL EROSION BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES IN UPLAND FIELDS THAT CONTRIBUTE TO SEDIMENT DEPOSITION IN HEADWATER STREAMS.

REED CANARY GRASS IS ALTERING THE STREAM HYDROLOGY AND AGGRESSIVE MANAGEMENT OF THIS INVASIVE GRASS NEEDS TO BE IMPLEMENTED TO IMPROVE WATER QUALITY AND QUANTITY IN THIS SEMI-ARID REGION. REED CANARY GRASS IS PROLIFIC ALONG INDIAN FORD CREEK AND SPECIFICALLY AT THE HEADWATERS OF THE STREAM AT BLACK BUTTE RANCH. SEEDS AND VEGETATIVE FRAGMENTS OF REED CANARY GRASS FLOAT, WHICH MAKES STREAMS EFFECTIVE DISPERSAL CORRIDORS. SEED GERMINATION PEAKS IN MARCH-MAY AND AGAIN IN JUNE-JULY AND GENERALLY ONLY NEED A SINGLE GROWING SEASON TO BECOME ESTABLISHED. RCG TOWERS OVER OTHER NATIVE SPECIES, UTILIZING ALL AVAILABLE SPACE AND LIGHT.TO BEGIN THE AGGRESSIVE MANAGEMENT OF REED CANARY GRASS IN THE INDIAN FORD WATERSHED, EFFORTS MUST START AT THE SOURCE TO DECREASE THE AMOUNT OF SEED DISPERSAL AND ESTABLISHMENT DOWNSTREAM. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PERFORM A VARIETY OF BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES OVER A 3-YEAR TIME FRAME TO REDUCE AND MANAGE REED CANARY GRASS POPULATIONS AT BLACK BUTTE RANCH. THIS WILL BEGIN THE LONG-TERM WATERSHED SCALE MANAGEMENT OF REED CANARY GRASS WITHIN INDIAN FORD WATERSHED. PRACTICES WILL BE PERFORMED IN BOTH THE FALL AND SPRING SEASONS FOR THE 3-YEAR TIME FRAME AND INCLUDE: HERBICIDE TREATMENT, GRAZING, EXCAVATION, MOWING, SEEDING, AND TREE SHRUB PLANTING. BELOW ARE MAPS OF THE PAST SURVEYED OF REED CANARY GRASS THAT WILL BE RECEIVING TREATMENT OVER A 3-YEAR TIME.

THIS PROJECT IS LOCATED ONE MILE NORTH OF POST, OREGON, IN THE LOWER HORSE HEAVEN CREEK HUC 6 WATERSHED. THIS PROJECT CONSIDERS A 2.5-MILE STREAM REACH OF HORSE HEAVEN CREEK, SITUATED BELOW HORSE HEAVEN RESERVOIR TRAVELING DOWNSTREAM PAST THE HWY 380 ROAD CULVERT AND ULTIMATELY INTO THE MOUTH OF THE CROOKED RIVER. THIS STREAM REACH IS NEARLY VOID OF WOODY VEGETATION ALONG THE RIPARIAN CORRIDOR AND THE STREAM CHANNEL IS BECOMING DISCONNECTED FROM THE FLOODPLAIN. APPROXIMATELY 70  OF THE 2.5 MILES OF THIS STEAM REACH HAS BEEN HISTORICALLY GRAZED BY CATTLE, DRAMATICALLY DEPLETING NATIVE RIPARIAN VEGETATION THAT SUPPORTS BOTH FISH AND WILDLIFE, CAUSING UNNATURAL EROSION, AND UNATURALLY ACCELERATING STREAM FLOWS. FURTHER, WATER RELEASES FROM THE RESERVOIR HAVE BEEN TIMED WITH IRRIGATION NEEDS BETWEEN MAY AND SEPTEMBER, WITH THE STREAM SERVING LARGELY AS A WATER TRANSPORT MECHANISM TO FEED TWO POINTS OF DIVERSION (PODS). THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE TO REACTIVE THE FLOODPLAIN BY INSTALLING BEAVER DAM ANALOGUES (BDAS) IN AREAS THAT WILL SLOW THE WATER DOWN, COLLECT SEDIMENT AND PUSH THE WATER LATERALLY ONTO THE FLOODPLAINS.

FINGER LAKES LAND TRUST (FLLT) WILL WORK WITH PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE STAFF AT THE NEW YORK FIELD OFFICE (NYFO) TO IMPLEMENT WETLAND AND UPLAND RESTORATION PROJECTS IN THE FINGER LAKES REGION IN UPSTATE NEW YORK. FLLT WILL PROVIDE INTERIM REPORTS THAT DESCRIBE HABITAT RESTORATION ACTIVITIES.THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF RESTORATION IS THE PRESERVATION OF ECOLOGICAL FUNCTION THROUGH ON-THE-GROUND WORK TO ESTABLISH GRASSLAND HABITAT, MANAGE EARLY SUCCESSIONAL HABITAT AND RESTORE WETLAND HABITAT. TWO OBJECTIVES ARE ADDRESSED IN THIS RESTORATION PLAN: TO RESTORE HABITATS FOR MIGRATORY BIRDS, INSECT POLLINATORS, LISTED AND AT-RISK SPECIES, TO INCREASE BIODIVERSITY  AND, TO IMPROVE THE WATER QUALITY IN NYFO PRIORITY AREAS.

COLLINS STREAM RESTORATION   DAYLIGHTING PROJECT:THE COLLINS STREAM RESTORATION   DAYLIGHTING PROJECT PROPOSES TO DAYLIGHT AND RESTORE 700 FEET AND RESTORE AN ADDITIONAL 300 FEET, FOR A TOTAL OF 1100 LINEAR FEET OF THE MAIN BRANCH OF AN UNMANNED TRIBUTARY TO THE CANE RIVER. THIS PROJECT WILL RESTORE THE HYDROLOGICAL FUNCTION OF FLOODPLAINS AND NATURAL WETLANDS COMPLEX ADJACENT TO THE STREAM. AFTER DAYLIGHTING THE STREAM, BLUE RIDGE RC D PROPOSES TO PLANT NATIVE WOODY VEGETATION AND ESTABLISH A VEGETATIVE BUFFER THAT WILL SECURE THE RIPARIAN SOIL, SHADE THE RIVER, AND FILTER OVERLAND RUNOFF. THE PROJECT IS LOCATED WITHIN 220 FEET OF THE CANE RIVER. THIS AREA IS CRITICAL HABITAT FOR THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED APPALACHIAN ELKTOE (ALASMIDONTA RAVENELIANA) MUSSEL. VALLE CRUCIS WATAUGA RIVER ACCESS PROJECT:THIS PROJECT PROPOSES STREAM RESTORATION AND FUNCTIONAL UPLIFT FOR 1,196 LINEAR FEET ALONG THE WATAUGA RIVER.  NATURAL CHANNEL DESIGN TECHNIQUES TO RESTORE CHANNEL DIMENSION AND ADJACENT FLOODPLAIN AREAS AND ACCESS. STRUCTURAL COMPONENTS WILL INCLUDE J-HOOK BOULDER STRUCTURES TO PROMOTE VERTICAL AND LATERAL STABILITY IN THE RIVER REACHS MEANDER. SLOPING AND BENCHING IS ALSO PROPOSED ALONG THE 1,196 LINEAR FEET PROJECT STREAM REACH. FLOODPLAIN FOREST RESTORATION IS PROPOSED FOR 5.36 ACRES AT THE PROJECT SITE. PLANS ARE TO PROVIDE A PUBLIC RIVER ACCESS AND ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION INFORMATION.SHADE YOUR STREAM (SYS) IS AN EDUCATIONAL PROGRAM THAT PROMOTES THE IMPORTANCE OF STREAM SIDE VEGETATION TO PROTECT WATER QUALITY, LAND QUALITY, AND AQUATIC HABITAT. BLUE RIDGE RC D WILL HOST SHADE YOUR STREAM BACKYARD STREAM REPAIR WORKSHOPS FOR PRIVATE LANDOWNERS IN WESTERN NORTH CAROLINA IN 2023-2026 TO LEARN HOW TO PROTECT RIPARIAN BUFFERS BY PLANTING NATIVE SPECIES VEGETATION.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO RESTORE INSTREAM AND RIPARIAN HABITATS IN A REACH OF THE SCOTT RIVER THAT HAS BEEN HIGHLY DEGRADED. THE PROJECT OCCURS IN THE TAILINGS REACH ON THE SCOTT RIVER SOUTH OF ETNA, CA. THE TAILINGS REACH WAS DREDGE MINED IN THE EARLY 1900S. THIS ACTIVITY GREATLY REDUCED CHANNEL COMPLEXITY AND FLOODPLAIN CONNECTIVITY, AND ALL BUT ELIMINATED EXISTING RIPARIAN HABITAT. TO ADDRESS THESE ISSUES THIS PROJECT PROPOSED TO CONSTRUCT A SERIES OF ENGINEERED LOG JAMS AND PLANT NATIVE WILLOW AND COTTONWOOD ALONG THE RIVER MARGINS. SPECIFICALLY, 15 LARGE LOG STRUCTURES, CONSISTING OF 14 TO 18 LOGS, WILL BE CONSTRUCTED INSTREAM TO CREAT SCOUR POOLS, SORT GRAVELS, AND RETAIN FINE SEDIMENT THROUGHOUT AN APPROXIMATELY 1,200 FOOT REACH OF THE SCOTT RIVER. ON THE RIVER LEFT BANK AND ON THE RIVER RIGHT GRAVEL BARS, A SERIES OF EIGHT SMALL LOG STRUCTURES CONSISTING OF EIGHT TO TEN LOGS WILL BE CONSTRUCTED TO RETAIN FINE SEDIMENT. WILLOWS WILL BE PLANTED DOWNSTREAM OF THE SMALLER STRUCTURES IN THE SEDIMENT RETENTION ZONES AND WITHIN THE INSTREAM LARGE LOG STRUCTURES. TWO LARGER AREAS TOTALING APPROXIMATELY 0.5 ACRES ON THE RIVER RIGHT FLOODPLAIN WILL ALSO BE PLANTED WITH WILLOWS AND COTTONWOODS. PLANTINGS WILL BE WATERED IN LATE SUMMER FOR UP TO FOUR YEARS POST PLANTING TO INCREASE SURVIVAL. THIS PROJECT WILL OCCUR IMMEDIATELY DOWNSTREAM AND IS A CONTINUATION OF FOUR PREVIOUSLY COMPLETED RESTORATION PROJECTS IN THE TAILINGS REACH DESIGNED TO IMPROVE MIGRATORY HABITAT FOR COHO SALMON, INCREASE SPAWNING HABITAT FOR CHINOOK SALMON, AND PROMOTE THE DEVELOPMENT OF A HEALTHY AND FUNCTIONING RIPARIAN CORRIDOR.

PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE REMOVING AND DISPOSING OF OLD BARBED WIRE FENCE THAT IS A HAZARD TO WILDLIFE AND LIVESTOCK. IT ALSOINCLUDES ENHANCEMENT OF WET MEADOWS THROUGH IMPLEMENTATION OF LIVESTOCK MANAGEMENT CONSERVATION PRACTICES.  THE PROPERTY IS OVER 800 ACRES, AND THIS PROJECT WILL DIRECTLY BENEFIT MULTIPLE ECOLOGICAL SITES FOUND ON THE PROPERTY INCLUDING APPROXIMATELY 400 ACRES OF WET MEADOWS. MULTIPLE SAGEBRUSH-OBLIGATE SPECIES WILL BENEFIT FROM THIS PROJECT INCLUDING BI-STATE SAGE-GROUSE, IDENTIFIED IN THE SAGE STRATEGIC HABITAT CONSERVATION DESIGN FOR SAGEBRUSH OBLIGATE BIRD BREEDING HABITATS ACROSS THE SAGEBRUSH BIOME (TACK 2016). INCREASES IN PLANT AND INSECT DIVERSITY WILL BENEFIT AVIAN SPECIES THAT UTILIZE WET MEADOWS AT DIFFERENT TIMES OF THE YEAR. FOR EXAMPLE, WET MEADOWS ARE IMPORTANT FOR SAGE-GROUSE IN THIS AREA FOR BROOD REARING.

WESTERN RESERVE LAND CONSERVANCY (WRLC) IS ONE OF THE LARGEST LAND TRUSTS IN THE NATION, FORMED IN 2006 BY THE LARGEST MERGER OF LAND TRUSTS IN U.S. HISTORY. THEIR MISSION IS TO PROVIDE THE PEOPLE OF OUR REGION WITH ESSENTIAL NATURAL ASSETS THROUGH LAND CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION. THEY ENVISION THRIVING, PROSPEROUS COMMUNITIES NOURISHED BY VIBRANT NATURAL LANDS, WORKING FARMS, AND HEALTHY CITIES. WORKING TOGETHER, WRLC AND PFW PROGRAM WILL IDENTIFY STRATEGIC HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS THAT WORK TOWARDS ACHIEVING THE MUTUAL GOALS EACH ORGANIZATION HAS. WRLC WILL ASSIST WITH OUTREACH TO PRIVATE LANDOWNERS THROUGH SOCIAL MEDIA, IN PERSON GATHERINGS, AND HANDOUTS. WRLC WILL ALSO ASSIST WITH THE ADMINISTRATIVE PORTIONS OF THE PROJECTS AND PROVIDE REIMBURSEMENT TO PRIVATE LANDOWNERS FOR ELIGIBLE EXPENSES ASSOCIATED WITH THE RESTORATIONS. THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE (PFW) HAS A LARGE RESTORATION FOOTPRINT IN NORTHEAST OHIO PROVIDING LANDSCAPE SCALE RESTORATION BENEFITS TO COUNTLESS FEDERAL TRUST RESOURCES. THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL FOCUS EFFORTS TO RESTORE HABITAT FOR MIGRATORY BIRDS, FEDERALLY THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES, AND OTHER FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES IN NORTHWEST OHIO. THE WORK WILL FOCUS ON RESTORING WETLAND AND UPLAND COMPLEXES IN THE LAKE ERIE WATERSHED OF NORTHEAST OHIO. THE WETLAND RESTORATION EFFORTS WILL AIM TO RESTORE WETLAND HYDROLOGY BY REMOVING FIELD TILE AND CONSTRUCTING LOW LEVEL BERMS, EXTENDING HYDROPERIODS IN EXISTING WETLANDS AND PROVIDING CRITICAL MIGRATORY BIRD HABITAT. UPLAND EFFORTS WILL FOCUS ON RESTORING HABITAT FOR MIGRATORY BIRDS AND POLLINATORS. PFW WILL WORK IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE RECIPIENT, AS WELL AS OTHER PARTNERS WHO ALSO SHARE A MUTUAL INTEREST IN RESTORING AND ENHANCING NATIVE HABITATS IN THIS AREA.

THE MINNESOTA SHARP-TAILED GROUSE SOCIETY WILL WORK COOPERATIVELY WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE ACROSSTHE STATE TO ASSIST IN ADMINISTERING THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM FOR THE BENEFIT OF FEDERAL TRUSTRESOURCES ON PRIVATE LAND. OUR GOALS AND OBJECTIVES ARE TO RESTORE AND ENHANCE WETLAND, GRASSLAND, AND BRUSHLANDHABITAT RESOURCES IN HIGH PRIORITY AREAS AS IDENTIFIED IN THE PRAIRIE POTHOLE JOINT VENTURE, THE UPPERMISSISSIPPI GREAT LAKES JOINT VENTURE AND THE MINNESOTA PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM 2022-2026 STRATEGIC PLAN. FUNDS WILL BE OBLIGATED AND SPENT ON HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS ON PRIVATE LANDS THAT MEET FWS640.1 PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM POLICIES. GOALS ARE TO RESTORE 800 ACRES OF WETLAND AND UPLAND HABITAT IN HIGH PRIORITY FOCUS AREAS THROUGHOUT MINNESOTA.

NORTH  SOUTHWESTERN POND TURTLES (WPT) SPEND UP TO 2 3 OF THEIR LIVES UPLAND OF FRESH WATERBODIES (PONDS, CREEKS, ETC.) AND REQUIRE SPECIFIC HABITAT TO SUCCESSFULLY BREED AND NEST. WHILE SCIENTISTS UNDERSTAND WHAT GOOD NESTING HABITAT IS, RANGELAND SPECIFIC HABITAT AND FREQUENCY THEY SELECT FROM THE AVAILABLE HABITAT TYPES, SUCH AS CHAPARRAL, GRASSLAND, OR OAK WOODLANDS, IS LESS KNOWN AND THEREFORE DIFFICULT TO PROTECT. IN ALAMEDA COUNTY SPECIFICALLY, LITTLE TO NO RESEARCH HAS BEEN CONDUCTED ON THE HABITAT NEEDS OF WPT. TO HELP FILL THIS GAP IN OUR KNOWLEDGE, THE ALAMEDA COUNTY RESOURCE CONSERVATION DISTRICT (ACRCD), IN COORDINATION WITH THE NATIONAL RESOURCE CONSERVATION SERVICE (NRCS) AND SONOMA STATE UNIVERSITY (SSU), PROPOSES TO INVESTIGATE UPLAND HABITAT USE BY THE WPT IN ALAMEDA COUNTYS RANGELANDS. USING BASIC AND INEXPENSIVE MONITORING TECHNIQUES (RADIO TELEMETRY, GPS, VEGETATION SURVEYS, ETC.) WE WILL GATHER CRITICAL INFORMATION ON UPLAND HABITAT USE BY WPT WHICH WILL BE USED TO INFORM VEGETATION RESTORATION AND GRAZING MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES ACROSS THE LANDSCAPE AND HELP INCREASE SUCCESSFUL BREEDING BY THE WPT. FOLLOWING MONITORING WORK, WE WILL CONDUCT A POND RESTORATION TO REMOVE BUILT-UP SEDIMENTS EXTENDING THE HYDROPERIOD AND INCREASES THE AVAILABILITY OF WETLAND HABITAT FOR WPT AND OTHER WILDLIFE SPECIES, INCLUDING THE LISTED CALIFORNIA TIGER SALAMANDER AND CALIFORNIA RED-LEGGED FROG. WESTERN POND TURTLE POPULATIONS ARE IN DECLINE MAKING IT VITAL WE INVESTIGATE THEIR HABITAT NEEDS SO WE CAN BEST PROTECT THEM.

THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS BEING IMPLEMENTED WITH THE OKLAHOMA CONSERVATION COMMISSION (OCC). THE OBJECTIVES ARE TO PROVIDE FUNDING TO PRIVATE LANDOWNERS WHO ARE ACTIVE MEMBERS IN AN OKLAHOMA PRESCRIBED BURN ASSOCIATION (OPB ASSOCIATIONS) AND HAVE COMPLETED A PRESCRIBED BURN ON THEIR PROPERTIES DURING THE TIME PERIOD OF THIS AGREEMENT. THIS AGREEMENT WILL HELP TO FACILITATE THE USE OF PRESCRIBED FIRE ON PRIVATE LANDS THROUGHOUT THE STATE IN AN EFFORT TO PROMOTE NATIVE PRAIRIE RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT, COMBAT THE SPREAD OF INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES, AND REDUCE FUEL LOADS IN URBAN INTERFACE AREAS.

THIS MULTIFACETED AGREEMENT WITH THE OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION (ODWC) COVERS CONSERVATION PRACTICES ON PRIVATE LANDS AND OTHER ACTIVITIES THROUGHOUT THE STATE OF OKLAHOMA. THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT (AGREEMENT) PROVIDES FINANCIAL BACKING TO ONGOING COLLABORATIVE CONSERVATION WORK BETWEEN THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS), ODWC, AND VOLUNTARY PRIVATE LANDOWNERS. THE AGREEMENT WILL SUPPORT THE RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT OF WETLANDS, GRASSLANDS, AND RIPARIAN HABITAT, INCLUDING ON-THE-GROUND PROJECTS WHICH WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE RECOVERY OF FEDERALLY-LISTED AND OTHER IMPERILED SPECIES SUCH AS THE LESSER PRAIRIE CHICKEN, AMERICAN BURYING BEETLE AND MONARCH BUTTERFLIES POLLINATORS. ADDITIONALLY, MOST PROJECTS WILL RESULT IN IMPROVED HABITAT FOR A VARIETY OF GAME SPECIES, WITH SOME FOCUSED ON IMPROVING HABITAT FOR OVERWINTERING WATERFOWL. SOME PROJECTS WILL FOCUS ON OUTDOOR EDUCATION AND FACILITATE THE CONSTRUCTION OF  OUTDOOR CLASSROOMS . THE AGREEMENT WILL CONTINUE TO IMPLEMENT PROJECTS ON PROPERTIES AND MONITOR LANDOWNERS WHO ARE ENROLLED IN THE LESSER PRAIRIE CHICKEN CANDIDATE CONSERVATION AGREEMENT WITH ASSURANCES. THE AGREEMENT SUPPORTS CONSERVATION ACTIONS IDENTIFIED AS PRIORITIES WITHIN THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM S STRATEGIC PLAN.

IN 2022, THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE RECEIVED FUNDING FROM PRESIDENT BIDEN S BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW (BIL) TO SUPPORT PROJECTS IN WESTERN STATES TO RESTORE AND CONSERVE STRATEGIC AREAS WITHIN THE SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEM. OVER THE FIVE YEARS (2022-2026) OF FUNDING DEDICATED THROUGH BIL, SERVICE STAFF WILL WORK WITH PARTNERS TO IMPLEMENT PROJECTS THAT WILL COMBAT INVASIVE GRASSES AND WILDFIRE, REDUCE ENCROACHING CONIFERS, SAFEGUARD PRECIOUS WATER RESOURCES FOR NEIGHBORING COMMUNITIES AND WILDLIFE, AND PROMOTE COMMUNITY AND ECONOMIC SUSTAINABILITY. PROJECTS IDENTIFIED AND IMPLEMENTED UNDER THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL BUILD UPON THE SUCCESSFUL PARTNERSHIP THAT HAS BEEN ESTABLISHED TO MANAGE THE BI-STATE SAGE GROUSE AND IS A COLLABORATIVE EFFORT AMONG MULTIPLE PARTNERS WHICH ARE CURRENTLY IMPLEMENTING OTHER EFFORTS TO MANAGE THIS AND OTHER SPECIES INCLUDING LAHONTAN CUTTHROAT TROUT.PROJECT OBJECTIVES FOR THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT INCLUDE ENHANCING AND RESTORING SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEM HABITATS AND THE CONSERVATION RECOVERY OF NATIVE TERRESTRIAL AND AQUATIC SPECIES WITH A FOCUS ON WET MEADOWS, STREAMS, AND ASSOCIATED UPLANDS IN MESIC AREAS.

THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN THE REMOVAL OF THE EAST WEAVER CREEK DAM (EWD), AN 18-FOOT HIGH (EQUIVALENT HEIGHT), 33 WIDE AND 25 LONG CONCRETE AND BOULDER DAM SPANNING EAST WEAVER CREEK, A TRIBUTARY TO THE TRINITY RIVER NEAR WEAVERVILLE, CALIFORNIA.THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO RESTORE FISH PASSAGE CONNECTIVITY FOR ALL LIFE STAGES OF ANADROMOUS FISH TO 2.5 MILES OF HIGH QUALITY, COLD WATER HABITAT UPSTREAM OF THE EXISTING DAM SITE. PROJECT OBJECTIVES INCLUDE REMOVING THE EXISTING DAM, INSTALLING GRADE CONTROL STRUCTURES AND LARGE WOODY DEBRIS (LWD), REMOVING AND RELOCATING AGGRADED STREAM MATERIAL, AND REPOSITIONING BOULDERS UNDERNEATH THE EXISTING DAM TO CREATE FULL FISH PASSAGE ACCESS, AS WELL AS FACILITATE PROPER GEOMORPHIC AND HYDROLOGIC FUNCTIONING OF THE STREAM CHANNEL THROUGH THE PROJECT AREA.THE SERVICE S PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM WILL WORK COLLABORATIVELY WITH THE COOPERATOR TO IMPLEMENT ALL PHASE OF THE PROJECT.

THIS PROJECT WILL CONTINUE IMPROVING HYDRAULIC FUNCTIONS IN DEADWOOD CREEK IN THE PORTION OF THE WATERSHED THAT WAS SEVERELY BURNED DURING THE 2018 CARR FIRE. PROJECT TREATMENTS CONSIST OF REMOVAL OF MINING AND LOGGING ROAD FILLS AT STREAM CROSSINGS TO MINIMIZE THE POTENTIAL OF STREAM CROSSING FAILURE AND SEDIMENTATION OF ADJACENT STREAM REACHES. THIS WORK WILL FOCUS ON THE LOWER REACHES OF THE MILL GULCH SUB-WATERSHED WITHIN THE 500-ACRE BROWN BEAR MINE PROPERTY. EACH CROSSINGS DIRT FILL WILL BE REPLACED WITH ROCKED FORDS TO PREVENT DIVERSION DOWN THE ROAD(S) DURING LARGE STORMS WHILE MAINTAINING LOW-MAINTENANCE ROAD ACCESS FOR FUTURE RESTORATION, FIRE SUPPRESSION, AND OTHER ACCESS NEEDS.IN ADDITION, REMNANT MINE FILL WILL BE REMOVED FROM THE STREAM CHANNEL UPSTREAM OF THE NEWLY INSTALLED MILL GULCH CROSSING ON DEADWOOD ROAD AND THE STREAM CHANNEL WILL BE RECONSTRUCTED TO RESTORE HYDROLOGIC AND GEOMORPHIC FUNCTION TO THIS REACH, AS WELL AS MINIMIZE POTENTIAL EROSION OF THIS FILL IN THE FUTURE.TWO STRATEGIC RIDGES, INCLUDING ONE WITH WESTERN AREA POWER ADMINISTRATION (WAPA) REGIONAL TRANSMISSION POWER LINES, WILL BE TREATED TO REMOVE DEAD TREES AND BRUSH TO CREATE FUEL BREAKS. THEWOODY RESIDUE WILL BE CHIPPED OR BURNED TO REDUCE FIRE RISK AND SEVERITY AND THE SITES WILL BE REPLANTED WITH NATIVE TREES.PROJECT DELIVERABLES INCLUDE INSTALLATION OF 21 ROAD DRAINAGE UPGRADES ON DEADWOOD ROAD, INCLUDING ENHANCING AND INSTALLING ROLLING DIPS, VENTED FORDS AND ROCK ARMORED FORDS. REMOVAL OF APPROXIMATELY 800-900 YD3 OF MINE FILL AND RECONSTRUCTION OF 100 FEET OF STREAM CHANNEL. REMOVAL AND MULCHING OF DEAD TREES AND BRUSH FROM 30 ACRES AND REPLANTING WITH 12,000 NATIVE CONIFER TREES.

THE RENO FWO PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM (PFW PROGRAM) WILL WORK WITH A PRIVATE LANDOWNER, A MULTI-GENERATION FAMILY OWNED AND RUN LIVESTOCK OPERATION IN ELKO COUNTY, NEVADA, TO PROTECT MESIC AREAS TO ENHANCE HABITAT FOR WILDLIFE WHILE MAKING IMPROVEMENTS FOR GRAZING MANAGEMENT PRACTICES. THERE ARE TWO PROJECT AREAS WITHIN CORE HABITAT IN THE ONEIL BASIN, A PRIORITY AREA FOR MULTIPLE PUBLIC AND PRIVATE PARTNERS. THE PRIMARY LAND USE IN THE AREA IS LIVESTOCK GRAZING AND PROJECT ACTIVITIES ARE PRIMARILY GRAZING MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (E.G., FENCING, OFF-SITE WATER DEVELOPMENT.)SITE 1: PIPE-RAIL FENCE WILL BE INSTALLED THAT WILL PROTECT AND ENHANCE 15 ACRES MEADOW 0.6 MILE STREAM CHANNEL. A LOW WATER CROSSING WATER GAP WILL ALSO BE A PART OF THIS PROJECT SO LIVESTOCK WILL HAVE ACCESS TO WATER OFF THE MEADOW.SITE 2: FENCING WILL BE INSTALLED THAT WILL ENHANCE 15 ACRES MEADOW 0.4 MILE STREAM CHANNEL. PIPE RAIL IS PREFERRED BUT WILDLIFE FRIENDLY, THREE-STRAND WIRE COULD WORK FOR THIS SITE. AN OFF-SITE WATER DEVELOPMENT (PUMP, PIPELINE AND TROUGH) WILL PROVIDE WATER FOR LIVESTOCK WHILE THE MEADOW IS PROTECTED AND ENHANCED THROUGH FENCING.THESE ARE STRAIGHTFORWARD PROJECTS THAT HAVE A HIGH RETURN ON INVESTMENT. THE PFW PROGRAM HAS IMPLEMENTED SIMILAR PROJECTS WITH THE LANDOWNER IN THE PAST, AND THE LIKELIHOOD OF SUCCESS OF THESE ACTIVITIES IS VERY HIGH.

THE EAST PINE FISH PASSAGE PROJECT IS LOCATED AT RIVER MILE 4.3 ON EAST PINE CREEK, A TRIBUTARY TO PINE CREEK AND IS APPROXIMATELY 1.5 MILES NORTHEAST OF HALFWAY, OR. THE SECTION OF EAST PINE CREEK ASSOCIATED WITH THIS PROJECT HAS THREE DIVERSIONS THAT ARE LISTED AS FISH PASSAGE BARRIERS ON THE 2019 ODFW FISH PASSAGE PRIORITY LIST. A TOTAL OF FOUR IRRIGATION DITCHES ARE CONNECTED TO THESE DIVERSIONS, NONE OF WHICH HAVE FISH SCREENS. EAST PINE CREEK IS DESIGNATED AS CRITICAL HABITAT FOR BULL TROUT AND IS PART OF A CORE RECOVERY AREA RANKED AS A FOCAL AREA FOR BULL TROUT RECOVERY ACTIONS. THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO COMBINE THE DIVERSIONS INTO ONE CONSOLIDATED POINT OF DIVERSION (POD  10.2 CFS TOTAL). THE NEW POD WILL INCLUDE A CONCRETE INTAKE STRUCTURE, HEAD GATE, BURIED PIPELINE, AND ROTARY DRUM FISH SCREEN. TWO OF THE EXISTING DIVERSION STRUCTURES WILL BE REMOVED AND REPLACED WITH ENGINEERED RIFFLE STRUCTURES TO PASS NATIVE MIGRATORY FISH, SPECIFICALLY BULL TROUT. ADDITIONAL PROJECTS ASSOCIATED WITH THIS PROJECT SITE (NOT PART OF THIS APPLICATION) INCLUDE THE REMOVAL OF THE THIRD DIVERSION BARRIER IN 2025 AND WATER EFFICIENCY PROJECTS ON THREE OF THE FOUR IRRIGATION DITCHES (2022 THROUGH 2025). THIS PROJECT IS A JOINT EFFORT BETWEEN THE EAGLE VALLEY SWCD AND IDAHO POWER COMPANY (IPC) WITH ADDITIONAL ASSISTANCE PROVIDED BY U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM, AS WELL AS THE NATIONAL FISH PASSAGE PROGRAM. THE PROJECT HAS FULL SUPPORT AND PARTICIPATION FROM LANDOWNERS AND DITCH USERS.

THE ALABAMA LANDCAN WEBSITE (WWW.ALABAMALANDCAN.ORG) WILL SERVE AS A COMPREHENSIVE PLATFORM TO PROVIDE EASY ACCESS TO A WIDE RANGE OF SERVICES OFFERED BY FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCIES, AND NON-PROFIT AND FOR-PROFIT SERVICE PROVIDERS. THE SITE WILL BE DESIGNED WITH DIRECT LINKS TO COUNTY-LEVEL RESOURCES AND CROSS-LINKS TO STATE AND NATIONAL PROGRAMS, ENSURING USERS CAN EASILY FIND RELEVANT INFORMATION.THROUGH VOLUNTARY, INCENTIVE-BASED OUTREACH, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL ENGAGE WITH LANDOWNERS AND PRIORITIZE THE HUMANITY OF FARMERS AND FOREST OWNERS. THIS APPROACH, WHICH FOCUSES ON BUILDING RELATIONSHIPS RATHER THAN JUST SCIENCE APPLICATION, MAPPING, AND HABITAT ACQUISITION, IS ESSENTIAL TO FOSTERING A SENSE OF TRUST AND ENCOURAGING PARTICIPATION.THE ALABAMA LANDCAN PROJECT IS A CRITICAL EFFORT TO PROMOTE SPECIES CONSERVATION ON PRIVATE LANDS IN ALABAMA. BUILDING ON PAST SUCCESSES AND FAILURES, THE PROJECT EMPHASIZES PARTNERSHIPS WITH PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AND STAKEHOLDERS, PROMOTING CONSERVATION WHILE ENHANCING RURAL ECONOMIES. THE WEBSITE WILL SERVE AS A VALUABLE RESOURCE FOR LANDOWNERS AND PROMOTE CONSERVATION SUCCESSES, LEADING TO A HEALTHIER ENVIRONMENT FOR ALL.

FOLLOWING UP ON A SUCCESSFUL PHASE 1 OF THE ROCK ISLAND CREEK PROJECT, PHASE 2 AIMS TO TO INSTALL 50-60 BEAVER DAM ANALOGS (BDAS), POST ASSISTED LOG STRUCTURES (PALS), AND WOODY DEBRIS IN A SECOND SECTION OF ROCK ISLAND CREEK IN DOUGLAS COUNTY, WA. TROUT UNLIMITED WILL CONTINUE THE PARTNERSHIP WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) AND THE NATURAL RESOURCES CONSERVATION SERVICE (NRCS) TO BUILD STRUCTURES THAT CREATE POOLS PONDS, INDUCE CHANNEL MEANDERING, REDUCE CHANNEL INCISION, AND EXPAND FLOODPLAIN AND WET MEADOW HABITAT. THE PROJECT WILL IMPROVE HABITAT QUALITY AND QUANTITY FOR A VARIETY OF NATIVE FISH, WILDLIFE, AND VEGETATION, WITH THE PRIMARY TARGET SPECIES BEING GREATER SAGE GROUSE (C. UROPHASIANUS) AND REDBAND RAINBOW TROUT UPPER COLUMBIA STEELHEAD (O. MYKISS).HABITAT QUALITY AND QUANTITY HAVE BEEN IMPACTED BY LAND USE PRACTICES. CURRENT LANDOWNERS ARE INTERESTED IN IMPROVING HABITAT CONDITIONS AND LAND MANAGEMENT PRACTICES. GOALS OF THIS PHASE INCLUDE GENERATING ABOUT 20-30 NEW PLUNGE, DAM, AND EDDY POOLS, INCREASING WETTED CHANNEL AREA BY AT LEAST 10  WHERE THIS IS A GOAL OF A BDA INSTALLATION, INCREASING WETTED PERIMETER BY AT LEAST 20  WHERE THIS IS A GOAL OF A BDA INSTALLATION, REDUCING INCISION BY AT LEAST 15  TRENCH DEPTH WHERE AGGRADATION IS A GOAL OF BDA INSTALLATION, AND INCREASING WET MEADOW RIPARIAN FLOODPLAIN BY AT LEAST 20 . LOW-TECH RESTORATION PROJECTS IN SIMILAR LANDSCAPES HAVE RESULTED IN SIGNIFICANT INCREASES IN PRIMARY PRODUCTIVITY WHILE BEING 10 TIMES MORE COST-EFFECTIVE THAN MORE HEAVILY ENGINEERED RESTORATION PROJECTS (SILVERMAN ET AL. 2019).THE SITE WILL BE MONITORED PERIODICALLY TO ASSESS CHANGES IN PHYSICAL CONDITIONS (E.G., HABITAT TYPE, POOL DEPTH, WETTED WIDTH, WETTED PERIMETER, VEGETATION, WET MEADOW RIPARIAN EXPANSION). SPECIES OBSERVATIONS (PARTICULARLY SALMONIDS AND SAGE GROUSE) WILL BE CONDUCTED EITHER AS A COMPONENT OF PROJECT MONITORING OR IN CONJUNCTION WITH OTHER EFFORTS TO EVALUATE THE AREA FOR THESE AND OTHER SPECIES. THE USE OF DRONES TO CAPTURE BEFORE-AFTER IMAGERY WILL BE COLLECTED IF FUNDING ALLOWS.AS A MULTI-PHASED PROJECT, ONCE PHASE 2 IS COMPLETE, THE INTENTION IS TO CONTINUE BEYOND PHASE 2 TO IMPLEMENT LOW-TECH RESTORATION PROJECTS IN OTHER REACHES OF ROCK ISLAND CREEK AS LANDOWNERS SIGN ON AND FUNDING ALLOWS. TROUT UNLIMITED WILL CONDUCT MONITORING ON AND MAINTAIN EXISTING STRUCTURES ON PHASES 1 AND 2 TO ENSURE THE LOW-TECH STRUCTURES ARE PROVIDING THE INTENDED BENEFITS. TU WILL WORK WITH PARTNERS TO ADAPTIVELY MANAGE EACH PHASE BY ADDING OR MODIFYING STRUCTURES AS NEEDED TO BENEFIT THE STREAM AND SURROUNDING HABITAT. TU HOPES TO CONTINUE TO PARTNER WITH THE USFWS PARTNERS PROGRAM, MICROSOFT, AND OTHERS TO HELP RESTORE HISTORIC WETLAND FUNCTION TO THE ROCK ISLAND CREEK WATERSHED.

THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL FOCUS EFFORTS TO RESTORE HABITAT FOR MIGRATORY BIRDS, FEDERALLY THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES, AND OTHER FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES IN NORTHWEST OHIO.  THE WORK WILL FOCUS ON RESTORING WETLAND AND UPLAND COMPLEXES IN THE LAKE ERIE MARSHES AREA OF OHIO. SITES COMING OUT OF AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION WILL BE PRIORITIZED, AS WILL EXISTING CONSERVATION AREAS THAT ARE CONDUCIVE TO FURTHER RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT OF THESE HABITATS. THE WETLAND RESTORATION EFFORTS WILL AIM TO RESTORE WETLAND HYDROLOGY BY REMOVING FIELD TILE AND CONSTRUCTING LOW LEVEL BERMS, EXTENDING HYDROPERIOD IN EXISTING WETLANDS. THE USFWS WILL WORK IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE RECIPIENT, AS WELL AS OTHER PARTNERS INCLUDING THE OHIO DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (ODNR), THE USDA-NATURAL RESOURCES CONSERVATION SERVICE (USDA-NRCS), AND OTHER PARTNERS WHO ALSO SHARE A MUTUAL INTEREST IN RESTORING AND ENHANCING NATIVE HABITATS IN THIS AREA.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS TO ESTABLISH A WORKING PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE SERVICE AND THE RECIPIENT FOR THE PURPOSE OF PROMOTING CONSERVATION ON PRIVATE LANDS. THE RECIPIENT WILL FACILITATE THE DEVELOPMENT OF CONSERVATION PROJECTS AND WORK COOPERATIVELY WITH THE SERVICE TO IDENTIFY, DEVELOP, AND ESTABLISH MUTUALLY BENEFICIAL CONSERVATION PROJECTS.  ALL PROJECTS WILL BE FACILITATED BY SITE-SPECIFIC PRIVATE LANDOWNER AGREEMENTS (PLAS) AS APPROVED AND ADMINISTERED BY THE SERVICE.  THIS AGREEMENT WILL RESTORE, ENHANCE, AND ESTABLISH HABITATS FOR THE BENEFIT OF (1) FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES  (2) SAGEBRUSH OBLIGATE BIRDS  (3) NATIVE FISH (4) MIGRATORY WATERBIRDS  AND (5) OTHER GAME SPECIES.  RESTORATION OF HABITATS WITHIN HIGH PRIORITY CONSERVATION FOCUS AREAS WILL CONTRIBUTE TOWARDS MEETING POPULATION AND HABITAT OBJECTIVES IDENTIFIED IN THE SERVICES 20222026 MOUNTAIN-PRAIRIE REGION STRATEGIC PLAN FOR THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM.

LOW-TECH PROCESS-BASED RESTORATION ACTIVITIES WILL BE IMPLEMENTED TO FACILITATE THE RESTORATION OF A STREAM IN ELKO COUNTY, NEVADA. THE BROAD RESTORATION GOAL IS TO RESTORE  2-4 MILES OF AN ANASTAMOSING STREAM TO ITS PROPER FUNCTIONING CONDITION CREATING A RESILIENT LANDSCAPE THAT CAN MAINTAIN ITS POTENTIAL IN SELF-SUSTAINING WAYS. SPECIFIC GOALS INCLUDE: INCREASED HEALTH AND DIVERSITY OF RIPARIAN VEGETATION,INCREASED CHANNEL-FLOODPLAIN CONNECTIVITY, PROCESSES OF WOOD ACCUMULATION AND OR BEAVER ACTIVITY ARE SELF-SUSTAINING, AND ENHANCED TROUT HABITAT.

THE PROJECT AREA IS LOCATED IN LOGAN, KINGFISHER, AND GARFIELD COUNTIES. THIS PROJECT IS LOCATED IN THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE MONARCH FOCUS AREA. THE ABSENCE OF NATURALLY OCCURRING FIRES WITHIN THE MIXED-GRASS REGION ALONG WITH THE ENCROACHMENT OF EASTERN RED CEDAR IS ALTERING THE VEGETATION STRUCTURE IN THIS ECOSYSTEM. THIS PLANT COMMUNITY HISTORICALLY CONSISTED OF MIXED GRASS SPECIES SUCH AS LITTLE BLUESTEMS, BIG BLUESTEM, SIDEOATS GRAMA, BUFFALOGRASS, SAND SAGEBRUSH, AND NUMEROUS FORBS AND LEGUMES. RECENT STUDIES HAVE DEMONSTRATED THAT SHIFTS ARE ALSO OCCURRING IN AVIAN COMMUNITIES WITHIN THIS GRASSLAND COMMUNITY DUE TO THE ABSENCE OF FIRE AND ENCROACHMENT OF EASTERN RED CEDAR.

LOVELACE DAM IS LOCATED ON PRIVATE PROPERTY NEAR WILDERVILLE, OREGON (JOSEPHINE COUNTY), ON SLATE CREEK WITHIN THE APPLEGATE RIVER SUBBASIN OF THE ROGUE RIVER BASIN. THIS STREAM-SPANNING CONCRETE DAM BLOCKS OR IMPEDES ADULT AND JUVENILE FISH PASSAGE TO OVER 25 MILES OF SPAWNING AND REARING HABITAT. IMPACTED SPECIES  STOCKS INCLUDE FALL CHINOOK SALMON, COHO SALMON, SUMMER AND WINTER STEELHEAD (RAINBOW TROUT), CUTTHROAT TROUT, KLAMATH SMALLSCALE SUCKERS, AND PACIFIC LAMPREY. LOVELACE DAM IS RANKED IN GROUP 2 OF ODFW S 2019 STATEWIDE FISH PASSAGE PRIORITY LIST AND SERVES NO WATER SUPPLY, FLOOD CONTROL, OR HYDROPOWER PURPOSE. IT DOES NOT COMPLY WITH NOAA OR ODFW FISH PASSAGE CRITERIA.THROUGH THIS PROJECT, WE WILL WORK WITH PARTNERS TO REMOVE LOVELACE DAM AND SUBSTANTIALLY IMPROVE PASSAGE CONDITIONS FOR ALL SPECIES AND ALL LIFE STAGES OF MIGRATORY AQUATIC ANIMALS TO 25 MILES OF HABITAT. THIS ACTION COMPLEMENTS OTHER RESTORATION EFFORTS ONGOING ACROSS THE ROGUE BASIN.PARTNERS INCLUDE THE LANDOWNER, ODFW, NOAA FISHERIES, BLM, RIVER DESIGN GROUP, ROGUE BASIN PARTNERSHIP, AND WATERWATCH OF OREGON.

FUNDING PROVIDED WILL SUPPORT 3 DIFFERENT INITIATIVES:1- FUNDING WILL PROVIDE RESTORATION SUPPORT TO LANDOWNERS IN THE LITTLE BUTTE UPPER ROGUE OAK INITIATIVE (INITIATIVE) FOCUS AREA, IN COOPERATION WITH THE KLAMATH-SISKIYOU OAK NETWORK (KSON). LOMAKATSI WILL ASSIST LANDOWNERS WITH PLANNING TO LEVERAGE OTHER FUNDING TO INCREASE FIRE RESILIENCY. BY ADDRESSING FUEL LOADS ON PRIVATE LANDS, THERE WILL BE IMPROVED OVERALL WATER QUALITY QUANTITY, IMPROVED WILDLIFE HABITAT FOR DECLINING SPECIES AS WELL AS LOWERING THE OVERALL RISK OF WILDFIRE DAMAGE TO WILDLIFE HABITAT, DWELLINGS STRUCTURES AND   ULTIMATELY, HUMAN SAFETY IN SOUTHERN OREGON.2- LOMAKATSI AND THE MEYER MEMORIAL TRUST ARE PARTNERING TO HOST ITERP PEER-TO-PEER LEARNING SUMMIT IN 2023. THE EVENT AIMS TO ELEVATE TRIBAL PARTNERSHIPS IN COLLABORATIVE FOREST AND WATERSHED RESTORATION AND INCREASE TRIBAL INCLUSION IN THE RESTORATIVE FORESTRY AGREEMENTS AND AQUATIC RESTORATION INITIATIVES THAT BENEFIT THEIR COMMUNITIES AND EMPOWER PARTNERSHIP TO CO-MANAGE, COINVEST, AND COLLABORATE ON LARGE, LANDSCAPE-SCALE INITIATIVES. 3- FUNDING SUPPORT FOR THE PRIVATE LANDS PARTNERS DAY 2024 AND TO HELP LOMAKATSI WORK WITH LANDOWNERS AND ENCOURAGE PARTICIPATION IN THE 2024 PARTNERSCAPES PRIVATE LANDS PARTNERS DAY IN REDMOND, OREGON.

PROJECT INTENDS TO ENHANCE  29 ACRES OF LONGLEAF PINE SANDHILL THROUGH THE APPLICATION OF PRESCRIBED FIRE AND HARDWOOD CONTROL VIA CHEMICAL AND OR MECHANICAL MEANS WHILE ESTABLISHING LONGLEAF PINE ON  31 ACRES THROUGH EFFECTIVE SITE PREP, PLANTING, AND GRASS STAGE MOWING PRIOR TO THE INTRODUCTION OF REGULAR PRESCRIBED FIRE. ALL WORK WILL TAKE PLACE IN MADISON COUNTY, FLORIDA.

THE PROJECT AREA IS LOCATED IN LINCOLN COUNTY. THE PROPERTY CAN BE DESCRIBED AS BOTTOM LAND TYPE HABITAT THAT IS FALLOW. HABITAT TREATMENTS WILL INCLUDE THE ENHANCEMENT OF A 6 ACRE WETLAND HABITAT TO BENEFIT FEDERAL TRUST RESOURCE SPECIES AND MIGRATORY BIRDS.THIS PROJECT WILL ADD ONE EARTHEN DIKE AND A DRAIN STRUCTURE TO PROVIDE THE LANDOWNER THE OPPORTUNITY TO MANAGE THE WETLAND WITH 6 ACRES OF WATER THAT IS 18 INCHES OR LESS THROUGH THE ENTIRE WETLAND. THIS WETLAND WILL BE MANAGED BY THE LANDOWNER FOR WATERFOWL AND OTHER MIGRATORY BIRDS.  THE HABITAT PROJECT WILL INCLUDE THE INSTALLATION OF A NEW DIKE, DRAIN STRUCTURE, AND STEEL PIPE TO BETTER MANAGE THE WETLAND HABITAT AS PREFERRED BY THE LANDOWNER. THE COOPERATOR MAY MANAGE FOR THE NATURAL WETLAND PLANTS OR MAY OPT FOR PLANTING AGRICULTURAL CROPS FOR A FOOD SOURCE FOR MIGRATING BIRDS AS WELL.  WATER LEVELS WILL BE RAISED IN THE FALL AND WINTER MONTHS FOR WATERFOWL USE.

THE PROJECT AREA IS LOCATED IN OTTAWA COUNTY. THE PROPERTY CAN BE DESCRIBED AS BOTTOM LAND TYPE HABITAT IN AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION FOR HAY. HABITAT TREATMENTS WILL INCLUDE THE ENHANCEMENT OF A 10 ACRE WETLAND HABITAT TO BENEFIT FEDERAL TRUST RESOURCE SPECIES AND MIGRATORY BIRDS.

THE PROJECT AREA IS LOCATED IN LOVE COUNTY. THE PROPERTY CAN BE DESCRIBED AS BOTTOM LAND TYPE HABITAT. HABITAT TREATMENTS WILL INCLUDE THE REMOVAL OF 47 ACRES OF CEDARS TO BENEFIT FEDERAL TRUST RESOURCE SPECIES AND MIGRATORY BIRDS.THIS PROJECT WILL REMOVE 47 ACRES OF CEDARS TO IMPROVE FOREST HEALTH AND ALLOW NATIVE VEGETATION TO GROW. THE PROJECT WILL INCLUDE MANUAL CEDAR REMOVAL THROUGH CLIPPING MULCHING. THE CEDAR REMOVAL WILL BENEFIT POLLINATOR AND MIGRATORY BIRDS.

PROJECT ABSTRACT WITH COOPERATION FROM THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE S ILLINOIS - IOWA ES FIELD OFFICE, TED JACKSON WILL RESTORE A PORTION OF HIS PROPERTY  TO NATIVE HABITAT FOR POLLINATORS, MIGRATORY BIRDS, AND OTHER WILDLIFE.  THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE IS TO PROVIDE YEAR ROUND HABITAT FOR THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED RUSTY PATCH BUMBLE BEE (BOMBUS AFFINIS) AND FORAGING HABITAT FOR THE CANDIDATE FOR LISTED MONARCH BUTTERFLY (DANAUS PLESIPPUS).  THE SECONDARY OBJECTIVE IS TO PROVIDE HABITAT FOR THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED NORTHERN LONG-EARED BAT AND FOR MIGRATORY BIRDS.  TED JACKSON AND HIS FAMILY SUPPORT SPACES FOR FOR ECOLOGICAL BENEFITS OF PRESENT AND FUTURE GENERATIONS.  THEY WORK TO CONSERVE HABITAT FOR HUNDREDS OF SPECIES OF WILDLIFE AND PLANTS.  THEY ARE EXCITED TO RESTORE PRAIRIE, SAVANNA AND OPEN WOODLAND HABITAT IN THE NEAR FUTURE AND STEWARD IT IN THE DISTANT FUTURE.

WESTERN JUNIPER TREES AND INVASIVE ANNUAL GRASSES HAVE ESTABLISHED DUE TO FIRE EXCLUSION ON SOME OF THE MORE PRIME SOUTH AND SOUTHWESTERN ASPECTS OF RANGELANDS ON THE PROPERTY. THIS PROJECT IS NEEDED TO SET BACK THE JUNIPER ENCROACHMENT, REDUCE THE NON-NATIVE ANNUAL GRASSES, AND RE-ESTABLISH A MIXTURE OF RANGE PLANT SPECIES THAT WILL OUTCOMPETE INVASIVE GRASSES AND PROVIDE HIGHLY PALATABLE FORAGE FOR NATIVE WILDLIFE. JUNIPER AND ANNUAL GRASS ENCROACHMENT IS A THREAT TO BOTH INSTREAM FLOWS AND NATIVE VEGETATION. THE LACK OF HISTORICAL DISTURBANCES (PRIMARILY FIRE) HAS CREATED ABNORMALLY HIGH DENSITY AND ABUNDANCE OF JUNIPER, WHICH HAS SIGNIFICANTLY IMPACTED GROUNDWATER LEVELS AND WATER AVAILABILITY IN THE REYNOLDS CREEK WATERSHED. THE NEGATIVE IMPACTS OF JUNIPER ENCROACHMENT IN THE WATERSHED INCLUDE SOIL, WATER, AND VEGETATION DEGRADATION FROM HISTORICAL NATURAL CONDITIONS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS TO ESTABLISH A WORKING PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE SERVICE AND THE RECIPIENT FOR THE PURPOSE OF PROMOTING CONSERVATION ON PRIVATE LANDS. THE RECIPIENT WILL FACILITATE THE DEVELOPMENT OF CONSERVATION PROJECTS AND WORK COOPERATIVELY WITH THE SERVICE TO IDENTIFY, DEVELOP, AND ESTABLISH MUTUALLY BENEFICIAL CONSERVATION PROJECTS.  ALL PROJECTS WILL BE FACILITATED BY SITE-SPECIFIC PRIVATE LANDOWNER AGREEMENTS (PLAS) AS APPROVED AND ADMINISTERED BY THE SERVICE.  THIS AGREEMENT WILL RESTORE, ENHANCE, AND ESTABLISH HABITATS FOR THE BENEFIT OF (1) FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES  (2) SAGEBRUSH OBLIGATE BIRDS  (3) NATIVE FISH (4) MIGRATORY WATERBIRDS  AND (5) OTHER GAME SPECIES.  RESTORATION OF HABITATS WITHIN HIGH PRIORITY CONSERVATION FOCUS AREAS WILL CONTRIBUTE TOWARDS MEETING POPULATION AND HABITAT OBJECTIVES IDENTIFIED IN THE SERVICES 20222026 MOUNTAIN-PRAIRIE REGION STRATEGIC PLAN FOR THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM.

THE SAN FRANCISCO GARTER SNAKE RECOVERY WORKING GROUP AND RESTORATION WILL SUPPORT THE RECOVERY OF SAN FRANCISCO GARTER SNAKE BY FACILITATING A COLLABORATION AMONG STAKEHOLDERS AND IMPLEMENTATION OF RECOMMENDED RECOVERY ACTIONS. THE PROJECT WILL LEAD TO THE CREATION AND COORDINATION OF A SAN FRANCISCO GARTER SNAKE RECOVERY WORKING GROUP TO ENCOURAGE REGIONAL SCALE THINKING AND COLLABORATION TOWARDS RECOVERING THE SNAKE AND ITS PREY SPECIES. THE PROJECT ALSO INCLUDES IMPLEMENTATION OF A 4-ACRE MULTI-BENEFIT RESTORATION PROJECT THAT WILL AID IN RECOVERY OF BOTH THE ENDANGERED SAN FRANCISCO GARTER SNAKE AND THE THREATENED CALIFORNIA RED-LEGGED FROG, AS WELL AS OTHER LISTED SPECIES SUCH AS STEELHEAD, COHO SALMON, AND WESTERN POND TURTLE.

THE LINCOLN SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION DISTRICT (LSWCD) AIMS TO INCREASE OREGON SILVERSPOT BUTTERFLY (OSB) HABITAT CONNECTIVITY, PUBLIC AWARENESS, AND PARTNERSHIP COLLABORATION THROUGH VEGETATION MANAGEMENT AND POLLINATOR HABITAT RESTORATION ON SMALL (LESS THAN ACRES) PRIVATE RESIDENTIAL PROPERTIES WITHIN NEWPORT AND YACHATS, OREGON THAT ARE WITHIN MILE OF THE OCEAN AND 4 MILES FROM THE NEAREST EXTANT OR FUTURE REINTRODUCTION SITE (SEE MAPS). THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT OSB RECOVERY EFFORTS AT YAQUINA HEAD AND ALONG THE CENTRAL COAST BY INCREASING PUBLIC AWARENESS OF THIS SPECIES AND THE IMPORTANCE OF SALT SPRAY MEADOW HABITAT FOR THE BUTTERFLY. CURRENTLY AT THOSE TWO LOCATIONS, THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT, SIUSLAW NATIONAL FOREST, AND THE OREGON PARKS AND RECREATION DEPARTMENT ARE WORKING TOGETHER TO RESTORE OSB HABITAT. IN ADDITION TO INCREASING PUBLIC AWARENESS IN SUPPORT OF THESE PARTNERS, THIS PROPOSAL WILL PROVIDE HABITAT CONNECTIVITY THROUGH WORKING WITH LOCAL PRIVATE LANDOWNERS VIA OSB SAFE HARBOR AGREEMENTS (SHA) ON DEVELOPING POLLINATOR GARDENS AND OSB HABITAT WHERE APPROPRIATE. PROPERTIES WITHIN 1 MILE OF YAQUINA HEAD OR CENTRAL COAST HABITAT WILL BE GIVEN PREFERENCE SHOULD PARTICIPATION EXCEED THE BUDGET EXPECTATIONS. THE PROJECT DURATION WILL BE 4 YEARS STARTING FALL 2022 THROUGH SPRING 2027.

RIPARIAN BUFFERS ARE EXTREMELY IMPORTANT TO THE HEALTH OF RIVER AND STREAM ECOSYSTEMS. A WELL WOODED BUFFER PROVIDES BANK STABILITY, A SOURCE OF ORGANIC MATERIAL AND TERRESTRIAL INVERTEBRATES, REGULATE WATER TEMPERATURE THROUGH SHADE, AND IS A SOURCE OF IN-STREAM COMPLEXITY THROUGH COURSE WOODY DEBRIS. INDUSTRIAL LOG DRIVES OF YESTERYEAR AND THE SUBSEQUENT NETWORK OF LOGGING ROADS HAVE TAKEN THEIR TOLL ON RIPARIAN BUFFERS IN A NUMBER OF AREAS. DURING THE LOG DRIVE ERA FORESTS WERE CUT ALL THE WAY TO THE STREAM BANKS REDUCING BANK STABILITY AND ALLOWING CHANNELS TO BECOME OVER WIDENED. DRIVING LOGS INVOLVED STORING WATER AND LOGS BEHIND A SERIES OF DAMS AND THEN RELEASING TORRENTS OF WATER IN THE SPRING SO THAT THE LOGS COULD BE TRANSPORTED ALONG WITH THE FLOOD OF WATER TO THE MILLS AT THE COAST. ANY IN-STREAM STRUCTURES (I.E. BOULDERS AND LOG JAMS) WERE SYSTEMATICALLY REMOVED EACH YEAR TO FACILITATE THE DRIVES. EVENTUALLY THE LOG DRIVES WERE REPLACED WITH A NETWORK OF LOGGING ROADS SO THAT INLAND WOOD COULD BE HARVESTED AND TRUCKED TO THE MILLS. THESE ROAD NETWORKS INCLUDE NUMEROUS STREAM CROSSINGS, MOST OF WHICH INVOLVED PLACING CULVERTS, THAT WERE OFTEN IMPROPERLY SIZED AND OR IMPROPERLY INSTALLED, AT THE STREAM ROAD INTERSECTIONS. THESE SITES OFTEN CAUSE SIGNIFICANT BACKWATER AREAS UPSTREAM OF THE ROAD. NOW THAT THESE CROSSINGS ARE BEING REPLACED WITH PROPERLY SIZED OPEN-BOTTOM STRUCTURES (BRIDGES OR ARCH CULVERTS) THERE ARE MANY LEGACY BACKWATER AREAS BEING DRAINED ACROSS THE LANDSCAPE. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO RE-VEGETATE THESE DRAINED BACKWATER AREAS TO HELP JUMP-START THE FOREST SUCCESSION. WE WILL ALSO BE REPLANTING RIPARIAN BUFFERS IN AREAS THAT ARE CONSISTENTLY SCOURED BY WINTER ICE FLOWS AND FLOOD EVENTS CAUSED BY THE LACK OF IN-STREAM STRUCTURE.

NATIONAL FISH AND WILDLIFE FOUNDATION (NFWF) REQUESTS  500,000 TO SUPPORT THE SIXTH YEAR OF A PARTNERSHIP WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (FWS) TO SUPPORT A PUBLIC-PRIVATE PARTNERSHIP TO IMPROVE THE QUALITY OF WESTERN MIGRATION CORRIDOR, STOPOVER, AND WINTER RANGE HABITAT. THE PROGRAM WILL ADVANCE THE GOALS OF SECRETARIAL ORDER 3362, IMPROVING HABITAT QUALITY IN WESTERN BIG-GAME WINTER RANGE AND MIGRATION CORRIDORS AS WELL AS THE RECENT EXECUTIVE ORDERS RELATED TO CLIMATE CHANGE. NFWF SPECIALIZES IN WORKING WITH MULTIPLE FEDERAL AGENCIES TO CREATE EFFICIENCIES OF SCALE TO ADDRESS SHARED CONSERVATION GOALS IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE PRIVATE SECTOR. THE MIGRATION CORRIDORS PARTNERSHIP WILL ALLOW NFWF TO WORK WITH OTHER FEDERAL AGENCIES, INCLUDING THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT (BLM), NATURAL RESOURCES CONSERVATION SERVICE (NRCS), AND U.S. FOREST SERVICE (USFS), AS WELL AS CONOCOPHILLIPS AND OTHER POTENTIAL PRIVATE SECTOR FUNDERS, TO SUPPORT WESTERN MIGRATIONS, BOLSTER LOCAL RANCHING ECONOMIES, AND IMPROVE ECOSYSTEM HEALTH TO SUPPORT BIODIVERSITY AND THE ABILITY OF SPECIES TO ADAPT TO A CHANGING ENVIRONMENT.

OCHOCO PRESERVE PROJECT - PHASE 2 NEAR PRINEVILLE, OREGON IS THE SECOND STEP IN A MULTI-YEAR, MULTI-PHASED RESTORATION EFFORT THAT SUPPORTS THE REINTRODUCTION OF SPRING CHINOOK SALMON AND SUMMER STEELHEAD AND HELPS TO ACHIEVE THE RESTORATION OF SELF-SUSTAINING UPLAND, WETLAND, FLOODPLAIN, AND STREAM ECOLOGICAL PROCESSES. OVER THE PAST 150 YEARS, LANDSCAPE CHANGES HAVE OCCURRED ON THE PRESERVE IN ORDER TO FACILITATE AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES. COMMON LAND MANIPULATIONS SUCH AS STREAM RELOCATION, STRAIGHTENING, ARMORING, AND DIKING HAVE TRANSPIRED. FURTHER, MOST OXBOWS AND WETLANDS WERE FILLED AND LEVELED. THE ECOLOGICAL VALUE OF THE PRESERVE HAS BEEN DRASTICALLY REDUCED. THIS PROJECT IS DESIGNED IN ORDER TO ALLOW OCHOCO CREEK AND THE CROOKED RIVER TO ACCESS FLOODPLAINS TO THE MAXIMUM EXTENT POSSIBLE WITH CONSIDERATION FOR RISK AND CONSTRUCTABILITY. THIS WILL ALLOW FOR A MORE SUSTAINABLE PROJECT OVER TIME, WHERE DYNAMIC STREAM PROCESSES OCCUR, THE FLOODPLAIN IS FREQUENTLY ACCESSED, AND VARIABLE HABITATS FORM THAT ARE ABLE TO SUPPORT ALL LIFE STAGES OF ANADROMOUS AND RESIDENT FISH.SIGNIFICANT LAND MANIPULATION MUST OCCUR IN ORDER TO RESET THE CURRENT CHANNELIZED CONDITIONS ON BOTH SYSTEMS . THEREFORE, HEAVY EQUIPMENT WILL BE USED TO CONSTRUCT STREAM CHANNELS, OFF-CHANNEL HABITATS, WETLANDS, FLOODPLAINS, AND UPLANDS ACROSS ABOUT 86 ACRES OF THE PRESERVE. THE LENGTH OF OCHOCO CREEK AND THE CROOKED RIVER WILL NEARLY DOUBLE. MUCH OF THE INCREASED LENGTH WILL INCLUDE COMPLEX HABITATS SUITABLE FOR CHINOOK AND STEELHEAD REARING. FOR EXAMPLE, THE NEWLY CREATED OCHOCO CREEK WILL CONTAIN 3,390 FEET OF SIDE CHANNELS, 34 POOLS, AND 35 RIFFLES.

SUNRISE MOUNTAIN RANCH (SMR) COVERS A LARGE AREA (APPROX. 14,000 ACRES) IN THE SPRAGUE RIVER WATERSHED AND INCLUDES PORTIONS OF THE SPRAGUE RIVER, SF SPRAGUE RIVER, NF SPRAGUE RIVER, MERYL CREEK, AND AN INTERMITTENT PORTION OF LONG CREEK. MERYL CREEK IS A SMALL TRIBUTARY OF THE NF SPRAGUE RIVER, DRAINS APPROXIMATELY 57 SQUARE MILES, AND IS IMPORTANT HABITAT FOR REDBAND TROUT (ONCORHYNCHUS MYKISS NEWBERRYI). THE LOWER 3.3 MILES OF MERYL CREEK FLOW THROUGH AN ALLUVIAL VALLEY THAT HISTORICALLY CONTAINED IMPORTANT WET MEADOW HABITATS. MOST OF LOWER MERYL CREEK (2.7 MILES) ARE ON SUNRISE MOUNTAIN RANCH. THE CURRENT CHANNEL IS INCISED, DISCONNECTED FROM THE FLOODPLAIN HABITAT ACROSS THE VALLEY, AND IS ALMOST ENTIRELY DEVOID OF INSTREAM HABITAT FOR NATIVE FISH. THE RIPARIAN IS SEVERELY DEGRADED DUE TO HISTORIC CATTLE OVERGRAZING, AND THERE ARE TWO MAJOR BARRIERS TO FISH PASSAGE ON MERYL CREEK. ALTHOUGH THERE IS NO CRITICAL HABITAT OR OCCUPIED HABITAT FOR ENDANGERED LOST RIVER AND SHORTNOSE (LRSN) SUCKERS ON THE RANCH, POOR WATER QUALITY ORIGINATING ON THE RANCH FLOWS DOWNSTREAM AND MAY IMPACT THESE SPECIES. UNFORTUNATELY, THIS REACH OF MERYL CREEK EXPORTS A LARGE AMOUNT OF SEDIMENT TO THE NF SPRAGUE RIVER WHICH CONTRIBUTES TO POOR WATER QUALITY. THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, TROUT UNLIMITED, AND THE PRIVATE LANDOWNER ARE PARTNERING TO ADDRESS THESE CONDITIONS IN LOWER MERYL CREEK.RESTORATION OBJECTIVES  RESTORE ENHANCE 2.7 RIVER MILES OF MERYL CREEK BY REVERSING CHANNEL INCISION REACTIVATE APPROXIMATELY 100 ACRES OF HISTORIC CHANNEL FLOODPLAIN CONNECTION IMPROVE THE CONDITION OF APPROXIMATELY 250 ACRES OF RIPARIAN HABITAT INCREASE INSTREAM HABITAT COMPLEXITY BY INSTALLING APPROXIMATELY 40 80 LARGE WOODY DEBRIS STRUCTURES IMPROVE ACCESS BY REMOVING EXISTING FISH PASSAGE BARRIERS

THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM (PFW) IS A PROVEN APPROACH TO VOLUNTARY CONSERVATION VIEWED POSITIVELY BY LANDOWNERS AND OTHER PARTNERS. PARTNERSCAPES HELPS CARRY OUT THE SERVICE S MODEL OF PRIVATE LANDS CONSERVATION BY ACTING AS VITAL COMMUNICATORS AND TRAINERS, FOSTERING A NON HOSTILE ENVIRONMENT FOR OUTREACH, CRITICAL CONVERSATIONS AND PRODUCTIVE RELATIONSHIPS IN PLACES IMPORTANT TO WILDLIFE, LANDOWNERS AND SPORTSMEN ACROSS THE COUNTRY. THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL SUPPORT TWO NATIONAL GATHERINGS OF PFW BIOLOGISTS, OTHER VOLUNTARY CONSERVATION PRACTITIONERS, AND LANDOWNERS, TWO SHORT FILMS HIGHLIGHTING THE MULTI PERSPECTIVE RELATIONSHIPS KEY TO WORKING LANDSCAPE CONSERVATION, AND TWO REGIONAL BIOLOGIST LANDOWNER LEARNING SESSIONS TO SUPPORT WORKING LANDSCAPE CONSERVATION.

THE PROJECT WILL CONTROL 51 ACRES OF NON NATIVE INVASIVE BRUSH ON PRIVATE PROPERTY IN TIPPECANOE COUNTY ADJACENT TO PERMANENTLY PROTECTED LAND HELD BY OTHER ENTITIES INCLUDING NICHES LAND TRUST, THE PURDUE RESEARCH FOUNDATION, AND THE WABASH RIVER ENHANCEMENT CORPORATION. THIS PROJECT IS PHASE I OF III IN THE RESTORATION PLAN FOR THE 200 ACRE ROSS HILLS PARK AND ROSS HILLS CAMP PROPERTYIMPROVING THE STRUCTURE AND COMPOSITION OF THIS FLOODPLAIN ADJACENT UPLAND FOREST WILL BENEFIT A VARIETY OF BIRD SPECIES INCLUDING CERULEAN WARBLERS, WOOD THRUSH, BLUE HERONS, BALD EAGLES. BENEFITS TO THESE BIRD SPECIES INCLUDE ENHANCED NESTING AND FORAGING HABITAT ALONG THE WABASH RIVER CORRIDOR.THE ROSS HILLS PARK PROPERTY IS PART OF A FORESTED CORRIDOR ALONG THE RIVER THAT PROVIDES IMPORTANT HABITAT TO MULTIPLE THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES. MAINTAINING A HEALTHY FOREST ECOSYSTEM WOULD BENEFIT THE NORTHERN LONG EARED BAT AND INDIANA BAT WHICH HAVE ROOST SITES ALONG THE WABASH RIVER CORRIDOR. AUTUMN OLIVE AND BUSH HONEYSUCKLE ARE THE MAIN COMPONENTS OF THE NON NATIVE INVASIVE BRUSH THAT IS PRESENT. AUTUMN OLIVE IS A NITROGEN FIXING NON NATIVE INVASIVE SHRUB THAT COULD ALSO ACT AS A SOURCE OF AQUATIC NITRATE POLLUTION THEREBY IMPACTING WATER QUALITY FOR THE FANSHELL, RABBITSFOOT, AND SHEEPNOSE MUSSELS FOUND IN THIS STRETCH OF THE RIVER. ADDITIONALLY, THE BUSH HONEYSUCKLE HAS BECOME THICK ENOUGH TO BLOCK SUNLIGHT FROM REACHING THE FOREST FLOOR AND INHIBITING THE NATIVE HERBACEOUS PLANT COMMUNITY. THIS RESTORATION PROJECT WILL HELP DEPLETE THE INVASIVE SPECIES SEED SOURCE AND CURB THE SPREAD OF INVASIVE SPECIES TO THE ADJACENT PERMANENTLY PROTECTED LANDS.THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN 51 ACRES OF UPLAND HABITAT TOWARD THE RESTORATION GOALS WITHIN THE SOUTHWEST RIVER CORRIDORS FOCUS AREA AS IDENTIFIED IN THE INDIANA PARTNERS FOR FISH AND  WILDLIFE STRATEGIC PLAN.THE PARTNERS BIOLOGIST COORDINATED WITH THE LANDOWNER, PROJECT PARTNERS, THE CONTRACTOR, AND WILL PROVIDE  15,000.00 COST SHARE TO TIPPECANOE COUNTY PARKS DEPARTMENT. THE PFW COST SHARE WILL BE APPLIED TOWARD HIRING A REPUTABLE CONTRACTOR FOR THE CUT STUMP TREATMENT AND FOLLOW UP HERBICIDE APPLICATION TO CONTROL THE NON NATIVE INVASIVE SPECIES. CUT STUMP TREATMENT WILL TAKE PLACE DURING THE WINTER MONTHS AND THE FOLIAR HERBICIDE APPLICATION WILL BE COMPLETED DURING THE GROWING SEASON. TIPPECANOE COUNTY PARKS DEPARTMENT WILL PROVIDE A TOTAL OF  40,500.00 CASH MATCH VIA TIPPECANOE PARKS FOUNDATION AND ROY WHISTLER FOUNDATION FUNDS TO THE CONTRACTOR FOR THE INVASIVE SPECIES CONTROL.

THIS PROJECT WILL RESTORE 42.9 ACRES OF REMNANT FORESTED HIGH DUNES AND OAK SAVANNA AT THE STOCKWELL WOODS NATUREPRESERVE PROPERTY LOCATED IN LAPORTE COUNTY, IN. ENCROACHMENT BY AGGRESSIVE NON NATIVE INVASIVE WOODY SPECIES,INCLUDING BUSH HONEYSUCKLE (LONICERA SPP), TREE OF HEAVEN (AILANTHUS ALTISSIMA), AUTUMN OLIVE (ELAEAGNUSUMBELLATA), ORIENTAL BITTERSWEET (CELASTRUS ORBICULATUS), MULTIFLORA ROSE (ROSA MULTIFLORA), JAPANESE BARBERRY(BERBERIS THUNBERGII), WINGED BURNING BUSH (EUONYMUS ALATUS), AND BUCKTHORN (RHAMNUS ATHARTICA) HAVE DEGRADED THEPROPERTY OWNED BY THE SAVE THE DUNES CONSERVATION FUND. IN ADDITION TO THE INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT, TREETHINNING IS NEEDED TO HELP RESTORE AND MAINTAIN THE OAK SAVANNA COMMUNITY AND STRUCTURE THAT HAS BECOMEOVERCROWDED WITH WOODY SPECIES FROM YEARS OF FIRE SUPPRESSION. THE TREE THINNING EFFORTS WILL TARGET A 5 ACREAREA OF OAK SAVANNA.SEVERAL STATE VULNERABLE, RARE, OR THREATENED SPECIES HAVE BEEN RECORDED AT STOCKWELL WOODS INCLUDING JACK PINE(PINUS BANKSIANA), EASTERN WHITE PINE (PINUS STROBUS), COMMON JUNIPER (JUNIPERIS COMMUNIS), SPOTTED WINTERGREEN(CHIMAPHILA MACULATA) AND SAND HEATHER (HUDSONIA TOMENTOSA). A PREVIOUSLY CONDUCTED FLORISTIC QUALITY ASSESSMENT PERFORMED ON THE PROPERTY RECORDED A NATIVE FLORISTIC QUALITY INDEX (FQI) OF 48.6 COMPRISED OF 87 NATIVE SPECIES.THE GOAL OF THIS HABITAT PROJECT IS TO ERADICATE NON NATIVE INVASIVE PLANTS, IMPROVE SAVANNA STRUCTURE, ANDPROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE NATIVE PLANT COMMUNITIES, ESPECIALLY THE HERBACEOUS LAYER, TO FLOURISH. HERBICIDEAPPLICATIONS ON NON NATIVE WOODY SPECIES VIA CHEMICAL AND MECHANICAL TREATMENTS WILL FAVOR THE DIVERSE REMNANTPLANT COMMUNITY SUPPORTING NUMEROUS MIGRATORY BIRD SPECIES INCLUDING A VARIETY OF WOODPECKERS, WARBLERS,FLYCATCHERS, AND VIREOS. APART FROM THE BENEFITS TO MIGRATORY BIRDS, THE CANOPY OPENING, AND INVASIVE SPECIESCONTROL WILL ALSO BENEFIT POLLINATOR SPECIES INCLUDING THE KARNER BLUE AND MONARCH BUTTERFLY BY ENHANCING FLORALRESOURCES. THE ORGANIZATION S LONG TERM GOAL IS FOR THE STOCKWELL WOODS PROPERTY TO BECOME A DEDICATED STATENATURE PRESERVE.THE PARTNERS BIOLOGIST WILL COORDINATE WITH THE LANDOWNER TO DEVELOP A RESTORATION WORK PLAN, CONDUCT AN ON SITEINVESTIGATION PRIOR TO RESTORATION ACTIVITIES, PROVIDE PROJECT OVERSIGHT, AND PERFORM A POST RESTORATION SITEINSPECTION TO VERIFY COMPLETION OF THE HABITAT RESTORATION WORK. THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM WILLPROVIDE  10,585.00 COST SHARE TOWARDS THE TREE THINNING DURING THE WINTER OF 2022 2023 AND THE INVASIVE SPECIESCONTROL IN SUMMER FALL OF 2023. THE LANDOWNER WILL PROVIDE  3,948.00 CASH MATCH TOWARDS THE INVASIVE SPECIESCONTROL IN 2024 AND CONTINUE RESTORATION EFFORTS BEYOND THE SCOPE OF THIS AGREEMENT TO IMPROVE THE WILDLIFE HABITAT VALUE OF THE PROPERTY.

THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO ENHANCE HABITAT AND WATER QUALITY AND PROTECT THE SPRAGUE RIVER STREAMBANK FROM EROSION WITH A COMBINATION OF FENCING, GRADING OF ERODED STREAM BANK, NATIVE RIPARIAN PLANTINGS, AND INSTALLATION OF HARDENED CATTLE CROSSING. SPECIES LIKELY TO BENEFIT FROM THIS PROJECT ARE RESIDENT NATIVE FISH INCLUDING ENDANGERED LOST RIVER (DELTISTES LUXATUS) AND SHORTNOSE SUCKERS (CHASMISTES BREVIROSTRIS), REDBAND TROUT (ONCORHYNCHUS MYKISS GAIRDNERII). FURTHER, MANY SPECIES OF RIPARIAN DEPENDENT AND NEOTROPICAL BIRDS, POLLINATORS, AND OTHER SHRUBBY RIPARIAN HABITAT DEPENDENT SPECIES ARE LIKELY TO BENEFIT FROM THIS PROJECT (E.G. YELLOW BILLED CUCKOO AND MONARCH).EXPECTED OUTCOMES FENCED RIPARIAN AREA   2,000 ERODED STREAM BANK RESTORATION   1,500  RIPARIAN PLANTINGS  3 ACRESCATTLE CROSSING  1

THE LAKE MARION SCRUB HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECT IS IN PARTNERSHIP WITH CONSERVATION FLORIDA AND A PRIVATE CONSERVATION LANDOWNER. THE LAKE MARION PROPERTY IS 700 ACRES, MOSTLY PRISTINE HABITAT DOMINATED BY SCRUBBY UPLANDS ALONG 3  MILES OF THE SHORE OF LAKE MARION IN POLK COUNTY, FLORIDA. THE PROPERTY WAS RECENTLY ACQUIRED BY A CONSERVATION INVESTOR AND IS MANAGED BY CONSERVATION FLORIDA WITH THE INTENT THE PROPERTY WILL BE TRANSFERRED AND MANAGED BY POLK COUNTY NATURAL RESOURCES AS A PRESERVE. WHILE DESCRIBED AS  PRISTINE , PARTS OF THE PROPERTY ARE OVERGROWN DUE TO FIRE SUPPRESSION AND MAY POSE A WILDFIRE RISK. TRESPASSING BY OFF ROAD VEHICLES HAS DISTURBED AREAS OF THE PROPERTY AND ALLOWED SOME INVASIVE SPECIES TO ENCROACH.RESTORATION PRACTICES FOR THIS PROPERTY INCLUDE  MECHANICAL TREATMENT OF OVERGROWN MIDSTORY VIA ROLLER CHOPPING OR CHAINSAW HAND CREWS. INSTALLATION OF FIRE BREAKS VIA DISKING OR MOWING TO PREPARE FOR PRESCRIBED FIRE. IMPLEMENTATION OF PRESCRIBED FIRE TO FURTHER REDUCE MIDSTORY. INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES MANAGEMENT VIA HERBICIDE AND OR MECHANICAL TREATMENT. INSTALLATION OF FENCING AROUND THE PROPERTY TO REDUCE TRESPASSING. REMOVAL OF TRASH FROM PREVIOUS TRESPASSING.REDUCTION OF OVERSTORY AND RE INTRODUCTION OF FIRE INTO SCRUB AND SANDHILL HABITATS ARE KEY TO PROVIDING NEEDED OPEN SAND PATCHES AND LOW SHRUB HABITATS THAT SCRUB JAYS AND OTHER SCRUB OBLIGATE SPECIES DEPEND ON. THE GOAL WILL BE FOR 50 TO 75 PERCENT OF THE AREA TO BE OAKS 1 TO 3M TALL, OPEN PATCHES OF BARE SAND TO COVER 10 TO 30 PERCENT OF THE AREA, AND NO MORE THAN 20 PERCENT CANOPY COVER BY TALLER TREES. THE PRACTICES FOR THIS PROJECT ARE SUPPORTED BY THE FWC S SCRUB MANAGEMENT GUIDELINES (2019) AND THE SOUTH FLORIDA MULTI SPECIES RECOVERY PLAN (SF MSRP, 1999).THE LAKE MARION SCRUB HABITAT RESTORATION PROPERTY CONTAINS AN EXPANSIVE ROSEMARY BALD, A RARE AND SPECIALIZED FORM OF SCRUB ONLY FOUND ON DRIER RIDGE CRESTS. THESE DRY RIDGE CRESTS ARE FREQUENTLY TARGETED FOR DEVELOPMENT, A THREAT TO RECOVERY OF SCRUB OBLIGATE SPECIES.FOCAL SPECIES  FLORIDA SCRUB JAY, FLORIDA SCRUB LIZARD, CARTER S MUSTARD, PYGMY FRINGE TREE, PAPERY WHITLOW WORT, SANDLACE, EASTERN INDIGO SNAKE, SAND SKINK, BLUETAIL MOLE SKINK, SOUTHEASTERN AMERICAN KESTREL, WOOD STORK, GOPHER TORTOISE, MONARCH BUTTERFLY, FLORIDA MOUSE. ALL FOCAL SPECIES ARE LIKELY TO OCCUR BASED ON FLORIDA NATURAL AREAS INDEX (FNAI) DATA AND  ANECDOTAL EVIDENCE FROM SITE VISITS. EXISTING PLANT SITE PROTECTION AND THE IMPLEMENTATION OF HABITAT MANAGEMENT USING APPROPRIATE PRESCRIBED FIRE ARE FACTORS IN THE RECOVERY OF SCRUB OBLIGATE LISTED PLANTS (2019 LAKE WALES RIDGE PLANTS RECOVERY PLAN AMENDMENT, SF MSRP, 2021 5 YEAR REVIEWS). PROTECTION AND RESTORATION OF THIS SITE IS STRONGLY SUPPORTED BY SCRUB JAY SPECIES LEAD TOM MECKLENBORG (EMAIL CORRESPONDENCE, 10 JAN 2022). THIS SITE IS WITHIN UNIT B (LAKE WALES RIDGE NORTH) AS A SUPPORT POPULATION FOR SCRUB JAYS (2019 FLORIDA SCRUB JAY RECOVERY PLAN AMENDMENT).LANDSCAPE CONSERVATION  THE LAKE MARION SCRUB HABITAT RESTORATION PROPERTY IS CONSIDERED AN  OPPORTUNITY AREA  UNDER THE FLORIDA WILDLIFE CORRIDOR PROJECT AND HIGH TO MEDIUM CONSERVATION PRIORITY UNDER THE SOUTHEAST CONSERVATION BLUEPRINT. LAKE MARION SCRUB IS A CRITICAL LINKAGE BETWEEN PROPERTIES OWNED BY THE SOUTH FLORIDA WATER MANAGEMENT DISTRICT (SFWMD), POLK COUNTY, USFWS, AND THE NATURE CONSERVANCY.

THROUGH PARTNERSHIP WITH THE USFWS, CONSERVATION FOUNDATION OF THE GULF COAST (CFGC) WILL RESTORE 45 ACRES OF LONGLEAF PINE FLATWOODS AND 37 ACRES OF MESIC HAMMOCK (82 ACRES TOTAL), LOCATED WITHIN MYAKKA HEADWATERS PRESERVE, A 432 ACRE PRESERVE OWNED AND MANAGED BY CONSERVATION FOUNDATION, LOCATED IN MYAKKA CITY, MANATEE COUNTY, FLORIDA. DOWNSTREAM, THE MYAKKA RIVER IS A STATE DESIGNATED WILD AND SCENIC RIVER. WITHIN THE FLATFORD LANDSCAPE, SURROUNDING FLATWOODS SERVE AS CRITICAL BUFFERS FOR WATER QUALITY, AND THE MIXTURE OF UPLAND AND WETLAND HABITATS ARE IMPORTANT HABITAT FOR SUCH SPECIES AS FOX SQUIRREL, WHO MAKE USE OF MULTIPLE HABITAT TYPES THROUGHOUT THEIR LIFE CYCLE. THIS PROPOSAL WILL RESTORE FLATWOODS AND MESIC HAMMOCK THROUGH HERBICIDE CONTROL OF EXOTIC INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES, MECHANICAL REDUCTION OF EXCESS OVERGROWTH, CREATION OF FIRE LINES, AND RE INTRODUCTION OF PRESCRIBED FIRE. AS A RESULT OF RESTORATION PRACTICES, FIRE WILL BE RE INTRODUCED ON THE LANDSCAPE, THE STRUCTURE OF THE PLANT COMMUNITY MADE MORE OPEN AND FLORISTICALLY DIVERSE, AND THE HABITAT GENERALLY IMPROVED FOR SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN), INCLUDING GOPHER TORTOISE.

THE PROPOSED WORK AREA FOR THIS PROJECT ENCOMPASSES BUCK CREEK IN PULASKI COUNTY AND ROUNDSTONE CREEK IN ROCKCASTLE COUNTY OF KENTUCKY. THE FUNDING PROVIDED THROUGH THIS PROJECT WILL FURTHER EXISTING EFFORTS TO WORK WITH PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AND CONSERVATION PARTNERS IN KENTUCKY THAT ARE INTERESTED IN IMPLEMENTING PROJECTS THAT WOULD RESTORE AND CONSERVE STREAMS, WETLANDS AND OTHER HABITATS THAT BENEFIT FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES. THESE EFFORTS WILL BE SPECIFICALLY DIRECTED TO PROJECTS ON PRIVATE LANDS AND WITH CONSERVATION PARTNERS THAT WOULD PROVIDE CONSERVATION BENEFITS FOR A VARIETY OF FISH AND WILDLIFE SPECIES INCLUDING MIGRATORY BIRDS, FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES AND OTHER AT RISK SPECIES, AS WELL AS, GAME AND NON GAME FISH AND WILDLIFE.SIGNIFICANT INVOLVEMENT THE USFWS PROJECT OFFICER WITH BE SUBSTANTIALLY INVOLVED IN ALL ASPECTS OF THIS PROJECT WITH SHARED PERFORMANCE RESPONSIBILITIES.TO INCLUDE, REVIEW AND APPROVE PROPOSED MODIFICATIONS OR SUB AWARDS, RESERVE THE RIGHT TO IMMEDIATELY HALT AN ACTIVITY OR REDIRECT THE WORK BECAUSE OF INTERRELATIONSHIPS WITH OTHER PROJECTS, PLANNING, BUDGETING, PROJECT DESIGN, IMPLEMENTATION, AND LIMIT RECIPIENT DISCRETION WITH RESPECT TO SCOPE OF WORK, MODE OF OPERATIONS AND OTHER MANAGEMENT PROCESSES.THE RECIPIENT WILL IDENTIFY AND REVIEW PROJECT PROPOSALS, ENGAGE IN PROJECT DEVELOPMENT, PROJECT PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION. PAY INVOICES AS REQUIRED AFTER COMPLETION OF PROJECTS.

THE CENTERTON LAKE DAM WAS LOWERED IN DECEMBER 2009 BY ORDER OF NJDEP DAM SAFETY AS IT WAS CRITICALLY WEAKENED BY TORRENTIAL RAIN. THE DAM BREACHED ON AUGUST 14, 2011, RESULTING IN SEVERE EROSION OF THE EMBANKMENT. THE IMPOUNDMENT REMAINS IN A LOWERED CONDITION AND THERE CONTINUES TO BE A SMALL DIFFERENCE IN WATER SURFACE ELEVATION (1  2 FEET) UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM OF THE DAM. CITIZENS UNITED TO PROTECT THE MAURICE RIVER AND ITS TRIBUTARIES, INC. (CU MAURICE RIVER) HAS BEEN WORKING TO CONNECT THE LANDOWNERS, A HOMEOWNERS ASSOCIATION, WITH RESOURCES FOR THE EVENTUAL REMOVAL OF THE EXTANT STRUCTURE. WHILE FUNDING RESOURCES EXIST FOR A FUTURE REMOVAL PROJECT, FIRST A FEASIBILITY STUDY NEEDS TO BE RENDERED IN ORDER TO SECURE SAID FUNDING. THE CENTERTON LAKE DAM IS A BLOCKAGE FOR DIADROMOUS FISH FROM REACHING HISTORIC SPAWNING AND REARING GROUNDS.

THROUGH PARTNERSHIP WITH USFWS, CONSERVATION FOUNDATION OF THE GULF COAST WILL RESTORE 46 ACRES OF PASTURELAND WITHIN THE 230 ACRE PINE ISLAND PRESERVE AT MATLACHA PASS, A COMMUNITY RESOURCE AND NATURE PRESERVE ON PINE ISLAND IN LEE COUNTY, FLORIDA. THE PASTURE WILL BE RESTORED TO PINE FLATWOODS HABITAT THAT WILL EXPAND EXISTING, CONNECTED FLATWOODS HABITAT TO OVER 240 ACRES, SPANNING MULTIPLE PRESERVES. THE PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON ESTABLISHING GROUNDCOVER WITHIN THE 46 ACRE PASTURE SITE  FIRST, BY REMOVING PASTURE GRASSES AND UNDESIRABLE PLANTS WITH HERBICIDE AND MECHANICAL TREATMENTS, AND SECOND, BY DIRECT SEEDING FIELD COLLECTED GRASSES TO RESTORE THE GROUNDCOVER COMPONENT OF THE FLATWOODS. PRESCRIBED FIRE WILL BE APPLIED EVERY 3 4 YEARS, OR AT LEAST ONCE WITHIN THE FUNDING PERIOD. THE PASTURE RESTORATION AREA WILL CONNECT SEAMLESSLY WITH EXISTING FLATWOODS AND PRIOR RESTORATION AREAS, EXPANDING HABITAT. ALL WORK WILL BE SUPERVISED AND MANAGED BY STAFF BIOLOGISTS AT CONSERVATION FOUNDATION. PINE ISLAND PRESERVE AT MATLACHA PASS IS A 230 ACRE PUBLIC PARK AND NATURE PRESERVE SERVING AS TRAIL HEAD FOR LEE COUNTY S 190 ACRE PINE ISLAND FLATWOODS PRESERVE, 173 ACRES OF CALUSA LAND TRUST PRESERVES, AND PUBLIC WATER ACCESS TO MATLACHA PASS NWR, CHARLOTTE HARBOR PRESERVE STATE PARK, AND MATLACHA PASS AQUATIC PRESERVE. IT IS IDENTIFIED AS HIGH VALUE CONSERVATION AREA WITHIN THE SOUTHEAST CONSERVATION BLUEPRINT 2020. INVESTMENTS FROM THE USFWS WILL BENEFIT EASTERN INDIGO SNAKE AND GOPHER TORTOISE FOUND ONSITE, AS WELL AS MANY OTHER SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED.

THE PROJECT AREA  BOONE VALLEY WILDLIFE AREA  FOR THIS AGREEMENT IS LOCATED WITHIN THE IOWA WETLAND MANAGEMENT DISTRICT AND THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM S PRAIRIE POTHOLE FOCUS AREA.WETLAND RESTORATION AT THE BOONE VALLEY WILDLIFE AREA WILL INCLUDE TILES SEARCHES, TILE BREAKS, SHALLOW WATER EXCAVATIONS, INSTALLATION OF A DIKE AND WATER CONTROL STRUCTURE, AND REPAIRING AGRICULTURAL EROSION TO RESTORE UP TO 8 ACRES OF PRAIRIE POTHOLE WETLANDS. COMPLETION OF THESE PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL IMPROVE DEGRADED WETLAND HABITAT THAT WAS PREVIOUSLY FARMED AND HAS FILLED WITH POST-SETTLEMENT ALLUVIUM  PSA  TO RESTORE THE AQUATICRESOURCE FUNCTION OF OFF-CHANNEL AND PRAIRIE POTHOLE WETLAND HABITAT ADJACENT TO THE PRAIRIE CREEK  BOONERIVER  TO BENEFIT WATERFOWL AND OTHER MIGRATORY BIRDS. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO BENEFIT THE PUBLIC THAT USES THE SITE FOR OUTDOOR RECREATION ACTIVITIES.

FEDERAL GOVERNMENT AGENCIES AND PARTNERS, LIKE THE DESERT BOTANICAL GARDEN  DBG , ARE COLLABORATING TO INCREASE THE SUPPLY OF NATIVE SEEDS FOR RESTORATION THROUGH THE NATIONAL SEED STRATEGY FOR REHABILITATION AND RESTORATION  NATIONAL SEED STRATEGY  TO GET THE RIGHT SEED IN THE RIGHT PLACE AT THE RIGHT TIME  THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS THE NATIONAL SEED STRATEGY WHICH IS A PUBLIC PRIVATE COLLABORATION TO INCREASE THE SUPPLY OF NATIVE SEEDS FOR RESTORATION PROJECTS TO ENSURE ECOSYSTEM RESILIENCE AND THE HEALTH AND PROSPERITY OF FUTURE GENERATIONS  THIS PROJECT WILL COLLECT, AMPLIFY, AND BANK SEEDS OF CAREFULLY SELECTED LOCALLY SOURCED NATIVE PLANTS OF ARIZONA  THE SERVICE, THE SOUTHWEST SEED PARTNERSHIP, THE DBG, AND THE ARBORETUM AT FLAGSTAFF  THE ARBORETUM  WILL WORK TOGETHER TO PRODUCE A TARGET LIST OF PLANTS  DBG, WITH ITS SUBCONTRACTOR THE ARBORETUM, PROPOSES TO VISIT AREAS THAT ARE LIKELY TO BE AFFECTED BY FIRE IN THE COMING YEARS TO COLLECT SEED AND THEN GROW PLANTS TO PRODUCE ADDITIONAL SEED OF KNOWN ECOTYPE  DBG AND THE ARBORETUM WILL INCORPORATE TRIAL PARTNERS AND LANDS WHERE POSSIBLE IN COLLECTING AND GROW OUTS  DBG AND THE ARBORETUM WILL USE THE SEEDS OF SUCCESS COLLECTION PROTOCOLS OR THE MORE CONSERVATIVE CPC GUIDELINES  DBG AND FWS WILL COORDINATE WITH SOUTHWEST SEED PARTNERSHIP, USFS, BLM, TRIBES, AND OTHERS AS NECESSARY TO ENSURE SEED COLLECTION COORDINATION ACROSS THE STATE  THE SOUTHWEST SEED PARTNERSHIP IS AN ESTABLISHED SEED COLLECTION AND TRACKING ENTITY THAT WILL PROVIDE GUIDANCE FOR THE PROJECT  DBG AND THE ARBORETUM WILL FOCUS ON COLLECTING SEEDS OF PERENNIAL AND ANNUAL FORBS, GRASSES, AND SHRUBS THAT PROVIDE HOST PLANTS AND NECTAR FOR POLLINATORS AND HABITAT FOR OTHER SPECIES  IN ADDITION, DBG AND THE ARBORETUM WILL WORK TO COLLECT AND GROW OUT SEEDS OF SELECT RARE AND LISTED PLANTS THAT GROW IN FIRE PRONE REGIONS WHERE POPULATIONS MAY BE DESTROYED BY FIRE

THE PROJECT OBJECTIVE IS TO CONSTRUCT A POOL AND WEIR FISHWAY AT THE CROOKED BROOK DAM ON BASKAHEGAN STREAM IN THE TOWN OF DANFORTH, MAINE  A SECONDARY OBJECTIVE IS TO IMPROVE PUBLIC ACCESS AND RECREATION OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE LOCAL COMMUNITY AT THE SITE AND TO MAINTAIN THE 20 YEAR MOMENTUM TO REBUILD SEA RUN FISHERIES THROUGHOUT THEIR HISTORIC RANGE IN THE PENOBSCOT WATERSHED  THIS PROJECT CONTINUES SEVERAL DECADES OF FISHERIES RESTORATION WORK IN THE PENOBSCOT RIVER AND IS THE MOST SIGNIFICANT HABITAT CONNECTIVITY PROJECT UNDERTAKEN TO DATE IN THE UPPER WATERSHED  THE FISHWAY WILL RECONNECT 137 STREAM MILES AND 8,960 ACRES OF POND AND LAKE HABITAT FOR ATLANTIC SALMON, ALEWIVES, BLUEBACK HERRING, SEA LAMPREY, AMERICAN EEL, AND EASTERN BROOK TROUT  GIVEN THE VAST AMOUNT OF HABITAT THAT WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE, IT IS ESTIMATED THAT A RUN OF UP TO 2 MILLION ADULT ALEWIVES AND BLUEBACK HERRING WILL BE PRODUCED ANNUALLY AS A RESULT OF THE PROJECT  IN ADDITION, ENDANGERED ATLANTIC SALMON WILL GAIN ACCESS TO AN ESTIMATED 557 UNITS OF SPAWNING AND REARING HABITAT ABOVE THE DAM AND AMERICAN EEL WILL GET IMPROVED ACCESS TO A HUGE AREA OF REARING HABITAT

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS GRANT AGREEMENT IS TO SUPPORT THE ANNUAL LONE STAR LAND STEWARD PROGRAM.ON MAY 26, 2022, TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT AND ITS PARTNERS WILL CELEBRATE THE 26TH ANNUAL LONE STAR LAND STEWARD AWARDS AT THE HYATT REGENCY IN AUSTIN. THE LONE STAR LAND STEWARD AWARDS RECOGNIZE PRIVATE LANDOWNERS IN TEXAS FOR THEIR CONTRIBUTIONS TO LAND, WATER, AND WILDLIFE STEWARDSHIP IN TEXAS, APPROXIMATELY 94 PERCENT OF LAND IS PRIVATELY OWNED, AND THE PARTICIPATION OF PRIVATE LANDOWNERS IS ESSENTIAL TO THE CONTINUED SUCCESS OF NATURAL RESOURCE AND CONSERVATION PROGRAMS. ESTABLISHED IN 1996, THE LONE STAR LAND STEWARD AWARDS PROGRAM RECOGNIZES AND HONORS PRIVATE LANDOWNERS IN TEXAS FOR THEIR VOLUNTARY CONTRIBUTIONS TO HABITAT ENHANCEMENT, WILDLIFE CONSERVATION, AND NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT.THE PROGRAM SUPPORTS PRESIDENT BIDEN'S "AMERICA THE BEAUTIFUL" INITIATIVE BY PURSUING A COLLABORATIVE AND INCLUSIVE APPROACH TO CONSERVATION THROUGH EDUCATING LANDOWNERS AND THE PUBLIC ABOUT THE IMPORTANCE OF TEXAS' NATURAL RESOURCES. ALSO, BY SUPPORTING LOCALLY LED AND LOCALLY DESIGNED CONSERVATION EFFORTS THROUGH NATURAL RESOURCES AGENCIES SUCH AS THE USFWS'S PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM. LASTLY,THIS PROGRAM ALSO SUPPORTS BIDEN'S INITIATIVE BY HONORING PRIVATE PROPERTY RIGHTS, SUPPORTING THE VOLUNTARY STEWARDSHIP EFFORTS OF PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AND ENCOURAGING VOLUNTARY PARTICIPATION IN HABITAT CONSERVATION,AND PROMOTING SUSTAINABLE LAND MANAGEMENT.THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) WILL NOT BE SUBSTANTIALLY INVOLVED IN THE LONE STAR LAND STEWARD AWARDS PROGRAM; HOWEVER, THE USFWS WILL PROVIDE $10,000 OF FEDERAL FUNDS AS A GRANT FOR PROGRAM SUPPORT TO DEVELOP OUTREACH AND PROMOTIONAL (PRINT AND VIDEO) MATERIALS FOR THE EVENT.

THIS IS A FEDERAL PASS-THROUGH GRANT FROM THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE IN THE AMOUNT OF $1,123,562. THE DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE MAY USE UP TO 2.5% OF THE TOTAL GRANT FOR ADMINISTRATION OF THE PROGRAM WITH THE REMAINDER DIVIDED AMONG THE 14 REGIONAL FISHERIES ENHANCEMENT GROUPS. THE RFEG PORTION OF THE GRANT WILL BE USED FOR PROGRAM ADMINISTRATION, SALMON/STEELHEAD ENHANCEMENT, HABITAT RESTORATION, AND EDUCATION AND OUTREACH.ALL PROJECTS CONDUCTED WITH THESE FUNDS ARE ALLOWED UNDER WASHINGTON STATE'S ENABLING LEGISLATION FOR THE RFEGS AS SPECIFIED IN RCW 77.95. ENHANCEMENT PROJECTS INCLUDE SALMON HABITAT RESTORATION AND ARE DEFINED BY WASHINGTON STATE LAWS AS: ". . . SALMON PROPAGATION ACTIVITIES INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, HATCHERIES, SPAWNING CHANNELS, REARING PONDS, EGG BOXES, FISHWAYS, FISH SCREENS, STREAM BED CLEARING, EROSION CONTROL, HABITAT RESTORATION, NET PENS, APPLIED RESEARCH PROJECTS AND EQUIPMENT, REAL PROPERTY OR OTHER INTEREST NECESSARY TO THE PROPER OPERATION THEREOF.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT THE ENHANCEMENT AND MAINTENANCE OF THE ONLINE SALMON RECOVERY PORTAL (SRP) DATA SYSTEM THAT TRACKS AND REPORTS PLANNED, ACTIVE AND COMPLETED SALMON RECOVERY PROJECTS THROUGHOUT WASHINGTON.SRP IS A VITAL TOOL FOR PLANNING AND REPORTING SALMON RECOVERY EFFORTS. SALMON RECOVERY ORGANIZATIONS USE SRP TO PLAN, TRACK, PRIORITIZE, SEQUENCE, AND REPORT SALMON RECOVERY PROJECTS THAT MEET HABITAT PROTECTION AND RECOVERY GOALS FOR MULTIPLE SALMON SPECIES INCLUDING THOSE LISTED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. SRP PROJECT DATA IS REPORTED IN THE BIENNIAL STATE OF SALMON IN WATERSHEDS REPORT AND WEBSITE. WE ALSO SHOWCASE PROJECT ACCOMPLISHMENTS AND THE NEED FOR CONTINUED FUNDING FOR SALMON RECOVERY AS PART OF THE EFFORT TO RECOVER SOUTHERN RESIDENT KILLER WHALES. BY REPORTING DIRECTLY FROM SRP AND AGENCY AFFILIATED WEBSITES, WE ARE ABLE TO PROVIDE TRANSPARENCY AND ACCOUNTABILITY OF SALMON RECOVERY BY SHOWING PLANNED AND COMPLETED PROJECTS IN A CONSISTENT AND PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE WAY. THIS IS CRITICAL INFORMATION TO SHARE THE PROGRESS OF RECOVERING THESE IMPORTANT ESA-LISTED SPECIES AND SHOW THE PUBLIC WHAT NEEDS TO BE DONE IN THE FUTURE.

FUNDS WILL SUPPORT THE RECIPIENT OF TROUT UNLIMITED S TROUT IN THE CLASSROOM  TIC  PROGRAM  TIC IS AN ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PROGRAM IN WHICH STUDENTS IN GRADES 4 THROUGH 12 RAISE RAINBOW TROUT FROM EGGS TO FRY, MONITOR TANK WATER QUALITY, ENGAGE IN STREAM HABITAT STUDY, LEARN TO APPRECIATE WATER RESOURCES, BEGIN TO FOSTER A CONSERVATION ETHIC, AND GROW TO UNDERSTAND ECOSYSTEMS  STUDENTS OF ALL AGES HAVE A CHANCE TO RAISE TROUT IN THE CLASSROOM SETTING  DURING THE EIGHT MONTHS THAT CLASSES SPEND RAISING TROUT, THEY CLOSELY MONITOR WATER TEMPERATURE, WATER CLARITY, DISSOLVED OXYGEN, AMMONIA LEVELS, AND PH  BECAUSE TROUT ARE EXTREMELY SENSITIVE TO CHANGES IN THEIR ENVIRONMENT, STUDENTS LEARN THE IMPORTANCE OF CLEAN WATER AND ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION  TIC BRINGS NATURE INTO THE CLASSROOM AND ALLOWS STUDENTS TO DEVELOP A PERSONAL INTEREST AND A SENSE OF THE CONVERSATION ETHICS THAT ARE AT THE CORE OF TROUT UNLIMITED S MISSION THE RECIPIENT WILL CONTINUE TO USE THE PROCESSES IN PLACE TO CHOOSE SCHOOLS TO PARTICIPATE IN THE PROGRAM  FUNDS FROM THIS GRANT WILL HELP THE RECIPIENT TO PURCHASE SUPPLIES NEEDED TO RAISE TROUT AT A SCHOOL LOCATION  SUPPLIES NEEDED INCLUDE AN AQUARIUM, FILTER, CHILLER, PUMP, AIR STONE, EGG BASKET, THERMOMETER, AQUARIUM HOOD, AQUARIUM STAND AND OTHER MISCELLANEOUS ACCESSORIES AND SUPPLIES  LOCAL TROUT UNLIMITED VOLUNTEERS SECURE EGGS FROM THE ARIZONA GAME AND FISH DEPARTMENT, FOOD FOR THE FISH, HELP SET UP AND MAINTAIN EQUIPMENT, PROVIDE GUEST SPEAKERS IN THE CLASSES ABOUT ALL SORTS OF TOPICS, AND HELP ORGANIZE OUTDOOR FISHING OPPORTUNITIES  IF POSSIBLE   IT IS ANTICIPATED FUNDS WILL HELP BRING TIC TO THREE ADDITIONAL CLASSROOMS IN ARIZONA IN THE UPCOMING SCHOOL YEAR
