THIS PROJECT WILL PROTECT 9,800 FEET OF DELTA WATERWAY AND FACILITATE THE RESTORATION OF 11.5 ACRES OF RIPARIAN UNDERSTORY HABITAT. THE PROJECT WILL PREVENT CATTLE FROM CAUSING INPUTS OF SEDIMENT AND BACTERIA TO THE STREAM, AND WILL ULTIMATELY CREATE A DIVERSE UNDERSTORY OF POLLINATOR HABITAT. THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES ARE PLANNED TO BE IMPLEMENTED FENCING TO EXCLUDE CATTLE   27,916 FEET (5.3 MILES). 12,250  WERE INSTALLED ALONG THE WATERWAY IN FEBRUARY 2022. REMAINDER OF THE FENCING (NORTH SIDE OF THE STREAM AND THE CROSS FENCING) IS TO BE INSTALLED BY NOVEMBER 2022.CATTLE WATERING TROUGHS   6 TOTAL. INSTALLED JANUARY 2022. THIS INSTALLATION INCLUDED PIPELINES TO THE TROUGHS AND REINFORCEMENT OF HEAVY USE AREAS FOR CATTLE ACCESS TO THE TROUGHS. GRAZING MANAGEMENT PLAN   IN PROGRESS WITH NRCS AND POINT BLUE CONSERVATION SCIENCE, TO BE COMPLETED BY NOVEMBER 2022.VEGETATED WATERWAY   PLANS IN PROGRESS WITH SOLANO RCD FWS, AND SCWA. FUNDING EXPECTED TO BE UNDER CONTRACT BY MAY 2023 (FROM THE CA WILDLIFE CONSERVATION BOARD), TO BE INSTALLED IN FALL 2023 OR FALL 2024. THIS WILL CREATE 11.5 ACRES OF NATIVE POLLINATOR AND RIPARIAN HABITAT.

THIS NEW AGREEMENT ALLOCATES A TOTAL OF  490,408 00 IN U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE GRANT FUNDING   200,970 FROM THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM   289,438 FROM THE FISH PASSAGE PROGRAM  DURING FY 2022 TO SUPPORT THE MULTIYEAR UPPER COOSA RIVER BASIN INITIATIVE  THE INITIATIVE HAS BEEN WORKING CLOSELY WITH THE PARTNERSHIPS FOR THE UPPER COOSA GROUP TO PLAN AND IMPLEMENT RESTORATION PROJECTS DESIGNED TO MINIMIZE MULTIPLE STRESSORS AND FACILITATE THE RECOVERY OF FEDERALLY LISTED AND AT RISK AQUATIC FISH AND MUSSEL SPECIES OCCURRING IN THE COOSA RIVER BASIN IN GEORGIA AND TENNESSEE  THE FY 2022 FUNDING WILL BE USED TO SUPPORT A TOTAL OF FIVE NEW PROJECTS THAT WILL LIKELY BE IMPLEMENTED DURING FY 2022 2023  THESE PROJECTS INCLUDE THE WARD FAMILY STREAM AND UPLAND RESTORATION PROJECT, JONES FAMILY STREAM RESTORATION PROJECT, YELLOW CREEK PINEY HILL ROAD CULVERT REPLACEMENT PROJECT, ROCK CREEK MCGILL CULVERT REPLACEMENT PROJECT, AND CITY OF DALTON RIPARIAN RESTORATION PROJECT  EACH OF THESE PROJECTS WILL UNDERGO BOTH IMPLEMENTATION AND EFFECTIVENESS MONITORING USING STANDARDIZED AND SCIENTIFICALLY DEFENSIBLE DESIGNS WORKING IN COLLABORATION WITH THE USFWS, GEORGIA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, AND UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA STAFF  THE PLANNED PROJECTS WILL BE DESIGNED TO HELP RESTORE NATURAL THERMAL AND FLOW REGIMES, REDUCE ANTHROPOGENIC SEDIMENTATION NUTRIFICATION AND OTHER FORMS OF CONTAMINATION, RECONNECT FRAGMENTED AQUATIC HABITATS, AND IMPROVE HABITAT COMPLEXITY AND QUALITY IN THE UPPER COOSA RIVER BASIN  ADDITIONALLY, THE PROJECTS WILL HELP BOLSTER PUBLIC EDUCATION AND OUTREACH ON AQUATIC CONSERVATION  THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES FROM THESE PROJECTS INCLUDE INCREASING OR MAINTAINING THE OCCUPANCY OR ABUNDANCE OF FEDERALLY LISTED OR AT RISK SPECIES IN REACHES OR AREAS WHERE RESTORATION OCCURS, IMPROVING AQUATIC HABITAT OCCURRING WITHIN AND DOWNSTREAM OF RESTORATION SITES, AND INCREASING PUBLIC INTEREST IN STREAM RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION  IF THE PLANNED PROJECTS ARE UNABLE TO BE IMPLEMENTED FOR UNFORESEEN REASONS, THE COOSA RIVER BASIN INITIATIVE WILL DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A COMPARABLE PROJECT S  ELSEWHERE IN THE UPPER COOSA RIVER BASIN

SOLANO RCD ACTIVELY ENGAGES FARMERS AND RANCHERS THROUGHOUT SOLANO COUNTY TO PLAN AND IMPLEMENT NATIVE HABITAT RESTORATION AND AGRICULTURAL BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES ON THEIR PROPERTIES. THIS PROJECT WILL   CREATION OF 4 MILES OF RIPARIAN HABITAT AND 80 ACRES OF RIPARIAN POLLINATOR UPLAND HABITAT.  PROVIDE A MINIMUM OF 6 LANDOWNERS WITH TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND CONSERVATION PLANS THAT DETAIL SITE SPECIFIC RECOMMENDATIONS FOR PLANTING PLANS AND PROTOCOLS, MAINTENANCE REGIMES, AND INTEGRATION WITH CURRENT AGRICULTURAL OPERATIONS.SERVICE WILL DEVELOP LANDOWNER WORK PLANS WITH PROPERTY OWNERS FOR EACH PROJECT. PLANS WILL INCLUDE, AS APPROPRIATE, SUMMARIES OF WORK TO BE PERFORMED, TIMEFRAMES FOR IMPLEMENTATION AND MANAGEMENT OF THE PROJECT FOR THE DURATION OF THE 10 YEAR (OR LONGER) LANDOWNER AGREEMENTS. EACH PROJECT WILL NOT EXCEED  70,000 FEDERAL CONTRIBUTION UNLESS SPECIFICALLY AUTHORIZED BEFOREHAND. A. OBTAIN A SIGNED LANDOWNER AGREEMENT THAT SHALL BE IN EFFECT FOR NOT LESS THAN 10 YEARS AND SHALL BE EXECUTED PRIOR TO COMMENCEMENT OF IMPLEMENTATION OF ACTIVITIES.2. PROVIDE BIOLOGICAL AND TECHNICAL ADVICE IN PROJECT PLANNING, DESIGN, IMPLEMENTATION, MONITORING AND MAINTENANCE OF FUNDED PROJECTS.3. ENSURE THAT THE PROJECT COMPLIES WITH THE FOLLOWING FEDERAL LAWS AND REGULATIONS  A. SECTION 106 OF THE NATIONAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION ACT B. NATIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY ACT C. ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT D. SECTION 404 OF THE CLEAN WATER ACT E. SECTION 10 OF THE RIVERS AND HARBORS ACT4. PROVIDE CONFIRMATION OF COMPLIANCE WITH THE ABOVE TO THE LANDOWNERS FOR IMPLEMENTATION ACTIVITIES TO BEGIN ON THE PROJECT.5. ASSIST THE LANDOWNER(S), AS NEEDED, IN PREPARING PROJECT PERMIT APPLICATIONS AS REQUIRED UNDER LOCAL, STATE, OR FEDERAL LAWS AND REGULATIONS.6. COORDINATE WITH SOLANO RESOURCE CONSERVATION DISTRICT TO APPROVE PROJECTS THAT HAVE BEEN COMPLETED FOR REIMBURSEMENT.7. ASSIST COOPERATOR WITH PREPARING PROJECT SUMMARY REPORTS FOR THE PROJECT AS OUTLINED IN THE REPORTING REQUIREMENTS SECTION.8. RETAIN FINAL APPROVAL AUTHORITY OVER ALL LANDOWNER AGREEMENTS UNDER THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT.9. COORDINATE WITH ALL PROJECT PARTICIPANTS, INCLUDING THE LANDOWNER(S), AND NOTIFY EACH PARTICIPANT THAT IMPLEMENTATION ACTIVITIES CAN BEGIN ONCE ALL APPROPRIATE LOCAL, STATE, AND FEDERAL PERMITS AND CLEARANCES HAVE BEEN OBTAINED.10. MONITOR PROJECTS FOR COMPLIANCE WITH THE HABITAT RETENTION PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE LANDOWNER AGREEMENT.COOPERATOR WILL  1. SERVE AS ADMINISTRATOR OF DISBURSEMENT OF THE USFWS S COST SHARE FOR ACTIVITIES RELATING TO PROJECT COMPLETION. 2. WORK COOPERATIVELY WITH THE USFWS TO CARRY OUT THIS AGREEMENT TO PARTICIPATE IN FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT RESTORATION ACTIVITIES TO BE CONDUCTED ON PRIVATE LANDS THAT ARE APPROVED BY THE USFWS. 3. MAINTAIN PROPER BOOKS, RECORDS, AND ACCOUNTS OF ALL SPECIFIC PROJECT EXPENDITURES FOR THE PROJECT. (THE USFWS MUST HAVE THE RIGHT TO REVIEW THE APPROPRIATE DOCUMENTATION TO VERIFY PROJECT EXPENDITURES UPON A 30 DAY NOTICE IN WRITING FROM THE USFWS.) 4. ADMINISTER THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT AND ANY OTHER CONTRACTS OR SERVICES REQUIRED TO SUCCESSFULLY COMPLETE THE PROJECT.PROJECT TIMELINETHE TIMELINE FOR THIS PROJECT ARE AS FOLLOWS  FALL  WINTER 2022 TO LATE SUMMER WINTER 2023  IDENTIFY PROJECT PARTNERS AND DEVELOP PROJECT SPECIFICS AND WORKPLANS SPRING 2023 TO SPRING 2024  FINALIZE PROJECT WORKPLANS, WORK WITH PARTNERS TO SECURE ANY NEEDED ADDITIONAL FUNDING, AND OBTAIN REQUIRED ENVIRONMENTAL COMPLIANCE PERMITS FOR THE PROJECT. SUMMER 2024 TO SUMMER FALL 2027  DELIVER PROJECT FOLLOWED BY MONITORING AND MAINTENANCE AS NEEDED.

THE SAN JOAQUIN VALLEY AND SURROUNDING REGIONS OF SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA HOST MANY RARE AND VULNERABLE SPECIES, INCLUDING SENSITIVE WILDLIFE ENDEMIC TO THE REGION, SUCH AS THE SAN JOAQUIN KIT FOX, CALIFORNIA CONDOR, BURROWING OWLS, AMPHIBIANS, REPTILES, MIGRATORY BIRDS, POLLINATORS, AND MANY LOCAL SPECIES  MOST OF THESE ANIMALS SUFFER FROM HABITAT LOSS AND FRAGMENTATION, THIS HABITAT IMPROVEMENT PROJECT WILL RESTORE APPROXIMATELY 55 ACRES OF RIPARIAN HABITAT AND GRASSLAND, BY PROVIDING RIPARIAN FENCING, AND INSTALLING PIPELINES, TROUGHS, TANKS, AND ASSOCIATED MATERIALS NEEDED TO MANAGE CONSERVATION GRAZING, ANNUAL GRASSES  AND PLANTING NATIVE RIPARIAN VEGETATION TO IMPROVE HABITAT DIVERSITY AND STRATIFICATION WITHIN THE RIPARIAN CORRIDOR  THE ACTIVELY GRAZED  RANCH PROVIDES SUITABLE HABITAT FOR SEVERAL RARE AND UNIQUE SPECIES INCLUDING SAN JOAQUIN KIT FOX, GOLDEN EAGLES, POND TURTLES, BURROWING OWLS, CALIFORNIA CONDOR, CALIFORNIA RED LEGGED FROG, AND CALIFORNIA TIGER SALAMANDERS  THE PRIMARY USE OF THE LAND IS CATTLE PRODUCTION, FOR WHICH THE RANCH IS WORKING TO IMPLEMENT A CONSERVATION GRAZING PLAN, WHICH WILL IMPROVE CONSERVATION STRATEGIES AND RANCH OPERATIONS   THIS RIPARIAN FENCING AND HABITAT IMPROVEMENT PROJECT WILL PROVIDE FURTHER ENHANCEMENTS BY ENCLOSING FENCING APPROXIMATELY 20 ACRES OF RIPARIAN AREA, WHICH INCLUDES APPROXIMATELY 0 8 MILES OF ACTIVE STREAM CHANNEL  THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM PROJECT WILL IMPROVE THIS NATIVE GRASSLAND RIPARIAN HABITAT WHILE CREATING OPPORTUNITIES TO PROMOTE CONSERVATION GRAZING NEEDED TO BENEFIT MANY PLANTS AND ANIMALS IN THE AREA  INCLUDING USE BY BOTH PERMANENT AND MIGRATORY WILDLIFE, FROM BIRDS AND MAMMALS TO AQUATIC SPECIES, AND INSECTS

THIS PROJECT IS A COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE S, PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE, INDIAN NATIONS CONSERVATION ALLIANCE, AND IS ENTERED INOT PURSUANT TO AUTHORITY CONTAINED IN THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE ACT OF 1956  P.L. 109-294 , THE FISH AND WILDLIFE COORDINATION ACT  16 U.S.C. 661 ET SEQ.  AND THE FISH AND WILDLIFE ACT OF 1956  16 U.S.C. 7421-J , AS AMENDED. THE SCOPE OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS TO ENHANCE HABITAT FOR FEDERAL TURST SPECIES BY PROVIDING FUNDING TO INDIAN NATIONS CONSERVATION ALLIANCE T WORK WITH PRIVATE LANDOWNERS, PROJECTS WILL IMPLEMENT BEST GRAZING AND RANGE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES TO ADDRESS RESOURCE CONCERNS, INCLUDING UPLAND AND RIPARIAN RESOURCES. THIS AGREEMENT AIMS TO RESTORE, ENHANCE, AND OR ESTABLISH TERRESTRIAL AND AQUATIC HABITATS THAT BENEFIT FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES, SPECIES OF SPECIAL CONCERN, AND OTHER WILDLIFE IN ARIZON. IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT AT LEAST 2 SUBRECIPIENT AGREEMENTS WILL BE COMPLETED UNDER THIS AGREEMENT. PROJECTS WILL OCCUR ON TRIBAL LANDS IN ARIZONA AND WILL BE COMPLETED WITHIN FIVE YEARS. ALL ENVIRONMENTAL COMPLIANCE DOCUMENTS WILL BE COMPLETED BEFORE ON-THE GROUND WORK IS TO BE BEGIN.

THIS PROJECT WORKS WITH THE A PRIVATE PROPERTY OWNERS NEAR THE SONNY BONO SALTON SEA NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE TO IMPROVE SEASONAL WETLAND HABITAT  THE MAIN PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE A PORTION OF THE PROPERTY THAT WAS USED TO BARROW SOIL IN ORDER TO GET MATERIAL FOR A SEA WALL  IN THIS PROJECT, WE WILL WORK WITH THE LANDOWNER TO ENSURE THAT THE WATER IS BEING DELIVERED AND MOVED ACROSS THE DUCK CLUB S SEASONAL WETLAND TO FLUSH SALT FROM THE SOIL AND IMPROVE THE GROWING CONDITIONS  AFTER THE FIRST SEASON OF FLOODING, THE LANDOWNER WILL PLANT THE SEASONAL WETLANDS WITH SEEDS TYPICALLY USED FOR WETLAND HABITAT IN THE SALTON SEA AS THE SITE REVEGETATES, WE EXPECT THAT SOME INVASIVE, NON NATIVE PLANTS SUCH AS TAMARISK  SALT CEDAR  WILL SPROUT  THE LANDOWNER WILL CONTROL INVASIVE PLANTS SO THAT THEY DO NOT BECOME ESTABLISHED  AS A RESULT OF THIS PROJECT WE HOPE TO HAVE AN ADDITIONAL SEASONAL WETLAND THAT PROVIDES HABITAT FOR WATERFOWL AND SHOREBIRDS AND SUPPORTS THE CONSERVATION EFFORTS OF THE ADJACENT NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE

THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS A COLLABORATIVE EFFORT BETWEEN PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE, THE WETLANDS INITIATIVE  TWI , AND A PRIVATE LANDOWNER IN LIVINGSTON COUNTY, ILLINOIS  THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT A RESTORED WETLAND VIA A SCRAPE AND A SMALL, CREATED WETLAND FOR AGRICULTURAL TILE DRAINAGE WATER TREATMENT ON PRIVATE FARMLAND  BOTH WETLANDS WILL PROVIDE WATER QUALITY IMPROVEMENT AND BENEFITS FOR WATERFOWL, WILDLIFE, AND POLLINATORS  THE 12 3 ACRE PROJECT CONSISTS OF A 0 58 ACRE WETLAND SCRAPE ON THE NORTH BANK FLOODPLAIN OF AN UNNAMED TRIBUTARY OF THE MAZON RIVER AND A 2 01 ACRE CREATED WETLAND ON THE SOUTH BANK FLOODPLAIN  THE GOAL IS TO DEMONSTRATE THE SUCCESSFUL DEPLOYMENT OF TWO WETLAND PRACTICES AT ONCE TO MEET MULTIPLE RESOURCE CONSERVATION OBJECTIVES

WITH LESS THAN 15 PERCENT OF THE FLORIDA NATIVE PRAIRIE HABITAT REMAINING AND AN EVER INCREASING HUMAN POPULATION, IT IS CRUCIAL TO PROVIDE HABITAT MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS AND FLEXIBLE FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE THAT SPANS THE LANDSCAPE AND BENEFITS MANY PARTNERS AND ADJACENT HABITATS  THIS PROJECT IS BEING PROPOSED TO 1  RESTORE NATIVE VEGETATION WITHIN FLATWOODS, PRAIRIES AND HAMMOCKS THROUGH INVASIVE PLANT TREATMENT, MOWING, ROLLER CHOPPING, PRESCRIBED GRAZING AND PRESCRIBED BURNING, WHICH PROVIDES NESTING HABITAT AND COVER FOR BIRDS, COVER FOR EASTERN INDIGO SNAKES, BURROWING SUBSTRATE FOR GOPHER TORTOISES, AND FORAGING HABITAT FOR NORTHERN CRESTED CARACARA 2  REDUCE HABITAT FRAGMENTATION, WHICH IS A KEY COMPONENT FOR THE FLORIDA PANTHER IN FLORIDA PER THE 2008 FLORIDA PANTHER RECOVERY PLAN AND 2019 SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENT 3  INCREASE FORAGE HEALTH AND AVAILABILITY FOR CATTLE WHICH PROVIDES ADDITIONAL ECONOMIC INCENTIVE FOR RANCHERS TO KEEP MANAGING LANDS ESSENTIAL FOR ALL WILDLIFE 4  INCREASE PRESCRIBED BURNING ON THE LANDSCAPE TO IMPROVE WILDLIFE HABITAT AND REDUCE WILDFIRE RISK CHANGES IN HYDROLOGY, CAUSED BY DECADES OF DITCHING AND DIVERTING WATER, AS WELL AS LOSS OF FIRE, HAVE ALLOWED NATIVE AND INVASIVE TREES AND SHRUBS TO THRIVE ACROSS THE CENTRAL FLORIDA LANDSCAPE  AS A RESULT, THE MIDSTORY HAS BECOME TOO DENSE AND TOO TALL, WHICH HAS DECREASED THE GROUNDCOVER AVAILABILITY AND DIVERSITY THAT MANY PRAIRIE, SCRUB, AND PINE FLATWOODS WILDLIFE SPECIES REQUIRE TO SURVIVE  DRY PRAIRIE IS DEPENDENT ON A ONE  TO TWO YEAR FIRE RETURN INTERVAL, PINE FLATWOODS 3  TO 5 YEAR, AND SCRUB 5 10  YEARS  ADDITIONALLY, THIS LANDSCAPE CONTAINS COGON GRASS, TROPICAL SODA APPLE, AND CLIMBING FERN, FLEPPC  FLORIDA EXOTIC PEST PLANT COUNCIL  CATEGORY I INVASIVE SPECIES, WHICH ARE INVADING THE AVAILABLE GRASSLANDS AND WETLAND MARGINS, ALTERING THE VEGETATION STRUCTURE AND FIRE SAFETY FUNDING WILL BE USED TO IMPLEMENT THE FOLLOWING MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS ROLLER CHOPPING TO REDUCE THE HEIGHT AND DENSITY OF SHRUBS AND, ON PRAIRIE SITES, REMOVAL OF ISOLATED NATIVE TREES OVER 4 FEET IN HEIGHT HERBICIDE AND OR MECHANICAL TREATMENT OF INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES  AN EFFORT TO REDUCE INVASIVE PLANT POPULATIONS BY 80  WOULD BE THE INITIAL GOAL PRESCRIBED FIRE ONCE THE VEGETATION STRUCTURE HAS BEEN MANAGED TO A LEVEL WHERE IT IS SAFE AND FEASIBLE TO BURN ALTERNATIVES TO PRESCRIBED FIRE SUCH AS MOWING AND GRAZING TO MAINTAIN HEALTHY GROUNDCOVER DURING YEARS WHEN FIRE IS NOT IMPLEMENTED APPLICATION AND TIMING OF SPECIFIC MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS IS OUTLINED IN THE INDIAN HAMMOCK HUNT AND RIDING CLUB HABITAT MANAGEMENT GUIDANCE  TOWLES, 2021  AND WILL BE COORDINATED ON AN ANNUAL BASIS WITH THE LANDOWNER

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO RESTORE STEELHEAD SPAWNING AND REARING HABITAT BY REINTRODUCING LARGE WOOD IN TO A SECTION OF COTTONWOOD CREEK THAT IS LACKING THIS HABITAT COMPONENT  SPECIFICALLY, THIS PROJECT WILL FALL 20 TO 30 TREES RANGING FROM 14 TO 30 INCHES IN DIAMETER DIRECTLY INTO THE CREEK  CALIFORNIA CONSERVATION CORPS STAFF WILL THEN USE HAND HELD TOOLS INCLUDING GRIP HOISTS, PULLEYS, AND CABLES TO MOVE AND INTERLOCK THE FALLEN TREES AND OR ANCHOR THE FALLEN TREES AGAINST CREEKSIDE TREES AND BOULDERS TO REDUCE THEIR MOBILITY  THE FALLING AND MOVING OF THE TREES WILL CREATE UP TO SIX DISCRETE LOG JAMS OF FOUR TO SIX TREES  THE LOG JAMS WILL RESTORE REARING HABITAT BY PROVIDING OVERHEAD COVER, AND BY CREATING SCOUR POOLS AND SLOW WATER HABITAT  THE LOG JAMS WILL RESTORE SPAWNING HABITAT BY CAPTURING AND SORTING THE GRAVEL STEELHEAD REQUIRE FOR SPAWNING  FOLLOWING PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION, USFWS STAFF WILL MONITOR THE MOVEMENT OF THE TREES IN THE CONSTRUCTED LOG JAMS TO EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF INTERLOCKING AND ANCHORING THE TREES USING THE GRIP HOIST, PULLEY, AND CABLE SYSTEM  THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE PUBLIC BY IMPROVING HABITAT FOR STEELHEAD TO SPAWN AND REAR IN COTTONWOOD CREEK

THE GOAL OF THE NORTHERN COPPERBELLY WATER SNAKE HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE KEY HABITATS FOR THE NORTHERN COPPERBELLY WATERSNAKE  NERODIA ERYTHROGASTER NEGLECTA  ON THE MICHIGAN NATURE ASSOCIATION S SARAH JANE S NATURE SANCTUARY  SARAH JANE S , LOCATED INAMBOY TOWNSHIP 8 SOUTH, RANGE 3 WEST, SECTION 35, HILLSDALE COUNTY, MICHIGAN  THE NORTHERN POPULATION SEGMENT OF THE COPPERBELLY ISLISTED AS FEDERALLY THREATENED, AS WELL AS STATE ENDANGERED IN MICHIGAN, OHIO, AND INDIANA  THE MICHIGAN NATURE ASSOCIATION  MNA ESTABLISHED SARAH JANE S FOR THE PURPOSE OF PROTECTING HABITAT FOR THE COPPERBELLY  AT 187 ACRES, SARAH JANE S REPRESENTS A UNIQUE COMPLEXOF WETLANDS AND UPLANDS ON THE LANDSCAPE, WHICH IS ESSENTIAL FOR ACCOMMODATING THE SNAKE S EXTENSIVE RANGE AND MOVEMENT PATTERNS CURRENTLY SARAH JANE S IS ONE OF ONLY THREE REMAINING SITES IN MICHIGAN AND NORTHERN OHIO WITH KNOWNEXTANT COPPERBELLY POPULATIONS THIS PROJECT FOCUSES ON IMPROVING TWO COMPONENTS OF THE COPPERBELLY HABITAT AT SARAH JANE S PRESERVE ENHANCE THE WETLAND VEGETATION ON 7 0 ACRES OF WETLAND HABITAT THAT PROVIDE HABITAT FOR THE CWS AND COMPLETE INVASIVE TREE AND SHRUBCONTROL ON 22 ACRES OF UPLAND HABITAT PREVIOUSLY PLANTED TO FOREST BY CONTROLLING INVASIVE AUTUMN OLIVE AND OTHER WOODY PROBLEM SPECIES

THIS PROJECT WILL BE A JOINT EFFORT OF THE SANIBEL CAPTIVA CONSERVATION FOUNDATION  SCCF , U S  FISH AND  WILDLIFE SERVICE  USFWS , AND THE CITY OF SANIBEL  THE SANIBEL ISLAND RICE RAT  ORYZOMYS PALUSTRIS SANIBELI  IS AN ENDEMIC SPECIES ON SANIBEL ISLAND, FL  THIS SPECIES IS LISTED AS THREATENED IN THE STATE OF FLORIDA AND A SPECIES OF SPECIAL CONCERN WITH THE U S  FISH AND  WILDLIFE SERVICE  THE PRIMARY HABITAT FOR THE SANIBEL ISLAND RICE RAT ARE OPEN CORD GRASS  SPARTINA BAKERI  MARSHES  THESE HABITATS, WHICH ARE MOSTLY ON CONSERVATION LANDS, ARE MAINTAINED BY PRESCRIBED FIRE AND OR MECHANICAL CLEARING  HOWEVER, DECADES OF HARDWOOD SUCCESSION AND INVASIVE PLANT INTRUSION HAS RESULTED IN A SUBSTANTIAL LOSS OF THEIR AVAILABLE HABITAT  ALTHOUGH, EXOTIC VEGETATION IS UNDER CONTROL, INVASIVE NATIVE PLANTS SUCH AS BUTTONWOOD  CONOCARPUS ERECTUS , SALTBUSH  BACCHARIS HALIMIFOLIA , AND WAX MYRTLE  MYRICA CERIFERA  QUICKLY INFILTRATE THESE OPEN AREAS, DURING LAPSES IN BURNING, AND QUICKLY DOMINATE THE AREA  BY RESTORING THESE WETLANDS BACK TO OPEN SPARTINA MARSHES, THE QUANTITY OF AVAILABLE HABITAT FOR THIS ENDEMIC SPECIES, AS WELL AS FOR WADING BIRDS, ANURANS, AND NUMEROUS EPHEMERAL SPECIES WILL BE INCREASED  ALSO, THERE ARE KNOWN RICE RAT MICRO POPULATIONS ON OPPOSITE SIDES OF THE PROPOSED RESTORATION SITE  BY RESTORING THIS SECTION, A WILDLIFE CORRIDOR WOULD BE CREATED TO ALLOW INTROGRESSION BETWEEN THOSE SITES  RESTORATION WILL INCLUDE REMOVAL OF SHRUBBY HARDWOODS FROM MARSHES WITH HEAVY MACHINERY  THE DEBRIS WILL BE TAKEN OFF SITE OR MULCHED DEPENDING UPON COST  AFTER SHRUBBY HARDWOODS AND ANY EXOTICS ARE REMOVED, GRASSES SUCH AS CORD GRASS AND SAWGRASS PLUGS WILL BE REPLANTED  RESTORATION PROGRESS AND RESULTS WILL BE MONITORED WITH PHOTO PLOTS

THE PROJECT GOAL IS TO CONSERVE AND RESTORE DECIDUOUS OAK WOODLANDS FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE WHITE BREASTED NUTHATCH  A U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE BIRD OF CONSERVATION CONCERN , MIGRATORY BIRDS, AND ELK  THE PROJECT IS A JOINT PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE SERVICE S  PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM   PARTNERS PROGRAM  AND A PRIVATE LANDOWNER TO PROTECT THE REMAINING OAK GRASSLAND HABITAT ON THE REMOTE PROPERTY  THE PARTNERS PROGRAM WILL PROVIDE FUNDING TO THE LANDOWNER, WHO WILL USE A LABOR CREW TO REMOVE YOUNG DOUGLAS FIR TREES THAT HAVE ENCROACHED INTO THE OAK WOODLANDS  IF LEFT UNTREATED, THE CONIFERS WILL EVENTUALLY OVERTOP AND KILL THE OAKS, RESULTING IN A CONVERSION TO CONIFER FOREST AND A LOSS OF THIS BIODIVERSE WILDLIFE HABITAT

THE PROPOSED PROJECT, LOCATED IN SHASTA COUNTY, CA, WILL ADDRESS WET MEADOW, SEASONAL WETLANDS, VERNAL POOLS, SAGE STEPPE, AND OAK WOODLAND HABITATS ACROSS 4500 ACRES  THE FALL RIVER RESOURCE CONSERVATION DISTRICT ACQUIRED THE LAKE AND MACARTHUR SWAMP PROPERTIES FROM PACIFIC GAS AND ELECTRIC COMPANY AND PLACED A PERMANENT CONSERVATION EASEMENT ON EACH  ACQUISITION OF THESE PROPERTIES DID NOT INCLUDE THE WATER RIGHTS  THEREFORE, MANAGING WATER FROM WELLS AND OVERLAND FLOW FROM TAILWATER, RAIN, AND SNOW MELT ARE VITAL FOR HABITAT SUSTAINABILITY  THE FALL RIVER RCD PROPOSES TO ADDRESS WITH THIS PROJECT THE TOP PRIORITY MANAGEMENT NEEDS OF EACH SITE  FOR EACH, THAT IS HYDROLOGY, ENCROACHING JUNIPER, AND REVEGETATION  ON THE LAKE PROPERTY, THE PRIMARY WATER LOSS IS THROUGH HEAD CUTS AND GULLIES, WHICH WILL BE ADDRESSED WITH GRADE CONTROL STRUCTURES  JUNIPER IS ENCROACHING ON MEADOW HABITAT, A PINE STAND, AND WITHIN AN OAK WOODLAND, REDUCING STAND RESILIENCE AND ACORN PRODUCTION AND RAISING FUEL LOADS  THE THIRD AREA TO ADDRESS IS THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF THE LAKE PROPERTY  PAST RANCHING ACTIVITIES HAVE REMOVED THE SAGE STEPPE VEGETATION AND RESULTED IN ANNUAL GRASSES DOMINATED BY CHEATGRASS  THIS AREA WILL BE PLANTED WITH NATIVE SAGE STEPPE BRUSH SPECIES  ON MCARTHUR SWAMP, THE MOST EXTENSIVE MANAGEMENT NEED TO ADDRESS AT THIS TIME IS THE NETWORK OF DRAINAGE DITCHES THAT CROSS ALL FIELDS  PRIORITY IS GIVEN TO THOSE AREAS WITH THE MOST SIGNIFICANT HYDRAULIC BENEFIT  TOP PRIORITY WILL BE GIVEN TO THE VERNAL POOLS DRAINED BY THESE DITCHES  THE VERNAL POOLS WILL FURTHER BE PROTECTED BY ADJUSTING EXISTING FENCE GATES TO MINIMIZE AND DISCOURAGE VEHICLE USAGE IN THE POOLS  THE TOTAL PROJECT WILL ADDRESS 300 ACRES OF WET MEADOWS, 150 ACRES OF SAGE STEPPE, AND 1 ACRE OF VERNAL POOL WETLAND HABITAT

THE RENO FISH AND WILDLIFE OFFICE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM WILL WORK WITH A PRIVATE LAND MANAGER WHO LEASES A LARGE RANCH IN ELKO COUNTY, NEVADA TO MANAGE LIVESTOCK GRAZING ALONG CREEK THAT IS IMPORTANT FOR BOTH LIVESTOCK MANAGEMENT AND WILDLIFE  THE FOURMILE CREEK WET MEADOW ENHANCEMENT PROJECT WILL ENHANCE UP TO 1 4 MILES OF STREAM AND AN ASSOCIATED 200 ACRES OF WET MEADOW  MESIC HABITAT   THERE ARE THREE POTENTIAL COMPONENTS OF THIS PROJECT THAT INCLUDE   1  FENCING,  2  OFFSITE WATER DEVELOPMENT, AND  3  INSTREAM PROCESS BASED RESTORATION  WE ARE CURRENTLY MOVING FORWARD ONLY ON THE FENCING COMPONENT AND WILL DETERMINE THROUGH MONITORING AND ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT FUTURE NEEDS FOR ADDITIONAL WATER SOURCES FOR LIVESTOCK AND OR ACTIVE INSTREAM ACTIVITIES TO ACCELERATE FLOODPLAIN CONNECTION AND RAISING THE WATER TABLE TO IMPROVE WET MEADOW FUNCTION  WE ANTICIPATE SUCCESSFUL NATURAL RECOVERY OF THE SYSTEM AFTER IMPLEMENTATION OF FENCING WHICH WILL ALLOW FOR CONTROL OF LIVESTOCK IN THE AREA

THIS GRANT WILL PROVIDE FUNDING TO THE PIEDMONT TRIAD REGIONAL COUNCIL  PTRC  FOR THE REMOVAL OF THE JESSUP MILL DAM ON THE UPPER DAN RIVER IN STOKES COUNTY, NC IN ORDER TO EXPAND AND RECONNECT POPULATIONS OF FEDERALLY LISTED AQUATIC SPECIES INCLUDING THE ENDANGERED ROANOKE LOGPERCH, THE ENDANGERED JAMES SPINYMUSSEL AND THE THREATENED ATLANTIC PIGTOE, AS WELL AS OTHER AT RISK SPECIES  STEPS OF THE PROJECT INCLUDE CONSULTING WITH THE RELEVANT PERMITTING AND REGULATORY AGENCIES, COMPLETING ENGINEERING DESIGNS AND PLANS, SECURING PERMITS, GRADUAL DRAWDOWN OF IMPOUNDED WATER, REMOVAL OF SEDIMENT BEHIND THE DAM, REMOVAL OF THE INSTREAM BARRIER AND ASSOCIATED STRUCTURES AND STABILIZATION OF STREAM BANKS  THE PROJECT IS EXPECTED TO BE COMPLETED BY DECEMBER 31, 2024  THIS IS A COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT  AS SUCH, THE SERVICE WILL BE INVOLVED WITH EACH STEP IN THE RESTORATION AND WILL PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE ALONG THE WAY

THE RENO FISH AND WILDLIFE OFFICE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM WILL WORK WITH A PRIVATE LANDOWNER IN ELKO COUNTY, NEVADA TO IMPROVE MEADOWS IN THE FLOODPLAIN OF COTTONWOOD CREEK THAT WILL HAVE BENEFITS FOR BOTH WILDLIFE AND LIVESTOCK  THE LANDOWNER OWNS A MULTI GENERATIONAL RANCH THAT IS COMPRISED OF PRIVATE PROPERTY AND PUBLIC LAND GRAZING ALLOTMENTS  FLOOD IRRIGATION HAS BEEN A RANCH PRACTICE FOR OVER 100 YEARS AND DEPLETION OF MINERALS IN THE SOIL HAS RESULTED, PARTICULARLY ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF THE RANCH  SOIL SATURATION IS NO MORE THAN A FEW INCHES DEEP WHICH HAS RESULTED IN A SHARP DECLINE OF NATIVE, PERENNIAL GRASSES IN THE MEADOW  THROUGH SOIL TESTING, CALCIUM LEVELS WERE DOCUMENTED AS LOW IN THESE MEADOWS  IN ADDITION, SOIL PITS DISPLAYED A 2 INCH LAYER OF THATCH  MECHANICAL AERATION WAS SUCCESSFUL IN IMPROVING WATER INFILTRATION, BUT THIS IS NOT A LONG TERM SOLUTION TO A SELF SUSTAINING MEADOW SYSTEM THE LANDOWNER HAS WORKED WITH PARTNERS TO DEVELOP A PLAN TO BRING THE CHEMICAL COMPOSITION BACK INTO BALANCE  I E , INCREASE SOIL CALCIUM   CALCIUM WILL FLOCCULATE THE SOIL OR, IN ESSENCE, DRAW SOIL COLLOIDS TOGETHER CREATING A  CLUMPY  SOIL WITH SPACES THAT ALLOW FOR WATER AND ROOT PENETRATION  THIS PROJECT HAS THREE COMPONENTS PHASE I  SOIL AMENDMENTS   PURCHASE AND APPLY 250 TONS OF CALCIUM CARBONATE  I E , A BY PRODUCT OF THE SUGAR BEET INDUSTRY IN IDAHO , 340 TONS OF DOLOMITE  SOURCES IN WINNEMUCCA, NV , 30 TONS OF DIAMMONIUM PHOSPHATE, AND 30 POUNDS OF ELEMENTAL SULFUR  PHASE II  COVER CROPS   EARLY IN PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION, COVER CROPS WILL BE PLANTED TO MAINTAIN GROUND COVER IN ORDER TO REDUCE EVAPORATION, RETAIN WATER, AND PROVIDE INPUTS BACK INTO THE SOIL  WHILE NOT NATIVE, THESE SPECIES WILL HAVE A FORAGE VALUE TO BOTH LIVESTOCK AND WILDLIFE PHASE III  NATIVE PLANTS   ULTIMATELY, THE OBJECTIVE IS FOR A SELF SUSTAINING MEADOW THAT HOSTS A VARIETY OF NATIVE PLANT AND FORB SPECIES

THIS PROJECT IS A COOPERATIVE EFFORT BETWEEN THE U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  USFWS , IN COLLABORATION WITH THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT  BLM  WHO OVERSEES THE NATIONAL SOS PROGRAM, AND WILL BE COORDINATED INSOFAR AS POSSIBLE WITH OTHER DEPARTMENT OF INTERIOR  DOI  BUREAUS, AS WELL AS USDA AND DOD AGENCIES  THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS AGREEMENT ARE TO  1 ASSIST THE DEPARTMENT OF INTERIOR, USFWS IN COORDINATION WITH BLM IN PLANNING SEED COLLECTIONS OF NATIVE PLANTS FROM THE SOUTHEASTERN U S  FOR THE SOS PROGRAM  2 DEVELOP THE SOS PROGRAM IN THE SOUTHEAST, WITH AN EMPHASIS IN ALABAMA, ARKANSAS, GEORGIA, KENTUCKY, LOUISIANA, MISSISSIPPI, SOUTH CAROLINA, AND TENNESSEE THAT FOLLOWS SOS PROTOCOL  3 ASSIST IN COORDINATING THE COLLECTION OF NATIVE SEED ACCORDING TO SOS PROTOCOL ACROSS THE SOUTHEASTERN U S  TO IMPROVE SEED RESOURCES AVAILABLE FOR RESTORATION  4 SUPPORT LOCAL SEED GROWERS BY PROVIDING TRAINING AND KNOWLEDGE ON THE NEED TO INCREASE THE SUPPLY OF ECOREGIONAL SEEDS FOR LOCAL RESTORATION PROJECTS  5 ENCOURAGE THE USE THE SOURCE IDENTIFIED NATIVE ECOTYPE SEEDS IN THE RESTORATION OF NATIVE HABITATS IN THE SOUTHEASTERN U S  6 EMPHASIZE COLLABORATIONS WITH MINORITY SERVING ACADEMIC AND RESEARCH INSTITUTIONS, GROWERS, AND EXISTING REGIONAL ECOREGIONAL NATIVE PLANT EFFORTS

THE NEW MEXICO PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE  PARTNERS  PROGRAM ASSISTS PRIVATE LANDOWNERS WITH THE RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT OF HABITATS LOST TO, OR DEGRADED BY, HABITAT LOSS, HABITAT FRAGMENTATION, HYDROLOGICAL ALTERATION, EXOTIC SPECIES ENCROACHMENT, DROUGHT, AND ALTERED FIRE REGIMES  HOWEVER, SOURCE  IDENTIFIED, LOCALLY ADAPTED PLANT MATERIALS ARE INSUFFICIENTLY AVAILABLE TO MEET PROJECT NEEDS  THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO INCREASE THE AVAILABILITY OF NATIVE PLANT SEED FOR PARTNERS PROJECTS IN THE FOUR  4  FOCUS AREAS INCLUDED IN THE 2022 2026 STRATEGIC PLAN, TO INCLUDE THE HIGH PLAINS, COLORADO PLATEAUS, SOUTHERN ROCKIES AND THE AZ NM MOUNTAINS ECOREGIONS  PROJECT OUTCOMES INCLUDE INCREASING THE SUPPLY OF NATIVE SEEDS AND PLANT MATERIAL FOR RESTORATION, CREATING PRIVATE SECTOR JOBS, ENHANCING GROWER CAPACITIES, AND EXPANDING AGENCY BOTANICAL CAPACITY TO SUPPORT NATIONAL COORDINATION ON IMPLEMENTING THE NATIONAL SEED STRATEGY AND UTILIZING THE SEEDS OF SUCCESS PROTOCOL FOR COLLECTION  THIS PROJECT IS A COLLABORATION WITH BLM, NPS, FWS, AND VARIOUS STATES AND TRIBES WHERE OPPORTUNITIES ARISE

ABSTRACT  VALLEY BOTTOM FLOODPLAINS AND MEADOWS ARE SOME OF THE WETTEST AND MOST PRODUCTIVE AREAS OF THELANDSCAPE  IN THE WESTERN UNITED STATES THESE AREAS TEND TO OCCUPY A SMALLER PORTION OF THE WATERSHED YETTHEIR POTENTIAL TO STORE WATER AND CARBON AND INFLUENCE WILD FIRE BEHAVIOR OR PROVIDE REFUGIAL HABITAT AREDISPROPORTIONALITY HIGH  MANY VALLEY BOTTOM STREAMS ARE DEGRADED AND NO LONGER CONNECTED TO THEIRFLOODPLAINS AND HAVE LOST THE ABILITY TO PROVIDE MOIST HABITAT REFUGIA BENEFITS FOR WILDLIFE DURING FIRESEASON  CURRENT STATE AND FEDERAL RESTORATION PROGRAMS INCLUDING THE PARTNERS AND COASTAL PROGRAMS AREINVESTING IN THE RESTORATION OF THESE SYSTEMS USING PROCESS BASED RESTORATION METHODS INCLUDING WORKINGWITH BEAVER TO RECONNECT VALLEY BOTTOM FLOODPLAINS AND HOLD WATER LATER INTO THE SUMMER DRY SEASON WHILE THESE PROJECTS HAVE DEMONSTRATED BENEFITS TO SENSITIVE FISH AND WILDLIFE SPECIES THIS STUDY WILLINVESTIGATE THE INFLUENCE OF RESTORED VALLEY BOTTOM STREAMS ON FIRE BEHAVIOR  THIS HAS IMPORTANTMANAGEMENT SIGNIFICANCE FOR UNDERSTANDING THE SPATIAL SCALE OF STREAM RESTORATION THAT IS NEEDED BY THESEPUBLIC PROGRAMS IF THEY ARE TO BE CONSIDERED A TOOL FOR FIRE MANAGEMENT AND THE POTENTIAL TO INTEGRATE FIREAND FOREST TREATMENT PROJECTS WITH STREAM RESTORATION EFFORTS THE PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON THREE CASE STUDY WATERSHEDS OF CURRENT OR FUTURE RIVER RESTORATION INTEREST ANDWHERE WILDFIRE OCCURRENCE IS OF GREAT CONCERN  THE STREAM STUDY AREAS WILL BE LOCATED IN THE CALIFORNIACOASTAL ECOREGION WITHIN THE TOMALES BAY WATERSHED, THE SIERRA NEVADA UPPER FEATHER RIVERWATERSHED, AND THE UPPER KLAMATH BASIN IN OREGON WITHIN THE SPRAGUE RIVER WATERSHED PROPOSED STUDY WATERSHEDS  LAGUNITAS TOMALES BAY WATERSHED, CA  SPRAGUE RIVER WATERSHED, OR AND YELLOW CREEK WATERSHED, CA  WITH EXPANSION FURTHER INTO UPPER FEATHER RIVER WATERSHED AS TIMEPERMITS

THE OREGON DESERT LAND TRUST OWNS TWO ADJACENT PARCELS OF PROPERTY AT THE BASE OF BEATYS BUTTE IN SOUTHEASTERN OREGON TOTALING 400 ACRES  THESE UNFENCED PROPERTIES ARE LOCATED WITHIN CORE SAGE GROUSE HABITAT  FIGURE 3 , AND CONTAIN MULTIPLE MESIC SITES CRITICAL FOR WILDLIFE  AFTER EXTENSIVE SURVEYS WERE CONDUCTED BY ONDA STAFF OF THE NORTH SPRINGS MESIC SITES AND DOZENS OF OTHER SIMILARLY SITUATED SPRINGS IN THE SURROUNDING LANDSCAPE, IT WAS DETERMINED THAT SUBSTANTIAL AND IMPORTANT RESTORATION OPPORTUNITIES EXISTED FOR IMPROVING VEGETATION AND HYDROLOGICAL CONDITIONS ON THE NORTH SPRINGS PROPERTIES  IN ORDER TO ACHIEVE THESE OPPORTUNITIES, ONDA STAFF WOULD WORK IN COOPERATION WITH ODLT TO EXCLUDE GRAZING FROM AS MUCH OF THE PROPERTY AS POSSIBLE, ALLOWING FOR PASSIVE RESTORATION OF DRIER UPLAND AREAS AND ACTIVE RESTORATION OF VEGETATION AND STREAM MORPHOLOGY IN THE RIPARIAN AND OTHER MESIC AREAS WHILE THE OPPORTUNITY TO RESTORE MESIC HABITAT AT THESE PARTICULAR SITES IS IN ITSELF VALUABLE, THE OVERALL GOAL IS TO BE ABLE TO CAPITALIZE ON LESSONS LEARNED AT THESE SITES TO INFORM AND INSPIRE THE RESTORATION OF OTHER SPRINGS, AND MESIC SITES ON PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDS IN THE SURROUNDING REGION TO SUPPORT PHASE 1 OF THIS LONG TERM, MULTI PHASE PROJECT, ONDA IS REQUESTING  25,000 FROM THE USFWS TO FUND THE COST OF CONSTRUCTING 3 1 MILES OF WILDLIFE FRIENDLY FENCING PROTECTING 296 ACRES

THE GRASSLANDS ECOLOGICAL AREA  GEA  OF THE SAN JOAQUIN VALLEY IS A RAMSAR DESIGNATED SITE AND SERVES AS AN IMPORTANT REGION FOR MIGRATORY WATERFOWL IN CALIFORNIA S CENTRAL VALLEY  HOWEVER, ITS NETWORK OF WETLANDS AND UPLANDS CAN AND DO ALSO BENEFIT A VARIETY OF OTHER WILDLIFE SPECIES  DUE TO THE ONGOING DROUGHT IN CALIFORNIA, MANAGEMENT OF NATURAL AREAS HAS FOCUSED ON MAXIMIZING HABITAT VALUE TO WILDLIFE GIVEN MINIMUM WATER AVAILABILITY  IN ORDER TO CAPITALIZE ON HABITAT RESTORATION OPPORTUNITIES THAT ARE LOCATED NEAR CURRENT WATER SOURCES, THE GWD HAS IDENTIFIED CANAL AND WETLAND EDGES AS PRIME LOCATIONS FOR ESTABLISHING HABITAT FOR POLLINATORS THE GRASSLAND WATER DISTRICT IS PARTNERING WITH THE EAST STANISLAUS RCD, VALLEY ECO, AND THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE  PFW  PROGRAM TO CREATE THIS VALUABLE POLLINATOR HABITAT ON PRIVATE WETLANDS IN THE GEA  THIS PFW PROJECT INTENDS TO FOCUS ON AT LEAST TWO DIFFERENT PRIVATE PROPERTIES AS PART OF THE GWD S LARGER  MONARCHS AMONGST THE TULES  PROJECT AND WILL CONTRIBUTE TOWARDS THAT PROJECT S GOAL OF ENHANCING APPROXIMATELY 125 ACRES OF POLLINATOR HABITAT  THIS PROJECT ALSO COMPLEMENTS THE GWD S ONGOING  MONARCH FRIENDLY CANALS  PROJECT DOING SIMILAR POLLINATOR WORK ON THE EDGES OF IRRIGATION CANALS, AND COINCIDINGLY SUPPORTING A SINGLE PILOT WETLAND ENHANCEMENT EFFORT  THIS PFW PROJECT WILL PRIMARILY BENEFIT THE MONARCH, AN IMPERILED SPECIES AND CANDIDATE FOR FEDERAL LISTING, BUT IS ANTICIPATED TO ALSO BENEFIT NUMEROUS POLLINATOR INSECTS INCLUDING OTHER BUTTERFLIES AND BEES  THE GEA AND THIS PROJECT FALL WITHIN A HIGH PRIORITY ACTION ZONE FOR RECOVERING WESTERN MONARCHS, SPECIFICALLY FOR DEVELOPING EARLY BREEDING HABITAT  XERCES SOCIETY   BY CREATING ADDITIONAL POLLEN NECTAR SOURCES IN THIS AREA, THE PROJECT WILL LIKELY INCREASE SURVIVAL OF MONARCH POPULATIONS DURING BOTH THE MIGRATION AND BREEDING PERIOD  INCORPORATING MILKWEED INTO PLANTING SEEDING EFFORTS WILL ALSO BE INDISPENSABLE TO MONARCH CATERPILLARS PARTNERING WITH LANDOWNERS AND ORGANIZATIONS ALIKE IS KEY TO FOSTERING THE CONTINUED ENHANCEMENT OF MULTI SPECIES BENEFITS THROUGHOUT THE GEA  THIS PROJECT WILL INVOLVE ESTABLISHING MILKWEED AND OTHER POLLINATOR FRIENDLY PLANTS THROUGH BOTH SEED AND PLUGS  IMPLEMENTATION STEPS MAY INCLUDE GROUND PREPARATION, IRRIGATION SYSTEM INSTALLATION, PLANTING SEEDING, AND WEED CONTROL  IT MAY ALSO INVOLVE MONITORING RESTORED HABITAT, DEVELOPING MANAGEMENT PRACTICES FOR LANDOWNERS, AND PROVIDING OUTREACH TO OTHER INTERESTED PARTIES

SUPPORTING AND SUSTAINING THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE APPROACH TO WORKING LANDSCAPE CONSERVATIONTHE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM  PFW  IS A PROVEN APPROACH TO VOLUNTARY CONSERVATION VIEWED POSITIVELY BY LANDOWNERS AND OTHER PARTNERS  PFW IS MARKING ITS 35TH YEAR IN 2022 AND LIKE MANY PROGRAMS AND ORGANIZATIONS THAT HAVE ACHIEVED THIS LEVEL OF MATURITY, IT IS CURRENTLY EXPERIENCING AN ACCELERATED LOSS OF LONG TENURED STAFF  PFC INC   PARTNERSCAPES  WILL WORK WITH THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE  PFW  PROGRAM TO DEVELOP PRODUCTS INCREASING THE AWARENESS, UNDERSTANDING AND APPRECIATION FOR THE PFW APPROACH BOTH INSIDE AND OUTSIDE THE PROGRAM  THIS INFORMATION TRANSFER WILL OCCUR THROUGH A VARIETY OF VIRTUAL AND IN PERSON CHANNELS INCLUDING WEBINARS, PODCASTS, VIDEOS, BLOG POSTS, AND OTHER WEB DISTRIBUTED TOOLS AS WELL AS IN PERSON MEETINGS AND OUTREACH  IDEAL MESSENGERS ARE LIKELY TO INCLUDE A MIX OF LANDOWNERS, EXPERIENCED PFW STAFF AS WELL AS OTHER PARTNER PERSPECTIVES THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE APPROACH TO VOLUNTARY CONSERVATION IS BASED, AT ITS CORE, ON RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN DIFFERENT PERSPECTIVES, BUILT ON TRUST AND CREDIBILITY, THAT ARE BOTH FLEXIBLE AND ACHIEVE RESULTS SEEN AS DESIRABLE BY ALL VIEWPOINTS INVOLVED  VERY LITTLE ABOUT THIS APPROACH TO CONSERVATION, EITHER IN PRACTICE OR THEORY, IS INCLUDED IN THE FORMAL EDUCATION OF INCOMING PFW STAFF  THE TRANSFER OF KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS, FROM EXPERIENCED PRACTITIONERS TO NEWER EMPLOYEES, IS ACCOMPLISHED BY MENTORING AND A SMALL NUMBER OF PFW DESIGNED LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES  IN THIS DELIVERABLE, PARTNERSCAPES WILL BRING A LANDOWNER PERSPECTIVE THROUGH PARTICIPATION IN THESE EXISTING TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES

THE GREAT BASIN INSTITUTE  GBI , IN COOPERATION WITH THE U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  USFWS  SOUTHERN NEVADA FISH AND WILDLIFE OFFICE, WILL SUPPORT ECOLOGICAL RESTORATION EFFORTS IN SOUTHERN NEVADA AND THE MOJAVE DESERT OF CALIFORNIA  GBI WILL PROVIDE ECOLOGICAL RESTORATION RESEARCH ASSOCIATES  RA  TO SUPPORT THE PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION OF HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS ON PRIVATE LANDS AND RECOVERY WORK FOR FEDERALLY THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES  THIS POSITION WILL PROVIDE RESEARCH AND PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITIES FOR COLLEGE STUDENTS, RECENT COLLEGE GRADUATES, GRADUATE STUDENTS, OR EXPERIENCED PROFESSIONALS LOOKING TO BEGIN OR ENHANCE A CAREER IN ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT, CONSERVATION, STEWARDSHIP, AND OTHER RELATED FIELDS

THIS PROPOSAL IS INTENDED TO INCREASE THE LIKELIHOOD OF TOLERANCE AND SURVIVAL OF RED WOLVES OCCURRING ON PRIVATE LANDS WITHIN THE FIVE COUNTY RECOVERY AREA  THE REMAINING WILD RED WOLVES ARE PRIMARILY LOCATED ON AND AROUND ALLIGATOR RIVER AND POCOSIN LAKES NWRS  WITH A TERRITORY OF UP TO 80 SQUARE MILES, PRIVATE LANDS NEAR THESE REFUGE LANDS REMAIN IMPORTANT FOR RED WOLVES AS TRAVEL CORRIDORS, FORAGING HABITAT, AND DENNING LOCATIONS  BY WORKING WITH CONSERVATION PARTNERS AND WILLING LANDOWNERS, WE WILL INCREASE THE PREY BASE AND IMPROVE HABITAT CONDITIONS ON THESE PRIVATE LANDS  IT IS ALSO IMPERATIVE TO BUILD RELATIONSHIPS WITH LANDOWNERS AND CONTINUE TO BUILD TRUST BETWEEN LANDOWNERS AND THE USFWS STRATEGIES TO ACHIEVE THESE GOALS INCLUDE IMPROVING HABITAT FOR THE WILDLIFE THAT LANDOWNERS VALUE AND PREY THAT RED WOLVES PREFER  BY INCREASING THE AMOUNT AND QUALITY OF EARLY SUCCESSIONAL AND WETLAND HABITATS, WE WILL IMPROVE CONDITIONS FOR SMALL MAMMALS AND WHITE TAILED DEER  HABITAT IMPROVEMENT WILL BE TAILORED TO EACH SITE AND THE LANDOWNERS INTERESTS  PRACTICES MAY INCLUDE CREATING RIPARIAN AREAS, WILDFIRE RISK REDUCTION, BRUSH MANAGEMENT, TREATING INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES, ESTABLISHING AND MANAGING EARLY SUCCESSIONAL VEGETATION, AND PLANTING TREES  LANDOWNERS WILL CONTRIBUTE A PORTION OF THE COSTS OF HABITAT IMPROVEMENT PRACTICES  IN ADDITION, THEY WILL AGREE TO ALLOW RED WOLVES TO ENTER AND INHABIT THEIR PROPERTY  OTHER ALLOWANCES MAY PROVIDE FOR THE SERVICE AND NC WILDLIFE FEDERATION STAFF AND OR OTHER PROJECT PARTNERS TO ACCESS THE PROPERTY TO CONDUCT MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES

THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT ("AGREEMENT") IS TO CONTINUE A STRONG AND PRODUCTIVE WORKING PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN DU'S GREAT PLAINS REGIONAL OFFICE AND THE SERVICE TO FACILITATE HABITAT CONSERVATION WORK ON PRIVATE AND TRIBAL LANDS ACROSS THE PRAIRIE POTHOLE REGION OF NORTH DAKOTA. A SPECIAL EMPHASIS WILL BE PLACED ON RESTORING, CREATING AND ENHANCING WETLAND AND GRASSLAND HABITATS THAT ARE VITAL TO BREEDING POPULATIONS OF A WIDE VARIETY OF BIRD GUILDS. PRIMARY HABITAT CONSERVATION PRACTICES TO BE JOINTLY IMPLEMENTED BY THE SERVICE AND DU INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO, WETLAND CREATIONS, WETLAND ENHANCEMENTS, WETLAND RESTORATIONS, GRASSLAND RESTORATIONS (SEEDINGS), ROTATIONAL GRAZING SYSTEMS, ALTERNATIVE WATERING SYSTEMS FOR LIVESTOCK, PRESCRIBED GRASSLAND BURNS AND RIPARIAN RESTORATIONS. ADDITIONAL EMPHASIS WILL BE PLACED ON OUTREACH AND COMMUNICATION EFFORTS DESIGNED TO STRENGTHEN CONSERVATION PARTNERS IN NORTH DAKOTA AND CREATE ADDITIONAL HABITAT CONSERVATION OPPORTUNITIES. ALL INDIVIDUAL HABITAT PROJECTS WILL BE FACILITATED BY SITE-SPECIFIC PRIVATE LANDOWNER AGREEMENTS (PLAS) AS APPROVED AND ADMINISTERED BY THE SERVICE'S ND PFW PROGRAM. THE HABITAT PROJECTS COMPLETED PURSUANT TO THIS AGREEMENT WILL SIMULTANEOUSLY PROVIDE BENEFITS TO PRIVATE LANDOWNERS, LOCAL RURAL COMMUNITIES AND POPULATIONS OF A WIDE VARIETY OF BIRD SPECIES. ALL OF THESE ACTIONS AND ASSOCIATED RESULTS WILL HAVE DIRECT AND ENDURING BENEFITS TO THE PUBLIC IN THE FORM OF HEALTHIER BIRD POPULATIONS AND IMPROVEMENTS IN BOTH WATER AND AIR QUALITY. RESTORATION, ENHANCEMENT AND CREATION OF HABITATS FROM THIS PROJECT WILL CONTRIBUTE TOWARDS MEETING POPULATION AND HABITAT OBJECTIVES IDENTIFIED IN THE SERVICE'S 2022-2026 MOUNTAIN-PRAIRIE REGION STRATEGIC PLAN FOR THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM, THE NORTH DAKOTA STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN AND THE PRAIRIE POTHOLE JOINT VENTURE IMPLEMENTATION PLAN AND PPJV ND STATE TACTICAL PLAN.

THIS FENCING, UPLAND PLANTING, AND WETLAND HYDROLOGY HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECT CONSISTS OF THE REMOVAL OF APPROXIMATELY 1,150 FEET OF CHAIN LINK FENCING, AND INSTALLATION OF  1,100 FEET OF CATTLE FENCE AND GATE AND FENCING ALONG THE BOULEVARD NEEDED TO EXPAND CONSERVATION GAZING OPPORTUNITIES AT THE PRESERVE  A PORTION OF THE ADDITIONAL 3 ACRE EXPANSION AREA CONTAINS CONTIGUOUS WETLAND AREAS THAT ARE CONNECTED TO PREVIOUSLY ENHANCED WETLANDS, WHICH CURRENTLY SUPPORTS A SMALL TRICOLORED BLACKBIRD BREEDING COLONY  THE ADDITIONAL 3 ACRE AREA WILL PROVIDE NEEDED ADDITIONAL FORAGING HABITAT FOR TRICOLORED BLACKBIRDS DURING THE CRITICAL NESTING PERIOD, WHEN REPRODUCTIVE BIRDS NEED HIGH PROTEIN FOR EGG PRODUCTION AND FEEDING HATCHLINGS  ADDITIONAL IMPROVEMENTS INCLUDE  REMOVAL OF SALT CEDAR, DEVELOPING A LONGTERM TRICOLORED BLACKBIRD MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR THE AREA AND PLANTING 5 ACRES MILKWEED HABITAT TO BENEFIT MONARCHS, OTHER POLLINATORS, AND LOCAL WILDLIFE

THE KONA HEMA PRESERVE PROTECTS AN ANCIENT KOA-OHIA FOREST ALONG THE SOUTHWEST FLANK OF MAUNA LOA VOLCANO ON THE ISLAND OF HAWAII. THE PRESERVE FORMS A CORE PIECE OF CRITICALLY IMPORTANT CONSERVATION AREAS THAT INCLUDE PRIVATE LANDS, STATE NATURAL AREA RESERVES, AND HAWAII VOLCANOES NATIONAL PARK. THE NATURE CONSERVANCY HAS MANAGED THE AREA SINCE 2000 WITH EMPHASIS ON FENCING, REMOVING FERAL HOOFED ANIMALS, CONTROLLING INVASIVE PLANT POPULATIONS, AND MANAGING THE THREAT OF WILDFIRE. TODAY, THE PRESERVE IS THE LARGEST CONTIGUOUS AREA OF PRIORITY WATERSHED NATIVE FOREST IN THE SOUTH KONA REGION THAT IS FREE OF THE THREAT OF FERAL HOOFED ANIMALS. THIS PROJECT WILL ENSURE THE CONTINUED PROTECTION OF 8,073 ACRES OF NATIVE UPLAND FOREST BY REPLACING 17.5 MILES OF PERIMETER FENCING AT KONA HEMA PRESERVE. THIS WORK INVOLVES BRUSH REMOVAL ALONG THE EXISTING FENCE LINE FOLLOWED BY REMOVAL, DISPOSAL AND REPLACEMENT OF WOVEN WIRE FENCE BY STAFF, CONTRACTORS, INTERNS AND VOLUNTEERS. EACH 330-FOOT SECTION OF WOVEN WIRE WILL BE REMOVED FROM EXISTING FENCE POSTS AND NEW WIRE WILL BE INSTALLED ON THE SAME DAY TO ENSURE THAT NONNATIVE ANIMALS INCLUDING PIGS, GOATS AND SHEEP DO NOT ENTER THE PRESERVE. PROJECT FUNDING WILL SUPPORT LOCAL FENCE CONTRACTORS, A NEW FULL-TIME FIELD TECHNICIAN POSITION AT THE NATURE CONSERVANCY AND ADDITIONAL INTERNSHIP OPPORTUNITIES. IT IS EXPECTED THAT REPLACEMENT OF THE FULL 17.5 MILES OF PERIMETER FENCE WILL TAKE BETWEEN TWO-TO-FIVE YEARS TO COMPLETE AT A TOTAL COST OF  924,000. THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT APPROXIMATELY 25,000 PEOPLE IN SOUTH KONA WHO RELY ON THESE FORESTS FOR FRESH WATER AND EROSION CONTROL AND ENSURE CONTINUED PROTECTION OF NATIVE FLORA AND FAUNA THAT DEPEND ON HEALTHY KOA-OHIA FORESTS IN THE KONA FOREST BELT. WATERSHED CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES AT KONA HEMA PROTECT AN ESTIMATED 6.168 BILLION GALLONS OF FRESHWATER YIELD FROM THE TIME OF FENCE ESTABLISHMENT UNTIL 2065, AND TAKING INTO ACCOUNT COSTS, 383 GALLONS OF FRESHWATER ARE PROTECTED FOR EVERY DOLLAR SPENT AT KONA HEMA.

THE VENTURA COUNTY RESOURCE CONSERVATION DISTRICT WILL WORK IN PARTNERSHIP WITH A PRIVATE LANDOWNER AND THE SERVICE, TO IMPLEMENT A HABITAT IMPROVEMENT PROJECT BY PLANTING NATIVE COAST LIVE OAKS AND WESTERN SYCAMORES  THE OBJECTIVE IS TO RESTORE WILDLIFE HABITAT AND ENHANCE ECOLOGICAL HEALTH AT THE FOUR SITES  LONG TERM OBJECTIVES ARE TO PROVIDE VIABLE STANDS OF OAKS AND SYCAMORES TO SUPPORT NATURAL RECRUITMENT OF NATIVE SPECIES AND REESTABLISH CONDITIONS THAT SUPPORT NATIVE VEGETATION TO THE DOWNSLOPE RIPARIAN ZONE PROJECT LOCATION  THIS PROJECT WILL OCCUR IN AN AREA GENERALLY KNOWN AS BARLOW CANYON WHICH LIES IN THE FOOTHILLS NORTH OF VENTURA, CA  GENERAL PROJECT LOCATIONS ARE SHOWN IN FIGURE 1  WHILE SPECIFIC PROJECT LOCATIONS WILL BE IDENTIFIED IN PROJECT SPECIFIC WORK PLAN THAT WILL BE DEVELOPED BY VCRCS AND THE PRIVATE LANDOWNER  S   ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL OCCUR ON PRIVATE PROPERTIES BASELINE ASSESSMENT THE GENERAL PROJECT AREA IS CURRENTLY UTILIZED FOR AGRICULTURE SUCH AS IRRIGATED ORCHARDS AND CATTLE GRAZING  HABITAT CONDITIONS ARE CONSIDERED POOR QUALITY DUE TO THE LACK OF WOODY VEGETATION, INCLUDING SHRUBS AND TREES, WHICH WERE LOST IN THE 2017 THOMAS FIRE  WHILE THERE ARE GRASSES AND FORBS, THE LACK OF SHRUBS AND TREES MEANS THERE IS A LACK OF HABITAT FOR NESTING, FORAGING, AND COVER  STATEMENT OF PROBLEM THROUGHOUT CALIFORNIA, OVER A MILLION ACRES OF OAK HABITAT HAS BEEN LOST DUE TO TIMBER HARVEST, LAND USE CONVERSION, AND CLIMATE CHANGE INDUCED STRESSORS  WILDFIRE, DROUGHT, PESTS, ETC    FURTHERMORE, AS THESE TREES ARE LOST AND THEIR HABITAT FRAGMENTED, THERE ARE TOO FEW SPECIMENS AVAILABLE TO MAINTAIN NATURAL RECRUITMENT  THIS IS AN ESPECIALLY RELEVANT FACTOR IN THE PROPOSED PROJECT AREA  SINCE THERE ARE NO TREES TO PROVIDE SEEDS FOR NATURAL PROPAGATION AND SINCE THE PRESENCE OF GRAZING CATTLE INHIBIT REGROWTH OF NATURALLY RECRUITED SHRUBS AND TREES FROM CACHED SEEDS, ANTHROPOGENIC INTERVENTION IS NECESSITATED FURTHERMORE, THE LONG TERM ABSENCE OF WOODY VEGETATION, TREES ESPECIALLY, HAS LIKELY ALTERED THE HYDROLOGIC CYCLE BETWEEN THE UPLAND AND RIPARIAN AREA, CONTRIBUTING TO THE DECLINE OF VIABLE VEGETATION TO PROTECT THE INTERMITTENT STREAM CHANNEL AND REDUCING THE QUALITY AND QUANTITY OF AQUATIC RESOURCES FOR WILDLIFE  WITHOUT INTERVENTION, THIS RIPARIAN HABITAT IS LIKELY TO CONTINUE TO DEGRADE RESTORATION HYPOTHESIS THE RESTORATION HYPOTHESIS IS THAT ESTABLISHING OAK WOODLANDS IN BARLOW CANYON WILL PROVIDE WILDLIFE HABITAT AND ENHANCE THE CLIMATE RESILIENCY OF THE RESTORATION AREA  PROPOSED ACTIONS INCLUDE PLANTING APPROXIMATELY 400 TREES  OAKS AND SYCAMORES  AND MAINTAINING MONITORING THE TREES THROUGH ESTABLISHMENT  WE EXPECT TO RE ESTABLISH STANDS OF OAKS AND INCREASE THE NUMBERS AND ABUNDANCE OF WILDLIFE USING THESE OAK STANDS

THE TALLY HO CREEK STREAM RESTORATION PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE CALIFORNIA RED LEGGED FROG  RANA DRAYTONII  CRLF , STEELHEAD TROUT ONCORHYNCHUS MYKISS , AND OTHER NATIVE STREAM AND RIPARIAN DEPENDENT SPECIES BY RESTORING AND ENHANCING A STRETCH OF TALLY HO CREEK IN ARROYO GRANDE, CALIFORNIA  THE PROJECT AREA ENCOMPASSES APPROXIMATELY 220 LINEAR FEET OF TALLY HO CREEK, BORDERED ON EITHER SIDE BY RESIDENTIAL PROPERTIES  THE CREEK IS CHOKED WITH NON NATIVE VEGETATION, INCLUDING VINCA, CAPE IVY AND ENGLISH IVY  THE PROJECT SITE IS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 3 MILES UPSTREAM FROM THE FCC, WHERE INCREASED SEDIMENT DEPOSITION FROM UPSTREAM SOURCES IS RESULTING IN A RAPID DECLINE OF FLOOD PROTECTION CAPACITY, AS WELL AS DEGRADING HABITAT FOR THE FEDERALLY LISTED STEELHEAD TROUT AND CRLF  THE FCC PROVIDES PROTECTION TO THE DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITY OF OCEANO, AS WELL AS TO HUNDREDS OF ACRES OF PRIME FARMLAND IN THE CIENEGA VALLEY  THE PROJECT WILL REDUCE SEDIMENT DEPOSITION IN THE ARROYO GRANDE FLOOD CONTROL CHANNEL, WHICH WILL RESULT IN INCREASED FLOOD PROTECTION FOR DOWNSTREAM COMMUNITIES AND FARMLAND, AND IMPROVED HABITAT FOR FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES RESTORATION ACTIVITIES INCLUDE REPAIR OF A 4 FOOT HEAD CUT AT THE DOWNSTREAM TERMINUS OF THE PROJECT REACH, EXCAVATION OF A LOW FLOW CHANNEL ALONG APPROXIMATELY 220 LINEAR FEET OF STREAM CHANNEL, LOWERING THE CHANNEL BASE TO MEET THE GRADE DOWNSTREAM OF THE HEAD CUT, AND RESTORING NATIVE RIPARIAN HABITAT BY REMOVING INVASIVE SPECIES AND REVEGETATING WITH NATIVES  THE PROJECT WILL INCREASE THE CHANNEL S HIGH FLOW CAPACITY, REDUCE FLOODING, AND REDUCE SEDIMENT MOBILIZATION INTO THE DOWNSTREAM FLOOD CONTROL CHANNEL  AQUATIC AND RIPARIAN HABITAT IMPROVEMENTS HAVE BEEN DESIGNED TO SPECIFICALLY BENEFIT STEELHEAD TROUT AND CRLF

THIS PROJECT WILL ADDRESS AND REDUCE STREAM AND HABITAT CONCERNS IN THE WENATCHEE RIVER WATERSHED BY HARNESSING BEAVER POWERED RESTORATION REALIZED THROUGH LANDOWNER ASSISTANCE AND BEAVER RELOCATIONS  WE PROPOSE TO ASSIST 10 20 LANDOWNERS AND RELOCATE 15 25 BEAVERS  THROUGH THESE TECHNIQUES WE WILL RESTORE AND CONSERVE IMPORTANT NATURAL STREAM AND HABITAT PROCESSES, SUCH AS POOL QUALITY AND QUANTITY, FLOODPLAIN RECONNECTION, LATE SEASON FLOW AND WILDFIRE RESILIENCY ALONG APPROXIMATELY 20 ACRES AND 3 MILES OF STREAM

THE ENDANGERED PAHRUMP POOLFISH  EMPETRICHTHYS LATOS  WAS EXTIRPATED FROM ITS NATIVE HABITAT AT MANSE SPRING IN PAHRUMP, NEVADA IN THE MID 1970S AND HAS BEEN RELIANT ON REFUGIA SITES FOR SURVIVAL SINCE  ESTABLISHING ADDITIONAL REFUGIA FOR PAHRUMP POOLFISH WILL ASSIST IN ACHIEVING RECOVERY CRITERIA FOR RECLASSIFICATION OF PAHRUMP POOLFISH, WHICH INVOLVES MAINTAINING THREE POPULATIONS WITH A MINIMUM OF 500 ADULTS FOR THREE YEARS FOR DOWNLISTING  DELISTING CAN BE CONSIDERED AFTER AN ADDITIONAL THREE YEAR EVALUATION PERIOD THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL INCLUDE THE CREATION OF A REFUGIUM FOR THE PAHRUMP POOLFISH ON PRIVATE LANDS IN BEATTY, NEVADA  THE PROPOSED SITE IS A GOOD LOCATION FOR POOLFISH INTRODUCTION DUE TO IT BEING A SECURE LOCATION ON PRIVATE PROPERTY WITH LIMITED PUBLIC ACCESS  THE SITE WOULD ALSO BE ARTIFICIALLY CREATED OUTSIDE OF THE AMARGOSA RIVER AND AWAY FROM HABITATS OCCUPIED BY NATIVE AQUATIC SPECIES  THE SITE IS CURRENTLY A DEVELOPED SPRING  BARNES SPRING  THAT POSSESSES SUITABLE WATER TEMPERATURE  78  F  FOR PAHRUMP POOLFISH AND HAS NO NON NATIVE AQUATIC SPECIES  THOUGH THE PAHRUMP POOLFISH HAS EXHIBITED A WIDE RANGE OF TEMPERATURE TOLERANCES IN REFUGIA, THEY EVOLVED IN A SINGLE SPRING THAT WAS A RELATIVELY CONSTANT 75  F, WHICH WOULD MAKE BARNES SPRING THE CLOSEST TEMPERATURE TO THEIR HISTORICAL HABITAT THE SERVICE ANTICIPATES THE PROJECT ACTION WILL INVOLVE THE EXCAVATION OF A BELOW GROUND POND AND RE PIPING THE SPRING FLOW TO BRING WATER TO THE POND, AND FLOW OUT OF THE POND  THE FOOTPRINT OF THE REFUGIUM WILL BE APPROXIMATELY 0 1 TO 0 2 ACRES WITH A WATER DEPTH OF 10 TO 12 FEET  ADDITIONAL DESIGN FEATURES, MAY INCLUDE, LINING THE POND TO PREVENT VEGETATION GROWTH, SCREENING TO PREVENT POOLFISH FROM LEAVING THE POND, A SHALLOW SHELF THREE TO FOUR FEET WIDE FOR JUVENILE FISH, AND FENCING THE POND TO KEEP LIVESTOCK AND WILD BURROS OUT OF IT  THE NEVADA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE WILL BE A PARTNER IN THE PROJECT

THE YAKIMA RM 150 RIPARIAN RESTORATION PROJECT WILL IMPROVE WATER QUALITY AND FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT BY EXCLUDING CATTLE AND RESTORING RIPARIAN HABITAT ALONG 500 STREAM FT ON THE RIGHT BANK OF A YAKIMA RIVER SIDE CHANNEL  THE PROJECT WILL SLOW BANK EROSION, INCREASE SEDIMENTATION DURING SURFACE FLOWS, AND CREATE CANOPY COVER BY REFORESTING 1 7 ACRES OF RIPARIAN HABITAT

HISTORICALLY, THE WILLAMETTE VALLEY ECOREGION CONTAINED LARGE SWATHS OF OPEN PRAIRIE FILLED WITH DIVERSE PLANT AND ANIMAL COMMUNITIES  TODAY, LESS THAN ONE PERCENT OF THIS HABITAT REMAINS, DUE TO HUMAN IMPACTS SUCH AS AGRICULTURE, URBAN DEVELOPMENT AND FIRE SUPPRESSION  MOREOVER, THE REMAINING PRAIRIE HABITATS ARE OFTEN FRAGMENTED AND INVADED BY EXOTIC WEEDS  THIS HABITAT LOSS, FRAGMENTATION, AND DEGRADATION HAS PUT MANY SPECIES A RISK OF EXTINCTION  IN PARTICULAR, KINCAID S LUPINE  LUPINUS OREGANUS , A SPECIES IN THE FABACEAE FAMILY AND THE HOST PLANT FOR THE ENDANGERED FENDER S BLUE BUTTERFLY  ICARICIA ICARIOIDES FENDERI  WAS FEDERALLY LISTED AS THREATENED IN 2000 THE RECOVERY PLAN FOR THE PRAIRIE SPECIES OF WESTERN OREGON AND SOUTHWESTERN WASHINGTON IDENTIFIES THE NEED TO RESTORE AND MAINTAIN A FUNCTIONING POPULATION NETWORK ACROSS THE SPECIES  HISTORIC RANGE, WHICH IS DIVIDED INTO NINE RECOVERY ZONES  THE FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT HABITAT RESTORATION ACTIONS IN THE DOUGLAS COUNTY RECOVERY ZONE  SPECIFICALLY, RESTORATION ACTIONS WILL TAKE PLACE ON PRIVATE LAND OWNED BY CHINOOK FOREST MANAGEMENT BUT MAY ALSO OCCUR ON PRIVATE LAND WHERE THERE IS POTENTIAL TO AUGMENT OR INTRODUCE KINCAID S LUPINE  E G , STEVE DENNEY AND ELKTON RESERVE LAND TRUST PROPERTIES   THE IMPLEMENTATION PLAN INCLUDES REMOVING NON NATIVE SPECIES VIA MECHANICAL, MANUAL, AND CHEMICAL PRACTICES AND PLANTING NATIVE SPECIES AND KINCAID S LUPINE WITH PLUGS AND SEED

AMERICORPS PROGRAM TO SUPPORT HABITAT RESTORATION EFFORTS IN WEST VIRGINIA THE APPALACHIAN FOREST NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA  AFNHA  REQUESTS FUNDING TO PROVIDE A TOTAL OF SIX AMERICORPS MEMBERS OVER A THREE YEAR PERIOD FROM SEPTEMBER, 2022 THROUGH DECEMBER, 2025TO ASSIST THE USFWS APPALACHIAN FISH AND WILDLIFE COORDINATION OFFICE  AFWCO  AND THEWEST VIRGINIA FIELD OFFICE  WVFO  PARTNER FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM WITH THEIR FOREST SONGBIRD PARTNERSHIP, PRIVATE LANDS HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS, AND THEIR ENDANGERED SPECIES EDUCATION AND  OUTREACH NEEDS  POSITIONS WILL BE BASED DIRECTLY OUT OF THE AFWCO IN WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, WV AND THE WVFO IN DAVIS, WV AND WILL BE UNDER DIRECT SUPERVISION OF AFWCO AND WVFO STAFF AFNHA WILL PROVIDE AMERICORPS MEMBERS FOR THE U S  FISH AND  WILDLIFE SERVICE  THESE POSITIONS WILL ASSIST THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM IN THE WEST VIRGINIA FIELD OFFICE AND THEAPPALACHIAN FISH AND WILDLIFE CONSERVATION OFFICE  FOR A TWO YEAR PERIOD, TWO OF THE POSITIONS WILL FOCUS ON THE FOREST SONGBIRD RESTORATION PROGRAM AS WELL AS ASSIST WITH EDUCATION AND OUTREACH NEEDS AND PRIVATE LANDOWNER OUTREACH AND A VARIETY OF ADDITIONAL FIELD WORKOPPORTUNITIES  FOR A TWO YEAR PERIOD, THE THIRD POSITION WILL FOCUS ON PRIVATE LANDS HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS AND OUTREACH RELATED TO PRIORITY SPECIES ACROSS THE STATE  SPECIFICALLY, THIS COULD INCLUDE DEVELOPING AND IMPLEMENTING OUTREACH PROGRAMS ON ENDANGERED FRESHWATER MUSSEL AND BAT CONSERVATION AND WEST VIRGINIA S NON NATIVE INVASIVE SPECIES, MANAGING AND RECRUITINGVOLUNTEERS TO ASSIST WITH PFW TASKS, AND NON NATIVE INVASIVE SPECIES CONTROL AND ERADICATIONACTIVITIES  AFNHA IN COOPERATION WITH THE AFWCO   WVFO WOULD DEVELOP AND MODIFY POSITIONDESCRIPTIONS EACH YEAR BASED ON THE MUTUAL NEEDS OF THE ORGANIZATIONS  AFNHA WILL THEN ANNUALLY RECRUIT APPLICANTS TO MEET THE NEEDS OF THE POSITIONS

NOFO  F22AS00095CFDA  15 631APPLIANT NAME  MILLS RIVER PARTNERSHIPTITLE  MILLS RIVER PARK STREAT AND ENHANCEMENT AND POLLLUTANT REDUCTIONPROJECT ABSTRACT  THE MILLS RIVER PARK PROPERTY WAS HISTORICALLY USED FOR FARMING  BOTTOMLAND IS SCARCE AND VALUABLE IN THE MOUNTAINS, SO IT WAS COMMON PRACTICE TO RELOCATE STREAMS INTO STRAIGHT DITCHES AND MOVE THEM TO ONE SIDE OF THE FIELD OR PROPERTY  THAT IS THE CASE WITH TWO STREAMS AT THE PARK  THE BENTHOS IS GREATLY DEGRADED DUE TO CONSTANT RUNOFF FROM AN ADJACENT DAIRY AND THE OTHER STREAM IS INUNDATED WITH SEDIMENT FROM A POORLY MAINTAINED PUBLIC GRAVEL ROAD  THE STREAMS CONVERGE NEAR THE MILLS RIVER ON THE SE CORNER OF THE PARK PROPERTY AND RUN DIRECTLY INTO THE MILLS RIVER A 100 FEET AWAY  THE MILLS RIVER IS A DRINKING WATER SOURCE FOR HENDERSONVILLE AND ASHEVILLE AND THIS PROJECT IS A HALF MILE UPSTREAM OF A WATER PLANT INTAKE  SEDIMENT AND FECAL COLIFORM ARE CONCERNS FOR THE WATER PLANT  THERE ARE SEVERAL SPECIES OF CRITICAL CONCERN IN THE MILLS RIVER WITH KNOWN LOCATION RECORDS NEAR THE CONFLUENCE WITH THIS UNNAMED STREAM  SLIPPER SHELL MUSSELS AND HELLBENDER SALAMANDERS HAVE BEEN FOUND IN THAT STRETCH OF RIVER, AS WELL AS THE ENDANGERED APPALACHIAN ELK TOE MUSSEL  ELIMINATING SEDIMENT LOADING TO THE MILLS RIVER WILL IMPROVE HABITAT FOR THESE SPECIES MILLS RIVER IS FAMOUS FOR DIVERSE BIRD SPECIES AND THE AREA IS A STOPOVER FOR MANY MIGRATING BIRDS  THE GREY BAT ROOSTS IN TREES ALONG THE RIVER  THIS PROJECT WILL INCREASE FOOD FOR THE BATS BY INCREASING HEALTHY HABITAT  MEANDERING THE STREAMS AND RETURNING THEM TO THEIR NATURAL STATE WILL PROVIDE ADDITIONAL HABITAT BY INCREASING THE FOOTPRINT OF THE STREAM AND RIPARIAN AREAS  ADDING NATIVE TREES AND SHRUBS WILL PROVIDE FOOD AND SHELTER TO POLLINATORS, BIRDS AND MACROINVERTEBRATES IN THE STREAMS SLOPING THE BANKS OF THE STREAM AND ADDING NATURAL BENDS WILL REDUCE SHEER STRESS DURING HEAVY RAIN EVENTS  LESS SHEER STRESS WILL IMPROVE BENTHIC SPECIES OVERALL BECAUSE THEY WILL NOT JUST WASH AWAY WITH EVERY STORM  USING NATURAL CHANNEL DESIGN ENGINEERING TECHNIQUES, THE STREAMS WILL BE RESTORED TO A MORE NATURAL STATE, WITH POOLS AND RIFFLES ADDING ADDITIONAL NICHE HABITAT FOR SMALL FISH AND MACROINVERTEBRATES  THERE MAY BE POTENTIAL TO MOVE THE SOUTH STREAM AWAY FROM THE ROAD DURING RESTORATION, GREATLY REDUCING SEDIMENT NATIVE PLANT SPECIES WILL INCLUDE ELDERBERRY, NINEBARK, SILKY DOGWOOD, RIVER BIRCH, MAPLE, SYCAMORE, SPICEBUSH, ECHINACEA, RIVER CANE, JUNCUS AND MANY OTHER WATER LOVING NATIVE PLANTS THAT CAN STABILIZE THE STREAM BANKS, REDUCE EROSION AND SHADE THE STREAMS  MILLS RIVER HAS LOST SO MANY HEMLOCK TREES IN RECENT YEARS, THE WATER TEMPERATURE IS INCREASING AND STRESSING AQUATIC SPECIES  SHADING THESE SMALL TRIBUTARIES WILL BE INCREASINGLY IMPORTANT FOR MAINTAIN COOL RIVER TEMPS THAT SO MANY SPECIES REQUIRE THIS RESTORATION WILL TURN THE  DITCH  INTO AN AESTHETICALLY PLEASING NATURAL FEATURE FOR PARK VISITORS  FURTHERMORE, IT WILL OFFER EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR CLASSES TO COME AND LEARN ABOUT WATER QUALITY AND AQUATIC SPECIES  THE PARK INTENDS TO ADD AND AN ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION COORDINATOR SOON AND WILL UTILIZE THE STREAM AS AN OUTDOOR CLASSROOM  ADDITIONALLY, MILLS RIVER PARTNERSHIP AND LOCAL TEACHERS WILL NOW HAVE MORE OPPORTUNITIES FOR WORKSHOPS AND CLASSES AND VOLUNTEER DAYS AT THE PARK  WE WILL LEAD VOLUNTEERS IN PLANTING LIVE STAKES ALONG THE STREAM BANKS  A FEW YEARS AFTER CONSTRUCTION, WE WILL HOST VOLUNTEER INVASIVE REMOVAL WORKSHOPS  ALL THESE VOLUNTEER DAYS HELP TO MAINTAIN THE PROJECT AND ALSO EDUCATE THE COMMUNITY THE PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN STATE, FEDERAL, LOCAL AND NON PROFIT ENTITIES, MAKES THIS AN IDEAL PROJECT THAT WILL HAVE MAXIMUM BENEFIT FOR THE COMMUNITY  THE COST OF THE PROJECT WILL BE SHARED BETWEEN LEVELS OF GOVERNMENT AND MILLS RIVER PARTNERSHIP

PALMAS POND WETLANDS IN SOUTHEAST PUERTO RICO HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED AS AN AREA IN NEED OF RESTORATION DUE TO THEIR IMPORTANCE AS HABITAT FOR NATIVE AND MIGRATORY WATERFOWL AND ITS DESIGNATION AS A CRITICAL WILDLIFE AREA  THIS AREA WAS ONCE USED TO PROMOTE HUNTING AND SPORT FISH ACTIVITIES  HOWEVER, IT HAS BEEN DEGRADED BY WEEDY SPECIES AND POSSIBLY HYDROLOGICAL DISRUPTIONS PROTECTORES DE CUENCAS  PDC  INTENDS TO COMPLETE THE PLANNING PHASE FOR THE INTERVENTION OF PALMAS POND RESTORATION ACTIVITIES THROUGH THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES  1  COORDINATE WITH PRIVATE LANDOWNERS TO DISCUSS PROJECT PLANS AND OPPORTUNITIES  2  CONDUCT A HYDROLOGIC AND HYDRAULIC  HAND H  STUDY AND A HYDROLOGICAL ANALYSIS  3  ASSESS THE PRESENCE OF INVASIVE SPECIES AND RECOMMEND ACTIONS TO CONTROL THEM  4  DEVELOP A PRELIMINARY SCHEMATIC DESIGN  AND 5  COMPLETE THE PRELIMINARY ENVIRONMENTAL PERMITTING AND COMPLIANCE  THE TARGETED CONSERVATION AREAS PROVIDE AGRICULTURAL LANDS AND HABITAT FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES, INCLUDING RESIDENT AND MIGRATORY BIRDS  IN ADDITION, THIS PROJECT BUILDS UPON AN ONGOING COASTAL PROGRAM FUNDED PROJECT WITH PDC TO RESTORE COASTAL AND WETLANDS ECOSYSTEMS WITHIN THE NORTHEAST ECOLOGICAL CORRIDOR NATURE RESERVE OF PUERTO RICO THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE FIVE PRIVATE LANDOWNERS OF THE WETLANDS BY PREPARING FOR THE RESTORATION OF THE IMPORTANT WETLAND ECOSYSTEM, WHICH IS EXPECTED TO FUNCTION AS PART OF AN ECOLOGICAL CORRIDOR AMONG WETLANDS  PDC ALSO EXPECTS THE RESTORATION ACTIVITIES TO BRING BACK NATIVE SPECIES AND THEREFORE ENHANCE RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR HUNTERS, ANGLERS, AND OTHER OUTDOOR INTERESTS  THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT ARE  1  ENGAGE A TOTAL OF FIVE PRIVATE LANDOWNERS SURROUNDING PALMAS POND TO PARTICIPATE IN THE RESTORATION OF THE PALMAS PALMS WETLANDS  2  IMPROVE PALMAS POND WETLAND HEALTH AND RESILIENCY THROUGH INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT AND THE RESTORATION OF NATIVE VEGETATION  AND 3  IMPROVE THE HABITATS OF THREATENED AND ESA LISTED SPECIES

THIS PROJECT IS LOCATED ALONG SEVERAL BIOLOGICALLY IMPORTANT RIPARIAN REACHES IN THE UPPER KLAMATH BASIN  THE PROJECT AREA RIPARIAN REACHES AND SURROUNDING AREAS WERE BURNED OVER IN THE 2021 BOOTLEG FIRE  MOST OF THE SHRUBS AND OR TREES IN THE RIPARIAN AREAS WE ARE TARGETING WERE KILLED IN THE WILDFIRE  THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO STABILIZE RIPARIAN AREAS, STREAMBANKS, AND SOILS BY PLANTING NATIVE TREES IN SELECTED RIPARIAN AREAS THAT WERE IMPACTED BY THE BOOTLEG FIRE  TREES WILL ADD STRENGTH AND STABILITY TO RIPARIAN AREA SOILS, WILL HELP TO MINIMIZE SOIL EROSION, AND WILL HELP KEEP STREAMBANKS INTACT  AS TREES GROW, THEY WILL PROVIDE FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT, SHADE, AND FUTURE LARGE WOODY STRUCTURE TO THE STREAMS  FUTURE LARGE WOODY STRUCTURE IN STREAMS WILL EVENTUALLY ENHANCE FISH HABITAT BY CREATING COMPLEXITY IN THE AREAS  MINIMIZING EROSION WILL PROTECT WATER QUALITY AND BENEFIT AQUATIC HABITAT WITHIN THE TREATED REACHES AND EVEN DOWNSTREAM  SPECIES LIKELY TO BENEFIT FROM THIS PROJECT ARE RESIDENT NATIVE FISH INCLUDING ENDANGERED LOST RIVER  DELTISTES LUXATUS  AND SHORTNOSE SUCKERS  CHASMISTES BREVIROSTRIS , REDBAND TROUT  ONCORHYNCHUS MYKISS GAIRDNERII  AND BULL TROUT  FURTHER, MANY SPECIES OF RIPARIAN DEPENDENT AND NEOTROPICAL BIRDS, POLLINATORS, AND OTHER SHRUBBY RIPARIAN HABITAT DEPENDENT SPECIES ARE LIKELY TO BENEFIT FROM THIS PROJECT  E G  YELLOW BILLED CUCKOO AND MONARCH  1800 ACRES OF RIPARIAN PLANTING WILL BE DONE

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONDUCT RESTORATION WORK AT FOUR SITES TO IMPROVE CONDITIONS FOR BOG TURTLES  GLYPTEMYS MUHLENBERGII  AND OTHER RARE SPECIES ASSOCIATED WITH SOUTHERN APPALACHIAN MOUNTAIN BOGS TANGLED BANK CONSERVATION APPLIED AND COMPETED FOR FUNDING FROM THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM IN FEBRUARY, 2022  THE AWARD WAS APPROVED  THE GOALS AND PURPOSE OF THE PROJECT IS TO RESTORE HABITAT FOR THE FEDERALLY THREATENED BY SIMILARITY OF APPEARANCE SOUTHERN BOG TURTLE ON PRIVATE LANDS IN WESTERN NC  ALL PROJECTS ARE VOLUNTARY  SOUTHERN APPALACHIAN BOGS ARE THREATENED BY INTENTIONAL DRAINAGE OF WETLANDS FOR OTHER USES  ACTIVITIES WILL BE PLANNED AND WORK TOGETHER WITH PARTNERS, US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  SERVICE  AND THE LANDOWNERS  PRACTICES INCLUDE CONVERTING FORESTED BOGS INTO A WET MEADOW BOG BY REMOVING TREES AND SHRUBS, PLUGGING DRAINAGE DITCHES TO RESTORE THE WETLANDS, REMOVAL AND TREATMENT OF INVASIVE EXOTIC, NON NATIVE SPECIES, AND MONITORING  RESTORATION AND SPECIES   DELIVERABLES INCLUDE PROJECT COORDINATION WITH THE SERVICE  WORKING WITH THE PRIVATE LANDOWNERS TO CONDUCT VOLUNTARY HABITAT RESTORATION WITHIN A SPECIFIED TIMEFRAME  DEVELOPING LANDOWNER AGREEMENTS PER PROJECT BETWEEN THE LANDOWNER, TANGLED BANK CONSERVATION, AND THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  UPDATING AND MAINTAINING PROJECT STATUS WITH THE PROJECT OFFICER WITH THE SERVICE  PERFORMING THE HABITAT RESTORATION WITHIN A SPECIFIED TIME PERIOD, AND SUBMITTING PERFORMANCE AND FINANCIAL REPORTING TO THE SERVICE REPRESENTATIVE WITHIN THE PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE SPECIFIED  THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE PRIVATE LANDOWNER WHERE THE PROJECT IS UNDERTAKEN, AND THE AQUATIC WILDLIFE FROM THE RESULTS OF RESTORED WETLAND HABITAT  THERE ARE NO SUB RECIPIENTS  THIS PROJECT WILL SERVE PRIVATE LANDOWNERS IN WESTERN NORTH CAROLINA WITHIN HIGH PRIORITY AREAS WERE RARE WILDLIFE POPULATIONS MAY OCCUR

THIS PROJECT WILL RESTORE NATIVE CHESAPEAKE BAY TIDAL WETLAND COMMUNITIES INCLUDING NATIVE FLORAL AND FAUNAL SPECIES WITH A SPECIAL FOCUS ON SALT MARSH BREEDING BIRDS  AUDUBON WILL PLAN AND IMPLEMENT RESTORATION OF NATURAL HYDROLOGY, ELEVATION, AND NATIVE FLORAL AND FAUNAL COMMUNITIES IN TIDAL WETLANDS IN THE CHESAPEAKE BAY REGION OF MARYLAND S EASTERN SHORE  SINCE THE 1930 S, THOUSANDS OF ACRES OF TIDAL WETLANDS HAVE BEEN LOST IN THIS AREA DUE TO A COMBINATION OF SEA LEVEL RISE, NUTRIA HERBIVORY, AND OTHER FACTORS  THIS REGION IS EXTREMELY IMPORTANT AS MIGRATING AND WINTERING HABITAT FOR WATERFOWL, BREEDING GROUNDS FOR AT RISK SALTMARSH BIRDS SUCH AS THE SALTMARSH SPARROW AND BLACK RAIL, AND IS ALSO ONE OF THE CHESAPEAKE BAY S MOST PRODUCTIVE ESTUARINE ASSETS, SUPPORTING DIVERSE AQUATIC AND EMERGENT PLANT AND ANIMAL COMMUNITIES AUDUBON WILL WORK WITH THE U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  SERVICE  CHESAPEAKE BAY FIELD OFFICE AND CHESAPEAKE MARSHLANDS NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE COMPLEX, THROUGH THE RESTORATION AND ADAPTATION COMMITTEE OF THE DELMARVA RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION NETWORK  DRCN , DEVELOP AN IMPLEMENTATION PLAN FOR MARSH RESTORATION ON A LANDSCAPE SCALE IN THE CHESAPEAKE BAY REGION OF MARYLAND S EASTERN SHORE  THIS PLAN SHOULD DESCRIBE MEASURES TO RESTORE TIDAL WETLANDS DEGRADED BY SEA LEVEL RISE, NUTRIA HERBIVORY AND OTHER FACTORS, INCLUDING SPATIALLY EXPLICIT PRIORITIZATION OF PROJECT SITES AND MEASURES TO STREAMLINE THE PERMITTING PROCESS  THE PLAN SHOULD INCLUDE STRATEGIES FOR MAKING TIDAL MARSHES MORE RESILIENT TO CLIMATE CHANGE, INCLUDING RESTORATION AND PROTECTION OF LANDS IN SEA LEVEL RISE WETLAND MIGRATION CORRIDORS  USING TECHNIQUES IDENTIFIED THROUGH STRATEGIC IMPLEMENTATION PLANNING, WORK WITH SERVICE AND OTHER DRCN PARTNERS TO BEGIN TO RESTORE DAMAGED TIDAL MARSH ON PRIVATE LANDS IN THE CHESAPEAKE BAY REGION OF MARYLAND S EASTERN SHORE  THIS SHOULD BE COORDINATED CLOSELY WITH RELATED TIDAL MARSH RESTORATION IMPLEMENTATION ACTIVITIES ON PUBLIC LANDS  RESTORATION MEASURES CAN BE EXPECTED TO INCLUDE COMBINATIONS OF THIN LAYER APPLICATION OF DREDGED MATERIAL, RUNNELS, STRATEGIC DITCH FILLING, RESTORATION OF NATURAL HYDROLOGY, AND INVASIVE SPECIES CONTROL, BOTH IN HISTORICAL TIDAL MARSHES AND IN SEA LEVEL RISE WETLAND MIGRATION CORRIDORS

COASTAL ECOSYSTEMS IN THE MAIN HAWAIIAN ISLANDS WERE ONCE DOMINATED BY SEABIRDS AND NATIVE PLANTS. AT PRESENT LESS THAN HALF OF THE COASTLINE SUPPORTS NATIVE VEGETATION AND 60 PERCENT OF THIS HABITAT IS SEVERELY DEGRADED  ONLY 17 PERCENT IS HIGH QUALITY HABITAT. SEABIRDS ARE MOSTLY ABSENT AND MANY OTHER PARTS OF THE ECOSYSTEM ARE ENDANGERED, INCLUDING ENDEMIC PLANTS AND NATIVE POLLINATOR SPECIES. INVASIVE, NON NATIVE PREDATORS AND HERBIVORES ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR MOST OF THIS LOSS.THIS PROJECT S MAIN FOCUS IS ON THE CONSTRUCTION OF A 1.1 MILE PREDATOR PROOF FENCE TO PROTECT 90 ACRES ALONG   OF A MILE OF SHORELINE IN FEDERALLY DESIGNATED CRITICAL HABITAT. THE PROJECT LOCATION IS ONE OF FIVE PRIORITY WORK SITES IN THE MAIN HAWAIIAN ISLANDS AS PER THE USFWS COASTAL PROGRAM S 2016 2021 STRATEGIC PLAN, AND MOLOKAI LAND TRUST (MLT) AND AMERICAN BIRD CONSERVANCY (ABC) ARE LISTED AS A KEY PARTNERS.  ALONG WITH PROTECTIONS FOR GROUND NESTING SEABIRDS, THE PROJECT WILL ALSO PROTECT NUMEROUS ENDANGERED PLANT SPECIES POPULATIONS AND ENDANGERED HAWAIIAN YELLOW FACE BEE POPULATIONS.  THESE THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES ARE NATURALLY EXPANDING THEIR POPULATIONS DUE TO HABITAT RESTORATION WITHIN THE CURRENT 60 ACRE SITE, WHICH IS PROTECTED BY A TEMPORARY FENCE EXCLUDING UNGULATES AND CURRENTLY MANAGED FOR HABITAT RESTORATION.  TWO RARE SPECIES THAT WERE EXTINCT IN THE WILD HAVE BEEN REINTRODUCED THROUGH A PARTNERSHIP WITH THE STATE OF HAWAII DLNR, INCLUDING THE STATE FLOWER HIBISCUS BRACKENRIDGEII OR MAO HAU HELE. PERMITS AND THE CONSTRUCTION MATERIALS HAVE BEEN SECURED, THESE FUNDS WOULD SUPPORT THE ACTUAL FENCE CONSTRUCTION.

BIDWELL CREEK IS A 12 MILE LONG PERENNIAL CREEK ON THE NORTH END OF SURPRISE VALLEY IN MODOC COUNTY, CA  THE CREEK SUPPLIES WATER TO THE UPPER ALKALI LAKE AND IS A VITAL CREEK TO SUPPORT THE FISHERIES IN SURPRISE VALLEY  BIDWELL CREEK S FISHES INCLUDE REDBAND TROUT, RAINBOW TROUT, AND MODOC SUCKER  THIS PROPERTY RECEIVED FUNDING FOR UPLAND RESTORATION IN 2011 FROM THE PARTNERS PROGRAM AND NRCS  THAT PROJECT COMPLETED A LARGE JUNIPER REMOVAL THROUGHOUT THE SAGE STEPPE HABITAT AND FENCE UPDATES TO MAKE WILDLIFE SAFE  THIS PROJECT WILL CONTINUE THE OVERALL HABITAT RESTORATION NEEDS OF THE LANDSCAPE  THIS PROJECT WILL ADDRESS INCISION AND FLOODPLAIN DISCONNECTION DOWNSTREAM OF A DIVERSION STRUCTURE IN BIDWELL CREEK  INSTALLATION OF A DIVERSION STRUCTURE AND STRAITENING OF THE CREEK BELOW THE DIVERSION CAUSED THE SUBSEQUENT DEGRADATION OF THE STREAM  ADDITIONALLY, AN OLD OXBOW HAS BEEN DEEPENED AND DISCONNECTED FROM THE HYDROLOGIC INFLUENCE OF FLOOD FLOWS  THIS OXBOW NOW FORD S POND OAK HABITAT RESTORATION   PHASE II, PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARYFORD S POND, IN SOUTHWESTERN OREGON, IS A 202 ACRE PROPERTY THAT INCLUDES A 95 ACRE FORMER LOG POND  SINCE ACQUIRING THE PROPERTY IN 2014, THE CITY OF SUTHERLIN, ALONG WITH THE FRIENDS OF FORD S POND, HAVE BEEN WORKING TO RESTORE AND DEVELOP THE PROPERTY AS A COMMUNITY PARK  WITH ITS LARGE POND AND VARIETY OF HABITAT TYPES, THE PROPERTY HAS GREAT POTENTIAL FOR SENSITIVE AND FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES ALONG WITH RESIDENT AND MIGRATORY BIRDS  A PLAN TO RESTORE OAK SAVANNA ON THE WESTERN PORTION OF THE PROPERTY WOULD PROVIDE VALUABLE HABITAT FOR THE PREVIOUSLY ENDANGERED COLUMBIAN WHITE TAILED DEER, OAK OBLIGATE NEOTROPICAL MIGRANT BIRDS, AND AT RISK POLLINATORS  OREGON S OAK HABITATS ARE THOUGHT TO SUSTAIN HIGHER LEVELS OF BIODIVERSITY THAN ANY OTHER UPLAND ECOSYSTEM TYPE IN THE STATE, BUT WITH LESS THAN 6  OF HISTORICAL OAK HABITAT STILL ON THE LANDSCAPE, IT IS ESSENTIAL THAT WE CONSERVE AND RESTORE THOSE THAT REMAIN PHASE I OF THE PROJECT FOCUSED ON THE WESTERNMOST 25 ACRES OF THE SITE, AND PHASE II WILL FOCUS ON AN ADJACENT 25 30 ACRES  THE RESTORATION PLAN AGAIN INCLUDES TREATING NON NATIVE, INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES WITH CUTTING OR MOWING AND HERBICIDE, SEED COLLECTION  AND PURCHASE , PLANT PROPAGATION AND OUTPLANTING, ALONG WITH SITE PREPARATION AND SEEDING NATIVE PLANTS  NOT ONLY WILL THE PROJECT ENHANCE AND RESTORE HABITAT FOR THE MULTITUDE OF SPECIES THAT DEPEND ON IT, BUT IT WILL ALSO PROVIDE A GREAT OPPORTUNITY FOR COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT, ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION, AND CONSERVATION STEWARDSHIP  BESIDES THE CITY OF SUTHERLIN AND FRIENDS OF FORD S POND, PROJECT PARTNERS INCLUDE SUTHERLIN HIGH SCHOOL  FUTURE FARMERS OF AMERICA STUDENTS AND TEACHER , LOCAL CONTRACTORS, AND A NUMBER OF SKILLED AND DEDICATED VOLUNTEERS

THE PURPOSE OF THIS COOP AGREEMENT IS TO BUILD A CAPACITY AND FUNDING PARTNERSHIP TO FACILITATE COOPERATION BETWEEN THE RECIPIENT  PHEASANTS FOREVER  AND THE SERVICE ON VARIOUS MUTUALLY ACCEPTABLE CONSERVATION EFFORTS THAT BENEFIT PRIORITY LANDSCAPES OF NORTHEAST WYOMING  THE OVERALL GOAL IS TO   A  CREATE THE NECESSARY CAPACITY  PF BIOLOGISTS  TO RESTORE, ENHANCE, MANAGE, MONITOR, AND EVALUATE UPLAND AND MESIC HABITAT  AND  B  CONTRIBUTE TOWARDS POPULATION AND HABITAT OBJECTIVES FOR FEDERALLY LISTED ENDANGERED AND THREATENED SPECIES, OTHER FEDERAL TRUST RESOURCES, STATE DESIGNATED PRIORITY SPECIES AND IMPORTANT SPECIES OF OUR CONSERVATION PARTNERS  THIS PARTNERSHIP EFFORT WILL ALSO ATTRACT ADDITIONAL FUNDING FROM OTHER SOURCES  THIS AGREEMENT ARRANGEMENT WILL CONTRIBUTE TOWARDS THE RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT OF THE ECOLOGICAL FUNCTIONS AND VALUES OF NATIVE ECOSYSTEMS IN WYOMING  THIS PROJECT WILL RESTORE AND ENHANCE WET MEADOW WETLAND AND UPLAND HABITATS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE SPECIES NATIVE TO THE AREA  RESTORATION OF HABITATS FROM THIS PROJECT WILL CONTRIBUTE TOWARDS MEETING HABITAT OBJECTIVES IDENTIFIED IN THE SERVICE S 2022 2026 MOUNTAIN PRAIRIE REGION STRATEGIC PLAN FOR THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM, AND THE WYOMING STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN, AND IS CONSISTENT WITH AND ALL WILL CONTRIBUTE TOWARD THE MISSION OF THE RECIPIENT

THE PURPOSE OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS TO ESTABLISH A WORKING PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE SERVICE AND THE RECIPIENT FOR THE PURPOSE OF PROMOTING CONSERVATION ON PRIVATE LANDS. THE RECIPIENT WILL FACILITATE THE DEVELOPMENT OF CONSERVATION PROJECTS AND WORK COOPERATIVELY WITH THE SERVICE TO IDENTIFY, DEVELOP, AND ESTABLISH MUTUALLY BENEFICIAL CONSERVATION PROJECTS. ALL PROJECTS WILL BE FACILITATED BY SITE-SPECIFIC PRIVATE LAND OWNER AGREEMENTS (PLAS) AS APPROVED AND ADMINISTERED BY THE SERVICE. THIS AGREEMENT WILL RESTORE, ENHANCE, AND ESTABLISH HABITATS FOR THE BENEFIT OF (1) FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES; (2) SAGEBRUSH OBLIGATE BIRDS; (3) NATIVE FISH(4) MIGRATORY WATERBIRDS; AND (5) OTHER GAME SPECIES. RESTORATION OF HABITATS WITHIN HIGH PRIORITY CONSERVATION FOCUS AREAS WILL CONTRIBUTE TOWARDS MEETING POPULATION AND HABITAT OBJECTIVES IDENTIFIED IN THE SERVICE'S 2022-2026 MOUNTAIN-PRAIRIE REGION STRATEGIC PLAN FOR THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM.

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO SUPPORT CONSERVATION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT ON PRIVATE AND PUBLIC LANDS IN THE BLACKFOOT WATERSHED OF MONTANA VIA A COMMUNITY BASED LANDSCAPE SCALE APPROACH  THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL FACILITATE COORDINATION BETWEEN THE SERVICE AND THE BLACKFOOT CHALLENGE ON VARIOUS RESTORATION PROJECTS, INCLUDING INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT AND PREDATOR CONFLICT ABATEMENT PROJECTS THROUGHOUT THE WATERSHED FUNDING UNDER THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL BE USED TO RESTORE HABITAT FOR FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES SUCH AS MIGRATORY BIRDS BY REMOVING INVASIVE SPECIES, INCLUDING ENCROACHING CONIFERS, FROM PRIORITY GRASSLAND AND SAGEBRUSH HABITATS  INVASIVE SPECIES REMOVAL PROJECTS MAY OCCUR ON FEDERAL LANDS BUT WILL SUPPORT PROJECTS ON ADJACENT PRIVATE LANDS THROUGH POTENTIAL COST SAVINGS ON MOBILIZATION DE MOBILIZATION AND ECONOMIES OF SCALE  IN ADDITION, BY TREATING ALL THE LAND IN AN AREA, WE CAN HELP REDUCE THE SEED SOURCE AND ENHANCE THE LONGEVITY OF THE HABITAT RESTORATION ACTIVITIES ON ADJACENT PRIVATE LANDS  FURTHERMORE, TREATING FEDERAL LANDS ADJACENT TO PRIVATE LANDS WILL HELP IMPROVE HABITAT CONNECTIVITY AND FACILITATE WILDLIFE DISPERSAL FUNDS UNDER THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL ALSO BE USED TO SUPPORT HUMAN GRIZZLY BEAR CONFLICT ABATEMENT IN THE BLACKFOOT VALLEY  THIS BLACKFOOT VALLEY IS WITHIN THE NORTHERN CONTINENTAL DIVIDE RECOVERY ZONE, AND THE MOST RECENT SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENT IDENTIFIED REDUCING HUMAN GRIZZLY CONFLICTS ON PRIVATE LANDS AS AN IMPORTANT FACTOR FOR REDUCING HUMAN CAUSED GRIZZLY MORTALITY AND HABITAT FRAGMENTATION IN THIS RECOVERY ZONE  SSA  SERVICE, 2022   ADDRESSING THESE STRESSORS WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE RECOVERY OF THIS SPECIES

KNIK TRIBE  KT  WILL HOST TWO COMBINATION VIRTUAL AND IN PERSON TRAININGS  ONE TRAINING WILL COVER WILLOW PLANTING  THE IN PERSON WORKSHOP WILLOW PLANTING WILL ALSO IMPROVE RIPARIAN HABITAT ON A KNIKATNU PARCEL ADJACENT TO COTTONWOOD CREEK  THE SECOND TRAINING WILL COVER ANADROMOUS WATERS CATALOG  AWC  SAMPLING USING MINNOW TRAPS  THIS TRAINING WILL INCREASE CAPACITY AT KT TO ENGAGE IN AWC WORK IN THEIR DISTRICT AND INCREASE CAPACITY AT OTHER ORGANIZATIONS  THE TRAINING WILL CONTINUE TO SPREAD THE MESSAGE OF THE AWC AND ENCOURAGE ORGANIZATIONS TO UNDERTAKE STREAM SAMPLING IN ORDER TO EFFECTIVELY MONITOR FISH POPULATIONS  SEVERAL WATERBODIES ON KNIKATNU LAND AND ELSEWHERE WITHIN THE KNIK DISTRICT HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED AS LIKELY SALMON HABITAT WITHOUT AWC NOMINATION  A SAMPLING EFFORT TO DETERMINE IF JUVENILE SALMON OCCUR IN THESE WATERBODIES WILL PROVIDE AWC PROTECTIONS AND DIRECT FUTURE RESTORATION EFFORTS

THE REESE RIVER IS A TRIBUTARY OF THE HUMBOLDT RIVER BUT IN RECENT YEARS HAS DWINDLED INTO A CHAIN OF SHALLOW POOLS BEFORE IT REACHES THE HUMBOLDT RIVER  THE LACK OF WATER PREVENTS THE DISTRIBUTION OF GRAZING PRESSURE ACROSS THE AREA, THEREBY LEADING TO AREAS BEING HEAVILY USED WHILE OTHERS ARE NOT USED AT ALL AND A HIGHER IMPACT IN MESIC AREAS  IN PHASE II, A WATER PIPELINE WILL BE CONNECTED TO THE SOLAR POWERED WATER SOURCE DEVELOPED IN PHASE I OF THIS PROJECT  TROUGHS WILL BE INSTALLED TO ALLOW FOR DISPERSED WATERING SOURCES FOR BOTH LIVESTOCK AND WILDLIFE  THE OUTCOME OF THIS PROJECT WILL ALLOW FOR FURTHER DISTRIBUTION OF LIVESTOCK GRAZING ACROSS THE PASTURES RESULTING IN THE OPPORTUNITY FOR SAGEBRUSH, GRASSES, AND FORBS TO RECOVER AND FOR PRESSURE TO BE REDUCED ON EXISTING RIPARIAN AND MESIC AREAS  WHILE ALL WORK WILL BE ON PRIVATE GROUNDS, THE HABITAT ON PUBLIC LANDS WILL BENEFIT AS WELL

THIS PROJECT WORKS WITH PRIVATE LANDOWNERS IN IMPORTANT SAGEBRUSH LANDSCAPES IN MONTANA S NORTHERN GREAT PLAINS AND MUSSELSHELL PLAINS TO PROTECT AND ENHANCE HABITAT FOR GREATER SAGE GROUSE AND DECLINING GRASSLAND SONGBIRDS  RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT ACTIVITIES WILL TARGET AREAS OF DEGRADED BY INVASIVE GRASSES, CONIFER ENCROACHMENT AND OTHER HABITAT DEGRADATION TO A HEALTHIER, FUNCTIONING STATE  SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE TO REMOVE CONIFERS ON AT LEAST 1,000 ACRES OF ENCROACHMENT, RESTORE 1,500 ACRES OF MARGINAL CROPLAND BACK TO NATIVE VEGETATION, AND INSTALL LIVESTOCK WATER AND FENCE INFRASTRUCTURE ON FIVE PRIVATE RANCHES IN CORE SAGEBRUSH HABITAT TO PREVENT CONVERSION FOR 20 YEARS

THIS PROJECT WORKS WITH PRIVATE LANDOWNERS IN IMPORTANT SAGEBRUSH LANDSCAPES IN MONTANA'S NORTHERN GREAT PLAINS AND MUSSELSHELL PLAINS TO PROTECT AND ENHANCE HABITAT FOR GREATER SAGE-GROUSE AND DECLINING GRASSLAND SONGBIRDS. SPECIFICALLY, OUR PARTNERSHIP IS WORKING TO ENROLL PRIVATE LANDS INTO A CANDIDATE CONSERVATION AGREEMENT WITH ASSURANCES (CCAA) THAT REDUCE 12 IDENTIFIED THREATS AND SUPPORT HABITAT QUALITY FOR COVERED SPECIES ON CCA PROPERTIES. ASSOCIATED RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE RESTORATION OF WET MEADOW HABITAT AND GRAZING MANAGEMENT TO ENHANCE PERENNIAL GRASS COMMUNITIES, REDUCE INVASIVE ANNUAL GRASS INVASIONS AND REDUCE RIPARIAN AND WET MEADOW DEGRADATION.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS TO ESTABLISH A WORKING PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE SERVICE AND THE COLORADO WILDLIFE HERITAGE FOUNDATION RECIPIENT FOR THE PURPOSE OF PROMOTING CONSERVATION ON PRIVATE LANDS THROUGH HABITAT CONSERVATION PROJECTS. FUNDS UNDER THIS AWARD ARE TO BE USED TO FACILITATE CONSERVATION WORK THAT IS MUTUALLY BENEFICIAL TO BOTH PARTIES. THIS PARTNERSHIP WILL PROVIDE SUPPORT FOR CONSERVATION OF PRIVATELY-OWNED LANDS IN MOFFAT COUNTY, COLORADO, THROUGH COST-SHARING OF CONSERVATION PRACTICES. CONSERVATION PRACTICES JOINTLY IMPLEMENTED BY THE SERVICE AND THE COLORADO WILDLIFE HERITAGE FOUNDATION WILL INCLUDE, BUT NOT LIMITED TO AERIAL APPLICATION OF REJUVRA HERBICIDE TO CONTROL CHEATGRASS AND OTHER INVASIVE PLANTS. ALL PROJECTS WILL BE FACILITATED BY SITE-SPECIFIC PRIVATE LANDOWNER AGREEMENTS AS APPROVED AND ADMINISTERED BY THE SERVICE. HABITAT CONSERVATION PROJECTS WILL BENEFIT HABITAT GOALS AND OBJECTIVES IDENTIFIED WITHIN THE COLORADO PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE STRATEGIC PLAN, PRIORITY SAGEBRUSH OBLIGATE BIRDS IDENTIFIED BY THE SERVICE'S SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEM TEAM, AND COLORADO PARKS AND WILDLIFE STATE ACTION PLAN FOR BIG GAME MIGRATION AND WINTER RANGE.
