THE BOOTLEG FIRE BURNED OVER 400,000 ACRES IN THE SPRAGUE RIVER WATERSHED IN 2021  THERE IS A NEED FOR STREAM CHANNEL STABILIZATION TREATMENTS TO REDUCE EROSION AND SEDIMENTATION IN STREAM CHANNELS THAT WERE AFFECTED BY THE FIRE  THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO INSTALL STRUCTURES IN BLUE CREEK TO SLOW WATER VELOCITY, TRAP SEDIMENT, AND MAINTAIN CHANNEL CHARACTERISTICS TO REDUCE NEGATIVE AFFECTS TO WATER QUALITY  UNDERSIZED CULVERTS THAT HAVE RESULTED IN EXCESSIVE EROSION AND DOWNCUTTING IN THE CHANNEL ARE ALSO PROPOSED  THE INSTREAM STRUCTURES USE WILLOW STAKES AND WEAVING MATERIAL, ALLUVIUM, AND BIODEGRADABLE FABRIC AND ARE CLASSIFIED AS CROSS VEINS AND OR BEAVER DAM ANALOGS

THE FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS TO WORK JOINTLY ON UPLAND HABITATS OWNED AND PROTECTED BY THE TUMBLING CREEK CAVE FOUNDATION  TCCF  WHICH WILL BE ENHANCED, RESTORED AND CAN BE USED AS A DEMONSTRATION SITE FOR OTHER LANDOWNERS  WE PLAN TO USE THIS PROJECT TO COLLABORATE WITH THE TCCF ON OTHER ENDANGERED SPECIES RECOVERY EFFORTS AS WELL  WE WILL ALSO COLLABORATE WITH THE SERVICE ON OTHER POTENTIAL UPLAND HABITAT ON PRIVATE LAND IN THE SURROUNDING AREA TO PROTECT MIGRATORY BIRDS IN DECLINE AND FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES BY WORKING WITH LANDOWNERS TO ENGAGE THEM IN ENHANCEMENT AND RESTORATION ACTIVITIES THROUGH THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM

THE PROPOSED PROJECT INCLUDES THE ENHANCEMENT OF APPROXIMATELY 928 ACRES OF EXISTING LONGLEAF PINE FOREST THAT IS  LOCATED WITHIN A PRIMARY FOCAL AREA FOR THE RECOVERY OF THE THREATENED LOUISIANA PINESNAKE  MUCH OF THE EXISTING  FOREST UNDERSTORY MIDSTORY IS OVERGROWN WITH WOODY VEGETATION DUE TO FIRE SUPPRESSION  PROPOSED MANAGEMENT  ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE TWO MILES OF FIREBREAK INSTALLATION MAINTENANCE  CLEARING NARROW STRIPS OF VEGETATION  DOWN TO THE BARE SOIL WITH MINIMAL OR NO DISTURBANCE TO THE TOPSOIL , EXISTING ROAD AND TRAIL IMPROVEMENT TO  CONTROL SOIL EROSION AND IMPROVE SITE ACCESS, AND 128 ACRES OF PRESCRIBED BURNING  ADDITIONAL ENHANCEMENT  ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE HERBICIDE APPLICATION TO APPROXIMATELY 800 ACRES TO REMOVE INVASIVE HARDWOOD TREES AND  SHRUBS FROM THE UNDERSTORY AND ALLOW SAFE PRESCRIBED BURNING IN THE FUTURE  THESE ACTIVITIES WILL FACILITATE  HERBACEOUS UNDERSTORY VEGETATION GROWTH  A REQUIRED COMPONENT FOR THE LOUISIANA PINESNAKE S MAIN PREY, BAIRD S  POCKET GOPHER   THIS HABITAT RESTORATION EFFORT WILL BENEFIT THE THREATENED LOUISIANA PINESNAKE, AS WELL AS  SEVERAL AT RISK SPECIES INCLUDING THE FROSTED ELFIN BUTTERFLY, MONARCH BUTTERFLY, HENSLOW S SPARROW, AND  BACHMAN S SPARROW

TITLE  2022 WESTERN MIGRATION CORRIDORS PARTNERSHIPNATIONAL FISH AND WILDLIFE FOUNDATION  NFWF  REQUESTS  500,000 TO SUPPORT THE FIFTH YEAR OF A PARTNERSHIP WITH THE U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  FWS  TO SUPPORT A PUBLIC PRIVATE PARTNERSHIP TO IMPROVE THE QUALITY OF WESTERN MIGRATION CORRIDOR, STOPOVER, AND WINTER RANGE HABITAT  THE PROGRAM WILL ADVANCE THE GOALS OF SECRETARIAL ORDER 3362, IMPROVING HABITAT QUALITY IN WESTERN BIG GAME WINTER RANGE AND MIGRATION CORRIDORS AS WELL AS THE RECENT EXECUTIVE ORDERS RELATED TO CLIMATE CHANGE  NFWF SPECIALIZES IN WORKING WITH MULTIPLE FEDERAL AGENCIES TO CREATE EFFICIENCIES OF SCALE TO ADDRESS SHARED CONSERVATION GOALS IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE PRIVATE SECTOR  THE MIGRATION CORRIDORS PARTNERSHIP WILL ALLOW NFWF TO WORK WITH OTHER FEDERAL AGENCIES, INCLUDING THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT  BLM , NATURAL RESOURCES CONSERVATION SERVICE  NRCS , AND U S  FOREST SERVICE  USFS , AS WELL AS CONOCOPHILLIPS, AND OTHER POTENTIAL PRIVATE SECTOR FUNDERS, TO SUPPORT WESTERN MIGRATIONS, BOLSTER LOCAL RANCHING ECONOMIES, AND IMPROVE ECOSYSTEM HEALTH TO SUPPORT BIODIVERSITY AND THE ABILITY OF SPECIES TO ADAPT TO A CHANGING ENVIRONMENT

WEST BEAR SOUTHERN OREGON ALL LANDS RESTORATION PROJECT AIMS TO COMPLETE A MINIMUM OF 7,500 ACRES OF FOREST RESILIENCY TREATMENTS SERVING MULTIPLE PRIVATE LANDOWNERS IN THE TALENT PHOENIX MEDFORD JACKSONVILLE WILDLAND URBAN INTERFACE AREA AND ADJACENT FOOTHILLS OF THE UPPER BEAR CREEK VALLEY   SYSKIYOU MOUNTAINS IN SOUTHWESTERN OREGON  LOMAKATSI S PROJECT MANAGEMENT AND TECHNICAL FORESTRY TEAMS WILL RECRUIT LANDOWNERS, DESIGN AND WRITE TREATMENT PLANS UTILIZING ADVANCED TECHNOLOGY, CONDUCT FOREST INVENTORIES AND OVERSEE PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION  THIS INCLUDES INSPECTIONS FOR QUALITY ASSURANCE FOR ECOLOGICAL FOREST RESTORATION AND FUELS REDUCTION THAT ENHANCES HABITAT AND REDUCES WILDFIRE SEVERITY RISK  PARTNERS PROGRAM FUNDING WILL ALLOW LOMAKATSI TO WORK WITH ADDITIONAL LANDOWNERS ADJACENT TO THESE EFFORTS ACROSS PRIVATE LANDS, WHICH WILL INCREASE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF TREATMENTS BENEFITING LOCAL COMMUNITIES AND ECOSYSTEMS

THIS PROJECT WILL RESTORE AND OR ENHANCE APPROXIMATELY 300 ACRES OF WILDLIFE HABITAT IN THE SACRAMENTO VALLEY AND FOOTHILLS CONSISTING OF GRASSLANDS, CENTRAL VALLEY RIPARIAN, AND WETLANDS  THIS PROJECT WILL IMPROVE WATER DELIVERY EFFICIENCY, WATER SOURCES AND ASSOCIATED HABITATS  PROVIDING BENEFITS TO MIGRATORY BIRDS AND OTHER FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES

IN MARCH 2022, A FIRE WAS STARTED ON NEARBY PRIVATE LAND, BURNING OVER 400 ACRES ALONG THE MOJAVE RIVER IN SAN BERNARDINO COUNTY, CALIFORNIA  THIS FIRE WAS NAMED THE HERITAGE FIRE AND ON PALISADES RANCH, OWNED BY THE MOJAVE DESERT LAND TRUST, THE FIRE BURNED 35 ACRES OF RIPARIAN FOREST INCLUDING THE BEST HABITAT FOR MOJAVE RIVER VOLE, A SPECIES OF SPECIAL CONCERN IN CALIFORNIA, AND NESTING LOCATIONS FOR THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED LEAST BELL S VIREO  IN ADDITION, THE FEDERALLY THREATENED YELLOW BILLED CUCKOO AND SIX OTHER SPECIES OF SPECIAL CONCERN IN CALIFORNIA USE THIS RIPARIAN FOREST MUCH OF THE VEGETATION IN THE HERITAGE FIRE PERIMETER IS RESPROUTING  BECAUSE THE FOREST IS MORE OPEN THAN BEFORE, THREE STATE LISTED NOXIOUS WEEDS HAVE BECOME MORE VISIBLE  PERENNIAL PEPPERWEED  LEPIDIUM LATIFOLIUM   TALL WHITETOP , GIANT REED  ARUNDO DONAX , AND SALT CEDAR  TAMARIX RAMOSISSIMA   PERENNIAL PEPPERWEED IN PARTICULAR HAS INCREASED SINCE THE FIRE AND SALT CEDAR IS KNOWN TO RESPROUT WELL AFTER FIRE  IN THIS PROJECT, MOJAVE DESERT LAND TRUST PROPOSES TO TREAT THE NOXIOUS WEEDS WITHIN THE FIRE PERIMETER TO IMPROVE RIPARIAN HABITAT FOR THE LISTED SPECIES AND SPECIES OF SPECIAL CONCERN  THEY WOULD USE VARIETY OF ESTABLISHED MECHANICAL AND CHEMICAL TREATMENT METHODS

THIS AGREEMENT WILL PROVIDE  55,000 00 TO WATERSHED MANAGEMENT GROUP  RECIPIENT  TO IMPLEMENT COMMUNITY AND SCHOOLYARD HABITATS AND WORK WITH A PRIVATE LANDOWNER TO ENHANCE HABITAT FOR MIGRATORY BIRDS  THE LANDOWNERS, RECIPIENT, AND USFWS WILL SIGN A SUB RECIPIENT LANDOWNER AGREEMENT  EXHIBIT 1  TO IDENTIFY WORK THAT WILL IMPROVE HABITAT TO BENEFIT FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES  THE SUB RECIPIENT LANDOWNER AGREEMENT WILL INCLUDE A PROJECT NARRATIVE AND BUDGET  THE RECIPIENT WILL OVERSEE THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE LANDOWNER AGREEMENT  THIS PROJECT WILL WORK TO ENHANCE POLLINATOR HABITAT, RIPARIAN HABITAT, AND OR UPLAND HABITAT AREAS THROUGH VARIOUS TECHNIQUES ON PRIVATE LAND  THE PRACTICES INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO, INSTALLING EROSION CONTROL STRUCTURES  RAIN GARDENS, CATTLE EXCLUSIONS, RESTORING NATIVE PLANT COMMUNITIES  INCREASING PLANT SPECIES DIVERSITY  AND IMPROVING WILDLIFE HABITAT

IN RECOGNIZING THE ECOLOGICAL IMPORTANCE OF BEAVER INFLUENCED WETLANDS FOR A WIDE ARRAY OF PLANTS AND ANIMALS ASWELL AS FOR THEIR ROLE IN MAINTAINING WATER QUALITY, RECHARGING AQUIFERS AND ATTENUATING FLOOD POTENTIAL, THEVERMONT FISH AND  WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT  VFWD  ENDEAVORS TO PROTECT THESE ECOSYSTEMS TO THE GREATEST EXTENT POSSIBLE HOWEVER, THE DAM BUILDING ACTIVITIES OF BEAVER ARE FREQUENTLY IN CONFLICT WITH HUMAN INTERESTS SUCH AS ROADS,POTABLE WATER SOURCES AND OTHER VITAL INFRASTRUCTURE  THE OCCURRENCE OF SUCH CONFLICTS IN VERMONT HAS BEENFURTHER EXACERBATED IN RECENT DECADES BY A DECLINE IN TRAPPER EFFORT AND AN ATTENDANT INCREASE IN THE BEAVERPOPULATION  TRANSPORTATION AGENCIES, MUNICIPALITIES AND CITIZENS OF THE STATE ARE INCREASINGLY FACED WITH THENEED TO RESOLVE BEAVER CONFLICTS IN A COST EFFECTIVE AND PREVENTATIVE MANNER OR RISK EXPOSURE TO LIABILITY AND ORPOTENTIALLY SIGNIFICANT REPAIR COSTS  HISTORICALLY, SUCH  RESOLUTIONS  HAVE BEEN NARROWLY FOCUSED ON THE REMOVALOF BEAVER DAMS OFTEN RESULTING IN THE DEGRADATION OF THE WETLAND HABITATS AND FUNCTIONS THE VFWD STRIVES TOMAINTAIN AND PROTECT

THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL CONTINUE THE WORK STARTED IN UPPER KEET SEEL CANYON, BETATAKIN CANYON, AND DOWOZHIBIETO CANYON AND WILL INCLUDE THE ENHANCEMENT OF HABITAT FOR MIGRATORY BIRDS BY INSTALLING EROSION CONTROL STRUCTURES FOR EROSION CONCERNS, FENCING TO HELP WITH GRAZING MANAGEMENT, AND ESTABLISHING NATIVE VEGETATION  ONE SUB RECIPIENT AGREEMENT  TEMPLATE INCLUDED IN EXHIBIT B  WILL BE FUNDED UNDER THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT  THE SPECIFICS OF THE PROJECT INCLUDING LOCATION MAY CHANGE BUT THE SCOPE OF THE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT TO ENHANCE HABITAT FOR FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES WILL REMAIN SAME

FOR THESE 2 PROJECTS TUCSON AUDUBON WILL WORK WITH THE NATURE CONSERVANCY ON THEIR CANELO CIENEGA PRESERVE AS WELL AS ANOTHER LANDOWNER YET TO BE DETERMINED FOR THE CONSERVATION AND BENEFIT OF FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES.ON THE CANELO CIENEGA PRESERVE EFFORTS WILL SPECIFICALLY BE FOR THE BENEFIT OF SPIRANTHES DELITESCENS, A RARE ORCHARD OF ARID WETLANDS AND ASSOCIATED PLANTS IN THE VERY RARE CIENEGA WETLAND HABITAT TYPE. CIENEGA HABITATS NOT ONLY SUPPORT AN EXCEPTIONAL ARRAY OF UNCOMMON-TO-RARE PLANTS, THEY ALSO SUPPORT A WIDE VARIETY OF BIRDS AND INSECT LIFE INCLUDING NUMEROUS POLLINATORS. GIVEN CHANGES TO PRECIPITATION PATTERNS AND TOTALS, CIENEGAS IN THE DESERT SOUTHWEST ARE FACING INCREASING THREATS AND NEED TO BE MAINTAINED INTENTIONALLY FOR THE BENEFIT OF SPECIES THAT RELY ON THEM.THE SECOND PROJECT IS YET TO BE DETERMINED, BUT WILL BE FOR THE BENEFIT OF LISTED SPECIES OR SPECIES OF CONCERN, UTILIZING TUCSON AUDUBON'S ACQUIRED EXPERTISE FOR HABITAT AND SPECIES-DRIVEN CONSERVATION.

THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL SERVE TO FACILITATE WORK WITHIN THE IDAHO PFW STRATEGIC PLAN  2022 2026  PRIORITY CONSERVATION IMPLEMENTATION ON PRIVATE LANDS  WITHOUT THIS AGREEMENT, STRATEGIC HABITAT CONSERVATION PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION WOULD BE LESS EFFECTIVE AMONG THESE BIOLOGICALLY AND ECOLOGICALLY RELEVANT SCALES AND BOUNDARIES PROJECTS WILL BE DEVELOPED AT THE LOCAL SCALE BY PFW BIOLOGISTS LOCATED ACROSS THE STATE OF IDAHO  PROJECTS WILL BE DEVELOPED IN CLOSE COORDINATION WITH PROJECT PARTNERS AND LANDOWNERS WITHIN FOCUS AREAS IN IDAHO  THE IDAHO PFW TEAM OF BIOLOGISTS WILL MEET ANNUALLY EVERY SPRING TO DETERMINE SPECIFIC PROJECT FUNDING  FUNDS WILL BE UTILIZED TO MAXIMIZE THE OVERALL CONSERVATION BENEFIT TO THE LANDSCAPE, ULTIMATELY BOLSTERING THE CONTINUATION OF HISTORIC ON THE GROUND CONSERVATION EFFORTS AND LOOKING TO UTILIZE NEW AND EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES TO ADDRESS IDENTIFIED CONSERVATION THREATS TO TRUST SPECIES

THIS PROJECT WILL FOCUS EFFORTS TO RESTORE HABITAT FOR MIGRATORY BIRDS, FEDERALLY THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES, AND OTHER FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES IN POLK COUNTY, IA  THE WORK WILL FOCUS ON RESTORING WETLAND AND UPLAND COMPLEXES IN THE CHICHAQUA BOTTOMS GREENBELT  CBG , AS WELL AS OTHER AREAS MANAGED BY POLK COUNTY CONSERVATION BOARD  SITES COMING OUT OF AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION WILL BE PRIORITIZED, AS WILL EXISTING CONSERVATION AREAS THAT ARE CONDUCIVE TO FURTHER RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT OF THESE HABITATS  THE WETLAND RESTORATION EFFORTS WILL AIM TO RESTORE WETLAND HYDROLOGY BY REMOVING POST SETTLEMENT ALLUVIUM  PSA  AND EXTENDING HYDROPERIOD IN EXISTING WETLANDS  THE UPLAND RESTORATION EFFORTS WILL AIM TO RECONSTRUCT NATIVE PRAIRIE AND ENHANCE EXISTING PRAIRIE TO INCREASE DIVERSITY AND ECOSYSTEM FUNCTIONING

THE PROJECT S MISSION AND GOAL IS TO ENHANCE RESTORE AVAILABLE HABITAT WITH AN EMPHASIS ON LONGLEAF PINE RESTORATION THROUGHOUT ITS HISTORIC RANGE IN NORTH FLORIDA S SUWANNEE, GILCHRIST, LEVY, ALACHUA, AND COLUMBIA COUNTIES THE PROJECT WILL SERVE PRIVATE LANDOWNERS BY IMPROVING THE ECOLOGICAL CONDITION OF THEIR PROPERTY IN SUPPORT OF HABITAT CONNECTIVITY AND BIODIVERSITY THROUGH ENHANCED LISTED AT RISK SPECIES HABITAT MANAGEMENT PRACTICES WILL INCLUDE LONGLEAF PINE PLANTING, CHEMICAL AND MECHANICAL TREATMENT OF ENCROACHING HARDWOODS AND OR INVASIVE EXOTIC PLANT SPECIES, PRESCRIBED FIRE PREP APPLICATION AND SUPPLIES NEEDED TO SUPPORT ALL PRACTICES INITIAL DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE ENHANCEMENT OF  307 ACRES OF SANDHILL  ENHANCEMENT AND RESTORATION OF  102 ACRES OF SANDHILL  AND RESTORATION OF 285 ACRES OF SANDHILL AND UPLAND PINE

ENVIROSURVEY WILL BE PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO THE FISH AND  WILDLIFE SERVICE  FWS  AND ITS PARTNERS TO EVALUATE THE VIABILITY OF PRIVATE PROPERTIES IN THE JOINT CHIEFS LANDSCAPE RESTORATION PARTNERSHIP  JCLRP    EAST REGION INITIATIVE  WE WILL ALSO ASSIST IN CERTIFYING THE PURPOSE AND QUALITY OF THE PLANT MATERIAL DELIVERED ON PRIVATE LANDS AND THE DESIGN AND SUCCESSFUL INSTALLMENT OF CONSERVATION PRACTICES NEEDED TO PROTECT,RESTORE, DEVELOP, OR ENHANCE WILDLIFE HABITAT WITHIN PRIVATE LANDS, AS ESTABLISHED ON THE JCLRP INITIATIVE PROPOSAL  ENVIROSURVEY WILL ASSESS VIABILITY ONLY IN THOSE PREVIOUSLY IDENTIFIED AND RECOMMENDED PRIVATE PROPERTIES BY THE JCLRP WORKING GROUP

THE ILLINOIS HILLS PRAIRIE RESTORATION PARTNERSHIP PROJECT WILL AWARD $50,0000 TO PRAIRIE HILLS RESOURCE CONSERVATION AND DEVELOPMENT, INC. PRAIRIE HILLS RESOURCE CONSERVATION AND DEVELOPMENT, INC WILL WORK COOPERATIVELY WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE'S PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM (FOR THE BENEFIT OF FEDERAL TRUST RESOURCES ON PRIVATE LAND. THE GOAL OF THE PARTNERSHIP IS TO ENHANCE AND RESTORE HILL PRAIRIE HABITAT IN ILLINOIS. PROJECTS WILL BE FOCUSED IN SCOTT AND MORGAN COUNTIES NORTH OF INTERSTATE 72, IN CASS AND MENARD COUNTIES, AND IN MASON COUNTY SOUTH OF HWY 136.CONSISTENT WITH ILLINOIS'S PARTNERS' FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE STRATEGIC PLAN, HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS ARE COMPLETED IN FOCAL AREAS AND OFTEN RELY ON EXPERTISE AND COST-SHARE FROM MULTIPLE PARTNERS. IN ILLINOIS, THE HILL PRAIRIE FOCUS AREA INCLUDES SCOTT, MORGAN, MASON, AND CASS COUNTIES OUTLINED IN THE PARTNERSHIP AGREEMENT. HILL PRAIRIE RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT MEETS THE PARTNERS PROGRAM'S OBJECTIVES OF RESTORING HIGH QUALITY POLLINATOR AND MONARCH HABITAT. THIS PROJECT AREA ALSO FALLS WITHIN A MAJOR MIGRATORY BIRD CORRIDOR AND WILL PROVIDE OPTIMAL STOPOVER HABITAT FOR NUMEROUS SPECIES OF PASSERINES. THE STATE ENDANGERED OTTOE SKIPPER AND PALE FALSE FOXGLOVE ARE FOUND IN SIMILAR PRAIRIE RESTORATION SITES WITHIN THE PROJECT AREA AND BOTH SPECIES ARE EXPECTED TO BENEFIT FROM HILL PRAIRIE RESTORATION.THE RESTORATION PROJECTS CONSIST OF RESTORING A NATIVE HILL PRAIRIE BY REMOVING INVASIVE CEDAR AND LOCUST TREES, AS WELL AS BY REMOVING NON-NATIVE PASTURE PLANTS SUCH AS SMOOTH BROME, CROWN VETCH AND FESCUE. RESTORING NATIVE WARM SEASON GRASS MAY INCREASE WATER QUALITY IN THE ILLINOIS RIVER WATERSHED. ADDITIONALLY, PRAIRIE HABITATS SEQUESTER CARBON AND CAN MITIGATE THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE.

THE PROJECT AREA  TENOLD TRACT OWNED BY WINNEBAGO COUNTY CONSERVATION BOARD  FOR THIS AGREEMENT IS LOCATED WITHIN THE IOWA WETLAND MANAGEMENT DISTRICT AND THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM S PRAIRIE POTHOLE FOCUS AREA THE OBJECTIVE OF THE PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT 4 6 SHALLOW WATER EXCAVATION ENHANCEMENTS  4 ACRES TOTAL  TO IMPROVE THE AQUATIC RESOURCE FUNCTION OF OFF CHANNEL WETLAND HABITAT ADJACENT TO LIME CREEK  WINNEBAGO RIVER   THESE ENHANCEMENT ACTIVITIES WILL IMPROVE DEGRADED WETLAND HABITAT THAT WAS PREVIOUSLY FARMED AND HAS FILLED WITH POST SETTLEMENT ALLUVIUM  PSA  TO BENEFIT WATERFOWL AND OTHER MIGRATORY BIRDS  THE PROJECT WILL ALSO BENEFIT THE PUBLIC THAT USES THE SITE FOR OUTDOOR RECREATION ACTIVITIES

THE USFWS AND NWF WILL WORK COOPERATIVELY THROUGH SUB RECIPIENT AGREEMENTS TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL AND FINANCIALASSISTANCE FOR THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE MONARCH HEROES PROGRAM TO SUPPORT THE CREATION OF AT LEAST TEN  10  OUTDOORCLASSROOMS MONARCH GARDENS ON SELECT AUSTIN  AND SAN ANTONIO AREA SCHOOL CAMPUSES  MONARCH HEROES IS A PROJECTBASEDPROGRAM THAT ENGAGES AND EMPOWERS STUDENTS AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO CREATE CRITICAL MILKWEED HABITAT ANDTO CONTRIBUTE, THROUGH CITIZEN SCIENCE, TO ONGOING RESEARCH ON THE MONARCH BUTTERFLY  THE PROGRAM IMPROVES SCIENCEENGAGEMENT AND MOTIVATION IN UNDER RESOURCED STUDENTS AND HELPS CONNECT THEM TO NATURE  THESE OUTDOORCLASSROOMS MONARCH GARDENS WILL PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR STUDENTS TO LEARN ABOUT AND APPRECIATE WILDLIFE ANDECOSYSTEMS AND DEVELOP AN UNDERSTANDING OF THE IMPORTANCE OF POLLINATORS  THE GARDENS WILL ALSO CREATE IMPORTANTHABITAT FOR MIGRATORY BIRDS AND POLLINATORS, INCLUDING THE MONARCH BUTTERFLY

THE ANCHORAGE PARK FOUNDATION WILL COMPLETE THREE PROJECTS WITH THIS GRANT.WE WILL PARTIALLY FUND THE COORDINATION AND INSTALLATION OF A NEW INDIGENOUS PLACE NAME SIGN AT POTTER MARSH. ANCHORAGE'S FIRST PEOPLE, THE DENA'INA, CALLED THIS PLACE HKADITALI, WHICH MEANS DRIFT WOOD AND OTHER DEBRIS WASHED UP FROM SHIP WRECKS. LOCATED AT THE SOUTHERN END OF THE ANCHORAGE COASTAL WILDLIFE REFUGE, RABBIT CREEK FLOWS UNDER THE BOARDWALK, PROVIDING A LEARNING OPPORTUNITY FOR THE PUBLIC TO SEE SPAWNING CHINOOK, COHO, AND HUMPBACK SALMON FROM MAY TO AUGUST, DEPENDING ON THE SPECIES.WE WILL CONTROL INVASIVE PLANTS IN ANCHORAGE IN 2022 & 2023 BY COMPLETING AT LEAST 2 VOLUNTEER EVENTS (AT LEAST ONE WILL INCLUDE TREE PLANTING).WE WILL HOLD AT LEAST 4 COOPERATIVE INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT AREA MEETINGS TO INCREASE COORDINATION AND ACTIONS TO PREVENT AND ADDRESS INVASIVE SPECIES IN THE MUNICIPALITY OF ANCHORAGE.

THIS GRANT WILL PROVIDE  25,000 TO THE NATIONAL WILDLIFE FEDERATION  NWF  TOWARDS THE RESTORATION OF THE 532 ACRE HOKE COMMUNITY FOREST LOCATED IN HOKE COUNTY, NORTH CAROLINA  LONGLEAF PINE RESTORATION WILL GENERATE INCOME FOR THIS UNDERSERVED COUNTY, PROVIDE RECREATION AND ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION FOR ITS CITIZENS, AND BENEFIT NATIVE WILDLIFE INCLUDING THE ENDANGERED RED COCKADED WOODPECKER  THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO SERVE AS AN INNOVATIVE MODEL FOR COMMUNITIES STRUGGLING TO BALANCE CONSERVATION AND ECONOMIC GOALS  RESTORATION ACTIVITIES INCLUDING TREE PLANTINGS, PRESCRIBED FIRE, REMOVAL OF INVASIVE SPECIES, TIMBER STAND IMPROVEMENT, WILDLIFE DEMONSTRATION PLOTS, NATIVE PLANT RESTORATION, HERBICIDE TREATMENT, TRAIL DEVELOPMENT AND SIGNAGE, WILL BE COVERED BY FUNDS FROM USFWS, WHICH WILL BE OVERSEEN AND ADMINISTERED BY NWF  MANY CONTRIBUTING PARTNERS ARE INVOLVED AND THE OVERALL PROJECT WILL EXCEED  200,000  NWF WILL NOT PROVIDE ANY CASH MATCH  THE TIMELINE FOR COMPLETING THIS PROJECT IS 36 MONTHS

THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE FOR THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS TO WORK WITH VARIOUS PRIVATE LANDOWNERS THROUGHOUT NORTHERN NEW MEXICO ON HABITAT RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT PROJECTS  THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE PUBLIC BY IMPROVING THE QUALITY OF WILDLIFE HABITAT, REDUCING EROSION AND SEDIMENT DEPOSITION, AND HELP EDUCATE LANDOWNERS AROUND RESTORATION PRACTICES THROUGH A HANDS ON LANDOWNER RESTORATION WORKSHOPS, IF FEASIBLE  THE AGUAS AND ITS PARTNERS ARE EQUIPPED WITH THE EXPERTISE TO ACHIEVE THIS PROJECT AS HABITAT RESTORATION ON PRIVATE LANDS IS THEIR MAIN ORGANIZATIONAL MISSION

WITH FUNDING SUPPORT FROM THE USFWS MIDWEST REGION, OUR PARTNERSHIP WILL FOCUS ON CONSERVATION DELIVERY AND CAPACITY BUILDING  THE PARTNERSHIP COORDINATOR WILL DIRECTLY ENGAGE LANDOWNERS THAT MAY BE INTERESTED IN HABITAT RESTORATION ENHANCEMENT  ANALYZE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE PARTNERSHIP S GOALS, OBJECTIVES, STRATEGIES AND  TACTICS AS THEY RELATE TO CONSERVATION DELIVERY  PREPARE THE PARTNERSHIP FOR FUTURE CONSERVATION CHALLENGES AND OPPORTUNITIES  AND SEEK FUTURE FUNDING TO SUSTAIN THIS HIGHER LEVEL OF LANDOWNER ENGAGEMENT AND PARTNERSHIP COORDINATION  QUANTIFIABLE OBJECTIVES INCLUDE OVER 50 LANDOWNER CONTACTS, 2 CONSERVATION WORKSHOPS, ADDITIONAL 500 ACRES ENROLLED IN FARM BILL PROGRAMS

THE PROJECT SUPPORTS MANAGEMENT OF OVER 80 ACRES OF FOREST IN OLONA GULCH, WHICH IS CRITICAL HABITAT FOR LOWLAND MESIC FOREST ECOSYSTEM  UNIT 6   ENDANGERED PLANT SPECIES TO BENEFIT FROM THIS PROJECT INCLUDE  SCHIEDEA KAALAE  ENDANGERED, PEPP, 12 IND  , PTERALYXIA MACROCARPA  ENDANGERED, 120 IND  , CYANEA CRISPA  ENDANGERED, PEPP, 16 TO 25 IND  , CYANEA ACUMINATA  ENDANGERED, 446 IND  IN THE KO OLAU MTNS  AND 715 IND  IN WAI ANAE MTNS   AND CYANEA TRUNCATA  ENDANGERED, PEPP, EXTINCT IN THE WILD, CA  100 INTRODUCED IND  AT SEVERAL SITES   VERY LITTLE MANAGEMENT CURRENTLY OCCURS IN THIS SITE, MOSTLY DUE TO THE REMOTENESS  FUNDS ARE REQUESTED TO WORK WITH DOFAW TO SPECIFICALLY PROTECT AND INCREASE POPULATIONS OF CYANEA TRUNCATA, SCHIEDEA KAALAE, AND PTERALYXIA MACROCARPA  THIS PROJECT SEEKS FUNDING FOR MONTHLY HELICOPTER ACCESS AND SUPPLIES TO FACILITATE SUSTAINED RARE PLANT THREAT MANAGEMENT  INVASIVE WEED, RAT AND SLUG CONTROL , MONITORING, AND FOREST RESTORATION BY KUALOA RANCH STEWARDSHIP STAFF IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE DOFAW PLANT EXTINCTION PREVENTION PROGRAM  STAFF WILL PREPARE SITES FOR OUTPLANTINGS OF 50 TO 100 IND  OF C  TRUNCATA AND S  KAALAE EACH, AS WELL AS SOME INDIVIDUALS OF P  MACROCARPA  REGULAR MONITORING WILL BE CONDUCTED FOR ALL RARE PLANTS, AS WELL AS SURVEYS TO IDENTIFY UNKNOWN INDIVIDUALS REMAINING IN THE AREA  FUNDING SUPPORTS MAINTENANCE AND RESTORATION OF A ONE ACRE FENCED SITE IN HAKIPU U WHERE C  TRUNCATA WILL BE PROTECTED IN A MORE ACCESSIBLE SITE  THESE PLANTS WILL BE EASIER TO MONITOR AND STUDY, AND WILL SERVE AS A LOCATION WHERE FRUIT CAN EASILY BE COLLECTED  ADDITIONALLY, THE SITE WILL BE USED IN OUTREACH EFFORTS TO CONVEY THE IMPORTANCE OF NATIVE HAWAIIAN FORESTS AND TO DESCRIBE AND SHOWCASE THE CHALLENGES AND SUCCESSES OF PERPETUATING RARE AND ENDANGERED PLANTS IN HAWAI I

THE PROJECT WILL CONSIST OF MECHANICALLY THINNING 117 ACRES OF CLOSED YAUPON THICKETS USING A FORESTRY MULCHER   OR SIMILAR MACHINE  TO OPEN WOODLAND FORESTS AND ENHANCE EXISTING SAVANNA GRASSLANDS OPENINGS  AN APPROPRIATELY  SIZED FORESTRY MULCHER WILL BE USED TO THIN THE WOODY UNDERSTORY FOCUSING ON YAUPON BRUSH  THE 117 ACRES PROJECT  SITE WILL BE MECHANICALLY THINNED AT A 80 85  TREATMENT TO PROVIDE A MOSAIC OF HABITAT TYPES TO BENEFIT RESIDENT  AND MIGRATORY WILDLIFE SPECIES  SOME FALLEN TREES AND SNAGS CAN BE LEFT IN PLACE TO PROVIDE ADDITIONAL HABITAT  FOR WILDLIFE  THE COOPERATOR CAN CONDUCT FOLLOW UP CHEMICAL TREATMENTS ON THE MECHANICALLY TREATED 117 ACRES ON  YAUPON RESPROUTS, AS APPROPRIATE  THE RECOMMENDED HERBICIDE TREATMENT IS LOW VOLUME BASAL BARK TREATMENT  STEM  SPRAY APPLIED TO INDIVIDUAL YAUPON RESPROUTS USING 10  TRICLOPYR  I E , GARLON 4 OR REMEDY  MIXED IN DIESEL, JLB  OIL PLUS OR OTHER APPROPRIATE DILUENT ADJUVANT  THIS INDIVIDUAL PLANT TREATMENT  IPT  IS MOST EFFECTIVE IF  APPLIED 6 18 MONTHS AFTER MECHANICAL TREATMENT  THE HERBICIDE CAN BE APPLIED USING A HANDHELD OR BACKPACK  SPRAYER  SPRAY CONTAINERS AND PUMPS SHOULD BE WELL RINSED AFTER USE TO PREVENT CORROSION AND USE OF AN INDICATOR  DYE IS RECOMMENDED ANY MECHANICAL BRUSH THINNING TREATMENTS AND OR HERBICIDE APPLICATIONS WILL TAKE PLACE OUTSIDE OF THE HOUSTON  TOAD  ACTIVE SEASON   MECHANICAL TREATMENT CAN BE CONDUCTED FROM JULY 1 TO DECEMBER 31

HISTORICALLY, THE KELLY CREEK AREA SUPPORTED A MULTITUDE OF WILDLIFE IN THEIR TRANSITION RANGES BETWEEN SUMMER AND WINTERING AREAS  PRIOR TO THE PINYON JUNIPER EXPANSION, THE CREEK WOULD HAVE FLOWED PERENNIALLY  THE PINYON JUNIPER WOODLANDS HAVE DESCENDED FROM THE ADJACENT MOUNTAINOUS ROCKY SLOPES AND BEGUN INVADING THE VALLEY FLOOR  THIS UNNATURAL CONDITION IS DEPLETING UNDERSTORY VEGETATION AND DEWATERING THE LANDSCAPE  PRIOR TO THIS EXPANSION, THE CREEK WOULD HAVE FLOWED PERENNIALLY  PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE THINNING THE TREES AND FOLLOWING THEIR REMOVAL WITH RESEEDING AND PLANTING NATIVE UNDERSTORY PLANTS  DISTURBANCES WITHIN THE MESIC AREAS HAVE RESULTED IN NOXIOUS WEEDS BECOMING ESTABLISHED  TREATING THESE NOXIOUS WEEDS ARE A PRIORITY AND WILL BE ADDRESSED WITH SPOT TREATING

PROJECT PARTNERS WILL INSTALL LOW TECH PROCESS BASED RESTORATION STRUCTURES IN SNAKE CREEK AND THE SYCAN RIVER AND REPLACE A WATER CONTROL STRUCTURE IN THE POND TO INCREASE FISH PASSAGE IN A RESTORED CHANNEL THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A DESIGN TO REPLACE THE EXISTING VERTICAL CORRUGATED PIPE CONTROL STRUCTURE IN THE POND THAT CONTROLS WATER LEVELS  A NEW STRUCTURE WILL ALLOW FOR MORE PRECISE CONTROL OF THE WATER LEVELS IN THE POND WHICH WILL RESULT IN MORE FLOW GOING DOWN THE EXISTING CONSTRUCTED PASSAGE CHANNEL  THIS EXAMPLE OF ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT WILL RESOLVE THE FISH PASSAGE ISSUE  OTHER ACTIONS INCLUDE THE INSTALLATION OF AT LEAST 5 BEAVER DAM ANALOGS  BDAS   THESE STRUCTURES WILL HELP SPREAD WATER ACROSS THE SNAKE CREEK FLOODPLAIN, STIMULATE NEW RIPARIAN PLANT GROWTH, AND REDUCE SEDIMENT INPUT INTO THE SYCAN RIVER  FINALLY, LARGE WOOD STRUCTURES OR POST ASSISTED LOG STRUCTURES WILL BE INSTALLED IN THE MAINSTEM SYCAN RIVER

THIS PROJECT WILL RESTORE AND/OR ENHANCE APPROXIMATELY 100 ACRES AND 1.0 STREAMLINE/SHORELINE MILE OF WILDLIFE HABITAT IN THE SACRAMENTO VALLEY, SIERRA MEADOWS AND FOOTHILLS CONSISTING OF OAK WOODLANDS, GRASSLANDS, RIPARIAN AND WETLANDS. THIS PROJECT WILL RESTORE HYDROLOGIC FUNCTION AND SEDIMENT TRANSPORT PROCESSES IN MOUNTAIN MEADOWS; CONTROL GRAZING IN SENSITIVE HABITATS NEAR WATERWAYS AND WET MEADOWS; RAISE WATER TABLES AND HOLDING CAPACITY IN WET MEADOWS; RESTORE NATIVE VEGETATION ALONG RIPARIAN CORRIDORS; AND PROVIDE WATER FOR WILDLIFE IN AREAS WHERE STREAMS ARE IMPACTED BY DROUGHT, FIRE, AND AGRICULTURE. THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT NUMEROUS SPECIES OF WILDLIFE INCLUDING DEER, ELK, TROUT, ANADROMOUS FISH, WATERFOWL, SENSITIVE AMPHIBIAN SPECIES, MIGRATORY BIRDS, AND OTHER FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES.

THE PROJECT SITE, LOCATED IN JOHNSTON COUNTY, OKLAHOMA, HAS AN OLD AND UNUSED LOW WATER DAM WHICH IS CREATING A BARRIER TO AQUATIC SPECIES AND DEGRADING HABITAT FOR MIGRATORY BIRDS DURING LOW FLOW PERIODS OF THE YEAR  REMOVAL OF THE DAM NEEDS TO BE COMPLETED IN ORDER TO ALLOW THE RIVER TO FLOW NORMALLY YEAR ROUND, AND TO ALLOW AQUATIC SPECIES TO MOVE UP AND DOWN THE RIVER, IMPROVING THE OVERALL QUALITY OF THE RIVER HABITAT FOR ALL SPECIES THAT USE IT  THE PROJECT SIZE WILL IMPACT APPROXIMATELY 0 1 ACRE OF THE BLUE RIVER, AND WILL CONNECT APPROXIMATELY 0 75 MILES OF STREAM DURING LOW FLOW PERIODS FOR AQUATIC SPECIES ON NATURE CONSERVANCY PROPERTY

THE MAIN OBJECTIVE OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS TO INCREASE THE USE OF PRESCRIBED FIRE ON PRIVATE LANDS IN OKLAHOMA  PRIVATE LANDOWNERS WHO ARE AN ACTIVE MEMBER IN AN OKLAHOMA PRESCRIBED BURN  OPB  ASSOCIATION MAY REQUEST FUNDING FOR COMPLETING A PRESCRIBED FIRE ON THEIR PROPERTY FROM THEIR LOCAL CONSERVATION DISTRICT OFFICE  ALL LANDOWNERS USING PRESCRIBED BURNS MUST FOLLOW STATE AND FEDERAL RULES AND REGULATIONS FOR PRESCRIBED FIRE AS PROVIDED BY THE OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE

THE PURPOSE OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS TO PROVIDE FINANCIAL SUPPORT FOR THE RESTORATION AND  CONSERVATION WORK IN THE MONTANA PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE CENTENNIAL AND BIG HOLE HIGH DIVIDE  CONSERVATION FOCUS AREAS AS IS IDENTIFIED IN THE USFWS REGION 6 PFW 5 YEAR STRATEGIC PLAN  THE  OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO RESTORE NATIVE UPLAND, STREAM AND WETLAND HABITATS FOR THE BENEFIT OF  SAGE GROUSE, ARCTIC GRAYLING, WESTSLOPE CUTTHROAT TROUT, TRUMPETER SWANS, AND GRIZZLY BEARS AND MANY  OTHER AND WILDLIFE SPECIES   PROJECTS WILL FOCUS ON RESTORING UPLAND, WETLAND, RIPARIAN AND INSTREAM  HABITATS, IMPROVING WATER QUALITY AND QUANTITY AND IMPROVING CONNECTIVITY BETWEEN HABITATS   PROJECT ACTIVITIES MAY INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO REDUCING GRIZZLY BEAR CONFLICTS BY REMOVING  ATTRACTANTS ON THE LANDSCAPE, ASSISTING RANGE RIDER PROGRAMS, PROVIDING ALTERNATIVE WASTE  MANAGEMENT STRUCTURES, PROMOTE BEAR AWARENESS AND SAFETY PROGRAMS  HABITAT RESTORATION  PROJECTS MAY INCLUDE STREAM AND WETLAND MESIC RESTORATION, IMPROVING WATER QUALITY AND  IMPLEMENT RIPARIAN MANAGEMENT PLANS THROUGH FENCING, STOCK WATER, IRRIGATION EFFICIENCY,  GRAZING MANAGEMENT, WEED MANAGEMENT, CONIFER REMOVAL AND INSTALLING FISH BARRIERS   CONNECTIVITY PROJECTS MAY INCLUDE INSTALLING FISH LADDERS, REMOVING NON FUNCTIONING CULVERTS,  CONSTRUCTING BRIDGES OR GRADE CONTROL STRUCTURES, REMOVING OR ALTERNATING FENCES, PROTECTING  IMPORTANT CORRIDORS THROUGH GRAZING MANAGEMENT OR LAND PROTECTION  SERVICE AND CVA PERSONNEL  WILL ANNUALLY PURSUE PROJECTS WITH STAKE HOLDERS, AGENCIES AND PRIVATE LANDOWNERS TO MEET PROJECT  OBJECTIVES

THE PROJECT WILL PROTECT AND RESTORE TWO LARGE, DEGRADED SPRINGS  TULE AND SLIDE SPRINGS  WITHIN THE SUMMIT LAKE PAIUTE TRIBE RESERVATION  SLPT   THE SPRINGS ARE DEGRADED FROM THE OVERGRAZING AND POLLUTION OF TRESPASS FERAL HORSES AND CATTLE  AN EXCLOSURE FENCE WILL BE INSTALLED AROUND EACH SPRING TO MINIMIZE TRESPASSER ACCESS  OVER TIME, THE REDUCED GRAZING PRESSURE SHOULD ALLOW THE SPRINGS TO RECOVER THEIR PROPER FUNCTIONING CONDITION  PFC  POTENTIAL AND THUS MAXIMIZE THE ECOSYSTEM SERVICES  INCLUDING DROUGHT RESILIENCY  PROVIDED TO LOCAL MIGRATORY WILDLIFE AND THE TRIBE  THIS PROJECT IS THE NEXT STEP TO CURRENT PROJECTS OR ACTIVITIES AIMED AT PROTECTING THE RESERVATION S SPRINGS

THIS MULTIFACETED AGREEMENT WITH THE OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION ODWC COVERS CONSERVATION PRACTICES ON PRIVATE LANDS AND OTHER ACTIVITIES THROUGHOUT THE STATE OF OKLAHOMA  THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT AGREEMENT PROVIDES FINANCIAL BACKING TO ONGOING COLLABORATIVE CONSERVATION WORK BETWEEN THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE USFWS ODWC AND VOLUNTARY PRIVATE LANDOWNERS  THE AGREEMENT WILL SUPPORT THE RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT OF WETLANDS GRASSLANDS AND RIPARIAN HABITAT INCLUDING ON THE GROUND PROJECTS WHICH WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE RECOVERY OF FEDERALLY LISTED AND OTHER IMPERILED SPECIES SUCH AS THE LESSER PRAIRIE CHICKEN AMERICAN BURYING BEETLE AND MONARCH BUTTERFLIES   POLLINATORS ADDITIONALLY MOST PROJECTS WILL RESULT IN IMPROVED HABITAT FOR A VARIETY OF GAME SPECIES WITH SOME FOCUSED ON IMPROVING HABITAT FOR OVERWINTERING WATERFOWL  SOME PROJECTS WILL FOCUS ON OUTDOOR EDUCATION AND FACILITATE THE CONSTRUCTION OF OUTDOOR CLASSROOMS  THE AGREEMENT WILL CONTINUE TO IMPLEMENT PROJECTS ON PROPERTIES AND MONITOR LANDOWNERS WHO ARE ENROLLED IN THE LESSER PRAIRIE CHICKEN CANDIDATE CONSERVATION AGREEMENT WITH ASSURANCES  THE AGREEMENT SUPPORTS CONSERVATION ACTIONS IDENTIFIED AS PRIORITIES WITHIN THE INTERIOR REGION 2 GREAT PLAINS AND EAST TEXAS OKLAHOMA EMPHASIS AREAS AND AS DESCRIBED IN THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAMS STRATEGIC PLAN

AND DISPERSE WATER FLOWS AND CAPTURE SEDIMENT  AS A RESULT OF RAISING THE WATER TABLE, WET MEADOW HABITAT WILL INCREASE AND PROVIDE ECOLOGICAL BENEFITS INCLUDING BREEDING AND FORAGING HABITAT FOR BIRDS AND INVERTEBRATES AND HABITAT FOR WETLAND PLANTS  FENCING OUT SPRING SOURCES PROVIDES PROTECTION TO CRITICAL WATER SOURCES  REMOVAL OF OLD FENCE AND IMPROVEMENTS TO EXISTING NEW FENCE WILL FACILITATE WILDLIFE MOVEMENT THROUGH THE AREA AND PROVIDE FOR CONTROLLED LIVESTOCK GRAZING  CONTROL OF NOXIOUS AND INVASIVE SPECIES WILL ALLOW FOR MORE DESIRABLE SPECIES TO DOMINATE AREAS AS WILL SPAWNING GRAVEL FOR REDBAND TROUT AND CHINOOK SALMON WILL BE ADDED TO STREAMS THROUGHOUT THE UPPER KLAMATH BASIN THE MAIN OBJECTIVE IS TO RESTORE IMPROVE HABITAT IN THE UPPER KLAMATH BASIN BY INCREASING SPAWNING AND REARING SITES FOR NATIVE FISH SPECIES

OVER THE COURSE OF THIS PROJECT, GRASSLAND HABITAT WILL BE RESTORED TO THE PROJECT AREA BY BRUSH CLEARING, INVASIVE SPECIES REMOVAL, SOIL QUALITY ENHANCEMENT, AND SEEDING OF GRASSES AND FORBS  THE GRASSES AND FORBS SEEDED WILL BE SELECTED TO PROVIDE THE GREATEST BENEFIT TO GRASSLAND BIRDS AND NATIVE POLLINATORS  SEEDED GRASSES AND FORBS WILL PROVIDE COVER, NESTING MATERIALS, AND FOOD RESOURCES FOR GRASSLAND BIRDS AND NATIVE POLLINATORS  AFTER COMPLETION, THE PROJECT AREA WILL BE MANAGED TO RETAIN GRASSLAND BIRD AND NATIVE POLLINATOR HABITAT

PLANNED CONSERVATION ACTIONS WILL ENHANCE VEGETATION COMMUNITIES IN THE SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEM AND PROTECT MESIC HABITATS  THROUGHOUT THE PAST 10 15 YEARS, SEVERAL FIRES HAVE BURNED THROUGH THE AREA DESTROYING HABITAT CRITICAL FOR GREATER SAGE GROUSE AND MULE DEER IN ADDITION TO MIGRATORY BIRDS AND OTHER SAGEBRUSH OBLIGATE SPECIES  THE COOPERATOR AND PARTNERS HAVE WORKED TOGETHER TO RESTORE AND ENHANCE THE HABITAT AFTER THE FIRES  THE COOPERATOR HAS BEEN ACTIVELY WORKING TO CREATE A FLEXIBLE GRAZING MANAGEMENT PROGRAM FOR THE RANCH ALLOWING FOR SUSTAINABLE GRAZING PRACTICES LEADING TO THE ENHANCEMENT OF HIGH VALUE SAGEBRUSH UPLAND AND RIPARIAN MESIC HABITATS ACTIVITIES FUNDED BY THIS EFFORT WILL INCLUDE PROTECTION FROM FIRE, I E , FIRE BREAKS, TO PROTECT RESTORED AND REMAINING SAGEBRUSH HABITATS  WILDLIFE FRIENDLY FENCING WILL BE CONSTRUCTED TO FACILITATE ROTATIONAL GRAZING ANDTHE ADJUSTMENT OF SEASON OF USE, REST PERIODS, AND LIVESTOCK ACCESS TO SENSITIVE HABITAT AREAS  ADDITION OF LIVESTOCK WATERING TANKS WILL BE ADDED IN PASTURES WHERE THE RIPARIAN MESIC AREAS HAVE BEEN FENCED OUT TO PROTECTTHOSE SENSITIVE AREAS  IMPLEMENTATION OF THESE ACTIVITIES WILL FOR ADAPTIVE GRAZING MANAGEMENT LEADING TO REDUCEDPRESSURE ON MESIC AREAS AND ENHANCED SAGEBRUSH WILDLIFE HABITAT

THE PURPOSE OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS TO ESTABLISH A WORKING PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE SERVICE AND THE  RECIPIENT FOR THE PURPOSE OF PROMOTING CONSERVATION ON PRIVATELY OWNED LANDS THROUGH A VARIETY OF ON-THE-GROUND  RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT PRACTICES. THE RECIPIENT WILL WORK COOPERATIVELY WITH THE SERVICE TO IDENTIFY,  DEVELOP AND ESTABLISH MUTUALLY BENEFICIAL CONSERVATION PROJECTS. ALL PROJECTS WILL BE FACILITATED BY SITESPECIFIC PRIVATE LANDOWNER AGREEMENTS (PLAS) AS APPROVED AND ADMINISTERED BY THE SERVICE. THIS AGREEMENT WILL  RESTORE AND ENHANCE HABITATS VARIETY OF FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES INCLUDING MANY SPECIES OF DECLINING GRASSLAND  NESTING BIRDS. RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT OF HABITATS WITHIN HIGH PRIORITY FOCUS AREAS WILL CONTRIBUTE TOWARDS  MEETING THE POPULATION AND HABITAT OBJECTIVES IDENTIFIED IN THE SERVICE'S 2022-2026 MOUNTAIN-PRAIRIE REGION  STRATEGIC PLAN FOR THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM.

THE CC 38 PROJECT IS LOCATED ON PRIVATELY OWNED PROPERTY ALONG CATHERINE CREEK DOWNSTREAM OF UNION, OREGON  THE PROPERTY IS CURRENTLY MANAGED AS AN OPERATING FARM AND RANCH, WITH MUCH OF THE HISTORIC FLOODPLAIN BEING IN HAY AND PASTURE PRODUCTION  THE CHANNEL THROUGH THE 1,600 FOOT PROJECT REACH IS MODERATELY CONFINED WITH A FLOODPLAIN WIDTH OF 67 FEET, A SINUOSITY OF 1 19, AND A STREAM GRADIENT OF 0 5  PROPOSED CONCEPTUAL ACTIONS ARE INTENDED TO INCREASE BOTH SUMMER AND OVER WINTERING HABITAT CONDITIONS FOR JUVENILE SALMONIDS  FAVROT AND JONASSON  2014  FOUND ONE POOL WITHIN THE PROJECT REACH CONTAINED THE LARGEST AMOUNT OF OVERWINTERING JUVENILE CHINOOK IN THE CATHERINE CREEK BASIN AND ALSO FOUND THAT A SECOND POOL IN THE REACH HAD THE NEXT HIGHEST BUT LACKED A LARGE WOOD COMPONENT  IN ADDITION, THEY IDENTIFIED THAT JUVENILE CHINOOK IN THE REACH WERE PRIMARILY ASSOCIATED WITH SMALL TRANSIENT WOOD OWNING TO THE LACK OF STABLE LARGE WOOD IN THE REACH THIS PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO ENHANCE AQUATIC HABITAT CONDITIONS FOR KEY SALMONID AND OTHER NATIVE FISH SPECIES IN FIVE POOLS WITH LARGE WOOD PLACEMENT, PROMOTE NATIVE RIPARIAN PLANT ESTABLISHMENT AND SURVIVAL, AND DECREASE EROSION AND MASS WASTING OF STREAM BANKS  TO ACHIEVE THESE OUTCOMES PROJECT ACTIONS WILL BE IMPLEMENTED TO REDUCE STREAM BANK SLOPE ANGLES, ENHANCE EXISTING POOL HABITAT AND PROMOTE DEEP POOL DEVELOPMENT, INCREASE INSTREAM CHANNEL COMPLEXITY AND COVER, AND IMPROVE THE RIPARIAN VEGETATION COMMUNITY  SPECIFIC CONSTRUCTION ACTIONS WILL PLACE APPROXIMATELY 206 PIECES OF LARGE WOODY MATERIAL, 200 PIECES OF SMALLER RACKING WOOD, AND 52 BOULDERS IN 20 LOCATIONS THROUGHOUT THE PROJECT REACH  RIPARIAN VEGETATION SPECIES WILL BE PLANTED THROUGHOUT THE REACH AT LOCATIONS BASED ON SITE SPECIFIC SOIL AND HYDROLOGY CONDITIONS WHERE SURVIVAL IS EXPECTED TO BE HIGH  PROJECT CONSTRUCTION IS PLANNED FOR THE SUMMER OF 2022

THIS AGREEMENT WILL PROVIDE  55,000 TO THE ALTAR VALLEY CONSERVATION ALLIANCE  RECIPIENT  TO WORK WITH PRIVATE LANDOWNERS IN THE ALTAR VALLEY  LANDOWNERS AND SUB RECIPIENTS  TO ENHANCE HABITAT FOR MIGRATORY BIRDS AND THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES  THE LANDOWNERS, RECIPIENT, AND USFWS WILL SIGN A SUB RECIPIENT LANDOWNER AGREEMENT TO IDENTIFY WORK THAT WILL IMPROVE HABITAT TO BENEFIT FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES  THE SUB RECIPIENT LANDOWNER AGREEMENTS WILL INCLUDE PROJECT NARRATIVES AND BUDGETS  THE RECIPIENT WILL OVERSEE THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE LANDOWNER AGREEMENT  THIS PROJECT WILL WORK TO ENHANCE WETLANDS, UPLANDS, OR RIPARIAN AREAS THROUGH VARIOUS TECHNIQUES ON PRIVATE LAND  THE PRACTICES INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO, REMOVING NATIVE AND NON NATIVE TREES, INSTALLING EROSION CONTROL STRUCTURES, LIVESTOCK MANAGEMENT, INVASIVE SPECIES CONTROL, NATIVE VEGETATION PLANTING, AND OTHER PRACTICES

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PROVIDE FEDERAL FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE FUNDING SO THAT TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT  TPWD  CAN DELIVER FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE DIRECTLY TO PRIVATE LANDOWNERS THROUGH THE LANDOWNER INCENTIVE PROGRAM  LIP  ACROSS TEXAS  EXHIBIT A   THE LIP IS A COLLABORATIVE EFFORT BETWEEN TPWD WILDLIFE AND INLAND FISHERIES DIVISIONS AND THE USFWS TO MEET THE NEEDS OF PRIVATE LANDOWNERS TO IMPLEMENT POSITIVE CONSERVATION PRACTICES ON THEIR LANDS TO BENEFIT 1  HEALTHY TERRESTRIAL AND AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS, AND 2  THE FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES THAT INHABIT THOSE ECOSYSTEMS

THE SAN JUAN ISLAND CONSERVATION DISTRICT WILL BE IMPLEMENTING, WITH ASSISTANCE FROM THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM, TEN NEW ISLAND MARBLE BUTTERFLY PROJECTS WHICH INCLUDE FENCED SUITABLE HABITAT PLOTS AND LONG-TERM "OPEN SPACE" FOR BUTTERFLY FLIGHT. THESE PROJECTS WILL BE IMPLEMENTED ON PRIVATE PROPERTIES ON BOTH SAN JUAN AND LOPEZ ISLANDS. THESE PROJECTS WILL EXPAND EXISTING PROJECTS/HABITAT AND ACT AS "STEPPING STONES" FOR THE BUTTERFLY TO UTILIZE AND INCREASE ITS RANGE ACROSS THE ISLANDS.

WATER CHESTNUT  TRAPA NATANS L   IS AN INVASIVE AQUATIC PLANT NATIVE TO EUROPE, ASIA AND AFRICA  FIRST CONFIRMED IN VERMONT IN LAKE CHAMPLAIN IN THE 1940S, ITS CURRENT RANGE IN THE LAKE IS FROM MISSISQUOI BAY SOUTH TO WHITEHALL, NEW YORK WITH THE DENSEST POPULATIONS NOW LIMITED TO THE SOUTH LAKE SEGMENT, SOUTH OF BENSON LANDING, VERMONT ONLY  WATER CHESTNUT CAN ALSO BE FOUND IN A NUMBER OF SOUTHERN LAKE CHAMPLAIN TRIBUTARIES, 30 OTHER VERMONT WATER BODIES AND AT SITES NORTH OF THE LAKE IN QUEBEC  IT IS ONE OF THE FEW AQUATIC INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES THAT ARE ANNUAL, REPRODUCING BY SEED  SEED VIABILITY NECESSITATES ON GOING CONTROL FOR MANAGEMENT EFFORTS TO BE SUCCESSFUL WITH THE ABILITY TO FORM DENSE MONOCULTURES IN A SHORT TIME PERIOD, WATER CHESTNUT CAN DISPLACE NATURAL PLANT DIVERSITY IN WETLANDS, LAKES AND RIVERS, DEGRADE WILDLIFE HABITAT AND REDUCE OXYGEN LEVELS  IT CAN ALSO NEGATIVELY ALTER THE RECREATION POTENTIAL OF THE INVADED WATER BODY AND REDUCE SHORELINE PROPERTY VALUES SINCE 1982, THE VERMONT DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION  VTDEC  HAS MANAGED WATER CHESTNUT IN LAKE CHAMPLAIN AND OTHER VERMONT WATERS ANNUALLY  FOR MORE THAN A DECADE, VTDEC HAS WORKED IN COOPERATION WITH THE U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  USFWS , AND NUMEROUS OTHER PARTNERS, TO MANAGE SPARSE POPULATIONS OF WATER CHESTNUT VIA HAND HARVEST  VTDEC EFFORTS HAVE WORKED TO SURVEY, EVALUATE AND CONTROL WATER CHESTNUT FROM ROUGHLY 500 ACRES OF WETLAND HABITAT ASSOCIATED WITH LAKE CHAMPLAIN SITES  MANY OF THESE SITES GENERALLY CONTINUE TO EXHIBIT A PATTERN OF DECREASING WATER CHESTNUT ABUNDANCE OR STABILIZATION  VTDEC PROPOSES TO CONTINUE CONTROL EFFORTS AT THESE SITES IN 2019 THROUGH 2021 THROUGH THIS PROJECT, VTDEC WILL   IMPROVE HABITAT AND NATIVE PLANT DIVERSITY THROUGH A NORTH TO SOUTH LAKE CHAMPLAIN AND ADJOINING TRIBUTARIES WATER CHESTNUT MANAGEMENT PROGRAM ANNUALLY THROUGH THE DURATION OF THE PROJECT PERIOD   IDENTIFY WATER CHESTNUT INFESTED AREAS BY SURVEYS AND SEARCHES   CONDUCT THE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM BETWEEN JUNE AND SEPTEMBER PROJECT TASKS   TARGET ROUGHLY 500 ACRES OF WETLAND HABITAT, AND HAND HARVEST WATER CHESTNUT IF FOUND, REMOVING STEMS AND ROOTS WHERE POSSIBLE   USE MOTORIZED AND NON MOTORIZED BOATS TO ACCESS SITES  PONTOON BOATS TRANSPORT CONTRACTED CREWS AND KAYAKS TO WATER CHESTNUT SITES NOT ADJACENT TO ACCESS POINTS   RECORD THE ESTIMATED NUMBER AND WEIGHT OF ROSETTES PULLED BY COUNTING AND WEIGHING A SUBSET   DISPOSE OF ALL PULLED ROSETTES ARE DISPOSED OF AT UPLAND, NON WETLAND SITES  WHEN POSSIBLE, SITES ARE TARGETED TWO OR MORE TIMES ANNUALLY EXPECTED OUTCOMES THE LAKE CHAMPLAIN WATER CHESTNUT CONTROL PROJECT WILL SURVEY AND SEARCH FOR WATER CHESTNUT IN ROUGHLY 500 ACRES OF WETLAND HABITAT ASSOCIATED WITH LAKE CHAMPLAIN  IF WATER CHESTNUT IS FOUND, PLANTS WILL BE HAND HARVESTED, REMOVING AS MUCH OF THE STEMS AND ROOTS WHERE POSSIBLE  REMOVAL OF THIS FLOATING LEAVED INVASIVE PLANT WILL IMPROVE WILDLIFE HABITAT AND INCREASE NATIVE PLANT DIVERSITY

CANAAN VALLEY INSTITUTE (CVI) WILL IMPLEMENT AQUATIC CONNECTIVITY, STREAM RESTORATION, AND RIPARIAN CORRIDOR ENHANCEMENT PROJECTS ON PRIVATE LANDS IN SOUTHWEST VIRGINIA, AND WILL INCLUDE SPECIFICALLY IDENTIFIED PROJECTS IN THE UPPER TENNESSEE RIVER BASIN AND BIG SANDY WATERSHED TO BENEFIT NUMEROUS FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES. THIS WILL INCLUDE PROJECT PLANNING, RIVER/STREAM ASSESSMENT, DAM REMOVAL FEASIBILITY AND ASSESSMENT, PROJECT DESIGN, PERMITTING AND ENVIRONMENTAL COMPLIANCE, MONITORING, PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION, OUTREACH AND EDUCATION, AND OTHER SERVICES DEEMED NECESSARY TO EFFECTIVELY DELIVER RESTORATION PROJECTS AND IMPROVE AQUATIC CONNECTIVITY. WHEN TASK 1 IS COMPLETED, ONE FISH PASSAGE BARRIER REMOVAL FEASIBILITY ANALYSIS (CLINCHCO DAM IN THE BIG SANDY WATERSHED), 1/2 MILE OF STREAM RESTORATION AND/OR STREAMBANK STABILIZATION, 3 ACRES OF RIPARIAN BUFFER ESTABLISHMENT. SERVICE FY22 CONTRIBUTION IS $60,000.00. CVI PROPOSES TO COMPLETE THIS PROJECT IN COLLABORATION WITH USFWS PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM (PFW). PFW WILL PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO COMPLETE THE SCOPE OF WORK, INCLUDING STREAM DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION MANAGEMENT. CVI WILL COORDINATE DIRECTLY WITH USFWS PFW TO OBTAIN ALL REQUIRED PERMITTING AND ENVIRONMENTAL COMPLIANCE DOCUMENTATION TO IMPLEMENT THE PROJECT.

NATURALAND TRUST IS REQUESTING FUNDING FOR FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES HABITAT RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT PROJECTS ON PRIVATE LAND  NATURALAND TRUST IS A PRIVATE, NONPROFIT LAND TRUST THAT PROTECTS SOUTH CAROLINA S BLUE RIDGE MOUNTAINS AND SPECIAL PLACES IN SOUTH CAROLINA S PIEDMONT  NATURALAND TRUST HAS PURSUED THIS MISSION FOR ALMOST 50 YEARS  THE TRUST HELPS CONSERVATION AGENCIES AND OTHER NONPROFITS ACQUIRE IMPORTANT PROPERTIES, AND THE TRUST ITSELF ACQUIRES AND OWNS PROPERTIES BECAUSE OF THEIR NATURAL AND ECOLOGICAL SIGNIFICANCE CURRENTLY, THE TRUST OWNS ALMOST 9,000 ACRES, MOSTLY IN THE BLUE RIDGE ESCARPMENT AND THE FOOTHILLS OF THE BLUE RIDGE MOUNTAINS  THIS IS AN AREA OF RECOGNIZED BIODIVERSITY, AND AS A RESULT THE PROPERTIES OWNED BY THE TRUST CONTAIN RARE SPECIES, INCLUDING FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES  IN ADDITION, THE TRUST HAS MADE A CONCERTED EFFORT TO ACQUIRE PROPERTIES CONTAINING HABITAT FOR FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES  FOR EXAMPLE, CURRENTLY THE TRUST OWNS PROPERTIES THAT CONTAIN POPULATIONS OF THE ENDANGERED BUNCHED ARROWHEAD  SAGITTARIA FASCICULATA  AND MAY CONTAIN THE THREATENED DWARF FLOWERED HEARTLEAF  HEXASTYLIS NANIFLORA , AS WELL AS PROPERTIES THAT ADJOIN AND BUFFER POPULATIONS OF FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES  THE TRUST IS ALSO PURSUING ACQUISITION OF OTHER SUCH PROPERTIES  HOWEVER, THESE HABITATS OF FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES ARE PLAGUED BY INVASIVE SPECIES, SUCH AS ENGLISH IVY, PRIVET, ASIAN WISTERIA, AND EXOTIC HOLLIES  THEY ARE ALSO IMPACTED BY STORMWATER RUNOFF AND OTHER HUMAN IMPACTS  THESE PROBLEMS CAN DIRECTLY HARM INDIVIDUAL SPECIMENS OF THE LISTED SPECIES AND ALTER, DEGRADE, AND SOMETIMES ELIMINATE HABITAT OF THE LISTED SPECIES THIS FUNDING IS REQUESTED TO ADDRESS THESE HARMS AND DEGRADATIONS OF HABITATS AND POPULATIONS OF FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES ON PROPERTIES OWNED BY NATURALAND TRUST

THE UPSTREAM HALF OF CRANE CREEK ON PRIVATE PROPERTY WAS RE ROUTED FROM THE STRAIGHTENED REACH AND RESTORED IN 2008, AND THE DOWNSTREAM HALF ON PRIVATE PROPERTY WAS RE ROUTED AND RESTORED IN 2021  THERE IS A SMALL SECTION BETWEEN THE TWO RESTORATION PROJECTS WHERE A FISH PASSAGE BARRIER EXISTS AND THE CHANNEL IS STILL LEVEED AND STRAIGHTENED  THE BARRIER, A DROP CULVERT THAT USED TO PROVIDE WATER CONTROL FOR IRRIGATION, PROHIBITS PASSAGE YEAR ROUND FOR NATIVE REDBAND TROUT  THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL DESIGN THE REMOVAL OF THE EXISTING CULVERT AND THE CONSTRUCTION NEW ROCK RIFFLE STRUCTURE, WHICH WILL ALLOW FOR UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM FISH PASSAGE IN CRANE CREEK  THE DESIGN WILL ALSO INCLUDE SPECIFICATIONS FOR INSTREAM AND RIPARIAN HABITAT IMPROVEMENTS DOWNSTREAM OF THE RIFFLE  E G  LARGE WOOD ADDITIONS, LEVEE REMOVAL

NUMEROUS RESTORATION ACTIONS WILL BE IMPLEMENTED TO RESTORE AND OR IMPROVE WETLAND HABITAT ON PRIVATE LANDS CURRENTLY ENROLLED IN THE WETLAND RESERVE EASEMENTS  WRE  PROGRAM THROUGH THE NATURAL RESOURCE CONSERVATION SERVICE AND FARM SERVICE AGENCY CONSERVATION EASEMENTS  RESTORATION ACTIONS WILL INCLUDE LEVEE REMOVAL AND NOTCHING, EARTH WORK TO RESTORE WETLAND HYDROLOGY, SOIL MANIPULATION  DISKING, PLOWING, ETC  , PURCHASE AND INSTALLATION OF WATER CONTROL STRUCTURES AND ASSOCIATED MATERIALS, INSTALLATION OF SMALL BERMS, AND ANY OTHER ACTIVITY ASSOCIATED WITH RESTORING WETLAND HYDROLOGY AND ECOSYSTEM FUNCTION  TWO PROJECTS HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED FOR FUNDING WITH LANDOWNER INTEREST  WE EXPECT TO RESTORE AND ENHANCE APPROXIMATELY 1,270 WETLAND ACRES

THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO INCREASE NATIVE FISH PRODUCTIVITY AND ENHANCE IN-STREAM FISHHABITAT, AS WELL AS PROMOTE RECOVERY OF SELF-SUSTAINING HYDROLOGIC PROCESSES ON THE LANDSCAPE.THIS PROJECT WILL IMPLEMENT IN-STREAM, RIPARIAN, AND FLOODPLAIN RESTORATION ACTIVITIES AIMED ATBOTH MITIGATING EFFECTS OF SUSTAINED RIPARIAN GRAZING AND IMPROVING FISH HABITAT IN WHISKY CREEKAND SPRAGUE RIVER. LOW-TECH PROCESS-BASED RESTORATION (LTPBR) SUCH AS BEAVER DAM ANALOGS(BDA'S), POST ASSISTED LOG STRUCTURES, AND LARGE WOODY DEBRIS (LWD'S), AND ZEEDYK STRUCTURES,WILL BE COMBINED WITH RIPARIAN PLANTING AND CATTLE EXCLUSION FENCING ON WHISKEY CREEK, SPRAGUERIVER, AND EPHEMERAL WATERWAYS. THE BDA'S AND LWD'S WILL INCREASE SEDIMENT RETENTION ANDIMPROVE CHANNEL COMPLEXITY IN WHISKY CREEK AND SPRAGUE RIVER. THE ZEEDYK STRUCTURES WILLINCREASE SEDIMENT RETENTION AND SLOW THE FLOW OF WATER ON THE EPHEMERAL WATERWAYS. WE WILLINSTALL A WATER CONTROL STRUCTURE AT THE CENTER OF THE PROPERTY TO ALLOW THE LANDOWNER TO MAINTAINHEALTHY WETLAND VEGETATION AND PREVENT THE BLOWING OUT OR EROSION OF SEVERAL OF THE LTPBRSTRUCTURES. WE WILL PLANT NATIVE TREES AND SHRUBS ALONG RIPARIAN AREAS AND AROUND LTPBRSTRUCTURES. PLANTING NATIVE VEGETATION WILL LIKELY REDUCE SEDIMENT INPUTS INTO WHISKY CREEK ANDSPRAGUE RIVER AND PROVIDE SHADE TO RIVER FISHES. FINALLY, A CATTLE CROSSING WILL BE INSTALLED ON THESPRAGUE RIVER TO REDUCE EROSION AND LOOSENING OF SEDIMENTS IN THE RIVER.THIS PROJECT WILL ENCOURAGE ADDITIONAL BEAVER ACTIVITY IN AN AREA WHERE BEAVER ARE ACTIVE NEARBY.SPECIES LIKELY TO BENEFIT FROM THIS PROJECT ARE RESIDENT NATIVE FISH INCLUDING ENDANGERED LOSTRIVER (DELTISTES LUXATUS) AND SHORTNOSE (CHASMISTES BREVIROSTRIS) SUCKERS, ENDANGERED BULL TROUT(SALVELINUS CONFLUENCES), REDBAND TROUT (ONCORHYNCHUS MYKISS GIBBSI), AND BROWN TROUT (SALMOTRUTTA). FURTHER, MANY SPECIES OF RIPARIAN DEPENDENT AND NEOTROPICAL BIRDS, POLLINATORS, AND OTHERSHRUBBY RIPARIAN HABITAT DEPENDENT SPECIES ARE LIKELY TO BENEFIT FROM THIS PROJECT (E.G. YELLOWBILLEDCUCKOO AND MONARCH).EXPECTED OUTCOMES:? IN-STREAM HABITAT IMPROVEMENTS: 1.5 MILES? RIPARIAN PLANTINGS: 30 ACRES? WETLAND: 90 ACRES

THE PROJECT AREA CAN BE DESCRIBED AS BOTTOM LAND TYPE HABITAT IN AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION FOR HAY. HABITAT TREATMENTS WILL INCLUDE THE ENHANCEMENT OF A 5 ACRE WETLAND HABITAT TO BENEFIT FEDERAL TRUST RESOURCE SPECIES AND MIGRATORY BIRDS.THIS PROJECT WILL ADD ONE EARTHEN DIKE AND A DRAIN STRUCTURE TO PROVIDE THE LANDOWNER THE OPPORTUNITY TO MANAGE THE WETLAND WITH 5 ACRES OF WATER THAT IS 18 INCHES OR LESS THROUGH THE ENTIRE WETLAND. THIS WETLAND WILL BE MANAGED BY THE LANDOWNER FOR WATERFOWL AND OTHER MIGRATORY BIRDS. THE HABITAT PROJECT WILL INCLUDE THE INSTALLATION OF A NEW DIKE, DRAIN STRUCTURE, AND STEEL PIPE TO BETTER MANAGE THE WETLAND HABITAT AS PREFERRED BY THE LANDOWNER. THE COOPERATOR MAY MANAGE FOR THE NATURAL WETLAND PLANTS OR MAY OPT FOR PLANTING AGRICULTURAL CROPS FOR A FOOD SOURCE FOR MIGRATING BIRDS AS WELL. WATER LEVELS WILL BE RAISED IN THE FALL AND WINTER MONTHS FOR WATERFOWL USE.

THE PURPOSE OF THE SCOTT RIVER TAILINGS OASIS PROJECT IS TO RESTORE INSTREAM HABITAT COMPLEXITY AND RIPARIAN VEGETATION IN A SECTION OF THE SCOTT RIVER THAT HAS BEEN DEGRADED BY PAST DREDGE MINING ACTIVITIES  THE PROJECT WILL CONSTRUCT A SERIES OF ELEVEN WOOD STRUCTURES, THREE INSTREAM AND EIGHT ALONG THE RIVER MARGINS, THROUGHOUT AN APPROXIMATELY 440 FOOT REACH OF THE RIVER  THE WOOD STRUCTURES WILL IMPROVE HABITAT FOR COHO AND CHINOOK SALMON AND STEELHEAD BY CREATING SCOUR POOLS AND SLOW WATER HABITATS FOR REARING FISH, SORT GRAVELS USED FOR SPAWNING, AND PROVIDE COVER DURING MIGRATION PERIODS  THE CREATION OF SCOUR POOLS WILL ALSO HELP IMPROVE CONNECTIVITY DURING LOW FLOW PERIODS  SUMMER AND FALL   APPROXIMATELY 0 5 ACRES OF RIPARIAN HABITAT, CONSISTING OF WILLOWS AND COTTONWOODS WILL BE PLANTED IMMEDIATELY DOWNSTREAM OF THE EIGHT LOG STRUCTURES ALONG THE RIVER MARGIN  OVER TIME, RIPARIAN PLANTINGS WILL PROVIDE SHADE OVER THE RIVER AND COOLER WATER TEMPERATURES THAT ARE MORE FAVORABLE FOR COHO, CHINOOK, AND STEELHEAD  COLLECTIVELY, THE THREE PROJECT PHASES WILL RESTORE APPROXIMATELY 1,000 FEET OF INSTREAM HABITAT AND 1 ACRE OF RIPARIAN HABITAT

THE SOUTHERN INITIATIVE FOR WOOD AND WILDLIFE WILL BE A PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN AMERICAN FOREST FOUNDATION AND THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE TO LEVERAGE RESOURCES AND PARTNERS FROM BOTH ORGANIZATIONS TO CONTINUE TO SUPPORT PRIVATE LANDOWNERS WHO OWN FORESTS IN THE SOUTH ALONG WHILE ALSO PROTECTING HABITAT FOR PRIORITY WILDLIFE SPECIES. THE GOAL OF THIS INITIATIVE IS TO ASSIST LANDOWNERS TO SUSTAINABLY MANAGE THEIR FORESTS AND AT THE SAME TIME CONSERVING AT-RISK AND LISTED SPECIES WHILE ASSURING THAT A ROBUST FOREST INDUSTRY CONTINUES TO OPERATE IN THE SOUTH. PRIVATE LANDOWNERS WILL RECEIVE FUNDING FOR MANAGEMENT PRACTICES, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, FINANCIAL INCENTIVES, AND REGULATORY PREDICTABILITY IN REGARD TO SPECIES. EVALUATIVE OUTCOMES OF IMPLEMENTED MANAGEMENT PRACTICES WITH DATA MONITORING WILL BE USED TO ASSESS LANDOWNER MANAGEMENT AND INFORM SERVICE BIOLOGISTS ON LISTING DECISIONS AND RECOVERY DETERMINATIONS.

THE FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS TO RESTORE, ENHANCE AND PROTECT RIPARIAN, IN-STREAM, SPRINGS AND SPRING-RUN AQUATIC HABITATS BY STABILIZING STREAMBANKS AND REDUCING SEDIMENTATION. RIPARIAN RESTORATION WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED BY INSTALLING FENCES AND ASSOCIATED FEATURES TO CONTROL LIVESTOCK ACCESS TO STREAMS, CONDUCTING SIT PREPARATION, PLANTING NATIVE TREES, SHRUBS OR HERBACEOUS VEGETATION TO RESTORE RIPARIAN BUFFERS USING BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES(BMOS) WHEN CONDUCTING FOREST MANAGEMENT, PRESCRIBED FIRE AND TARGETED OUTREACH TO LANDOWNERS. NATURAL CHANNEL DESIGN WILL BE EMPLOYED ALONG STREAM REACHES WHERE STREAMBANK STABILIZATION IS NECESSARY TO ABATE CONTINUED BANK DEGRADATION.ADDITIONALLY, CAVE-DWELLING BATS, AS WELL AS CAVE OBLIGATES SUCH AS CAVEFISH AND CAVE CRAYFISH, HAVE BEEN IN STEADY DECLINE. THE PFW RO BAT STRATEGY OUTLINES MANY FACTORS THREATENING CAVE ECOSYSTEMS AND THE SPECIES THAT DEPEND ON THEM. THESE FACTORS INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO HUMAN DISTURBANCE, VANDALISM, POLLUTION, (ILLEGAL TRASH DUMPS, ETC) INADEQUATE SUMMER/FORAGE HABITAT, AND WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME. FOREST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES HAVE LED TO LIMITED ROOSTING HABITAT FOR TREE ROOSTING BATS IN SOME AREAS AS WELL. THIS PROJECT WILL HELP PRESERVE THE INTEGRITY OF THE KARST HABITAT BY MITIGATING THE ABOVE-LISTED THREATS THROUGH THE INSTALLATION OF APPROPRIATE CAVE GATES/FENCES, SPRING/SPRING RUN PROTECTION AND ENHANCEMENT, AND FOREST MANAGEMENT THAT ENHANCES OR PRESERVES SUITABLE FOREST HABITAT TYPES NECESSARY FOR FORAGING.A PORTION OF THE FUNDING FOR THIS PROJECT IS IN SUPPORT OF THE REGIONAL CONSERVATION PARTNERSHIP PROGRAM EFFORT LED BY THE ARKANSAS-LOUISIANA CONSERVATION DELIVERY NETWORKS OPEN PINE LANDSCAPE RESTORATION PARTNERSHIP WILL ADVANCE THE RECOVERY OF SPECIES OF CONSERVATION CONCERN BY IMPLEMENTING DESIRED FOREST CONDITION MANAGEMENT PRACTICES ACROSS 30,000 ACRES OF PRIVATE LANDS IN ARKANSAS AND LOUISIANA. PFW PROGRAM FIELD STAFF WILL HELP FACILITATE THIS EFFORT THROUGH CONTINUED COLLABORATION WITH PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AND THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE GROUND RESTORATION PROJECTS. USDA-APPROVED CONSERVATION PRACTICES INCLUDE: 338-PRESCRIBED BURNING, 394 -FIREBREAK, 643-RESTORATION OF RARE OR DECLINING NATURAL COMMUNITIES-WOODLAND, GLADE, BARREN, SAVANNA OR PRAIRIE RESTORATION, 645-UPLAND WILDLIFE HABITAT MANAGEMENT( HABITAT MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT, MEDIUM INTENSITY AND COMPLEXITY) AND 666 FOREST STAND IMPROVEMENT.

THE PASTURES FOR UPLAND BIRDS (PUB) PROGRAM WILL PROVIDE INCENTIVES TO TEXAS LANDOWNERS WHOSE GOAL IS TO CONVERT EXOTIC GRASS SITES TO NATIVE BUNCHGRASSES AND FORBS. TEXAS PARKS & WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT (TPWD AND RECIPIENT) WILL WORK COLLABORATIVELY WITH THE U.S. FISH & WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) TO ENROLL PRIVATE LANDOWNERS INTO THE PARTNERS FOR FISH & WILDLIFE PROGRAM VIA SUB-RECIPIENT LANDOWNER AGREEMENTS. THIS PROGRAM FILLS A NICHE FOR LANDOWNERS THAT MAY NOT QUALIFY FOR OTHER COST-SHARE PROGRAMS SUPPORTING NATIVE GRASS RESTORATION. ADDITIONALLY, PROPERLY MANAGED NATIVE WARM SEASON GRASSES MAY PROVIDE SUITABLE FORAGE PRODUCTION AND PROTEIN LEVELS REQUIRED FOR LIVESTOCK. THIS PROGRAM BENEFITS LANDOWNERS WHOSE GOALS INCLUDE HABITAT IMPROVEMENT FOR BUTTERFLIES, QUAIL, TURKEY, MIGRATORY SONGBIRDS, WHITE-TAILED DEER, POLLINATORS, TEXAS HORNED LIZARD, OTHER NONGAME WILDLIFE, WILDLIFE TAX VALUATION, SUSTAINABLE FORAGE PRODUCTION, OR PRESERVING TEXAS' NATIVE PRAIRIE LEGACY. THE BROADER PUBLIC BENEFITS FROM NATIVE PRAIRIE RESTORATION THROUGH IMPROVED WATER QUALITY, GROUNDWATER RECHARGE, CARBON SEQUESTRATION, EROSION CONTROL, OUTDOOR EDUCATION, AND RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES.THE PUB PROGRAM WILL PROMOTE A CONSERVATION STEWARDSHIP ETHIC THROUGH SUB-RECIPIENT LANDOWNER AGREEMENTS WITH PRIVATE LANDOWNERS DIRECTED AT IMPROVING HABITAT FOR MIGRATORY WILDLIFE AND RESIDENT GAME AND NON-GAME SPECIES USING AREAS ENROLLED IN PUB. HABITAT IMPROVEMENTS ARE ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH CONSERVATION SCIENCE WHICH DETERMINE THE BEST PRACTICES TO MANAGE LAND AND WATER RESOURCES AND DETERMINE ADEPT MANAGEMENT ACTIONS. THE PROJECT SUPPORTS TPWD AND PRIVATE LANDOWNERS IN IMPROVING THE OVERALL TEXAS LANDSCAPE TO CREATE OUTDOOR RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES. FINALLY, THROUGH BEING A BETTER NEIGHBOR WITH THOSE CLOSEST TO OUR RESOURCES THE PROJECT HELPS TO PROMOTE THE EFFORTS OF OUR OTHER CONSERVATION PARTNERS.

IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE USFWS, PHEASANTS FOREVER, INC. IS PROPOSING THE MI WPA/NWR GRASSLAND IMPROVEMENTCOOPERATIVE AGREEMENT AS MEANS TO RESTORE AND ENHANCE OVER 150 ACRES OF DIVERSE, NATIVE GRASSLANDS ON MICHIGAN'SFIVE (5) WATERFOWL PRODUCTION AREAS AND ONE SITE ON SHIAWASSEE NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE. PROJECTS FUNDED THROUGHTHIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL FALL INTO ONE OF THE FOLLOWING TWO CATEGORIES:GRASSLAND RESTORATION ACTIVITIES WILL FOLLOW BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES AND ARE GENERALLY THE SAME FOR EACHPROPOSED SITE. FIRST, EXISTING UNDESIRABLE VEGETATION WILL BE REMOVED BY MOWING, FELLING OR WHOLE-TREE CHIPPING.THIS WILL BE FOLLOWED BY A TREATMENT OF THE SITE WITH A NON-SELECTIVE HERBICIDE, MIXED ACCORDING TO LABELSPECIFICATIONS,TO ELIMINATE AS MUCH VEGETATIVE COMPETITION AS POSSIBLE FOR THE NEW PLANTING. FOLLOWING THEHERBICIDE APPLICATION, ANY RUTS OR UNEVEN GROUND WILL BE SMOOTHED WITH LIGHT MECHANICAL TILLAGE AS NECESSARY. THEFIELDS WILL THEN BE PLANTED TO DIVERSE MIXTURES OF NATIVE-WARM SEASON GRASSES AND WILDFLOWERS OR COOL SEASONGRASSES AND LEGUMES USING SITE-ADAPTED TECHNIQUES. FIELDS WILL BE PLANTED WITH CUSTOM NO-TILL SEED DRILLS BUILTSPECIFICALLY FOR PLANTING NATIVE SPECIES AT THE APPROPRIATE DEPTH FOR OPTIMAL GERMINATION.GRASSLAND ENHANCEMENT ACTIVITIES ARE DESIGNED TO INCREASE SPECIES DIVERSITY IN ESTABLISHED GRASSLANDS THAT LACK ASUFFICIENT WILDFLOWER COMPONENT. FIRST, THESE FIELDS WILL BE DISTURBED WITH MECHANICAL TILLAGE (DISKING) TOCREATE A GOOD SEEDBED FOR PLANTING WILDFLOWER SEEDS AND TO OPEN THE CANOPY SO THAT LIGHT CAN REACH NEW SEEDLINGS.WILDFLOWER SEED WILL THEN BE PLANTED WITH CUSTOM NO-TILL SEED DRILLS BUILT SPECIFICALLY FOR PLANTING NATIVESPECIES AT THE APPROPRIATE DEPTH FOR OPTIMAL GERMINATION.

THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL FOCUS EFFORTS TO RESTORE HABITAT FOR NATIVE POLLINATORS AND THE MONARCH BUTTERFLY IN NORTHEAST IOWA. THE WORK WILL FOCUS ON RESTORING AND ENHANCING REMNANT HILL PRAIRIES, OAK WOODLANDS AND SAVANNA, AND WETLAND HABITATS FOR NATIVE POLLINATORS SUCH AS THE RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE (BOMBUS AFFINIS), THE AMERICAN BUMBLE BEE (BOMBUS PENSYLVANICUS), THE MONARCH BUTTERFLY (DANAUS PLEXIPPUS), AND REGAL FRITILLARY (SPEYERIA IDALIA). ADDITIONALLY, WORK TO RESTORE OR RECONSTRUCT PRAIRIE HABITATS ON PREVIOUS WORKING LANDS OR LOW DIVERSITY GRASSLANDS WILL ALSO BE PRIORITIZED.

DUCKS UNLIMITED (DU) AND THE USFWS MICHIGAN PRIVATE LANDS OFFICE SEEK TO ESTABLISH A COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT TO INCREASE EFFICIENCY AMONG GRANT AND PROJECT ADMINISTRATION, HABITAT DELIVERY, AND REPORTING TO FOCUS THE BULK OF OUR RESOURCES TO ON-THE-GROUND CONSERVATION. DU IS REQUESTING $231,000.00 FROM THE USFWS THROUGH THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT TO INITIATE THIS PROGRAM FOR THE PERIOD JUNE 1, 2022 THROUGH SEPTEMBER 30, 2024. WE ANTICIPATE THAT THESE FUNDS WILL RESTORE APPROXIMATELY 100 ACRES OF WETLANDS AND 125 ACRES OF NATIVE GRASSLAND AND POLLINATOR HABITAT ON PRIVATE LANDS WITHIN THE PROPOSED PROJECT AREA.THE DU AND USFWS PFW BIOLOGISTS WILL IDENTIFY INDIVIDUAL PROJECTS BASED ON OUR COLLECTIVE CONSERVATION PRIORITIES AND FOCUS AREAS. THE PROPOSED PROJECT AREA INCLUDES MICHIGAN'S LOWER PENINSULA. WE WILL PRIORITIZE PROJECTS GEOGRAPHICALLY BY EMPHASIZING ON MICHIGAN PFW STRATEGIC PLAN FOCUS AREAS (2017-2024), DU'S PRIORITY REGION IN MICHIGAN, AND DU'S ESTIMATED BREEDING MALLARD DISTRIBUTION MAP.

PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARY: RECOVERING ENDANGERED SPECIES IN SAN MATEO COUNTY PARKS: SAN MATEO THORNMINT RECOVERY AND MISSION BLUE BUTTERFLY HOST PLANT ENHANCEMENTCREEKSIDE SCIENCE IS SPEARHEADING RECOVERY ACTIONS FORSEVERAL LISTED TAXA, INCLUDING TWO THAT OCCUR IN SAN MATEO COUNTY PARKS. ONE OF OUR HIGH PRIORITY PROJECTS IS RECOVERY OF ACANTHOMINTHA DUTTONII(ABRAMS) JOKERST (SAN MATEO THORNMINT) THROUGH NEW OCCURRENCE CREATION. ANOTHER IS ENHANCING MISSION BLUE BUTTERFLY HABITAT BY INCREASING CONNECTIVITY AND RESILIENCE BY EXPANDING THE DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE OF HOST PLANTS (LUPINUS SPP.).WE ANTICIPATE ~50,000 TO 100,000 SAN MATEO THORNMINT SEEDS PLANTED AND UP TO 50,000 LUPINE SEEDS PLANTED. THESE ARE AVAILABLE NOW FOR PLANTING IN 2022-2023/YEAR 1.WE ANTICIPATE PROPAGATING MORE SEEDS IN 2022-2023, LIKELY 50,000-100,000 SAN MATEO THORNMINT SEEDS AND ~70,000 LUPINE SEEDS.~135 ACRES GRASSLAND ENHANCED AS SAN MATEO THORNMINT HABITAT BUFFER AT EDGEWOOD PRESERVE.~200 ACRES GRASSLAND ENHANCED AS MISSION BLUE BUTTERFLY HABITAT AT SAN BRUNO MOUNTAIN

THIS PROJECT WILL RESTORE AND ENHANCE HISTORICAL WETLANDS ON A FIELD THAT WAS DITCHED AND DRAINED FOR AGRICULTURE. THIS FIELD IS ADJACENT TO A STATE-OWNED WILDLIFE AREA MANAGED FOR THE BENEFIT OF WESTERN POND TURTLES ENDEMIC TO THE SITE, AS WELL AS OTHER WETLAND ORGANISMS.OBJECTIVES:-RESTORE WETLAND HYDROLOGY TO ~2.5 ACRES;-EXCAVATION OF TWO DEEP-WATER PONDS;-RE-SHAPING OF AN EXISTING AGRICULTURAL POND TO RESTORE HABITAT SUITABILITY;-PLANT APPROPRIATE SUITE OF NATIVE SPECIES (+/- 1,000 STEMS) TO SUPPORT POND FUNCTION AND TURTLE HABITAT.-POST-CONSTRUCTION OUTREACH ACTIVITIES, LIKELY TO INCLUDE TWO EDUCATIONAL SITE VISITS WITH PARTNER AGENCIES AND/OR LANDOWNERS.

CBBEP IS PROPOSING TO CONTRACT WITH LOCAL SCHOOLS TO INSTALL THREE OUTDOOR CLASSROOMS PER YEAR FOR A TOTAL OF 15 OUTDOOR CLASSROOMS OVER A FIVE YEAR PERIOD  WHILE EVERY OUTDOOR CLASSROOM CONTAINS ITS OWN UNIQUE DESIGN CHARACTERISTICS, CBBEP WILL STRIVE TO ENSURE THAT THEY ALL OBSERVE THE FOLLOWING KEY ELEMENTS  ECOLOGICALLY SOUND, BENEFIT WILDLIFE AND PEOPLE, INTEGRATED INTO CURRICULUM, DESIGNED TO ENCOURAGE LONG TERM STEWARDSHIP  SCHOOLS WILL BE ENCOURAGED TO FOLLOW THE PROCESS DESCRIBED IN THE USFWS SCHOOLYARD HABITAT PROJECT GUIDE FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF OUTDOOR CLASSROOMS, AND CBBEP STAFF WILL BE AVAILABLE TO ASSIST THEM WITH THIS PROCESS

THESE PROJECTS WILL RESTORE AND/OR ENHANCE APPROXIMATELY: A 107 ACRE WET MEADOW AND A 196 ACRE AGRICULTURAL FIELD IN THE LOWER KLAMATH LAKE REGION ALONG A STRETCH OF THE KLAMATH RIVER FROM KENO, OR TO MIDLAND, OR. PROJECTS MAY INCLUDE: REBUILDING AND CONSTRUCTING LEVEES AND WATER CONTROL STRUCTURES TO RESTORE WET MEADOW HYDROLOGY, RETAINING FLOOD IRRIGATION TRADITION TO MAINTAIN WATERBIRD HABITAT AND RECHARGE GROUNDWATER, FIELD LEVELING TO INCREASE IRRIGATION EFFICIENCY, INSTALLATION OF WATER CONTROL STRUCTURES, IMPROVEMENT OF DRAINS, INSTALLATION AND REMOVAL OF FENCING IN ASSOCIATION WITH LEVEE IMPROVEMENTS, ALTERING AGRICULTURE PRACTICES TO LEAVE UNHARVESTED GRAIN FOR WILDLIFE FOOD; AND SO FORTH. THESE PROJECTS WILL BENEFIT NUMEROUS SPECIES OF WILDLIFE INCLUDING DEER, ELK, TROUT, WATERFOWL, AND OTHER FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES. IN PARTICULAR, WITH BOTH TULE LAKE AND LOWER KLAMATH NWRS BEING COMPLETELY DRY DUE TO DROUGHT, THESE 2 PROJECT LOCATIONS WILL CONTINUE TO PROVIDE WATERFOWL HABITAT.1) LOWLAND FARMS WET MEADOW:THIS PROJECT WILL CONTINUE TO EXPAND ON THE WATERFOWL HABITAT AT THIS LOCATION. FLOOD IRRIGATION IS STRONGLY LINKED TO WATERFOWL POPULATIONS IN THE BASIN, THIS 107 ACRE WET MEADOW IS AN IMPORTANT AREA THAT IS RETAINING ITS' FLOOD IRRIGATION TRADITION. HOWEVER, DILAPIDATED INFRASTRUCTURE AND AN INCOMPLETE LEVEE REDUCES THE AVAILABILITY OF WATERFOWL HABITAT AND IMPAIRS WET MEADOW HAY PRODUCTION. THIS PROJECT WILL HELP TO REBUILD SEVERAL DILAPIDATED LEVEES AND WATER CONTROL STRUCTURES AND WILL PROVIDE FLOODED WET MEADOW HABITAT DURING SEPTEMBER/OCTOBER, A TIME WHERE FORAGING RESOURCES FOR WATERBIRDS ARE EXTREMELY LIMITED. OLD FENCING WILL BE REMOVED AND NEW FENCING INSTALLED TO PREVENT ACCESS BY COWS.1) IRRIGATION EFFICIENCY PROJECT ON KLAMATH DRAINAGE DISTRICT:IN RESPONSE TO THE DROUGHT MANY AGENCIES HAVE PROMOTED THE IDEA OF IRRIGATION EFFICIENCY, WHICH GENERALLY TRANSLATES TO WHEEL LINES AND CENTER PIVOT SPRINKLER SYSTEMS. SEVERAL STUDIES HAVE SHOWN THAT IRRIGATION EFFICIENCY OFTEN AMPLIFIES THE EFFECTS OF DROUGHT BY REDUCING GROUND WATER RECHARGE, RESULTING IN GROUND WATER DECLINES. LASER LEVELING IS AN ALTERNATIVE WATER EFFICIENCY TECHNIQUE WHICH REDUCES THE AMOUNT OF WATER NEEDED FOR FLOOD IRRIGATION WHILE MAINTAINING WATERBIRD AND GROUNDWATER RECHARGE BENEFITS. LASER LEVELING USES PRECISE SURVEY TECHNOLOGY TO MOVE SOIL FROM HIGH AREAS OF A FIELD TO LOW AREAS, CREATING A GENTLE EVEN SLOPE ACROSS A FIELD. THIS PROCESS WAS USED ON AREA K IN LOWER KLAMATH NWR, AN AREA CO-MANAGED BY THE BUREAU OF RECLAMATION AND THE FWS. LASER LEVELING ON LOWER KLAMATH OFTEN REDUCED THE AMOUNT OF WATER NEEDED TO FLOOD A FIELD BY 33% OR MORE. WE PROPOSE TO UTILIZE LASER LEVELING TECHNIQUES ON A 196 ACRE FIELD IN KDD FOR THE PURPOSES OF WATER EFFICIENCY. FOR OUR PROPOSAL, THE LANDOWNER WOULD LEAVE A 1/4 OF HIS GRAIN FIELD UN-HARVESTED FOR 4 YEARS AS AN IN-KIND MATCH, AND MAY ASSIST WITH EARTHWORK ACTIVITIES AS NEEDED. INCORPORATING UN-HARVESTED GRAIN LEAVE WOULD INCREASE THE CARRYING CAPACITY OF THIS FIELD BY NEARLY 10 FOLD. THIS PROPOSAL SUPPORTS MULTIPLE OBJECTIVES: 1) REDUCING THE WATER BUDGET, 2) INCREASING THE AMOUNT OF WATERFOWL SUPPORTED ON THE LANDSCAPE FOR A 4-YEAR PERIOD, 3) INCREASED GROUND WATER RECHARGE, AND 4) IMPROVED LONG-TERM AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION.

THIS PROJECT IS A COLLABORATION BETWEEN THE YUROK TRIBE AND THE ARCATA PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM TO RESTORE ONE MILE OF LOWER AH PAH CREEK, A TRIBUTARY TO THE LOWER KLAMATH RIVER NEAR KLAMATH, CALIFORNIA THIS PROJECT WILL ENHANCE STREAM AND FLOODPLAIN HABITAT WITHIN REACHES OF THE MAINSTEM AND SOUTH FORK AH PAH CREEK TO IMPROVE ECOSYSTEM FUNCTION  PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE COMPLETING ENVIRONMENTAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCE COMPLIANCE REQUIREMENTS, CONDUCTING PHYSICAL MONITORING, AND CREATING LOW VELOCITY STREAM AND WETLAND HABITAT BY RECONFIGURING IMPAIRED HABITATS TO INCREASE FLOODPLAIN CONNECTIVITY AND GROUND WATER RECHARGE, ADDING STRUCTURAL ELEMENTS  WOOD ACCUMULATIONS , AND IMPROVING RIPARIAN HABITATS TO PROMOTE BENEFICIAL SELF MAINTAINING PHYSICAL AND BIOLOGICAL PROCESSES  THIS WILL BE THE FIRST PHASE OF STREAM ENHANCEMENT TO BE IMPLEMENTED AND WORK CONDUCTED WILL INCLUDE DEVELOPMENT OF FUTURE RESTORATION DESIGNS OBJECTIVES FOR THE AH PAH CREEK PROJECT INCLUDE REDUCING STREAM VELOCITIES AND CHANNEL INCISION, INCREASING HABITAT COMPLEXITY AND FLOODPLAIN CONNECTIVITY, AND MONITORING RESTORATION PERFORMANCE TO APPLY LESSONS LEARNED TO FUTURE PHASES  THE OVERALL GOAL IS TO IMPROVE SPAWNING AND REARING CONDITIONS FOR NATIVE SALMONIDS AND LAMPREY BY INSTALLING ROUGHNESS FEATURES  COMPLEX WOOD JAMS, POST ASSISTED LOG STRUCTURES  AND RECONNECTING AND OR EXPANDING FLOODPLAINS  THIS PROCESS BASED, PHASED APPROACH SHOULD FACILITATE LONG TERM FORMATION AND MAINTENANCE OF PRODUCTIVE FISHERIES HABITATS AND SUPPORT VITAL BIOLOGICAL PROCESSES

AN AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE PLACER RESOURCES CONSERVATION DISTRICT AND PARTNERS PROGRAM WILL FUND PROJECTS TO RESTORE APPROXIMATELY 7 MILES OF STREAM/CREEK AND 4 ACRES OF RIPARIAN AREAS. INDIVIDUAL LANDOWNER AGREEMENTS WILL BE COMPLETE AS NEEDED. WORK WILL OCCUR WITHIN PLACER COUNTY, CA TO BENEFIT NATIVE PLANTS AND WILDLIFE. EFFORTS WITHIN DRY CREEK COULD SPECIFICALLY BENEFIT THREATENED STEELHEAD (ONCORHYNCHUS MYKISS). WORK WILL BEGIN AUGUST 1, 2022 AND WILL BE COMPLETED BY AUGUST 2027. OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT ARE: 1) DECREASE RED SESBANIA, A NON-NATIVE SPECIES, ALONG DRY CREEK AND ITS TRIBUTARIES; 2) IDENTIFY EXISTING RESOURCE CONCERNS (OTHER INVASIVES, STREAM BANK EROSION, PLANT DIVERSITY NEEDS); 3) ENHANCE AND PROTECT RIPARIAN AREAS THROUGH FENCING, PLANTING, OR OTHER RESTORATION ACTIONS.RED SESBANIA IS NATIVE TO SOUTH AMERICA AND DISPLACES NATIVE VEGETATION AND CAN DISPLACE WILDLIFE AND DECREASE STREAMBANK STABILITY WHEN IT FORMS DENSE THICKETS.TASKS IDENTIFIED TO MEET PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE: 1) PLANNING AND PERMITTING/COMPLIANCE WORK WHICH WILL START AUGUST 2022 AND IS ANTICIPATED TO BE COMPLETE IN A YEAR; 2) REMOVAL OF RED SESBANIA ALONG APPROXIMATELY 7 MILES OF STREAM/CREEK AND POND EDGE IN THE DRY CREEK WATERSHED (HU - 1802011101). THIS IS ANTICIPATED TO START MAY 2023; 3) FENCE CONSTRUCTION AND/OR PLANTING TO ENHANCE OR PROTECT APPROXIMATELY 4 ACRES OR MORE OF RIPARIAN AREA. THIS WORK MAY START AS SOON AS AUGUST 2022 PENDING COMPLETION OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AND COMPLIANCE REQUIREMENTS. PLANTING WILL TAKE PLACE AS APPROPRIATE BY SEASON AND WILL BE BASED ON SPECIES REQUIREMENTS.MONITORING WILL INCLUDE PHOTO POINT WORK (STARTING 2022), ANNUAL REPORTS (DUE DECEMBER EACH YEAR), TREATMENT AND RESTORATION INSPECTIONS/SITE VISITS (SUMMER 2024/2025), AND A FINAL PROJECT REPORT. THE TIMELINE FOR EACH OF THESE TASKS IS INCLUDED IN A WORK PLAN THAT HAS BEEN AGREED TO BY THE PLACER RESOURCE CONSERVATION DISTRICT AND THE PARTNERS PROGRAM. ADDITIONAL SITE VISITS MAYBE REQUIRED AND WILL BE COMPLETED AS PLANNED IN COLLABORATION BY THE TWO PARTIES IN THIS AGREEMENT.

THIS PROJECT IS A COLLABORATION BETWEEN THE YUROK TRIBE AND THE ARCATA PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM TO RESTORE RIPARIAN HABITAT IN ONE MILE OF LOWER TERWER CREEK, A TRIBUTARY TO THE LOWER KLAMATH RIVER NEAR KLAMATH, CALIFORNIA  THIS PROJECT WILL IMPLEMENT RIPARIAN HABITAT RESTORATION IN LOWER TERWER CREEK TO BOOST ECOLOGICAL BENEFITS SUCH AS INCREASED STREAM SHADING, REDUCED NEAR BANK SHEAR STRESS AND THUS ENHANCED PROTECTION OF VEGETATED FLOODPLAIN SURFACES, AND IMPROVED WOOD RECRUITMENT POTENTIAL  THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED BY PLANTING NUMEROUS NATIVE TREES AND SHRUBS AND INSTALLING WILLOW BAFFLES IN SELECTED RIPARIAN AREAS WITHIN A ONE MILE REACH OF TERWER CREEK  PROPOSED WORK WILL BENEFIT FROM PAST RESTORATION ACTIONS THAT HAVE CREATED IMPROVED RIPARIAN GROWTH AND SURVIVAL POTENTIAL  WE INTEND TO PLANT OVER 2,000 NATIVE TREES AND SHRUBS AND INSTALL  1,000 LINEAR FEET OF WILLOW BAFFLES WITHIN THE PROJECT AREA  THE PROJECT ALSO INCLUDES PHOTO MONITORING AND PLANT SURVIVAL MONITORING TO HELP ASSESS RESTORATION PERFORMANCE  OBJECTIVES INCLUDE PLANTING NATIVE TREES AND SHRUBS AND IMPLEMENTING BIOENGINEERING WITHIN SELECT AREAS ALONG A ONE MILE REACH OF TERWER CREEK TO HELP INCREASE STREAM SHADING, REDUCE NEAR BANK SHEAR STRESS, PROMOTE IMPROVED LONG TERM WOOD RECRUITMENT POTENTIAL TO FLUVIAL HABITATS, AND PROVIDE HIGH QUALITY HABITAT FOR RIPARIAN DEPENDENT SPECIES  THE OVERALL GOAL IS TO BOOST ECOLOGICAL FUNCTION WITHIN THIS HIGH PRIORITY LOWER KLAMATH TRIBUTARY IN SUPPORT OF NATIVE FISH RECOVERY AND HELP FACILITATE CLIMATE RESILIENCY

HE USFWS WILL PROVIDE $25,000 TO SKY ISLAND ALLIANCE TO WORK WITH THE NATURE CONSERVANCY TO REMOVE NON-NATIVEVINCA (VINCA SPP.) FROM THE ARAVAIPA PRESERVE. THE SUB-RECIPIENT LANDOWNER AGREEMENT (EXHIBIT 1) WILL BE SIGNEDBY THE LANDOWNER (THE NATURE CONSERVANCY, THE RECIPIENT), SKY ISLAND ALLIANCE, AND USFWS AND WILL IDENTIFY WORKTHAT WILL IMPROVE WETLAND AND RIPARIAN HABITAT TO BENEFIT FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES. THE LANDOWNER AGREEMENT(EXHIBIT 1) WILL INCLUDE A PROJECT NARRATIVE AND BUDGET. SKY ISLAND ALLIANCE WILL OVERSEE THE IMPLEMENTATION OFTHE LANDOWNER AGREEMENT AND SECURE NON-FEDERAL FUNDS AND/OR IN-KIND SERVICES IN THE AMOUNT OF $20,363.60 TO BEUSED AS A MATCH.
