THESE PROJECTS WILL BENEFIT THE PUBLIC BY IMPROVING SENSITIVE HABITATS, WILDLIFE HABITAT FORMIGRATORY BIRDS, AND PROVIDING WILDLIFE VIEWING OPPORTUNITIES.

THIS PROJECT IS A COLLABORATION BETWEEN THE YUROK TRIBE AND THE ARCATA PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM TO RESTORE ONE MILE OF LOWER BLUE CREEK, A TRIBUTARY TO THE LOWER KLAMATH RIVER NEAR KLAMATH, CALIFORNIA.THIS PROJECT WILL CONTINUE ENHANCING STREAM AND FLOODPLAIN HABITAT WITHIN LOWER BLUE CREEK TO IMPROVE ECOSYSTEM FUNCTION FOR NATIVE FISH AND WILDLIFE. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE CONDUCTING PHYSICAL MONITORING AND CREATING LOW VELOCITY STREAM AND WETLAND HABITAT BY RECONFIGURING IMPAIRED HABITATS TO INCREASE FLOODPLAIN CONNECTIVITY AND GROUND WATER RECHARGE, ADDING STRUCTURAL ELEMENTS (WOOD ACCUMULATIONS, BEAVER DAM ANALOGUES), AND IMPROVING RIPARIAN HABITATS TO PROMOTE BENEFICIAL SELF-MAINTAINING PHYSICAL AND BIOLOGICAL PROCESSES. THIS WILL EXPAND UPON THE FIRST PHASES OF RESTORATION OF LOWER BLUE CREEK AND WORK CONDUCTED WILL INCLUDE DEVELOPMENT OF FUTURE RESTORATION PHASES IN THIS VITALLY IMPORTANT WATERSHED.OBJECTIVES INCLUDE REDUCING STREAM VELOCITIES, CHANNEL INCISION, AND RIPARIAN DYSFUNCTION WITHIN LOWER BLUE CREEK AND ASSOCIATED TRIBUTARIES. THE LARGER PICTURE GOAL OF THIS AND FUTURE RESTORATION PHASES IN LOWER BLUE CREEK IS TO INCREASE WATERSHED RESILIENCY TO CLIMATE IMPACTS SUCH AS REDUCED SNOWPACK AND/OR RAINFALL ACCUMULATIONS AND INCREASED AIR/WATER TEMPERATURES. ADDITIONAL OBJECTIVES ARE TO ASSESS PROJECT PERFORMANCE TO INCREASE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF RESTORATION EFFECTIVENESS AND TO APPLY LESSONED LEARNED TO FUTURE DESIGNS AND ON-GOING DEVELOPMENT OF STREAM AND RIPARIAN STEWARDSHIP PLANS.

A COMPREHENSIVE AND COORDINATED STRATEGY IS NEEDED IN THE UMPQUA BASIN TO REDUCE BARRIERS TO ACCESS FOR NATIVE PLANTS, AND TO DEVELOP LOCAL MARKETS FOR LOCAL NURSERY PLANT AND SEED CROP GROWERS  A DIVERSE GROUP OF LOCAL STAKEHOLDERS AND REGIONAL EXPERTS AGREE THAT THE DEVELOPMENT OF A NATIVE PLANT PARTNERSHIP IS THE LOGICAL FIRST STEP TOWARDS MEETING THESE NEEDS  THE GOALS OF THE NEWLY DEVELOPING UMPQUA NATIVE PLANT PARTNERSHIP  UNPP  ALIGN WITH THOSE IN THE NATIONAL SEED STRATEGY, AS WELL AS THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PRIORITIES OF SPECIES CONSERVATION, HABITAT CONNECTIVITY AND RESILIENT ECOSYSTEMS  THIS WORK WILL ALSO BENEFIT PRIVATE LANDOWNERS BY PROVIDING FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF A NATIVE UNDERSTORY SEED MIX FOR OAK SAVANNAS, MEADOWS AND POLLINATOR HABITAT RESTORATION IN THE UMPQUA BASIN THE UNDERSTORY INITIATIVE WILL DEVELOP AND EXPAND THE UMPQUA NATIVE PLANT PARTNERSHIP TO IMPROVE ACCESS TO LOCALLY SOURCED NATIVE PLANT MATERIALS  THIS WORK DIRECTLY SUPPORTS GOALS 1, 3, AND 4 OF THE NATIONAL SEED STRATEGY IN THE 2022 2024 FUNDING CYCLE, THE UNDERSTORY INITIATIVE UMPQUA NATIVE PLANT PARTNERSHIP WILL 1  ADDRESS THE SUPPLY GAP BY INCREASING AVAILABILITY OF NATIVE SEEDS AND CONTAINER STOCK TO MEET RESTORATION NEEDS ACROSS THE THREE ECOREGIONS OF THE UMPQUA BASIN 2  DEVELOP UNPP LEADERSHIP AND FIVE YEAR STRATEGIC PLAN 3  PROVIDE AN AVENUE FOR PUBLIC PRIVATE COLLABORATION AND COMMUNICATION FOR NATIVE PLANT MATERIALS DEVELOPMENT THROUGH REGULAR UNPP MEETINGS 4  DEVELOP A PRIORITY PLANT MATERIALS NEEDS ASSESSMENT, FOCUSED ON POLLINATOR AND THREATENED HABITATS SUCH AS OAK SAVANNAS AND GRASSLANDS 5  PERFORM COMMUNITY OUTREACH TO EDUCATE THE PUBLIC ABOUT THE VALUE OF NATIVE PLANTS IN LANDSCAPING AND RESTORATION PROJECTS 6  BUILD LOCAL CAPACITY AND PARTNERSHIPS TO COLLECT, GROW OUT  INCREASE  AND DISTRIBUTE NATIVE SEEDS 7  PRIORITIZE AND DEVELOP A NATIVE UNDERSTORY GRASS FORB MIX TO PUT INTO PRODUCTION 8  HOLD AT LEAST ONE PLANTING EVENT FOR OAK POLLINATOR HABITAT RESTORATION USING PLUGS SEEDS COLLECTED AND PRODUCED IN THE UMPQUA BASIN

THE OBJECTIVE IS FOR THE LONGLEAF ALLIANCE  TLA  TO DELIVER COST ASSISTANCE TO PRIVATE LANDOWNERS FOR LONGLEAF PINE RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT IN ALABAMA FOR THE BENEFIT OF LISTED, AT RISK, AND OTHER ENDEMIC SPECIES OF THE LONGLEAF PINE ECOSYSTEM  FUNDS WILL BE USED TO REIMBURSE PRIVATE LANDOWNERS FOR IDENTIFIED WORKS OF IMPROVEMENT IMPLEMENTED UNDER FULLY EXECUTED SUB RECIPIENT LANDOWNER AGREEMENTS  THE PUBLIC WILL BENEFIT THROUGH THE RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT OF THE LONGLEAF PINE FOREST ECOSYSTEM

THIS PROJECT IS A RESPONSE TO THE BOOTLEG FIRE OF JULY AND AUGUST 2021 IN KLAMATH AND LAKE COUNTIES, OREGON  A CONSEQUENCE OF THIS FIRE WAS DAMAGE TO FOREST LAND AND RIPARIAN AREAS SURROUNDING FIVEMILE CREEK, CHARACTERIZED AS NEARLY COMPLETE REMOVAL OF VEGETATION AND ORGANIC MATTER ON THE FOREST FLOOR  THIS CREEK CONTAINS MULTIPLE SENSITIVE SPRING HABITATS AND HISTORICALLY HAD REDBAND TROUT  THE ENTIRE PERIMETER FENCE LINES KEEPING CATTLE OFF THE PROPERTIES  AND SUBSEQUENTLY RIPARIAN AREAS  WAS DESTROYED IN THE FIRE  CATTLE GRAZING ON THE ADJACENT FOREST SERVICE AND GREEN DIAMOND LANDS IS AN ISSUE, AND WITHOUT EXCLUSION FENCING, LIVESTOCK CAN COME ONTO THE PROPERTY FREELY AND DAMAGE RIPARIAN AND STREAM HABITATS  THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE REPLACEMENT EXCLUSION FENCING TO PROTECT APPROXIMATELY 1 6 TOTAL MILES OF FIVEMILE CREEK AND ASSOCIATED SPRING HABITATS WITHIN THE PROPERTIES  THE FENCING WILL REDUCE OR ELIMINATE CATTLE ACCESS, THEREBY GREATLY REDUCING EROSION OF SOILS FROM CATTLE WHILE SIMULTANEOUSLY ALLOWING THE VEGETATION TO NATURALLY REGROW AND PROTECT THE BANKS  THIS WILL REDUCE NEGATIVE IMPACTS TO WATER QUALITY AND BENEFIT AQUATIC SPECIES, INCLUDING REDBAND TROUT WHICH OCCUPIED THE STREAM PRE FIRE

THE KARUK TRIBAL FISHERIES PROGRAM (KTFP) IS A LEADER IN FISHERIES RESTORATION PROJECTPLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION IN THE MIDDLE KLAMATH RIVER. KARUK FISHERIES WORKS CLOSELYWITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM (PFW) ANDLOCAL PARTNERS TO ACCOMPLISH THIS IMPORTANT WORK. KARUK FISHERIES WORKS IN CLOSECOLLABORATION WITH THE MIDDLE KLAMATH WATERSHED COUNCIL TO INCREASE LOCAL CAPACITY TOIMPLEMENT PROJECTS, BUT STAFF CONTINUES TO WORK ON MANY UNFUNDED TASKS INCLUDING; PROJECTOUTREACH, PROJECT PLANNING AND DESIGN, PERMITTING, PROJECT MANAGEMENT, GRANT WRITING ANDCOORDINATION WITH PRIVATE LANDOWNERS. THE KTFP ALSO COLLABORATES WITH THE SALMON RIVERRESTORATION COUNCIL AND SISKIYOU RCD ON PROJECTS IN OTHER KLAMATH RIVER SUB BASINS. THEREIS A CRITICAL NEED FOR INCREASING OUR PROGRAM CAPACITY TO KEEP PACE WITH THE INCREASING DEMANDFOR ACTIONS THAT IMPROVE SALMON HABITAT IN THE KLAMATH BASIN. INCREASING KARUK FISHERIESPROGRAM CAPACITY IS THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THIS PROJECT. KARUK FISHERIES WILL HIRE A FULL TIMEHABITAT RESTORATION PROJECT MANAGER WHOM WILL WORK ON TASKS INCLUDING: 1) RESTORATIONPLANNING, DESIGN, PERMITTING, AND IMPLEMENTATION; 2) PROJECT MANAGEMENT AND MATCHING FUNDSGRANT PROPOSAL DEVELOPMENT; 3) PROJECT EFFECTIVENESS MONITORING AND RESTORATION-RELATEDHABITAT AND FISHERIES ASSESSMENTS,4) COORDINATING WITH OTHER KARUK NATURAL RESOURCEDEPARTMENT PROGRAMS, STATE AND FEDERAL RESOURCE AGENCIES, BASIN PARTNERS, AND/OR STAKEHOLDERSON VARIOUS ISSUES RELATED TO IMPLEMENTATION OF KLAMATH RIVER BASIN HABITAT RESTORATIONPROJECTS. THE KARUK TRIBE RELIES SOLELY ON ANNUAL GRANTS AND AGREEMENTS TO SUPPORT FISHERIESPROGRAM STAFF AND PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT AND HAS A DIFFICULT TIME MAINTAINING THE CAPACITYNECESSARY FOR A FUNCTIONAL HABITAT RESTORATION PROGRAM. TO ADDRESS THIS PROBLEM THE KARUKTRIBE IS REQUESTING FUNDING TO SUPPORT A FULL TIME HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECT MANAGER FOR FOURYEARS BEGIN IN FY 2022 THROUGH FY 2025.

THE FULL 5 YEAR PROJECT  WHICH WILL BE IMPLEMENTED IN PHASES, THIS ROUND BEING PHASE 2  GOAL IS TO INCREASE FLOODPLAIN CONNECTIVITY, OFF CHANNEL HABITAT, AND RIPARIAN FOREST FOR THE BENEFIT OF FEDERALLY LISTED COHO SALMON, CHINOOK SALMON, AND STEELHEAD  THE FULL PROJECT IS IN ITS SECOND OF FIVE CONSTRUCTION SEASONS  WHEN FULLY BUILT, IT WILL IMPROVE 0 8 MILES OF INSTREAM HABITAT, RESTORE CONNECTIVITY TO APPROXIMATELY 23 ACRES OF FLOODPLAIN AND BACKWATER EMERGENT HABITAT, AND RESTORE AND ENHANCE 4 ACRES OF EMERGENT WETLAND, 19 ACRES OF RIPARIAN VEGETATION, AND 9 4 ACRES OF REDWOOD FOREST  ANTICIPATED BENEFITS INCLUDE INCREASED HABITAT DIVERSITY, FLOODPLAIN CONNECTIVITY, COTTONWOOD RIPARIAN ESTABLISHMENT, AND RESILIENCY OF AQUATIC HABITATS TO DROUGHT AND OR CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACTS  I E  INCREASED SURFACE WATER EXPRESSION FOR AQUATIC DEPENDENT SPECIES, AND INCREASED GROUND WATER RECHARGE AND STORAGE   IT IS HYPOTHESIZED THAT FLOODPLAIN RECONNECTION IN THE LOWER RIVER WILL RESULT IN INCREASED SALMONID SURVIVAL AND PRODUCTIVITY, ESPECIALLY WHEN THE LACK OF ESTUARY HABITAT IS CONSIDERED, AND A MEANINGFUL INCREASE IN RIPARIAN HABITAT FOR MIGRATORY SONGBIRDS  PARTNERS PROGRAM FUNDS WILL BE USED TO FILL A CRITICAL GAP IN FULL PROJECT FUNDING, WITH A FOCUS ON INVASIVE PLANT TREATMENTS TO AUGMENT THE ACTIONS BY HEAVY EQUIPMENT AND DURING FULL PROJECT CONSTRUCTION  REMOVAL OF THESE INVASIVE PLANTS, INCLUDING KLAMATH KNOTWEED, PAMPAS GRASS, COTONEASTER AND ENGLISH IVY, ARE CRITICAL TO FULL PROJECT SUCCESS  THIS WILL BUILD UPON INVASIVE PLANT ERADICATION EFFORTS FUNDED IN FISCAL YEAR 2021 BY THE COASTAL PROGRAM

THE KENAI PENINSULA COOPERATIVE INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT AREA IS A DIVERSE PARTNERSHIP OF STATE, FEDERAL, BOROUGH, TRIBAL, AND NON-PROFIT ENTITIES AND LOCAL CITIZENS WHO ARE COLLECTIVELY IMPLEMENTING EARLY DETECTION AND RAPID RESPONSE (EDRR) OF HARMFUL INVASIVE SPECIES THROUGHOUT THE KENAI PENINSULA. WE HAVE IDENTIFIED THE FOLLOWING CRITICAL COMPONENTS OF A SUCCESSFUL EDRR PROGRAM: 1) PUBLIC OUTREACH AND EDUCATION; 2) COORDINATION AND RELATIONSHIP BUILDING AMONG PARTNERS, COMMUNITY GROUPS AND LANDOWNERS OF ALL SCALES; 3) INCORPORATION OF SCIENCE AND DATA SUPPORT INTO PRIORITIZATION OF EDRR ACTIVITIES; 4) SURVEYING AND MONITORING; 5) IMPLEMENTATION OF BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS) AND INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT PLANS (IPMS) FOR RAPID RESPONSE; AND 6) INCREASED CAPACITY THROUGH DIVERSE FUNDING SOURCES.

WE PROPOSE TO INSTALL LOG-JAM AND BOULDER STRUCTURES REQUIRING 100 TREES AND 150 BOULDERS TO RESTORE IN-STREAMHABITAT COMPLEXITY, LONG TERM STABILITY, AND ENHANCE FISH HABITAT QUALITY IN A 3/4 MILE STRETCH OF THE MAIN STEM OFTHE MEDUXNEKEAG RIVER JUST SOUTH OF MALISEET RIVERSIDE VILLAGE EXTENDING SOUTH AND UPSTREAM HALF WAY TO WHEREI-95 CROSSES THE RIVER. THIS STRETCH IS JUST UPSTREAM 3.8 MILES RESTORATION COMPLETED ON THE MAIN STEM AS OF2020. THIS PROJECT CONTINUES AN ESTABLISHED AND LONG TERM EFFORT BY HBMI TO RESTORE AQUATIC HABITAT AND IMPROVEWATER QUALITY IN THE MEDUXNEKEAG WATERSHED BY MITIGATING LEGACY IMPACTS OF LOGGING AND DAMS IN THIS HISTORICALSALMON STREAM. HBMI WILL CONTINUE CONTRACTING WITH JOHN FIELD, FLUVIAL GEOMORPHOLOGIST AND CERTIFIED USDA, NRCSTECHNICAL SERVICE PROVIDER FOR PROJECT DESIGN AND IMPLEMENTATION. FIELD IS THE AUTHOR OF OUR AQUATIC HABITATSTUDY FOR THE MEDUXNEKEAG WATERSHED. NATURAL / EXISTING LOG-JAM AND BOULDER STRUCTURES FIELD OBSERVED IN THEWATERSHED WILL BE REPLICATED TO IMPROVE HABITAT CONDITIONS FOR WILD BROOK TROUT AT THE RESTORATION SITE. MAINPROJECT TASKS INCLUDE (1) GATHERING /ACQUIRING PROJECT MATERIALS (BOULDERS AND TREES WITH ROOT WADS), (2)OBTAINING STATE/FEDERAL PERMITS, (3) INSTALLING HYDRO-MODIFICATION BMPS (BOULDER AND LOG STRUCTURES THAT CREATESHADE, RIFFLES AND POOLS), AND (4) PHOTOGRAPHING AND RESURVEYING THE CHANNEL AND CHANNEL FEATURES TO DOCUMENTRESULTING CHANGES. A CONSIDERABLE AMOUNT OF BOULDERS AND WOODY DEBRIS WERE LOST FROM THE MEDUXNEKEAG IN THE1800S. THIS LACK OF POOL AND RIFFLE FORMING FEATURES CREATED WIDE, SHALLOW STREAM CHANNELS WITH LITTLESTRUCTURAL COMPLEXITY AND IMPAIRED AQUATIC HABITAT. THE SHALLOW, SLOW-MOVING WATER WARMS MORE QUICKLYCONTRIBUTING TO TEMPERATURES ALSO UNSUITABLE FOR THE RIVER'S COLD WATER FISH AND OTHER AQUATIC ORGANISMS.ANTICIPATED ENVIRONMENTAL OUTCOMES INCLUDE: (1) IMPROVED AQUATIC HABITAT (POOLS, RIFFLES, SHADE) AND (2)INCREASED OPPORTUNITY FOR COLD-WATER FISH SUCH AS SALMON TO MIGRATE UPSTREAM INTO TRIBAL WATERS AND TO REACHCOLD-WATER REFUGIA IN ADJACENT TRIBUTARIES. ONE OF HBMI'S OVERARCHING NATURAL RESOURCE GOALS IS "SALMON IN OURWATERS."

THE PURPOSE OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS TO ESTABLISH A WORKING PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE SERVICE AND THE RECIPIENT FOR THE PURPOSE OF PROMOTING CONSERVATION ON PRIVATE LANDS. THE RECIPIENT WILL FACILITATE THE DEVELOPMENT OF CONSERVATION PROJECTS AND WORK COOPERATIVELY WITH THE SERVICE TO IDENTIFY, DEVELOP, AND ESTABLISH MUTUALLY BENEFICIAL CONSERVATION PROJECTS. ALL PROJECTS WILL BE FACILITATED BY SITE-SPECIFIC PRIVATE LANDOWNER AGREEMENTS (PLAS) AS APPROVED AND ADMINISTERED BY THE SERVICE. THIS AGREEMENT WILL RESTORE, ENHANCE, AND ESTABLISH HABITATS FOR THE BENEFIT OF (1) FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES; (2) SAGEBRUSH OBLIGATE BIRDS; (3) NATIVE FISH (4) MIGRATORY WATERBIRDS; AND (5) OTHER GAME SPECIES. RESTORATION OF HABITATS WITHIN HIGH PRIORITY CONSERVATION FOCUS AREAS WILL CONTRIBUTE TOWARDS MEETING POPULATION AND HABITAT OBJECTIVES IDENTIFIED IN THE SERVICE'S 2022-2026 MOUNTAIN-PRAIRIE REGION STRATEGIC PLAN FOR THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM.

THIS WOOD LOADING AND FLOODPLAIN CONNECTIVITY PROJECT WILL IMPROVE INSTREAM AND RIPARIAN HABITAT IN THE SOUTH FORK OF THE SCOTT RIVER. TWO SIDE CHANNELS WILL BE EXCAVATED THROUGH HISTORIC MINE TAILINGS TO INCREASE FLOODPLAIN CONNECTIVITY AND CREATE SLOW WATER REARING HABITAT FOR SALMONIDS. WILLOWS WILL BE PLANTED THROUGHOUT THE SIDE CHANNELS TO INCREASE THE DEPTH OF THE RIPARIAN CORRIDOR. FIVE ENGINEERED LOG JAMS WILL BE CONSTRUCTED IN THE MAIN STEM OF THE SOUTH FORK SCOTT RIVER TO INCREASE INSTREAM HABITAT COMPLEXITY FOR SALMONIDS AND INCREASE ACTIVATION OF THE RIVER LEFT FLOODPLAIN.

THIS WOOD LOADING AND THINNING PROJECT WILL IMPROVE INSTREAM AND RIPARIAN HABITAT IN UPPER SUGAR CREEK. SPECIFICALLY, THIS PROJECT WILL FALL 20 TO 30 TREES, RANGING FROM 14 TO 30 INCHES IN DIAMETER DIRECTLY INTO AN 800 FOOT SECTION OF THE CREEK. CONIFERS WILL BE THE PREFERRED SPECIES BUT AN OCCASIONAL ALDER MAY BE FELLED IF IT WOULD BE DAMAGED BY THE FALLING OF A CONIFER. SCOTT RIVER WATERSHED COUNCIL STAFF WILL THEN USE GRIP HOISTS, CABLES, AND PULLEYS TO MOVE AND INTERLOCK THE FELLED TREES AND/OR SOFT ANCHOR THE FELLED TREES AGAINST CREEK SIDE TREES AND BOULDERS TO REDUCE THEIR MOBILITY. THE FALLING AND MOVING OF TREES WILL CREATE UP TO SIX DISCRETE LOG JAMS OF FOUR TO SIX TREES (FIGURE 1). FOLLOWING PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION, SRWC STAFF WILL MONITOR THE MOVEMENT OF THE TREES IN THE CONSTRUCTED LOG JAMS TO EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF INTERLOCKING AND SOFT ANCHORING THE TREES USING THE GRIP HOIST AND PULLEY SYSTEM. WITHIN THE INSET FLOODPLAINS, CONIFERS WILL BE THINNED WHERE THEY ARE ENCROACHING MORE DESIRABLE RIPARIAN SPECIES. THINNED CONIFERS WILL BE ADDED TO THE LOG JAMS OR BE PILED BY HAND AND DISPOSED OF AT A LATER DATE. THE RESTORATION OBJECTIVES FOR THIS PROJECT ARE: " INCREASE THE AMOUNT OF LARGE WOOD IN THE PROJECT REACH BY 100% OVER THE CURRENT CONDITION. " INCREASE SLOW WATER REARING HABITAT IN THE PROJECT REACH BY 50% OVER THE CURRENT CONDITION. " INCREASE THE FREQUENCY AT WHICH INSET FLOODPLAINS ARE INUNDATED BY 25%. " IMPROVE THE HEALTH AND FUNCTION AND REDUCE THE LIKELIHOOD OF UNCHARACTERISTICALLY SEVERE WILDFIRE ON ONE ACRE OF RIPARIAN HABITAT.

THE BENEFICIARY OF THIS AWARD WILL BE THURSTON CONSERVATION DISTRICT AND PRIVATE LANDOWNERS.THURSTON CONSERVATION DISTRICT {TCD) HAS BEEN WORKING CLOSELY WITH VARIOUS PRIVATE LANDOWNERS IN SOUTH PUGET SOUND PRAIRIE AND OAK WOODLAND HABITATS. TCD IS UNIQUELY SITUATED AND EQUIPPED TO HELP LEAD THIS INNOVATIVE, LANDSCAPE SCALE, MULTI-BENEFIT PROJECT ON PRIVATE PROPERTIES. TCD HAS IDENTIFIED FEAR OF REGULATION AND UNCERTAINTY AS A LIMITING FACTOR FOR LANDOWNERS WHO WOULD BE OTHERWISE INTERESTED IN IMPROVING AND RESTORING THE UPLAND HABITATS ON THEIR PROPERTY. THIS VOLUNTARY AND NON-REGULATORY PROGRAM WILL ADDRESS THESE CONCERNS BY PROVIDING REGULATORY CERTAINTY, WHILE FACILITATING EFFECTIVE PARTNERSHIPS AND RESTORATION.THIS AGREEMENT WILL IMPLEMENT A SUITE OF CONSERVATION PRACTICES THAT WILL IMPROVE AND PROTECT PRAIRIE AND OAK WOODLAND HABITATS. THESE PRACTICES INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO, PRESCRIBED GRAZING {LIVESTOCK FENCING, PIPELINE,WATERING FACILITIES, ETC.), PRESCRIBED BURNING, UNDESIRABLE VEGETATION CONTROL {MECHANICAL AND CHEMICAL), AND NATIVE SEEDING AND PLANTING.

SOUTHERN KENAI PENINSULA MOTORIZED TRAILS ASSESSMENTAND STREAM CROSSING RESTORATION PRIORITIZATIONTHE SOUTHERN KENAI PENINSULA CONTAINS OVER 100 MILES OF UNMANAGED OFF-ROAD VEHICLE TRAILS. MOST OFTHESE ORIGINATED FROM HISTORIC PIONEER ACCESS TRAILS, TRAPPING AND SEISMIC EXPLORATION TRAILS OR "SEISLINES". THESE TRAILS WERE NOT DEVELOPED WITH MOTORIZED VEHICLE USE IN MIND. THEY CROSS NUMEROUSWETLANDS AND ANADROMOUS WATERBODIES CAUSING EXTENSIVE DAMAGE TO THE LANDSCAPE, VEGETATION ANDHABITAT. THE INTENTION OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IDENTIFY THESE LOCATIONS IN NEED OF RESTORATION, BUT ALSO TOIDENTIFY DIFFERENT METHODS FOR BUILDING APPROPRIATE STREAM CROSSINGS. DISCUSSIONS HAVE ALREADY BEGUNWITH THE MAIN TRAIL USER GROUP REGARDING TWO ANADROMOUS CROSSINGS ON THE DRY HOLE TRAIL. THEY ARERELATIVELY CLOSE TO THE ROAD SYSTEM SO THESE LOCATIONS WILL BE THE FIRST PRIORITY SITES FOR RESTORATION.

THIS PROJECT IS A COLLABORATION BETWEEN TOM BESSETTE (PRIVATE LANDOWNER/RANCHER) AND THE ARCATA PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM TO PROTECT 65 ACRES OF ADJOINING WETLAND HABITAT AND 3,400 FEET OF STREAM CHANNEL IN LOWER HUNTER, SALT, MYNOT, AND SPRUCE CREEKS, TRIBUTARIES TO THE KLAMATH RIVER ESTUARY IN KLAMATH, CALIFORNIA.TOM BESSETTE AND THE SERVICE WILL WORK COLLABORATIVELY TO REBUILD AND RELOCATE THE EXISTING LIVESTOCK EXCLUSIONARY FENCING TO CONTINUE TO EXCLUDE LIVESTOCK FROM THE LOWER HUNTER, SALT, MYNOT AND SPRUCE CREEK RIPARIAN ZONES AND ADJOINING WETLANDS. IN ADDITION, WE WILL REPLACE THE EXISTING OFF-CHANNEL WATER TANKS WITH PROPERLY SIZED AND LONG-LASTING CONCRETE TANKS AND CONSTRUCT CROSS FENCING IN BOTH PASTURES TO ALLOW FOR SEASONAL ROTATION OF LIVESTOCK UNDER VARYING SEASONAL WETLAND CONDITIONS.CONTINUED PROTECTION OF THIS RIPARIAN ZONE AND ADJOINING WETLANDS WILL BENEFIT MIGRATING AND REARING COHO SALMON, CHINOOK SALMON, STEELHEAD, COASTAL CUTTHROAT TROUT AND PACIFIC LAMPREY. THE SEASONAL WETLANDS IN THE LOWER PORTIONS OF THE PASTURES REGULARLY HOST SEVERAL WATERFOWL SPECIES, INCLUDING MALLARD, WOOD DUCKS, GREEN-WINGED AND CINNAMON TEAL, RING-NECKED DUCK, AMERICAN WIGEON, AND GADWALL. IN ADDITION, THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT SEVERAL SPECIES OF MIGRATORY BIRDS, INCLUDING OLIVE-SIDED FLYCATCHER, RUFOUS HUMMINGBIRD, YELLOW WARBLER, WILSON'S WARBLER, AND CHESTNUT-SIDED CHICKADEE, AS WELL AS ENHANCING BREEDING AND REARING HABITAT FOR NORTHERN RED-LEGGED FROGS.

THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE THE HOOPA VALLEY TRIBE THE ABILITY TO PLAN, DESIGN, IMPLEMENT, AND MONITOR PRIVATE LANDS HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS IN SUPPORT OF SHARED RESTORATION PRIORITIES OF THE HOOPA VALLEY TRIBE AND THE SERVICES PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM (PARTNERS PROGRAM).  SPECIFIC RESTORATION ACTIONS COULD INCLUDE, BUT MAY NOT BE LIMITED TO, RIPARIAN VEGETATION ENHANCEMENT AND PROTECTION, STREAM CHANNEL AND STREAM BANK RESTORATION, UPLAND RESTORATION TO REDUCE SEDIMENT INPUT, AND REMOVAL OF FISH PASSAGE BARRIERS.THE PARTNERS PROGRAM IN THE KLAMATH BASIN IS OPERATING UNDER A PRIORITIZED APPROACH TO PROJECT SELECTION THAT IS AIMED AT REDUCING STRESSORS TO A FEW HIGH PRIORITY RESOURCE CONCERNS.  THIS APPROACH IS DESCRIBED IN THE PACIFIC SOUTHWEST REGION PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM STRATEGIC PLAN.  THE INTENT IS TO EXPAND TRIBAL CAPACITY AND INVOLVEMENT IN RESTORATION ACTIVITIES WITHIN THE TRINITY AND KLAMATH BASIN WHILE SIMULTANEOUSLY DIVERSIFYING THE OVERALL RESTORATION PRACTITIONER AND IMPLEMENTATION CAPABILITIES IN THE AREA. THE INCREASED RESTORATION CAPACITY IN THE KLAMATH BASIN WILL SUPPORT THE TRIBE, THE SERVICE AND OTHERS IN MEETING THE HABITAT RESTORATION GOALS FOR THE KLAMATH BASIN.

THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS TO FORM A FIVE-YEAR PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) AND PHEASANTS FOREVER TO FACILITATE VOLUNTARY HABITAT CONSERVATION WORK ON PRIVATE AND TRIBAL LAND THROUGHOUT SOUTH DAKOTA THAT IS MUTUALLY BENEFICIAL TO THE USFWS AND PHEASANTS FOREVER.     THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM WILL BE THE USFWS LEAD FOR DELIVERING ALL FACETS OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT. AN EMPHASIS WILL BE PLACED ON RESTORING, CREATING AND ENHANCING WETLAND, GRASSLAND AND RIPARIAN HABITATS THAT ARE VITAL TO A WIDE VARIETY OF BIRD POPULATIONS. BIRD SPECIES TO BE BEFITTED VIA THESE CONSERVATION ACTIONS INCLUDE MALLARDS, NORTHERN PINTAILS, RING-NECKED PHEASANTS, GREATER PRAIRIE CHICKEN, SHARP-TAILED GROUSE, GRASSHOPPERS SPARROWS, WESTERN MEADOWLARKS, AND UPLAND SANDPIPERS. ADDITIONAL NATURAL RESOURCE BENEFITS WILL BE PROVIDED IN THE FORM OF IMPROVED GRASSLAND CONDITION AND ENHANCED WATER QUALITY. DURING THE FULL PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IT IS PROJECTED THAT 25,000 ACRES OF GRASSLAND AND WETLAND HABITAT WILL BE BENEFITED THROUGHOUT SOUTH DAKOTA. SPECIFIC CONSERVATION PRACTICES TO BE JOINTLY IMPLEMENTED BY THE USFWS AND PHEASANTS FOREVER INCLUDE WETLAND CREATIONS, WETLAND ENHANCEMENTS, WETLAND RESTORATIONS, NATIVE GRASS SEEDINGS, MANAGED GRAZING SYSTEMS, ALTERNATIVE WATERING SYSTEMS FOR LIVESTOCK GRAZING PLANS, AND RIPARIAN ENHANCEMENTS.

TROUT UNLIMITED (TU) AND THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) WILL WORK COOPERATIVELY TO RESTORE AND RECONNECT SALMON AND BROOK TROUT HABITAT WITHIN THE SARANAC RIVER BASIN. THREE MAJOR TASKS WILL BE UNDERTAKEN BY THIS EFFORT. (1) TU WILL FACILITATE THE REMOVAL OF BARRIERS TO AQUATIC ORGANISM PASSAGE IN THE LOWER SARANAC RIVER THROUGH PROJECT ADMINISTRATION, OVERSIGHT, AND COORDINATION. (2) TU, USFWS, AND PARTNERS WILL COMPLETE A SALMON AND/OR BROOK TROUT HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECT THROUGH NATURAL CHANNEL DESIGN. (3) LASTLY, TU WILL COMPLETE A WATERSHED ASSESSMENT, MANAGEMENT PLAN, AND SURVEY OF A HIGH PRIORITY PROJECT TO PROMOTE FUTURE CONNECTION AND RESTORATION PROJECTS WITHIN THE SARANAC WATERSHED. FOLLOWING THIS COOPERATIVE PROJECT, THE VISION FOR TU IS TO CONTINUE WORKING WITH PARTNERS THROUGHOUT THE WATERSHED TO ACHIEVE RESTORATION OUTCOMES DEVELOPED THROUGH THE WATERSHED MANAGEMENT PLAN AND OTHER SHARED OBJECTIVES IDENTIFIED BY USFWS.

THIS PROJECT WILL INVOLVE A PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE FRIENDS OF OTTAWA NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE (FONWR) AND THE USFWS PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM (PFW). THE FONWR AND PFW HAVE A LOT OF COMMON GOALS AND OBJECTIVES WITHIN THEIR RESPECTIVE PROGRAMS. PFW WAS DEVELOPED TO OUT OF A NEED TO HELP RESTORE HABITAT ON LANDS ADJACENT TO REFUGES IN ORDER TO EXPAND THE REACH OF THE USFWS MISSION. IN NORTHWEST OHIO, PFW IS FOCUSED ON RESTORING HABITAT IN STRATEGIC FOCUS AREAS, ONE OF WHICH IS THE LAKE ERIE MARSHES. FONWR WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1997 TO SUPPORT CONSERVATION IN THE LAKE ERIE MARSHES BY INCREASING AWARENESS AND CABABILITY OF OHIO'S ONLY NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE. WORKING TOGETHER, FONWR AND PFW WILL IDENTIFY STRATEGIC HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS THAT WORK TOWARDS ACHEIVING THE MUTUAL GOALS OF EACH ORGANIZATION. HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS WILL BE FACILITATED BY THE SERVICE BIOLOGIST THROUGH A PFW LANDOWNER AGREEMENT FOR EACH PROJECT. FONWR WILL ASSIST WITH THE ADMINISTRATIVE PORTION OF PROJECTS AND PROVIDE REIMBURSEMENT TO PRIVATE LANDOWNERS FOR ELIGIBLE EXPENSES ASSOCIATED WITH RESTORATIONS. AS PART OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT A MINIMUM OF 75 ACRES OF WETLAND WILL BE RESTORED.

THE PROJECT AREA (MALLARD MARSH WILDLIFE AREA) FOR THIS AGREEMENT IS LOCATED WITHIN THE IOWA WETLAND MANAGEMENT DISTRICT AND THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM'S PRAIRIE POTHOLE FOCUS AREA.WETLAND ENHANCEMENTS AT MALLARD MARSH WILDLIFE AREA WILL INCLUDE REPLACEMENT OF TWO WATER CONTROL STRUCTURES THAT ARE AT THE END OF THEIR LIFESPAN, AND RESHAPING AND ARMORING OF THEIR ASSOCIATED DIKES AND OUTLETS. COMPLETION OF THESE PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL ENSURE CERRO GORDO COUNTY CONSERVATION BOARD CAN CONTINUE TO MANAGE ~56.3 ACRES OF WETLAND HABITAT TO MAXIMIZE HABITAT CONDITIONS AND FUNCTIONS FOR MIGRATORY BIRDS. THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE PUBLIC THAT USES THE SITE FOR OUTDOOR RECREATION ACTIVITIES.

THE PROJECT GOAL IS TO CONSERVE AND RESTORE DECIDUOUS OAK WOODLANDS FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE WHITE-BREASTED NUTHATCH (A U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE BIRD OF CONSERVATION CONCERN), MIGRATORY BIRDS, AND ELK. THE PROJECT IS A JOINT PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE SERVICE'S "PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM" (PARTNERS PROGRAM) AND A PRIVATE LANDOWNER TO PROTECT THE REMAINING OAK-GRASSLAND HABITAT ON THE REMOTE PROPERTY. THE PARTNERS PROGRAM WILL PROVIDE FUNDING TO THE LANDOWNER, WHO WILL USE EQUIPMENT AND A LABOR CREW TO REMOVE YOUNG DOUGLAS-FIR TREES THAT HAVE ENCROACHED INTO THE OAK WOODLANDS. IF LEFT UNTREATED, THE CONIFERS WILL EVENTUALLY OVERTOP AND KILL THE OAKS, RESULTING IN A CONVERSION TO CONIFER FOREST AND A LOSS OF THIS BIODIVERSE WILDLIFE HABITAT.

AU SABLE RIVER ASSOCIATION (ASRA)AND THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) HAVE BEEN AND WILL CONTINUE WORKING COOPERATIVELY TO RESTORE, ENHANCE AND RECONNECT BROOK TROUT HABITAT WITHIN THE LAKE CHAMPLAIN BASIN IN NEW YORK. ASRA WILL WORK ON TWO TASKS ASSOCIATED WITH HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONNECTIVITY. (L)ASRA WILL FACILITATE THE REMOVAL OF BARRIERS (DARNS AND/OR CULVERTS) TO AQUATIC ORGANISM PASSAGE IN THE LAKE CHAMPLAIN BASIN THROUGH PROJECT ADMINISTRATION AND DEVELOPMENT, DESIGN OVERSIGHT AND IMPLEMENTATION OVERSIGHT IN COORDINATION WITH USFWS BIOLOGISTS. (2) ASRA WILL MONITOR HABITAT USAGE AND DISTRIBUTION OF BROOK TROUT AND LAND-LOCKED ATLANTIC SALMON IN COORDINATION WITH LOCAL PARTNERS, LANDOWNERS AND USFWS BIOLOGISTS. FOLLOWING THIS COOPERATIVE PROJECT, ASRA WILL CONTINUE TO WORK WITH PARTNERS AND LANDOWNERS THROUGHOUT THE WATERSHED TO ACHIEVE RESTORATION OUTCOMES DEVELOPED THROUGH THE WATERSHED MANAGEMENT PLAN AND OTHER SHARED OBJECTIVES IDENTIFIED BY USFWS.

PHEASANTS FOREVER, INC., WILL WORK COOPERATIVELY WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE IN MINNESOTA TO ASSIST IN ADMINISTERING THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM FOR THE BENEFIT OF FEDERAL TRUST RESOURCES ON PRIVATE LAND OWNED OR UNDER EASEMNT BY PHEASANTS FOREVER, INC. OR THE SERVICE. THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES ARE TO RESTORE AND ENHANCE GRASSLAND AND WETLAND RESOURCES IN HIGH PRIORITY AREAS AS IDENTIFIED IN THE PRAIRIE POTHOLE JOINT VENTURE, MINNESOTA PRAIRIE CONSERVATION PLAN, AND THE MINNESOTA PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE STRATEGIC PLAN FOCUS AREAS, FUNDS WILL BE OBLIGATED AND SPENT ON HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS ON PRIVATE LAND THAT MEET FWS 640.1 PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM POLICIES. GOALS ARE TO RESTORE APPROXIMATELY 76 ACRES OF WETLAND AND 542 ACRES OF UPLANDS IN HIGH PRIORITY FOCUS AREAS THROUGHOUT MINNESOTA.

THE PROJECT TITLED MULTI-SITE PENNSYLVANIA STREAMS HABITAT IMPROVEMENT, BANK STABILIZATION, INFRASTRUCTURE PRESERVATION, AND WETLAND RESTORATION WILL SIGNIFICANTLY IMPROVE BOTH WETLAND AND STREAM HABITAT AT MULTIPLE LOCATIONS AND STREAMS IN PENNSYLVANIA. THE COMPLETION OF THIS PROPOSED PROJECT WILL SEE THE RESTORATION OF OVER 200 ACRES OF WETLAND IN TWO SITES IN PENNSYLVANIA. RESTORATION OF AT LEAST 70 ACRES WILL BE ACHIEVED BY REGRADING AREAS WITHIN AND ADJACENT TO EXISTING WETLANDS, REMOVING HYDROLOGIC RESTRICTIONS AND INSTITUTING WETLAND PLANTINGS, ALL TO RESTORE WETLAND FUNCTIONS AND VALUES THAT WERE LOST DUE TO PRIOR AGRICULTURE ACTIVITY. AN ADDITIONAL 130 ACRES WITH EXISTING ALTERED WETLANDS THAT WERE DIKED, DEEPENED, AND MANAGED AS OPEN WATER IMPOUNDMENTS WILL BE RESTORED THROUGH REGRADING IMPOUNDMENTS AND SURROUNDING AREAS TO ALLOW FOR NATURAL FLUCTUATING HYDROLOGY THAT WILL SUPPORT A WIDE VARIETY OF WETLAND VEGETATION AND BREEDING AND MIGRATORY AND WINTERING BIRD SPECIES THAT ARE KNOWN TO INHABIT THE REGION. INCLUDED IN THIS PROJECT IS THE ENHANCEMENT OF AQUATIC HABITAT AND THE STABILIZATION OF ERODING BANKS IN OVER 1.75 MILES OF PENNSYLVANIA STREAMS ON PRIVATE LANDS, RESULTING IN A SIGNIFICANT REDUCTION IN EROSION AND THE SUBSEQUENT SEDIMENT LOADING OF THE RESPECTIVE STREAMS. AT LEAST SEVEN DIFFERENT STREAM PROJECTS WILL BE INCLUDED IN THE PROJECT; FIVE TARGETED SITES WITH HIGH VERTICAL ERODING BANKS THAT PRESENT A SIGNIFICANT THREAT TO LOCAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND A GENERAL LACK OF AQUATIC HABITAT. AT LEAST TWO ADDITIONAL PROJECTS ON PENNSYLVANIA STREAMS WILL BE SELECTED FOR RESTORATION WHERE THE SEDIMENT LOADS CAN BE SIGNIFICANTLY REDUCED.

THE MINNESOTA SHARP-TAILED GROUSE SOCIETY WILL WORK COOPERATIVELY WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE ACROSS THE STATE TO ASSIST IN ADMINISTERING THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM FOR THE BENEFIT OF FEDERAL TRUST RESOURCES ON PRIVATE LAND. OUR GOALS AND OBJECTIVES ARE TO RESTORE AND ENHANCE WETLAND, GRASSLAND, AND BRUSH-LAND HABITAT RESOURCES IN HIGH PRIORITY AREAS AS IDENTIFIED IN THE PRAIRIE POTHOLE JOINT VENTURE, THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI GRAET LAKES JOINT VENTURE, AND THE MINNESOTA PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM STRATEGIC PLAN FOCUS AREAS. FUNDS WILL BE OBLIGATED AND SPENT ON HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS ON PRIVATE LANDS THAT MEET FWS 640.1 PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM POLICIES. GOALS ARE TO RESTORE 334 ACRES OF WETLAND AND 506 ACRES OF UPLAND HABITAT IN HIGH PRIORITY FOCUS AREAS THROUGHOUT MINNESOTA.

PARTNERS FOR CONSERVATION INC. (DBA PARTNERSCAPES) WILL WORK WITH THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE (PFW) PROGRAM AND A MULTI-ORGANIZATION PLANNING TEAM (ARKANSAS PRIVATE LANDS STEWARDSHIP ALLIANCE) IN ARKANSAS TO PLAN AND DELIVER PRIVATE LANDS PARTNERS DAY 2002 IN AND AROUND FAYETTEVILLE, ARKANSAS IN OCTOBER 2022 WHICH WILL HIGHLIGHT THE IMPORTANCE OF VOLUNTARY PRIVATE LANDS CONSERVATION AND PUBLIC-PRIVATE PARTNERSHIP IN THE CONSERVATION OF FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES AND LANDSCAPES BOTH IN ARKANSAS AND NATIONALLY. THE EVENT WILL FEATURE A FIELD TRIP, LIVE CONFERENCE-STYLE SESSIONS AND A VIRTUAL COMPONENT FOR THOSE THAT CANNOT ATTEND IN PERSON.

PHEASANTS FOREVER, INC. (PF) WILL HELP IDENTIFY AND COORDINATE MULTIPLE PRIORITY CONSERVATION PROJECTS WITHIN THE MOUNTAIN HOME AIRFORCE BASE (MHAFB) AS DESCRIBED IN THE INTEGRATED NATURAL RESOURCES MANAGEMENT PLAN (INRMP) AND FURTHER GUIDED BY THE RECENTLY COMPLETED 0.5M RESOLUTION VEGETATION INVENTORY (VI). THIS AGREEMENT WILL FOCUS ON PROJECTS THAT WILL ADDRESS NATURAL RESOURCE ISSUES IDENTIFIED BY THE VI INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO INVASIVE VEGETATION MANAGEMENT, POST-FIRE RESTORATION, AND MONITORING. PROJECTS WILL IMPLEMENT THESE ACTIONS WITH THE GOAL OF SHIFTING VEGETATION TYPES ON MHAFB MANAGED PROPERTIES FROM A NON-NATIVE FIRE-PRONE COVER TO A NATIVE FIRE-RESISTANT COVER UTILIZING THE VI TO PRIORITIZE WORK.

THE WILLOW SPRINGS PRESERVE RESTORATION PROJECT IS LOCATED ALONG WHYCHUS CREEK IN DESCHUTES COUNTYDOWNSTREAM OF SISTERS ON PROPERTY OWNED BY THE DESCHUTES LAND TRUST (DLT). WHYCHUS CREEK DRAINS INTOTHE DESCHUTES RIVER JUST UPSTREAM OF LAKE BILLY CHINOOK. ALTHOUGH PORTIONS OF WHYCHUS CREEK HAVERECOVERED NATURALLY SINCE IT WAS CHANNELIZED IN THE 1960'S, MUCH OF THE PROJECT REACH PROVIDES POORSALMON, STEELHEAD AND RESIDENT FISH HABITAT BECAUSE CHANNELIZATION DECREASED FISH HABITAT, INCREASEDCHANNEL INCISION, AND ELIMINATED THE CONNECTION BETWEEN THE STREAM AND THE FLOODPLAIN. WITHOUT STREAMCHANNEL AND FLOODPLAIN RESTORATION, WHYCHUS CREEK AND THE ASSOCIATED FLOODPLAIN HABITAT WILL NOT REACHITS FULL ECOLOGICAL POTENTIAL.FUNDING WILL BE USED TO IMPLEMENT ON THE GROUND RESTORATION ALONG 0.75 MILES OF WHYCHUS CREEKACCORDING TO RESTORATION DESIGNS. THE UPPER DESCHUTES WATERSHED COUNCIL (UDWC) SEEKS TO USE THERESTORATION PROJECT TO ACCELERATE STREAM EVOLUTION AND RECOVERY PER ESTABLISHED MODELS OF STREAMEVOLUTION TO ACHIEVE THE MOST ECOLOGICAL UPLIFT POSSIBLE UNDER THE SITE CONSTRAINTS, OPPORTUNITIES ANDPOTENTIAL. PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION WILL MINIMIZE SITE DISTURBANCE, AVOID ARTIFICIAL STRUCTURES AND WILL RELYON NATURAL MATERIALS APPROPRIATE TO SITE CONDITIONS. THESE APPROACHES ALL SHARE SIMILAR GOALS OF PROMOTING NORMATIVE RATES OF EROSIONAL AND DEPOSITIONALPROCESSES IN WHYCHUS CREEK AND ITS FLOODPLAIN, RECONNECTING FLOODPLAINS WHERE POSSIBLE, AND RAISING THEWATER TABLE TO FURTHER SUPPORT RIPARIAN AND FLOODPLAIN PLANT ESTABLISHMENT.CONSTRUCTED POST-ASSISTED LOG STRUCTURES (PALS) AND BEAVER DAM ANALOG (BDA) STRUCTURES WILL PROMOTECOMPLEX HABITAT EVOLUTION AS THEY INTERACT WITH SUCCESSIVE HIGH FLOW EVENTS. RESTORED WATERSHEDPROCESSES SUCH AS FLOODPLAIN CONNECTIVITY WILL ALLOW DYNAMIC CHANNEL MOVEMENT, SEDIMENT AND GRAVELSORTING AND DEPOSITION, RAISING OF THE VALLEY WIDE WATER TABLE AND RE-ESTABLISHMENT OF WET MEADOW ANDRIPARIAN VEGETATION.

PROJECT ABSTRACTUPPER BLACK RIVER COUNCIL- UPPER BLACK RIVER IN-STREAM RESTORATIONTHE UPPER BLACK RIVER COUNCIL, A NON-PROFIT NGO IN NORTHERN LOWER MICHIGAN, IS WORKING IN CONJUNCTION WITH NUMEROUS PARTNERS INCLUDING THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE TO STRATEGICALLY PLACE LARGE WOODY DEBRIS THROUGHOUT THE BLACK RIVER. STRATEGIC PLACEMENT OF WOODY STRUCTURES IS DESIGNED TO REDUCE BANK EROSION AND FLUSH SEDIMENT DOWNSTREAM UNCOVERING RIFFLE AND POOL HABITAT CURRENTLY CLOGGED BY LARGE AMOUNTS OF SEDIMENT. ONCE IN PLACE, THE RESTORED HABITAT WILL BENEFIT BROOK TROUT, THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED HUNGERFORD'S CRAWLING WATER BEETLE POPULATION, AND COLD WATER AQUATIC HABITAT IN THE BLACK RIVER FOR AT LEAST TWO RIVER-MILES.

THE UNDERSTORY INITIATIVE'S MISSION IS TO FACILITATE THE RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION OF NATIVE SPECIES HABITATTHROUGH PARTNERSHIP AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT. COLLECTIVELY, STAFF MEMBERS OF THE UNDERSTORY INITIATIVEMANAGE A NUMBER OF DATA COLLECTION, MONITORING PROJECTS, RESTORATION PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION, ANDVEGETATION MANAGEMENT PLAN DEVELOPMENT RELATED TO VARIOUS PLANT COMMUNITIES AND MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES INWESTERN OREGON. THESE PROJECTS INCLUDE RARE SPECIES HABITAT MONITORING, RESTORATION TREATMENT MONITORING INTHE GRASSLANDS OF THE CASCADE-SISKIYOU NATIONAL MONUMENT, DATA COLLECTION IN SUPPORT OF EXPERIMENTALNOXIOUS WEED TREATMENTS ON SOLAR ENERGY GENERATION FACILITIES, AND SENSITIVE SPECIES POPULATION MONITORING.THE SOUTHERN OREGON MONARCH AND POLLINATOR INITIATIVE PROGRAM CURRENTLY SEEKS TO CREATE AND ENHANCEPOLLINATOR HABITAT ON PRIVATE LANDS. THIS WORK ENTAILS SOURCING AND PROPAGATION OF NATIVE SEED MATERIAL, THEFORMATION OF COLLABORATIVE RELATIONSHIPS WITH PRIVATE LANDOWNERS, PROVISION OF TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE,COORDINATION WITH THIRD PARTIES THAT MAY ALIGN WITH THIS WORK, AND INTERNAL DOCUMENTATION AND PLANNING TOPROVIDE THIS WORK ACROSS THE ROGUE BASIN. TUI ADDITIONALLY OPERATES A COASTAL PROGRAM OF THE SAME NATURETHAT SPANS THE COASTAL AREA FROM THE OREGON BORDER AND NORTHWARDS UP TO THE COOS BAY AREA. THIS STRETCH OFCOASTAL AREA SPANS INLAND AS FAR AS THE ECOREGION, LEVEL III BOUNDARY OF THE REGION 8 COASTAL AREA IN OREGONSPECIFIES. THROUGH BOTH OF THESE PROGRAMS TUI SEEKS TO COLLABORATE WITH PROJECT PARTNERS TO INCREASE THEAVAILABILITY OF VIABLE HABITAT FOR MONARCH AND ADDITIONAL POLLINATOR COMMUNITIES IN SOUTHWESTERN OREGON.

THE COQUILLE RIVER SYSTEM INCLUDES OVER 900 MILES OF FISH BEARING STREAMS. THE MAINSTEM COQUILLE  RIVER ENCOMPASSES THE LONGEST ESTUARY IN OREGON (41 MILES) APART FROM THE COLUMBIA RIVER. THE  COQUILLE WATERSHED INCLUDES FOUR MAJOR FORKS ORIGINATING FROM THE COAST RANGE THAT CONVERGE TO  FORM THE MAINSTEM COQUILLE RIVER NEAR THE TOWN OF MYRTLE POINT, OR. HISTORICALLY, THE TRIBUTARIES  AND FORKS OF THE COQUILLE PROVIDED EXCELLENT SPAWNING AND REARING HABITAT FOR ANADROMOUS FISH THAT WAS COOL, COMPLEX, AND ABUNDANT AND THE ESTUARY PROVIDED OPTIMAL OFF-CHANNEL REARING CONDITIONS  FOR OUT-MIGRATING JUVENILES. IT IS ESTIMATED THAT PEAK ABUNDANCE OF RETURNING ADULT COHO TO THE  COQUILLE WAS 412,000 RETURNING ADULTS (LAWSON ET AL. 2007), NOW CURRENT ESTIMATED ABUNDANCE IS AT  8% OF THE HISTORICAL AVERAGE. ACTIONS WILL BE DEVELOPED AND IMPLEMENTED THAT IMPROVE AND EXPAND  HABITATS FOR SALMONIDS IN THE COQUILLE BASIN. PROJECTS WILL RESTORE FLOODPLAIN CONNECTIVITY, INSTALL LARGE  WOOD, CREATE OFF-CHANNEL HABITAT, REMOVE PASSAGE BARRIERS TO MIGRATORY FISH, AND PLANT RIPARIAN  VEGETATION

THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS IN SUPPORT OF A COLLABORATIVE PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM, AND PHEASANTS FOREVER/QUAIL FOREVER TO CONSERVE GRASSLANDS IN TEXAS. THIS AGREEMENT WILL PROVIDE FUNDING IN PARTIAL SUPPORT OF A PF/QF STATE COORDINATOR POSITION AND FUNDING TO SUPPORT HABITAT IMPROVEMENT PROJECTS WITH PRIVATE LANDOWNERS.

WWA WILL WORK COOPERATIVELY WITH THE SERVICE IN THE PROJECT AREA TO ASSIST IN ADMINISTERING THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM FOR THE BENEFIT OF FEDERAL TRUST RESOURCES ON PRIVATE LAND. OUR GOALS AND OBJECTIVES ARE TO RESTORE AND ENHANCE GRASSLAND AND WETLAND RESOURCES IN HIGH PRIORITY AREAS AS IDENTIFIED IN THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI GREAT LAKES JOINT VENTURE AND THE WISCONSIN PARTNERS PROGRAM STRATEGIC PLAN (FOCUS AREAS). FUNDS WILL BE OBLIGATED AND SPENT ON HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS ON PRIVATE LANDS THAT MEET FWS 640.1 PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM POLICIES. GOALS ARE TO RESTORE 100 ACRES OF WETLAND AND 190 ACRES OF UPLANDS IN HIGH PRIORITY FOCUS AREAS THROUGHOUT WISCONSIN. ON AVERAGE, WETLAND PROJECTS WILL COST NO MORE THAN $1250/ACRE AND UPLAND PROJECTS NO MORE THAN $500/ACRE.

S.O. 3362 HABITAT IMPROVEMENT ON PRIVATE LANDS

THE LOVE RESERVOIR SAGE-GROUSE HABITAT ENHANCEMENT PHASE I PROJECT SEEKS TO ADDRESS SEVERAL OF THE MAJOR THREATS TO 
SAGE-GROUSE HABITAT IDENTIFIED IN THE COMPREHENSIVE SAGE-GROUSE THREAT REDUCTION PLAN 
(TRP); INVASIVE ANNUAL GRASSES, OTHER NOXIOUS WEEDS, UNDERSTORY VEGETATION ENHANCEMENT, 
MESIC HABITAT IMPROVEMENT, AND FENCING. TRI-COUNTY WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH THE PRIVATE 
LANDOWNERS AND NRCS TO IMPLEMENT NOXIOUS WEED INVENTORY/TREATMENTS, SEEDING OF 
NATIVE/NON-NATIVE SPECIES, AND FENCING TO ROTATE GRAZING. THIS PROJECT WAS DESIGNED TO 
COMPLEMENT THAT WORK THAT OTHER PROJECT PARTNERS HAVE ALREADY PUT INTO THIS AREA AND 
ENSURE THAT HABITAT IMPROVEMENT PROJECTS ARE SUCCESSFUL LONG AFTER THE GRANT PERIOD.
THE PROJECT PERIOD OF THIS AWARD IS 7/1/20 THROUGH 6/30/22. THE HABITAT RETENTION PERIOD ENDS ON 8/31/32.
FUNDS UNDER THIS AWARD ARE TO BE USED TO RESTORE SEVEN ACRES OF WETLAND.

FUNDS UNDER THIS AWARD ARE TO BE USED TO FORM A PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE ' COLORADO PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE ('SERVICE')
AND THE COLORADO WILDLIFE HERITAGE FOUNDATION AND TO FACILITATE CONSERVATION WORK.

A SPECIAL EMPHASIS WILL BE PLACED ON RESTORING, CREATING AND ENHANCING WETLAND AND GRASSLAND
HABITATS THAT ARE VITAL TO BREEDING POPULATIONS OF A WIDE VARIETY OF BIRD GUILDS. PRIMARY 
HABITAT CONSERVATION PRACTICES TO BE JOINTLY IMPLEMENTED BY THE SERVICE AND THE TRUST 
INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO, WETLAND CREATIONS, WETLAND ENHANCEMENTS, WETLAND 
RESTORATIONS, GRASSLAND RESTORATIONS (SEEDINGS), ROTATIONAL GRAZING SYSTEMS, ALTERNATIVE 
WATERING SYSTEMS FOR LIVESTOCK, PRESCRIBED GRASSLAND BURNS AND RIPARIAN RESTORATIONS.  
ADDITIONAL EMPHASIS WILL BE PLACED ON OUTREACH, COMMUNICATION AND COLLABORATIVE 
CONSERVATION EFFORTS DESIGNED TO STRENGTHEN CONSERVATION PARTNERSHIPS IN NORTH DAKOTA AND 
CREATE ADDITIONAL HABITAT CONSERVATION OPPORTUNITIES.  ALL INDIVIDUAL HABITAT PROJECTS 
WILL BE FACILITATED BY SITE-SPECIFIC PRIVATE LANDOWNER AGREEMENTS (PLA'S) AS APPROVED AND 
ADMINISTERED BY THE SERVICE'S ND PFW PROGRAM.

FUNDS UNDER THIS AWARD ARE TO BE USED TO RESTORE APPROXIMATELY EIGHT OFF-CHANNEL OXBOW WETLANDS IN THE
THREE GEOGRAPHIC FOCUS AREAS.
FUNDS UNDER THIS AWARD ARE TO BE USED TO PERFORM HABITAT RESTORATION ACTIVITIES ON SOUTH FORK CROOKED RIVER, CROOK COUNTY OREGON.

TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL AND FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE WITH THE LITTLE SNAKE RIVER CONSERVATION DISTRICT FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT RESTORATION, ENHANCEMENT
AND CONSERVATION.

FUNDS UNDER THIS AWARD ARE TO BE USED TO AUTHORIZE GRASSLANS CHARITABLE FOUNDATION AS A FISCAL AGENT FOR SUB-RECIPIENT LANDOWNERS WHO ENROLL IN THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM TO DEVELOP PROJECTS THAT BENEFIT MIGRATORY BIRDS, THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES, NATIVE POLLINATORS, AND MONARCH BUTTERFLY HABITAT.

SOUTHERN OREGON PRIVATE LANDS POLLINATOR INITIATIVES

FUNDS UNDER THIS AWARD ARE TO BE USED FOR:  1) THE RECRUITMENT OF THREE TO SIX PRIVATE LANDOWNERS WHO WILL BE TRAINED ON HOW TO GROW AND HARVEST NATIVE SEED WHICH WILL BE USED ON LOCAL PRIVATE LANDS POLLINATOR HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS; 2) DEVELOPING A FINANCIAL SUPPORT FRAMEWORK TO PAY FOR SEED PRODUCTION COSTS AT THESE FARM SITES; AND 3) PROVIDE ACCESS TO CERTAIN SPECIALIZED NATIVE SEED FARMING SUPPLIES FOR THE DURATION OF THE AGREEMENT.
HI LINE HABITAT CONSERVATION 2020

FUNDS UNDER THIS AWARD WILL BE USED TO SUPPORT CONSERVATION PROJECTS THAT IMPROVE MIGRATION CORRIDOR, STOPOVER, AND WINTER RANGE HABITAT FOR TARGETED SPECIES IN ARIZONA, CALIFORNIA, COLORADO, IDAHO, MONTANA, NEVADA, NEW MEXICO, OREGON, UTAH, WASHINGTON, AND WYOMING.  PRIMARY FOCUS SPECIES IDENTIFIED IN SECRETARIAL ORDER 3362 INCLUDE MULE DEER, ELK, AND PRONGHORN.  ADDITIONAL SPECIES WILL BE CONSIDERED AS THEY ARE IDENTIFIED THROUGH PRIORITIZATION CONVERSATIONS BETWEEN THE DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR AND WESTERN STATES.

FUNDS UNDER THIS AWARD WILL BE USED TO CONNECT ANGLERS AND CONSERVATIONISTS ACROSS THE NATION WITH THE SERVICE AND SPECIFICALLY THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE (PARTNERS) PROGRAM.  THE EXPANSION OF FISHING OPPORTUNITIES ACROSS THE NATION WILL BE A FOCUS OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WITH A SPECIAL EMPHASIS ON THE NEXT GENERATION OF UPCOMING ANGLERS. TROUT UNLIMITED IS ONE OF THE MOST EFFECTIVE COLDWATER FISHERIES CONSERVATION ORGANIZATIONS IN THE COUNTRY.

WISCONSIN WATERFOWL AND WETLAND PARTNERSHIP III

FUNDS UNDER THIS AWARD ARE TO BE USED TO CREATE WETLAND AND UPLAND HABITAT IN HIGH PRIORITY AREAS AS IDENTIFIED IN THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI GREAT LAKES JOINT VENTURE AND THE WISCONSIN PARTNERS PROGRAM STRATEGIC PLAN (FOCUS AREAS).  THE WISCONSIN WATERFOWL ASSOCIATION (WWA) WILL WORK COOPERATIVELY WITH THE SERVICE IN THE PROJECT AREA TO ASSIST IN ADMINISTERING THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM FOR THE BENEFIT OF FEDERAL TRUST RESOURCES ON PRIVATE LAND.  THESE ACTIVITIES ARE SUPPORTIVE OF THE HABITAT RESTORATION GOALS OF THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI GREAT LAKES JOINT VENTURE, A BROAD COALITION OF CONSERVATION AGENCIES OF WHICH THE SERVICE AND WWA ARE MEMBERS.  FUNDS WILL BE OBLIGATED AND SPENT ON HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS ON PRIVATE LANDS THAT MEET THE SERVICE'S 640 FW 1, PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM POLICIES.  GOALS ARE TO ENHANCE 125 ACRES OF WETLAND AND 222 ACRES OF UPLAND HABITAT IN HIGH PRIORITY FOCUS AREAS THROUGHOUT WISCONSIN.

FUNDS UNDER THIS AWARD ARE TO BE USED TO ACCOMPLISH WOODY INVASIVE SPECIES REMOVAL, HERBACEOUS INVASIVE SPECIES
CONTROL, LIMITED CANOPY THINNING, AND NATIVE PLANT ESTABLISHMENT THAT IS PLANNED FOR A 6-ACRE PORTION OF
THE MANAGEMENT UNIT OVER THE NEXT THREE YEARS.

CENTRAL PLATTE RIVER VALLEY HABITAT RESTORATION PARTNERSHIP

FUNDS UNDER THIS AWARD ARE TO BE USED TO FORM A PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (SERVICE) AND THE PLATTE RIVER WHOOPING CRANE TRUST (TRUST) TO RESTORE, ENHANCE, MANAGE, MONITOR, AND EVALUATE HABITAT ALONG THE CENTRAL PLATTE RIVER AND OTHER BIOLOGICALLY IMPORTANT LANDSCAPES IN NEBRASKA.  PROJECTS WILL CONTRIBUTE TOWARDS POPULATION AND HABITAT OBJECTIVES FOR FEDERALLY LISTED ENDANGERED AND THREATENED SPECIES (WHOOPING CRANE, LEAST TERN, AND PIPING PLOVER), MIGRATORY WATERBIRDS (E.G., SHOREBIRDS, WATERFOWL, WADING BIRDS), GRASSLAND NESTING BIRDS, POLLINATORS AND OTHER INSECTS (E.G., MONARCH AND REGAL FRITILLARY BUTTERFLIES AND NATIVE BEES) AND NUMEROUS OTHER FEDERAL TRUST FISH, WILDLIFE, AND PLANTS.  HABITAT PROJECTS WILL BE FACILITATED BY SITE-SPECIFIC PRIVATE LANDOWNER AGREEMENTS (PLAS) AS APPROVED AND ADMINISTERED BY THE SERVICE. THIS AGREEMENT WILL ALSO ESTABLISH A WORKING PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE SERVICE AND THE TRUST FOR THE PURPOSE OF PROMOTING CONSERVATION ON PRIVATE LANDS THROUGH A VARIETY OF EDUCATIONAL, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND OUTREACH PROGRAMS.

FUNDS UNDER THIS AWARD ARE TO BE USED TO CONSERVE, ENHANCE, AND PROTECT SALMONID HABITAT ALONG
ANADROMOUS WATER BODIES IN THE INTERIOR AND TO WORK IN COOPERATION WITH PRIVATE LANDOWNERS TO PROVIDE
PROJECTS AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE.

FUNDSUNDER THIS AWARD ARE TO BE USED TO CREATE FUNCTIONAL SEASONAL WETLAND AND NATIVE UPLAND HABITAT ON PRIVATELY-OWNED PROPERTY IN ADJACENT TO THE SONNY BONO NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE IN IMPERIAL COUNTY,
CALIFORNIA AT THE SOUTH END OF THE SALTON SEA.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS FOR THE RECIPIENT, WITH THE ASSISTANCE OF THE SERVICE, TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL
AND FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE FOR THE CREATION OF POLLINATOR HABITAT (10 POLLINATOR PARKS AND ONE
APPROXIMATELY 4 ACRE AREA) AND PRAIRIE RESTORATION AREA IN AREAS CURRENTLY CONTAINING NON-NATIVE AND
INVASIVE GRASSES. INTERPRETIVE SIGNAGE CONTAINING THE SERVICE LOGO WILL ALSO BE INSTALLED TO EDUCATE
THE PUBLIC AND RESIDENTS ON THE IMPORTANCE OF NATIVE HABITAT AND TO IDENTIFY NATIVE SPECIES. WILDLIFE
STRUCTURES SUCH AS BAT, BIRD AND DUCK BOXES WILL BE INSTALLED TO PROVIDE ARTIFICIAL HABITAT TO MIGRATORY
SPECIES AND TO ENCOURAGE SECRETARIAL ORDER 3356, WHICH IS THE SUPPORT AND EXPAND OF CONSERVATION
STEWARDSHIP, THE IMPROVEMENT WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT, AND THE INCREASE OF OUTDOOR RECREATION
OPPORTUNITIES FOR ALL AMERICANS BY CONNECTING CHILDREN TO NATURE.

THIS PROJECT WAS SELECTED FOR FUNDING BECAUSE THE LANDOWNER(S) SHARE(S) A COMMON OBJECTIVE WITH THE USFWS TO RESTORE HABITAT FOR THE BENEFIT 
OF FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES ON PRIVATE LANDS, AND THE PROJECT SUPPORTS PRIORITY ACTIONS IDENTIFIED IN THE REGIONAL PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE (PARTNERS) PROGRAM STRATEGIC PLAN.
NESTING AND BROOD REARING HABITAT FOR THE SOUTHERNMOST GREATER SAGE GROUSE POPULATION. IT IS ALSO CRITICAL SUMMER HABITAT FOR THE PAUNSAUGUNT MULE DEER HERD.

FUNDS UNDER THIS AWARD ARE TO BE USED TO:  AFFORD OPPORTUNITIES TO IMPROVE A 2.5-ACRE MEADOW AREA ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE PARK THROUGH RESEEDING WITH A NATIVE SEED MIX CONTAINING NATIVE GRASSES AND POLLINATOR PLANTS.  IN ADDITION, THIS PROJECT AIMS TO IMPROVE VISITOR ACCESS BY REMOVING NON-NATIVE, INVASIVE VEGETATION AND UNDESIRABLE TREES TO OPEN UP THE CANOPY AND RE-ROUTING EXISTING WALKING TRAILS.  STRUCTURES FOR WILDLIFE, SUCH AS BIRD HOUSES AND INTERPRETIVE EDUCATIONAL SIGNS WILL ALSO BE INSTALLED.
FUNDS UNDER THIS AWARD ARE TO GRUB MESQUITE FROM ~127 ACRES ON THE NEWBERRY TRACT WITH THE PURPOSE OF IMPROVING UPLAND HABITAT FOR THE BENEFIT OF MIGRATORY BIRDS AND LESSER PRAIRIE CHICKEN.

FUNDS UNDER THIS AWARD ARE TO BE USED TO DELIVER ON-THE-GROUND RESTORATION AND MANAGEMENT PROJECTS BENEFITTING WILDLIFE IN THIS SAGEBRUSH-GRASSLAND LANDSCAPE. FOCAL WILDLIFE INCLUDE GRASSLAND SONGBIRDS, SAGE-GROUSE, WATERFOWL AND MIGRATORY OR WINTERING UNGULATES.

THROUGH THE LANDOWNER INCENTIVE PROGRAM (LIP). THE LIP IS A COLLABORATIVE EFFORT BETWEEN TPWD WILDLIFE AND INLAND FISHERIES DIVISIONS AND THE SERVICE TO 
MEET THE NEEDS OF PRIVATE LANDOWNERS TO IMPLEMENT POSITIVE CONSERVATION PRACTICES. THESE PRACTICES WILL BENEFIT HEALTHY TERRESTRIAL AND AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS
AND THE STATE AND FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES THAT DEPEND ON THEM.

IN AN EFFORT TO DEVELOP THE NEXT GENERATION OF HIGH DESERT CONSERVATION CHAMPIONS, OREGON NATURAL DESERT ASSOCIATION AND NORTHWEST YOUTH CORPS HAVE PARTNERED TO CREATE THE TRIBAL STEWARDS PROGRAM. THE AIM OF THE PROGRAM IS TO BRING TOGETHER A TEAM OF YOUNG ADULTS FROM THE CONFEDERATED TRIBES OF WARM SPRINGS AND THE BURNS PAIUTE TRIBE WHO WILL UNDERTAKE RESTORATION PROJECTS THROUGHOUT OREGON'S HIGH DESERT AND GAIN EXPERIENCE IN PUBLIC LANDS ADVOCACY AND A WORKING KNOWLEDGE OF THE FUNDAMENTALS OF LANDSCAPE CONSERVATION. AS THESE CREW MEMBERS ADVANCE IN THEIR CAREERS AND MOVE INTO LEADERSHIP POSITIONS WITHIN THEIR TRIBES, THEY WILL SERVE AS CHAMPIONS FOR CONSERVATION.
PROJECTS WILL BE DESIGNED AND LED BY CONSERVATION PROFESSIONALS FROM FEDERAL LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES, NON-PROFITS AND TRIBAL NATURAL RESOURCES DEPARTMENTS. IN ADDITION TO HANDS-ON TRAINING, PROJECT LEADS WILL PROVIDE CAREER MENTORING, CONTEXT FOR HOW EACH PROJECT FITS INTO A BROADER CONSERVATION STRATEGY TO IMPROVE LAND AND WATER RESOURCES, AND HOW TRIBAL STEWARDS CAN SERVE AS STRONG CHAMPIONS FOR THE CONSERVATION.
TRIBAL STEWARDS TEAM MEMBERS WILL SPEND EIGHT WEEKS CAMPING, WORKING AND TRAVELING TOGETHER. MEMBERS CAN EXPECT TO WORK ON PHYSICALLY CHALLENGING PROJECTS IN HIGHLY VARIABLE WEATHER. AFTER EACH WORKDAY, THE CREW WILL RETURN TO CAMP AND PARTICIPATE IN COMMUNITY ACTIVITIES INCLUDING MEAL PREPARATION, WATER COLLECTION AND TREATMENT, AND TOOL MAINTENANCE, FOLLOWED BY A FAMILY STYLE DINNER. EVENINGS WILL INCLUDE EDUCATIONAL AND RECREATIONAL ACTIVITIES; INCLUDING FORMAL LESSONS TAUGHT BY TEAM MEMBERS, GROUP DISCUSSIONS ABOUT LAND CONSERVATION PHILOSOPHY, AND STARGAZING AROUND THE CAMPFIRE.

LA SD-64590-17-033FMH  GRAZING MANAGEMENT PROJECT
THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE (PFW) PROGRAM IS A VOLUNTARY, INCENTIVE-BASED PROGRAM THAT PROVIDES DIRECT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE IN THE FORM OF COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS TO PRIVATE LANDOWNERS TO RESTORE AND CONSERVE FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT FOR THE BENEFIT OF FEDERAL TRUST RESOURCES. THE PFW PROGRAM IS DELIVERED THROUGH MORE THAN 250 FULL-TIME STAFF, ACTIVE IN ALL 50 STATES AND TERRITORIES. PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM STAFF COORDINATE WITH PROJECT PARTNERS, STAKEHOLDERS AND OTHER SERVICE PROGRAMS TO IDENTIFY GEOGRAPHIC FOCUS AREAS AND DEVELOP HABITAT CONSERVATION PRIORITIES WITHIN THESE FOCUS AREAS. GEOGRAPHIC FOCUS AREAS ARE WHERE THE PFW PROGRAM DIRECTS RESOURCES TO CONSERVE HABITAT FOR FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES. PROJECT WORK PLANS ARE DEVELOPED STRATEGICALLY, IN COORDINATION WITH PARTNERS, AND WITH SUBSTANTIAL INVOLVEMENT FROM SERVICE FIELD STAFF. PROJECTS MUST ADVANCE OUR MISSION, PROMOTE BIOLOGICAL DIVERSITY, AND BE BASED UPON SOUND SCIENTIFIC BIOLOGICAL PRINCIPLES. PROGRAM STRATEGIC PLANS INFORM THE TYPES OF PROJECTS FUNDED UNDER THIS OPPORTUNITY. APPLICANTS SEEKING FUNDING UNDER THIS PROGRAM SHOULD REVIEW THE PROGRAM STRATEGIC PLAN AND ALSO CONTACT THE REGIONAL PFW PROGRAM OFFICE PRIOR TO SUBMITTING AN APPLICATION FOR FUNDING.
